content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
IntroductionMad Max is a post-apocalyptic, open-world action game featuring Max, a man haunted by his past. Your goal is travel across the Sands of Silence but to do so you’re going to have to build a new car capable of the long journey, after your trusty Black on Black is stolen by the Immortal Scrotus. Much to Max’s dismay, he can’t build this car alone and must enlist the help of several characters from across the Great White, including the trusty blackfinger, Chumbucket.PresentationMad Max is an incredibly good looking game. The graphics are excellent even when not running the game on maxed out settings (I was playing on normal-high) but adding all the bells and whistles makes this game absolutely gorgeous. The character and vehicle models are all very detailed, particularly Max and The Magnum Opus (the car you’re building). MM’s User Interface is minimalistic and clean, only showing you information that you need when you need it and most of it stays out of the way during regular gameplay. The main menu, in my opinion, is where the presentation is let down slightly. For the most part the menu is easy to navigate but when choosing settings you have to select each setting before editing it and then save each setting individually, not only did this make changing settings significantly slower than usual, it also meant that I kept accidentally returning to the previous menu by trying to change values before selection the option.GameplayMM’s gameplay predominantly consists of combat, both on-foot and while in vehicles, both are fun but not without issues. Melee combat is effectively the same as in the Batman games apart from the fact that you don’t have to jump all over the room to keep your combo going, Max isn’t quite as agile as Batman. As well as your fists, sometimes you can find melee weapons, such as maces, though these break after a few hits. However, it’s not all good; you’ll never be attacked by two enemies at once (apart from charging enemies) which makes controlling a fight a little too easy, once you start building up a heavy attack you can’t interrupt it to counter an enemy and enemies always use the same tactics so they very quickly become predictable. Vehicular combat is easily one of the best parts of MM, there’s nothing quite as satisfying as taking on a convoy though taking on two or three cars can sometime feel tedious. To aid you in vehicular combat you can unlock and upgrade several weapons throughout the game such as a harpoon, rim grinders and anti-boarder spikes. MM also features several abilities to use during vehicular combat (most of which are unlocked alongside Opus upgrades) such as the ‘ricochet bash’ which smashes you from a car on one side to one on your other side, dealing increased damage. These two types of combat are used across the game’s activities. What are these activities? There’s the obvious story missions and side missions, both of which I’ll return to later, but you also can liberate enemy bases, disarm minefields, take down enemy scarecrows and sniper towers, go up in hot air balloons to survey the area you’re in and of course, take down enemy convoys. Apart from the hot air balloons, all of these activities contribute to lowering the danger in a region which in turn unlocks upgrades for the Magnum Opus.StoryIf you’re familiar with the films, you’ll know that they aren’t as popular as they are because they have stellar plots, it’s all about the action. This game very much follows the same rule. While the game does have a story-arc it doesn’t really get more complex than what I mentioned in my introduction, it mainly consists of going to certain places to get certain things in order to upgrade the Opus. Of course there are some missions which aren’t like this but those are pretty much just to get them to help you get more Opus parts. I won’t say too much about it, so that I don’t spoil the story for those who care, but I personally found the ending a little disappointing. The final boss fight was nowhere near as difficult as it should have been, I breezed through it in around five minutes, and the story sort of just ends after that fight with no implication as to what Max is going to do, they’re probably setting it up for a sequel or DLC. The main missions and side missions take around 20 hours to complete, the rest of my playtime comes from doing the other activities that I mentioned, not bad for the price.CustomisationMad Max features a great deal of customisation options for three different ‘things’. First and foremost, we have the upgrades for the Magnum Opus, with eighteen different categories and between three and twelve upgrades for each category there are a huge number of options for your car. It’s also not just a case of the more expensive thing is better, some upgrades have a negative impact on your car as well as positive ones so it’s important to find a good balance which suits your play-style. Up next, we have the upgrades for Max himself. With eight different categories there’s a lot you can do with Max; you can choose his jacket, his hair and beard style, what shotgun he uses as well as unlock skills which help you in melee combat. Unlike with the Opus, all of these upgrades (excluding the skills and tools categories where each upgrade is separate) provide and improvement over the one from the previous level. On top of all of these, you also get upgrades from a character called Griffa using Griffa tokens which you earn by levelling up. Griffa upgrades include improved maximum health, longer lasting melee weapons, and the ability to find more water. Lastly, you can upgrade the Strongholds which you find across the Great White, these upgrades directly benefit Max, for example building an Armoury at a Stronghold will refill all of your ammunition when you travel to said Stronghold and building a Water Tower will refill your canteen.AudioThe audio in this game is, apart from the occasional bug, absolutely spot on. The voice acting is excellent, particularly from the actors playing Max, Chumbucket and Stank Gum. The game’s soundtrack is fitting, there’s even a nice little Fury Road easter egg thrown in. The sound effects are also very good, particularly the bone crunching combat sounds and the engine and nitro sounds for the Opus. However, I did encounter an audio bug several times where certain sound effects would not play for minutes at a time such as no engine sound or no sounds during combat.MiscellaneousAs you will have heard, the game’s optimisation is incredibly good, I had a solid 30FPS running the game on normal-high on my pretty mediocre PC The map is pretty damn big, taking a fair few minutes to drive from one end to the other. Of course most of it is empty but what do you expect from a post-apocalyptic wasteland?The non-story/side mission activities get incredibly repetitive, not so much capturing War Boy bases or taking on convoys but driving around to pull down scarecrows or search for scrap gets pretty boringThere’s a first person camera for when you’re in a vehicle, not a major thing but it’s pretty cool to see the wasteland through Max’s eyesMad Max features the same incredibly good Capture mode as Shadow of Mordor which if you’re a fan of screenshots, is just great. MM’s Capture mode even allows you to record videos, though I didn’t try that out myselfAs well as the Magnum Opus you can drive any vehicles which you take from enemies and the store in StrongholdsVerdictEssential Purchase.Mad Max is a fantastically good post-apocalyptic, open-world game with great graphics, tons of customisation and a lot of activities to keep you busy. Just Reviews.El K.

												A bit of Far Cry mapping, big world, Batman fist fighting mechanism with a raw street fighting feel that makes you want to fight more and more, oddly the same kind of feel of Assasin's Creed Black Flag when you're driving your car in this endless waste , instead of a boat and lots of water in Black Flag, and take care of enemy vehicles (including storms but we have sandstorms here), collecting this and that along the way (reminded me of Just Cause), the way they made driving and racing a whole lot of fun in this kind of game (hello Rage!) , upgrading your character and car by doing things...and there are a lot of things to do in this world.....you would almost forget the story. And that's also very good so far. Voice acting is top and the whole scenery and atmosphere is great. It's Mad Max. And you can be Mad Max. So let me make this clear. It's not a shooter. There are guns and you can shoot them but the focus is not at shooting. The driving and fist fighting takes the most of it. And what a pleasure that is!They took a long look at some very good games out there and mold it together to make Mad Max look great. They succeeded. Great game, lots of fun. Yep, after 5 hours of gameplay I can see where this is going. Another lots of sleepless nights.After 45 hours of gameplay: Yep, it's a very good and addictive game. I saw some reviews with a bit of complaining 'bout that it gets the same after a while. Taking a break now and then will help. After an 8 hours work shift everyone wants to go home and do something else. But after a view hours of 'doing something else' it's great to step in Mad Max's shoes again. They get comfortable the more you wear it.After 80 hours of gameplay: Woh, time is getting abstract playing this game. That's always a good sign when you're having fun. There are some very good missions here. Got the heart pounding and the adreneline rushing. Almost have completed the map but still not sure how much more I get and I realy don't wanna know. As far as I'm concerned this game can go on and on and on. I got 73% of the achievements so the end must be near. My advise is to don't rush the missions and first clear out the regions one by one and do the missions when they are in the regions you cleared out. And take your time and enjoy searching for all the goodies! It'll be over too soon. Very good game this is.

Posted: March 5
												At first glance, Mad Max is a fantastic open-world adventure teeming with things to do. The excitement can give way to boredom because the short story can’t hide the required grind to advance. Still, there is a plethora of different dusty environments and strongholds / outposts, while the detailed landscape is full of things to do and discover.Total size on my hard drive: 32.8 GB++ Optimization is stunning. One of the best optimized games of the past year or two.+ Graphics are great. Light, dust, haze is a great icing on a highly detailed cake.  Clouds look a little low-res at times, but the skybox looks fantastic in general (if you like sunsets / sunrises, there are some great screenshot opportunities).+ Punchy sound design. Explosions have great impact.+ Great story - gritty and grim - but it’s short. Do yourself a favor and complete the Wasteland side-missions in addition to the main campaign. You’ll get to know the factions a bit better and the game feels more complete.+ The wasteland is wonderfully detailed. Rocks, caves, forts, pumping stations, strongholds, outposts – even though it is a dusty wasteland, there is plenty of visual variety.+ Customizing the car. From the body style, to the suspension, engine, armor, and more, you can really make the car you want to play the way you want.+ All the unfinished missions and quests return after finishing the main story campaign so you can take your time, explore the wasteland, and 100% the game if you want.+/- The hand-to-hand combat is a riff on the Batman Arkham combat system with fancy finishers but without gadgets. It works well enough, but nothing outstanding about it.  (If keyboard & mouse is your preference, be sure to have a 3-button mouse.)+/- The game is a grind for scrap, which is used for much-needed upgrades. If you hate grinding, walk away. If you enjoy exploration and looting, then Mad Max is an amazing experience.+/- Child slavery content warning. There isn’t much, but it is there.- Checkpoint saving is the primary method of storing progress. Awkward in a sandbox game. You can save the game from the menu, but it does not hard-save the last checkpoint; it saves Max to the nearest fast-travel location. Not very useful.- Driving mechanics are sub-par; floaty and imprecise, the smallest bump can send the car flying, leaving Max facing the wrong way in seconds as the enemy speeds off into the distance. Not good in a game that focuses so much on driving. The Gastown race almost made me rage-quit the game.- Enemies are endlessly re-used.- Grinding is required. Upgrades are sometimes hidden behind completely clearing a region of threats. - Glitchy menus. Hitting Escape to view a new log entry would frequently result in seeing the menu headings, but no images or text. Switching to another menu then switching back would usually fix the issue.- Messed up mission progression. Need to build the “Jack”, a special class of car referred to as an Archangel. Well, the next part of the mission wouldn’t trigger, no matter what I did. Checked online. As it happens, I had parts on the car that were a level HIGHER than what was required to progress. I had to un-equip all upgrades on the car, and re-equip only the upgrades the game told me to, and the rest of the mission triggered properly.- Some quests that were supposedly optional disappeared without warning because I chose to continue with the main story first. All the missions return for completion after finishing the main campaign, though, so there’s that.It was a challenge to bring Mad Max to an open world game, and Avalanche delivered an incredibly gritty, detailed world and a mature story. While the story itself is not open-ended, there is clearly a chance for sequels - with possible franchise potential. Fans of Mad Max and open-world explore-and-loot games should give it a try – especially since it now discounts during Steam sales to $10 or less. There’s a lot of value here. Recommended.

Posted: October 16, 2015
												Mad Max is an intriguing game to review, and a tough one to succinctly assess. It captures the atmosphere of its source material very well, presenting an open world of majestic dunes and industrial wreckage, replete with anarchy, chaos and quasi-spiritual linguistic quirks. Avalanche toss players right into this turbulent land, and the game thrives in the moments where Max is jostling with War Boy raiders on the open road or tossing ignited cans of gasoline into their scrappy fortresses. But it’s also a title which seems, at some point, to have gone through significant changes (perhaps related to its delay in 2014), and some of the hastier joins around the story pacing, resource systems and progression mechanics still remain.Befitting of a Mad Max game, the vast majority of the plot concerns Max’s tireless quest for a V8 engine. He’s forced to build a new car (with the help of the irrepressible sidekick/acolyte Chumbucket), after his famous Interceptor is stolen by a roid-abusing chap with the very Mad Max name of Scabrous Scrotus. Though this encounter leaves him bruised and bereft of car, clothes and equipment, Max does at least leave a chainsaw blade in Scrotus’ forehead for good measure. In order to piece together a vehicle worthy of Chumbucket’s ‘Magnum Opus’ moniker, Max needs to roam the dusty wastelands, scavenging scrap, trading favours with local warlords, and ramming or punching every War Boy, Buzzard or general road filth who tries to get in his way.Pretty much everything in Mad Max is upgraded through the scrap resource (including, somewhat bizarrely, Max’s combat skills), so any of the open world activities that reward scrap are potentially worth doing. Luckily, that’s basically all of them; so unless you have a worrying compulsion to clear the entire map of icons it’s possible to almost exclusively stick to the things you enjoy. A few of the story missions will force you into owning certain upgrades or tackling specific side-areas, but this is kept in moderation.Avalanche’s art team have done just as tremendous a job as their technical division (the game runs incredibly well even on minimum-spec PCs), creating a dozen or so desert zones that actually look distinct from one another. Red, Mojave-like scrublands border rolling dunes, which in turn become rockier, mesa-filled landscapes, or areas pocketed by vents of near-luminous sulfur. For an area of land that’s ostensibly barren, it offers a palette of bold colours and striking, post-civilisation landmarks.Roaring through these realms in pursuit of a convoy, harpoon primed to pull wheels off escorts, War Boy boarders tumbling in your wake, and a well-aimed shotgun blast turning another wheeled foe into a spinning, combusting ball of debris, is one of Mad Max’s most exhilarating diversions. The versatile Shadow of Mordor-esque photo mode isn’t just in the game for moody shots of the desert, it’s also for snapping some of the magnificent explosions in full bloom.The various camps, hide-aways, and ramshackle dwellings scattered across the wastes do eventually end up seeming over-familiar. For a decent while though, it’s a delight to roll up on a new location, comb it for scrap, engage in some un-gentlemanly BatMax fisticuffs with the locals, and explore whether there are any unique, handcrafted little dioramas contained with. Such encounters are only enhanced by the random events of Max’s world. You may end up having to deal with a honking patrol showing up while you’re on foot and vulnerable, or a powerful dust storm bellowing its way across the dry earth.Of such things are the finest of Mad Max’s moments made. There are some shonkier aspects though, which aren’t gigantic problems in themselves but are amplified by being repeated across hours upon hours of playing. Max has a bit of a case of ‘Geralt movement’, where the weight of his animation will often carry him beyond the ladder, box of scrap, or weapon you’re trying to line him up with. A great many things in this game demand that you stand somewhat perfectly in front of them and hold down E (or equivalent) for a bit, so that gets rather old.It’s also extremely aggravating to have to watch an almost-cut-scene every single time Max tips gasoline into something or refills his water canteen (effectively your back-up health potion, and probably preferable to the other options of consuming maggots and dog food). This is borderline crazy, because I’m pretty sure it all still happens in-engine. Having the game cut to black after those actions makes very little sense. If modding is ever possible, the removal of these repeat irritations must be a priority.Though it doesn’t directly detract from a lot of the fun, Mad Max shows various signs of features being hastily changed or wrapped up before they were quite ready. The game’s opening tries to impress the importance of fuel and water for survival, when in fact those resources are now found in abundance across the wasteland (I never ran out of fuel, and having an empty canteen has no additional penalty).Every ‘Top Dog’ mini-boss looks basically the same, attacks in the same manner (a couple do have assistance from underlings), and may even use the same voice actor. Encounters in the wasteland offer ‘intel’ on these fights, vaguely hinting at a sort of Mordor Nemesis system of particular weaknesses, but it’s obvious stuff like ‘he doesn’t like being shivved in the neck!’ The same tactics which work on all of them. Clearing minefields seems like a hold-over from a time where Max was intended to regularly use a wider selection of vehicles than the Magnum Opus. You can still collect a full set of cars, but outside of races or a sneaky plan to drop mines in front of a convoy, only the mine-clearing buggy (and attendant dog) has such a specific purpose.Unfortunately, some of the Magnum Opus upgrades are tied to the reduction of ‘threat’ in different regions, and that can mean having to take time off from your campaign of chaos to settle into some familiar busywork. Getting the top level harpoon (the only one which can reliably yank down the most hardy ‘scarecrow’ structures dotted around the land, and one of the most hilarious weapons overall), means sniffing out a whole lot of minefields.Some of the unlocking methodology may irritate, but the way upgrades for the Opus are handled is quite novel. Later armor and ramming options are not automatically the best way to go; they’re heavy, and become a trade-off with speed and handling. In this sense, you do actually have to design a workable car to some extent. It’s refreshing that the ‘last’ upgrade in a chain isn’t automatically superior by default, but is instead a new variable to consider. Mad Max has its fair share of quirks and odd design decisions, but creates a sandbox of anarchic chaos that’s both wonderfully rendered and, on PC, a technical marvel. A word on the sound design too, which is just as responsible as the art design and animation for capturing the whump of explosions and jaw-breaking punches alike. There’s much to revel in. But although it’s appropriate that a game from this universe should feel like some aspects are misshapen or hastily bodged into shape to fit a grander vision, the annoyances really peel away at you over the course of a title as long as this one. Like the original 1979 film, Mad Max seems destined to be a cult classic; beloved by many, in spite of the components that appear to have been ripped out and reassembled, or otherwise abandoned to the desert basin.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												Mad Max is a third person, action game set in an open world environment, based on the Mad Max film series. It was released on September 1st 2015 on PC, PS4 and Xbox One. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic setting, much like Fallout New Vegas, we have plenty of deserts, canyons, wreckage and tunnels to explore.  You play the character, Max Rocktanksky on the story to regain your lost car, and along the way you will build your own car, The Magnum Opus. Game play within Mad Max is very heavily focused around vehicular style. Half the game is based inside of your car and you are having to deal with other enemies in their cars as well as on foot. You can use a series of different techniques, whether it be simply ramming the opponents, using your shotgun to blow tires out, or your harpoon weapon to take down the threats.  The other half of the game is done in a commonly seen third person action style - this is extremely similar to the style of combat on show in the Batman Arkham series of games. The hand to hand combat is simply brilliantly put together and you can pull of some amazing combos, blocks and parries, and it all looks so fluently done.  I played this game on 4k resolution, so of course the game looks good, but seriously, this is the best looking game on PC I have seen. It just looks gorgeous, every single one of the textures is high resolution, the animations are perfect, some amazing screenshots can be taken. One would probably expect that when on 4k, but it still looks amazing when playing on the lower resolutions, I'm not even going to say 1080 is low, it looks gorgeous even on that.  It's easy to see why they pulled production on this game being released on the PS3 and Xbox360, I would think even the current gen consoles would struggle with this. The story in Mad Max is a stand alone and is in no way related to any of the films. As someone who has only seen the recent Mad Max film, I didn't have much nostalgia going into this game, but I can honestly say that I was drawn into the plot from the get go. I got attached to the characters straight away, Chumbucket (your cars mechanic) becomes your friend as you progress through the game and quickly turns into a friendly companion. There are some scenes which really take your breathe away as they are very unpredictable and some of which had shouting out in sheer horror as to what was happening, that is just how invested I got into this game's plot. This game is not exactly a difficult game to play. The Arkham style combat mechanism is very easy to pick up and pretty much master and the art of vehicle combat can very easily be learnt after a few trial runs. The boss fights in the game can be pretty challenging, as they should be, and you will probably have to redo a few of them until you nail down the perfect fight. You will more than likely die more from accidentally blowing your self up, driving down a cavern which has no bottom, or something silly which you weren't really meaning to happen. As with most open world games like this, you can really make your character way too overpowered for the stage in the story you are on with upgrades and stat increases, so if you too much, you can soon make the game have no challenging aspect at all. The open world side of this game is truly awesome. I have never seen a map so full of things to do, areas to explore, items to find, hidden objects to locate, side quests, everything. There is literally never a minute in this game where I was bored. If you don't feel like doing a story mission, go for a drive into the dessert and kill some bad guys for more scrap to upgrade your car. Want to go do some exploration? Go digging in an under ground cave for that hidden object to tick off the list. There is literally something every 30 seconds of traveling in game to see or do. Some open world games feel like they are as vast as an ocean, but as deep as a puddle. Mad Max completely blows that theory out of the water. Not to mention the world is absolutely huge, there is so much depth to whats in it, you will never struggle to find something to do. On the topic of side quests, another nice little mechanic which I really loved in this game, was the ability to upgrade towns and strongholds which you venture into, by completing "Projects", these are simply a style of fetch quest which in turns gives you a little buff in that area of the map you are in, such as whenever you come back to town, you'r ammo gets replenished or something. A key one to try work your way towards in every town, is to collect scrap even when offline, it's nice to login after a few hours to see you've collated a few hundred scrap and can now upgrade your car! The full story, and I would say 80% of the side missions completed, took me just over twenty five hours to complete. That to me is a huge amount of content, purely from the story mode and the side missions alone, I still have plenty of hidden objects I want to seek out, strongholds to take over, cars to unlock and races to take part in, this is easily another ten hours worth of content to see. Not to mention the amount of achievements on offer too. I only reached 18 out of 49 on my run through, so there is plenty to do on that side of things too. Even though I was playing on 4k resolution, with all of the options at max graphical settings, I was still getting a constant 60 FPS. This game is perfectly optimized for any rig, and will run like a dream on almost anything if you set the options correctly. The only technical problems I ran into, was that sometimes the dialog on a few of the NPCs in the open world sometimes cut out half way through, but as long as you have subtitles on, that won't really make a difference - it only happened three or four times for me in the 25 hours I have played. In my opinion, I think Mad Max is going to be a surprise contender for "Game of the Year 2015", it is simply amazing and I will go as far to say it is in my top 10 best games of all time. Hats off to Avalanche Studios, and Warner Brothers, who have redeemed them selves ever so slightly with this amazing PC release. Do not waste any more time and get this game now!  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

												Mad (for looting) MaxI have mixed opinions on this game, mainly cause I've spent 60 hours playing every single story and side mission, as well as looting every possible thing I could in the Big White. I'll start by saying good things about the game; it is gorgeous. It has a lot of Mad Max lore easter eggs and the main story of the game is pretty good. Probably my favorite side stuff was taking down convoys which are the closest thing to the Fury Road movie. And now to the bad side; it can be VERY repetitive and frustrating to do some challenges. Doing some looting is interesting cause of the locations the devs put their effort into (like camps), but most of the looting locations are just copy/pasted and always the same: 2-3 loot crates and maybe 1 history relic. You'll rarely stumble on new car models unless you've previously maxed out the strongholds so you know where to go.And don't even get me started on the annoying clearing minefields and challenges ("Stick It To Ya" being absolutely THE WORST challenge to accomplish).Overall, this game reminds me of Assassin's Creed/Far Cry games. They're not bad, but they aren't anything special really. I know that once I've completed every possible thing I could and unlocked all achievements that I will never play this game again. Not because it's bad, but because it felt so good finishing it.tl;dr - the game's like pancakes. You'll love it at first, but play it too much (like myself with 60+ hours) and you'll get sick of it.

 Drought, gasoline, fist fights and fast cars! Max, a lone wolf who just wants to leave this damn filthy piece of land where survival of the fittest applies vigorously. All Max knows is this post-apocaliptic society stucked around Gastown. It's the last bastion of humanity surrounded by hostile land called Big Nothing. Max desires crossing part of Big Nothing called Plains of Silence in order to find what lays behind and start a new life. Forget what was lost. Rumour has it water and green vegetations are plenty there, but no one ever returned to confirm these legends. Still there would be no reason to return to this brutal and violent land led by masochists and maniacs. Max focuses everything just on one purpuse - build a car able to cross Plains of Silence - but what happens on his way its up to you to discover.Mad Max offers surprisingly large open world full of brutality, violence and day to day surviving. Wait, let me stop here, survival in this world for Max is as difficult as swimming for Michael Phelps. I would expect more elements and threats, but in this desert it's easier to meet a stranger than in my town on Sunday. Even though the Mad Max's world is welldesigned and every location is unique after a while you won't know whats lack of gasoline, water or even ammunition. On the other hand action parts of the game are spectacular and make the game very enjoyable. Beating to death almost every person you meet, destructing cars of other survivors and dismantling Scrotus's (President of Gastown and surrounding lands) camps makes game very entertaining.When we move to RPG elements, don't expect much. Story is short and plain. I was so curious about Max, or even about the past, how the world turned into this hellish place, but no, sorry, no explanation for you. Eventhough many relics (usually postcards) and monuments (lighthouse etc.) persisted the decline of civilization, you are here only to look around and examine them. It's not bad, but there could be so much more! Max's memories or just tale from anyone who you meet through the game. After all this game feels amazing despite all negatives. Pros✪ Amazing graphics and cutscenes✪ Welldesigned and unique world✪ Large open World✪ Action combat✪ Nice system of improving Max's abilities✪ Car customisation✪ Interesting collectibles✪ Races!Cons✪ Lack of survival elements - plenty of water, gasoline, ammo...✪ Short and plain story✪ Very easy to complete, the only "hard" parts demand your time not skill✪ Missing depth -  at any cost I wouldn't call this RPG✪ Repetitive side missions✪ Lack of options7/10 Good quality action game

												Finished Mad Max late last night. Being an open-world game, I neglected the main story for the most part and did all sorts of side activities. Usually not much of a completionist but this time around I did a lot of that. Cleared the Threat Level in each area to Zero, leveled up Max to the Max and so on. Didn't do any races though, not a fan of races. Anyway, I think there is plenty good with the game but it definitely won't be a good time for everyone. The campaign itself is fairly standard in length but the world itself took centerpiece during my time. Probably one of my favorite post-apocalyptic wasteland worlds in all of gaming. The atmosphere is on point. Desolate, destroyed, almost alien. Inhabitants having lost all sense of mercy or ethics. So does Max, the protagonist. One of the few games where the players actions feel perfectly in line with the character and world. Characters and story are sadly passable at best. There's only very little to get you invested in them. An alright excuse to keep things moving. Besides the main story there are several major side stories which happen at the four friendly strongholds. Each has their own ideology and it was compelling to see how humans could make sense of living in an utterly destroyed world. These strongholds can also be upgraded by scavenging for special loot-crates in the world which open up permanent benefits for Max, health-refill, tank-refill, etc. These are very useful and make the tedious scavenging hunt worthwhile.Most of your time will be spent doing other things though. The world is huge and it is daunting at how much there is to explore at the beginning. You slowly discover new areas but in the end it all goes the same way. You search for the hot air balloon at each area and by using it, the fog of war clears, enemy camps and other points of interest get marked on your map. These places are identical across the whole world, so it's easy to get in a repetitive motion very quick. Taking over enemy camps, clearing minefields, looting the many small loot locations, taking out convoys. The thing that makes this still fun and worthwhile is the constant change of activities. At one point you are brawling your way through enemy camps where you can spice things up by melee weapons, makeshift bombs and special finishing moves. On the surface the combat is not deep but the combination of ways you can fight makes it always fun and satisfying. It's a similar story with the second big pillar of combat, by car. This one starts of seriously under-powered and you will have a hard time tackling even smaller convoys. Upgrading your car - especially weaponry - will drastically turn the tides and soon you'll feel like an absolute bad♥♥♥♥♥of a one-man army ripping off tires during high-speed car battles, sending enemies flying through their windshields with your high-powered hook or straight up turn vehicles into fiery explosions of metal with your thunderpoon. It's as bad♥♥♥♥♥as it sounds really and does not get old.This all, the actual gameplay and the beautiful and diverse areas help make the otherwise repetitive tasks a joy to fulfill for the tenth, twentieth time but in the end, they are repetitive tasks and if it is not fun the first time, I doubt things will change. For me it just clicked. I enjoyed clearing the world of enemy patrols and camps, upgrade my car, destroy huge enemy convoys and see how strongholds strived and prospered by my hand. After clearing the whole map of threats and doing all side missions, tackling the final third of the story became sort of a final pay-off to me. A nice and fitting end to a long road.

												Story is you are Max, left stranded for dead, vehicle taken and dismantled to scraps, and left with nothing but your clothes.Now full of vengeance and teamed up with your hunchback sidekick Chumbucket, it is now your destiny to rebuild a better machine called the Magnum Opus, something that the wasteland will tremble in fear from decades to come.That is basically it as you will have to travel the wastelands going into uncharted territory to build and upgrade your new vehicle from scrap all the way to making the Scrotus clan eat your deadly wheels as you will have to fight to survive by gathering food and water, taking over enemy clans camps, and racing your way to collect scrap as you upgrade.The vehicle has much to offer as you upgrade everything from wheels with better traction, harpoons to destroy enemy vehicles, paint job, armor, and all the works.You can also upgrade Max as well from his looks to his uniform to upgrade in combat as well, combat system kind of reminds me of Batman, only with shotguns and plenty of satisfying German Suplex's to even make Brock Lesnar jealous.Other form of combat comes from your vehicle as you the other half of the time you will come across gang of other vehicles looking to demolish, this all comes in handy as you can use your shotgun to shoot the enemy fuel tank in on kill or be strategic and use your harpoon to take off portions of the vehicle or lasso the driver out and flip him to oblivion.Now this may not be a popular opinion and I do apologize but to me, the racing and the driving controls in general were just way too stiff and clunky for me, I know you can upgrade for better traction but even half way through the upgrades my vehicle still felt like it was swimming through Crisco. Also, good luck with racing in the game, if you even as much get hit and swerve into the rocks while driving, you might as well restart the race because it takes forever to catch up to your enemy drivers while avoiding hazards to make sure your vehicle does not spontaneously combust while skating through the crisco wasteland. That may not happen to others, I don't know but that is my opinion.The other little minor issue I have is the weak ending. Throughout the game you will also have your share of boss battles which they all fight in the same pattern pretty much, either dodge out of the way to avoid their powerful attack or click the mouse to counter their attacks and lay into them with a series of punches and kicks as you will also go into fury mode which turns you into a ninja and you become a buffed up one man wrecking crew..but yeah the bosses were kind of weak, especially the ending boss, oh god the ending boss, which made the ending feel anti climatic..I mean here is the build up for the Lord of the wasteland called Scrotus, built up to make him look like a complete bad a**, and what do they do? Oh let's just put him into a car playing scaredy cat as we toss like 3-4 harpoons at him..and thats it..thats the last boss. Also the ending story just came out of nowhere as I felt like it was rushed, once again, maybe it was just me but they could have done something more to it.Other than that, graphics are great, I love traveling through the desolate wasteland to the creepy tunnels.Music and everything else is pretty good.So on this game it is kind of in the middle for me, but I do recommend it, just let the price go down a bit and then see what you guys will think. It is a good game with a decent length of 15-25 hours of gameplay depending on how many missions you go on. So yeah, a little repetitive but still something worth checking out.

Why couldn't Arkham Knight have been this good?Grand Max Auto: The Arkham WastelanderThe Good~+ The rich and engaging story of Mad Max~+ 18 hours in, at the time of this writing, and I've only just barely upgraded the first of five strongholds and explored about a fifth of the map. (This is a plus because it means at least 100+ hours of  game play.)+The driving feels solid, and the collisions are very satisfying.+ The combat is very similar to the Batman Arkham series, with powerful combos and counters, taking on 5 - 10 people at once. + The game map is massive. I couldn't tell you how many miles it is, but at full speed in a car with nitro it takes about six minutes to go from Jeets (East) to Pinky's (West.) And it's a relatively short distance on the map.+ DOZENS of upgrades for Max himself, and the Magnum Opus (your car.)+ Your actions feel like they influence the world, and have weight on it's people and economy.+ The lack of guns has no impact on the game. Even with a single home-made shot gun the game is always fast past and action packed.+ Awesome graphics+ Awesome voice acting+ You get a bomb sniffing dog!The Bad~- Exploration is limited to scalable area's marked with yellow paint. You can't climb just any ledge or rock. Due to there being so many of these areas, however, the game does not feel linear at all.- The Sniper Rifle Mod for the car is more of a tool than an actual weapon. Yes, it kills people, but you can only use it from the Magnum Opus. You'll end up just using it for reconnoiter and safely taking out key defenses.- With any massive open world game there is a bit of repetitiveness. Collecting scrap can become tedious in the beginning, but eventually people will help you when you build up the strongholds. - Chumbucket can get a little annoying. But that's not really a bad thing on the game's part. Just my preference for his character. - I've found a few bugs. But not many. Sometimes the map won't open and you have to exit the game to reset it. Stomping out rats and lizards for food can sometimes launch you into the air, which will result in you dying upon hitting the ground. The pause menu can get stuck on a bio entry, even if you've read it. But it's easy to just click out to where you need to go.  The game doesn't like it when the car rolls........ .... ..... ..All in all, the game is awesome. Pick it up if you can. You won't be disappointed. ~Love and Peace

Posted: August 27, 2016
												Mad Max is a game where the divine meets the driveshaft. Where fates and furies touch a flywheel.It's awesome.First of all, it's gorgeous. The monotony of the sand dunes is mitigated by a surprising amount of variety in the environment. Pools of oil, rock formations, and flocks of birds split things up naturally. But there are also traces of the past civilization: broken bridges, artificial roads, and vehicle wreckage abound.The lighting and particle systems are also excellent. The sun's rays make for a lot of dramatic imagery against what might have been an otherwise dreary landscape. I think I took more screenshots of Mad Max than any game I've ever played. My random travels generated breathtaking vistas at an astonishing rate.And the first time you're caught in a storm outside away from any shelter - it's an unforgettable experience. Progress on challenges gets lost if you die, so the storms can present a real threat to you. They disable fast travel too, so there's no easy escape. This is all as it should be. It makes for some tense segments where you will absolutely have to improvise to stay alive.Dying is otherwise not that big of a deal because most other types of progress generate an auto save. This is also as it should be. The system encourages you to be bold and more reckless than you might be otherwise, and that seems really in tune with the spirit of Mad Max.And that's another positive in general: Mad Max was ripe for an open world driving game, but I had no idea. A lot of the concepts and themes translate perfectly. The explosions, the fighting, ramming cars together - it's all a ton of fun.That said, the melee combat is one of my chief complaints about the game. It gets very repetitive very fast. I was hoping there would be a way to acquire more guns like a silenced pistol for stealth or an assault rifle for mowing down large groups. Sadly there's only the shotgun, and its upgrades don't feel that significant. There was a chance for a lot more depth in both the leveling system and the combat progression for the game as a whole, and the developers didn't take advantage of it.The car combat, on the other hand, is fantastic. I haven't had this much fun blowing up cars since Twisted Metal, and that came out 20 years ago. The amount of customization and improvements you can make is great, with the possible exception of the weapons. Having to choose between rockets and a minigun might've made things more interesting. But it's hard to knock it at all because the Thunderpoon is the best weapon I've used in a game in years. Plus it has the best name ever.THUNDERPOON!The open world aspects and the collectibles were pretty standard, though I was impressed by the variety. Most of it didn't feel old, even at the end. There are three notable exceptions.First, clearing the minefields was tedious, and this is largely because you have to get a different car from a base and it disappears if you fast travel - I wasted a lot of time forgetting that fact.Second, the day/night system. There are some missions that can only be performed at night. There are also only certain enemy and car types that appear depending on the time of day, and those distinctions are necessary to complete some of the challenges. BUT, there's no way to fast forward time. What's worse, time can get "stuck" and not move at all. You can spend literally forever waiting for the time to change so you can do that one mission and it will never happen. Nothing you do will affect it. It's incredibly frustrating, and I don't understand how it survived the testing phase.Third, the challenges. There's a single achievement related to getting all of them, and if you didn't know that before you finished mopping up everything, then you really screwed yourself over. There's no new game plus where the challenges carry over. And enemy spawns at the end of the game when it's all been cleared out are basically nonexistent. Just Cause 3 solved this problem with its "Re-Oppress" feature. Having now played a similar game where that doesn't exist makes me appreciate it a lot more. Plus, that one achievement will add 15-20 hours to your time even if you're prepared for it. They should've found another way, or at least eliminated the more troublesome, time-consuming challenges. It's ridiculous.Finally, let's talk about the story. It's generally presented well. I have a minor gripe that some of the cinematic action sequences would've been even better if they were playable. It felt like I was forced to watch instead of do things too often. What's worse is the story they were telling itself - clearly, secondary to the gameplay. Max is very much removed from all the characters in this part of the world: he doesn't know a single soul when he gets there. And whatever connections he does make throughout the game seem forced and one-sided. He's just not that sympathetic of a character the way they portrayed him here. On top of that, it doesn't feel like Max had a lot of agency to make choices or change anything. The world is more or less the same for his passing, despite everything you do as the player.The writing is amazing though. It makes Mad Max one of the best examples I can think of to showcase how dialogue and diction can be top notch while the overall story and plot is bland. Every time Chumbucket (there's a main character named Chumbucket!!!) opened his mouth I wanted to write everything down to save for later. Each of the characters has their own distinct personality and vocab. The voice acting on top of the writing is solid. These things came together in micro-moments where the cinematic sequences were shining bright examples of what can be done in the medium.Mad Max is a great game. Probably the best open world game I've played in recent memory. It's easily better than Watch Dogs and Shadow of Mordor. The comparison starts to get more interesting when looking at Sleeping Dogs, as one game's strengths might be the other's weaknesses. If Mad Max had a combat/upgrade system more similar to Sleeping Dogs and an improved story, then I think it would've been unstoppable, and competing with the likes of Fallout 4 for GOTY 2015 awards. Hopefully they make a sequel and improve those few areas while adding things like a true stealth mode and more time with Dinki Di. I'd buy that game faster than you can say "Thunderpoon."

Posted: September 22, 2015
												From nearly start to finish I enjoyed my time in the Wastelands with Max.  Yes, the missions and tasks were repetitive and, yes, the combat was more of the same from Batman or Shadow of Mordor but the world was immersive enough, attractive enough (in its own wasteland way) and just plain fun enough to keep me returning.Nearly every "repetitive" aspect managed to find a way to stay interesting.  Melee combat felt heavy and brutal and slamming a guy's head into a wall or suplexing him never got old for me.  There's a hundred or so locations where you can seek scrap metal or water but they varied from tents to old subway cars to cliffside villages to abandoned restaurants to deep caves.  You're tasked with tearing down giant metal "scarecrows" but, to the last, I enjoyed flying past (or through) them, launching a harpoon and collapsing them behind my racing vehicle.  You'll do a LOT of driving but the landscape is wonderfully created as you progress from dried ocean bottom to ravaged desert towns and upland desert to the mountains of waste and scrap surrounding Gastown.Vehicular combat is a special joy and from early on you are armed with a harpoon that can tear off armor, tires or doors or pull a War Boy out of his car or a sniper out of his tower.  Further car enhancements allow you to attach grinders to your wheels Ben-Hur style or launch explosive spears to quickly end a fight.The game certainly isn't perfect.  Boss fights are almost all copies of each other, clearing mine fields is tedious busy work and there is a major plot-required race that deviates from all the other driving you'll do in game.  The plot is nothing special and this game is definitely more about the journey than the destination.  But Mad Max and the Wastelands kept me coming back for more days on end managed to never feel "old".

Posted: August 31, 2015
												There once was a guy named Max, Who didn't know how to relax, Some guys stole his car, but they didn't get far before he cut off and flossed with their sacks.Max is not a happy guy. His car gets stolen, and a lot of people want to kill him, his only friend being a crazy mechanic who is basically Smeagol high on Petrol fumes. Walking around a desert with sand in your boots all day would make anyone mad.This sets Max on a quest to build the perfect car, the Magnum Opus, which draws a lot of comparisons with how the game plays. Like the Opus, the game itself is incredibly well optimised; it runs smoothly, at a very high frame rate, and has clearly been crafted with a lot of care and attention. The downside to this is that I feel like they could have used those spare resources to do more with the game engine, to make the game look better than it currently does - it's not ugly, but there is definitely room for an upgraded "Definitive Edition" later down the road. AA does a mediocre job of eliminating jaggies and it would be nice to have an MSAA option, with higher quality textures.Using a third-party injector, I managed to improve the colour palette - a desert will never be bright and shiny and colourful, but there's definitely room to enhance and sharpen the existing palette. All in all, it's beautiful to behold, and the night sky is a sight to behold.I've never been a fan of the films, but I love this game's story. It's clearly explained, I know exactly what's going on at all times, and it's interesting. I also like the upgrade system, which is fairly comprehensive and gives you some great options to customise both Max and the Magnum Opus.A lot of folks complained that I hadn't spent much time with the game and therefore had no right to judge it, so I'm changing my review to reflect having spent more time with the game - I now give it an 8.5 out of 10. While it may not technically be the best game ever made, for me, it ticks all the right boxes and does a LOT of things right. You won't regret buying this, I can promise you.

When I first heard of this game I thought "oh a movie tie in that will follow the film plot and be pretty pointless". As you are in a fairly open world you can also compete in races, collect relics or farm scrap to your hearts desire. I plugged many hours into the game doing just that and although I have had my fill, did not manage to get all the achievements by the games end. I might be tempted to go back though at a later date.The game isn't too difficult but adds a fair challenge at certain stages and is great fun to play. Definately in my top 5 games of 2015. Unfortunately I think it was over shadowed by Metal Gear being released at a similar time. Now I am just hoping for a Bullet Farm DLC.

												Prepare thine buttox, ye who enter this realm of criticism.I'm not trying to be a prick here, I just want to be honest about what I actually think and experienced.While this game has cool GRAYFIX and all that, gameplay is lacking pretty hard.Here's the generally good stuff;*Very nice visuals, as I mentioned.*Even though the world is mostly sand and rock, each territory has nice variety and cool locations to check out.*Melee combat has a lot of fun moves and contextual things like slamming heads into walls or pushing people over rails to their doom.*Vehicle combat is satisfying and visceral.*Story is fairly good, not much to complain about here, except the ending is a bit anticlimactic in my opinion.*Characters are interesting and memorable.*Voice acting is superb.*Low usage of invisible walls, instead uses level design and deadly storms to create boundries, that's a plus in my book.And here's the rest;*Poorly balanced, very easy to get very overpowered.You can reach close to Max (ohoho) level before you leave even the first territory of the game, obviously designed towards being rushed through, which is a bit sad.*Supplies are extremely abundant, fuel, water, food, ammo, whatever.Never once did I run out of anything other than water, which I promptly refilled moments later.Skill upgrades are detrimental to the game, making supplies 'even' more abundant, giving you a ton of health turning you into a tank (combine with good armor and you'll be unstoppable), making combat even easier, etc.*The only thing that ever got me killed was me being silly where I fell off cliffs or such, oops.*Melee combat is pizz-easy(yay censorship), even if you use no combat upgrades.Melee combat also had potential to be a bit more interesting, but for no actual reason everyone fights with their fists, nobody except you has a gun (not counting snipers), and melee weapons are fairly useless and magically break after a handful of hits.You also can't store melee weapons, not even in your car.*Vehicle combat is pretty fun and provides some challenge, only real complaint here would be that you'll never ever leave the main vehicle to drive any of the other tons of vehicles available, because you can't bring cumbucket with you on anything else.*Vehicles handle poorly with keyboard controls, so get a controller if you wanna have more fun driving.Additonally, vehicle physics are a bit strange, with vehicles uprighting themselves constantly and being near impossible to flip.*Some vehicle upgrades are a bit silly, for example Armour upgrades where you stick a few guard rails on the side of your car and suddenly it weighs enough to warrant a military tank licence.You also can't even unlock and purchase the V8 stuff until there's like, 5-10% left of the game to play.*Gameplay is very (VERY) repetative, all bosses (yes literally all) are copy-pasted with different colours and voice lines.That is a huge point deduction in my little book.*Side missions are fun for the first few times, until you realize they're all copy-pasted as well, sadly.*Sub-par freedom of movement, unbefitting a modern game with a modern engine,you can only climb specially marked areas, nothing else, not even a belly-high fence.It feels very primitive and unorganic, especially for a modern 3rd person game.*Racing is, as you probably would guess by now, pizz-easy.You either outrace every other driver within 20 seconds or shoot out all their tires within 10 seconds ( ͠° ͟ʖ ͡°)I can't write much else about it since it nullifies its own existance so quickly.*Exploring can be fun for eyecandy alone, but don't expect to be rewarded with anything substansial, only generic supplies, and Project Parts here and there, but..Projects makes the game, once again, even easier, giving you infinite fuel, ammo, water, health refills, etc."But hey, it's fun to upgrade strongholds you big meanie!"So thought I, as I assumed it actually had purpose, but it turns out it has no function whatsoever. None.Unless you count looking less arze with each stage, but yeah..*So this is supposed to be related to Fury Road right?Supposedly, but there are no real ties between the movie and the game, in either direction.Max himself also acts wildly differently between the movie and the game, it doesn't even seem like they're the same person.Compared to the movie, in the game barely anybody has guns and Max can't fight anywhere near as good in the movie as he does in the game.But now I'm stepping towards reviewing the movie instead of the game so let's drop it here shall we.All in all, if you like Mad Max, you'll get a thrill or two out of this generally casual game, but it's certainly not worth full price, it's more along the lines of 15-20 euros.

												When I start playing a new game, I always take notes of my first impressions (I was a reviewer of pc games about a decade ago), it's like a habit now for me. And I've rarely been so impressed with the early game as I was with Mad Max.The menu, the presentation and early game - very well done. The game world is unbelievably beautiful. It's freakin' gorgeous! Probably my most visually impressive 3rd person action game that I've ever played. Characters have good animations and are detailed. Controls are intuitive. Special effects and lighting is jaw-breaking. Weather effects <3, scenery <3 - everything is eye-gasmic. Day and night cycle makes the desert look so real and beautiful and ... sometimes lonely (in a good way).This game is based all around the battle cars and combat between them. It's very satisfying to combat a full convoy of them. The cars look deadly and diverse. Cars sounds are very satisfying. Even the controls are pretty good! Nitro animations looks awesome + you can speed up your car with it and whack other cars of the cliffs and stuff.I really like the hand-to-hand combat (It has some Shadow of Mordor vibe to it) and how the upgrade system works in Mad Max (too bad that you can get all the upgrades before or slightly after the midpoint. Of course, only if you do lots of side objectives, like I always do in these kind of games. And there are a lot of those little objectives or mini quests that you can participate in. (Just like in Batman or Far Cry, or Assassin's Creed games).The random storms are awesome. You really feel like you are in the middle of a f*cking disaster! Lots of mini tornadoes, lightning and flying debris that can damage you greatly. I really like how quickly you can descend the ladder. You just slide down and you're good to go. I hate when other games puts you in that unskippable animation and you sometimes have to waste 10 seconds of your precious life on the ladder.I really like how quickly Max can get out of a burning car before it explodes. You are never stuck in silly scripted animations.One thing that made me wonder - why Max can't jump high? He really despises jumping. I bet he couldn't even jump over his own shoes if they were lying somewhere on the ground. But then I realized. He looks like a ~35-40 year old man. He probably had to do a lot of jumping and running in his life so somehow he damaged his knees and he is just not able to do this sh|t anymore, so he said - f*uck it, I will not jump in my life anymore! Just like big NBA players in their late 30s. They can only run at a slow speed and can't even think about lifting off of the ground. Oh and explosions. Explosions. Seriously, explosions. No other game has better looking explosions. Period.This game has a little thingy called - capture mode. It literally makes you a photographer. if you want to be one - you can learn some basic things here: composition, depth of field, perspective and so on. Last 15 hours I was just hunting screenshots. Sometimes to make/take a perfect shot you need to invest dozens of minutes, but it's well worth it at the end. I've done like ~300 screenshots. I believe I could have done thousands of them If I would have used that mode from the very start. It's a great tool and I urge you to try it. (It's a bit buggy sometimes, but you will enjoy it anyway).Since I mentioned bugs - this game is pretty bug-free. BUT. I was trying to 100% this game and hunt for all the achievements and then a bug happened. I completed a mission and as a reward I had to receive the ability to build a maggot farm in one of my strongholds, but the game doesn't allow that. I've searched the internet and this thing is STILL not fixed (sad, sad face). I was/am disappointed. A great game with such a -+ game-breaking bug. But this should only matter to those who like to hunt for achievements.As a 3rd person action game - it has it all. And if you are one of those people that like to LIVE in the world, not just run through the main quest and be done with it - this game will provide you with lots and lots of fun hours.On a side note - this is how Fallout 4 should have looked like (from a graphical standpoint).

Mad MaxNote: Each field is weighted differently, and thus affects the overall score differently.  Field Rating Review   Graphics 8 A strangely beautiful wasteland to explore, with some extremely satisfying explosions. The storms you encounter in the wasteland are something to behold, especially as they come rolling towards you in the distance. The textures could stand to be a higher resolution, and occasionally glare out at you. But for the more part, Mad Max has done a great job crafting a desert that you're actually interested in exploring. Also of worthy note is the audio. Voice acting is well done, though Max himself can sound kind of strange at times. Sound Effects are fantastic and satisfying. Guns sound like they're actually powerful, explosions are wonderful to behold, and sandstorms are ridiculously intense. The combat animations in the game are also quite well done.   Gameplay 8 If you have played Shadow of Mordor, that's a great game to compare Mad Max to, gameplay wise. You spend the majority of your time exploring locations for scrap, destroying enemy camps, and competing in the occasional race. Combat is a simple combination of buttons to punch, execute, block, dodge, and shoot. Even after several hours of combat, I've found it still very enjoyable to smash some War Boy's faces in. There is no stealth in this game, and the variety of weapons is mediocre (shotgun, thunderpoon, harpoon, occasional melee weapons on the ground which all function the same way, and your fists). Driving your car is at the heart of this game, and Mad Max knows this. It can take a little bit to get used to driving your car, and sometimes you'll find yourself wondering why it spun out the way it did, but for the more part it is an entertaining ride through the wasteland. Car Combat is also very well done, with satisfying impacts as you smash into other vehicles, and a few options on how to take them down (shoot out the tires, pull the driver out with a harpoon, dismantle the car with a harpoon, etc). Of note is the upgrade system for your car. Max's upgrade system feels almost pointless, as it simply serves to make him stronger. However, your car is where the upgrades shine, with each upgrade offering different advantages/disadvantages. There is plenty of customization on the car to fit your style.    Story 6 I am not yet done with the storyline, but thus far it has been relatively engrossing. I won't say to much as to spoil anything, but Mad Max does do a decent job of keeping you curious what will happen next. The story does take many hours to complete, so there is plenty of content there.   Multiplayer N/A This game is single-player only.   Replayability 6 This is a toss up. While a very enjoyable game to hop into and beat folks up/destroy some cars, I don't see Mad Max as a game that one would come back to over and over. This is simply because of the fact that anything other than the main quest in the game can become somewhat repetitive. Mad Max's redeeming factor in this field is how satisfying the combat is, both on foot and in the car.   Overall 7.2/10 While a solid, mostly bug-free, wonderfully optimized game, Mad Max suffers from being a little to repetitive at times. That being said, I would recommend Mad Max to most any gamer, as the gameplay is very well done, and as a whole the game is fun experience. Take the chance to explore a well-crafted wasteland, and some of the best car combat I've seen in a game. 												It's repetitive. I know this isn't a unique thing to say about it, but if you are the person checking the negative reviews for more depth and not just constant praise then you are in the same boat I was in a few days ago.It isn't just combat, while it's literally click. click. click. right click. click. click. over and over again, this wouldn't bother me. And I told myself it wouldn't bother me when I decided to take a chance with the game anyway.You have no tactical approach to ANYTHING, I know ammo is scarce, but your only gun is a shotgun that you will likely only have a shell or two for most of the time. You don't get any of the other guns you saw in the movies. The problem with this is that if we had more guns in the game with specific uses then combat would actually have a bit of variety with it. The world is not good, I know it's a big♥♥♥♥♥desert, but look what Fallout 3 and Borderlands 1 have. This game copy pastes a lot of locations, and once you've played the first 2 hours you have seen everything unique about the game. It's after you start exploring where you realize this game has about as much depth to /anything/ as a puddle. You won't find unique NPCs or locations and you don't have random encounters. It just feels stale, like the world was generated by a computer and untouched by humans. You aren't ever going to find anything, it's always going to be scrap. Not unlike other games where you could find all sorts of loot, lore or interesting sights and characters. Nope just scrap.This adds to the repetitive nature, I can handle barebones combat, but if the environment and enemies are all the same, it's basically replaying a level over and over again for hours at that point, and that would drag on for anyone. Except those that have hundreds of hours somehow.You might think the car stuff is the bees knees and the rest pales in comparison, but car combat is pretty meh at best, I like traveling in a car I slowly upgrade overtime, I like hookshotting parts of other cars or people in the car and ripping them off. But you won't find the combat anything like it is in fury road, it usually dwells into driving in a circle around the other trying to nitro boost ram them over and over until they blow up. It just isn't enough.You can assault locations like oil rigs, and the game implies some form of tactics here in its tutorial, destroying perimeter defenses and eventually the gate. But it's always the same damn defenses so what is the point?! And you take out all 3 of them (Sniper tower, fire tower, and gate) by just driving past it and using the hookshot to knock them over. It takes all of several seconds to accomplish this!The last thing that initially hooked me, was when I first started I fell in love with how the game was looking like I was in an actual desperation for ammo, food and water. No regenerating health, you need to recover by eating or drinking water, which doesn't come in a large abundance. Ammo is scarce so making careful use of your shotgun for vital targets (No such thing) is important. I kept trying to conserve bullets thinking I should focus on vital targets, but no such targets exist. And of course they ♥♥♥♥ the survival up too with strongholds. With strongholds you can enter them and get your car refueled, health restored, water cantine refilled and ammo fully restocked for no charge. It nullifies the survival feel entirely. Storywise it's incredibly basic, Max just wants to assault GasTown for a V8 engine and some spritual journey crap blah blah. It's nothing special, it ain't bad. But it's not going to be something you remember.Technical wise the game runs fantastic and looks above average for it's time. More forms of anti aliasing would be great since FXAA looks dreadful in this game. I think TXAA would have been fantastic with the subtle blurring. Lip syncing is BEYOND BAD like this is bad english dub anime bad, the lips don't even move and if they do it's not synced at all. AT ALL! How does this still happen in a 2015 game?! It's distracting as hell.The voice acting for the most part was acceptable, but then you find these NPCs, they are like random NPCs that don't do much other then sometimes giving you worthless intel or a little scrap. And I have never wanted to stop hearing so much before, the dialogue is terribly written, the accent is bad, and the voice quality is terrible. The lines feel so forced and feel like a medicore mod was installed in my game instead of it being a triple A game. Hell even the audio for these NPCs are slightly louder then the rest and it stands out.I really can't suggest this game, I haven't played it in like 2 days and I don't feel the impulse to ever play it again. It's sad because I waited a long time to try it, and wanted to enjoy it but I can't. If I had any word to describe this game it'd be "padding" I think it would have worked better with a tighter focus on the story and less on putting out another sandbox game.

												"Mad Max" flirts with great, and dances with brilliant, but doesn't end up marrying either of them.The main mission path is really well done as a piece of storytelling, especially as it twists the knife in both Max and the player. (You'll know what I mean.)But...there are all these other, potentially fascinating characters that barely get any exploration at all.The world is both large AND quite detailed as an environment. The effort put in by Avalanche on that front is obvious and impressive.But...when it comes down to it, what there is to actually do in the world is very "samey." Sure there are variations on the themes, but those variations are pretty minor. On top of that, all progression pretty much amounts to the same thing (getting scrap to pay for upgrades), and you can get essentially Maxed out (see what I did there?) relatively early. At that point, your actions seem pretty academic and rote, even though there's still lots of territory potentially unexplored.I personally felt that the vehicular combat was extremely solid, and maybe even stellar at points. If you were going to make a road-warrior sort of game, "Max" would be an excellent template to follow. The controls make plenty of sense after a bit of explanation and practice, and the overall balance is just about right to get challenge without frustration.But...vehicle combat ends up being rather less central than you might expect. Instead, a lot of what you have to do to advance the game is focused on dismounted, hand-to-hand fighting. The mechanics there actually aren't bad, but the way the encounters are structured makes man-to-man fights boring and repetitive.The Magnum Opus is a very cool piece of customizable hardware, and it's great fun to experience its upgrades as bits and pieces are added.But...for some reason, the Opus never seems as durable as Chumbucket's dune buggy. Sure, the buggy isn't good at vehicle offense, but it can roll over almost any terrain and take a HUGE pounding. Your super-rad, armored assault car goes off a small ledge, and a very sizable chunk of structural integrity gets chewed up. The buggy, on the other hand, seems like it could fall from 30,000 feet and not register any damage. It's a little bizarre.Speaking more generally, I think that one main measure of an open-world game is how well it hides the fact that it's all built on repetition. It's not that something like "Far Cry" doesn't have a similar amount of cut-and-paste as "Mad Max." It's just that the "Far Cries" and the "Fallouts" manage to get enough of both uniquely crafted material and fun, snappy gameplay "loops" into the mix that the repeated elements become washed out. With "Mad Max," the feeling that you're continually leaving and arriving at the same party just isn't countered very well.Was I unhappy that I spend my money on this game? Not at all. It was worth it. I put a bunch of time into the experience. Avalanche did quite well, but it seems like all the effort got put into the environment when they might have spread out the resources a bit more evenly. It's a touch unfortunate - the game could have been an instant classic if it were smaller but more interesting - but I'm not really "Mad" about it. (See what I did there?)

												*Note: I'm almost five hours into an open world game that could potentially take 30+ hours to completely clear based on the huge map. I've sampled every different type of open world activity and have unlocked all the core "equipment" under Max's glossary.Let's start with what Mad Max *isn't* for those who may be looking for something specific: Mad Max is not a survival game. It has gameplay elements that sound like they would belong in a survival game like water and food scrounging, but this is an open world sandbox action game. Because it's an open world game, it's not as focused on delivering a narrative and tightly scripted action scenes as the recent "Fury Road".Now let's get down to what Mad Max is. Mad Max is an excellent open world sandbox in the vein of Just Cause. I say "sandbox" specifically because this game gives you a vast number of things to do and unleashes you upon the world to do them. Besides a few main quest goals (the story is frontloaded in the first few hours, as far as I can tell), you are given leave to plunder the wasteland while reducing the threat level presented by the big bad warlord Max is seeking to topple.The graphics in Max's wasteland are solid and I never felt like the world was merely one big desert. This really becomes apparent when you ascend in a scouting balloon and see just how many interesting land features there are to explore. In a way it reminds me of the Fallout series, barren but interesting. The sound design, though, is the real star. Engines revving, powerful explosions, and the crack of Max's shotgun and punches really sell the brutal experience.I can see the core gameplay loop of Max getting old if you don't particularly enjoy the activities of car combat, fighting, and exploring camps. However, I quite enjoyed the "Arkham" style combat and the great combat racing that allows you to slow down time to execute amazing attacks against foes that scream along the roads at breakneck speeds.I think it's safe to say that if you played tons of Just Cause (the other game these devs are famous for) then you'll love this game, but if you're looking for an open world game with an involved narrative like GTA or The Witcher, you may be less excited to take your twentieth bandit camp.I'd say Mad Max is a definitely worth a buy if you love the post apocalypse and want to spend hours tweaking a cool car, exploring camps and caves, and turning Max from a scrawny survivor into a Top Dog of the wastes (with an epic beard to match).
