YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Mad Max 

			Views: 1,436		

			Trent returns for his review of Mad Max! Watch to find out what he thinks! Review by: Trent Audio: Trent Editing: Valente		

The video game world is by no means short on post-apocalyptic wastelands to explore but unless a game comes out based on A Boy and His Dog comes out, none of them can claim to be based on one of the most influential pieces of Post-Apocalyptic media of the past 35 years. In this sense, Avalanche Studios’ Mad Max is an exciting licensed property in the game world and the prospect of playing another post-apocalyptic title, even amidst a market full of them, has only been sweetened by the most recent film in the Mad Max franchise: Fury Road. Given Avalanche’s mastery of creating exciting sandbox gameplay with ample opportunity for organic, play it your way hijinks, Mad Max seems poised to be this year’s Shadows of Mordor style sleeper hit.  Much like the films, Mad Max’s narrative is sparse but unlike the films, the supporting cast lacks the charisma to carry the events forward in a satisfying manner. Beginning with an overlong cutscene depicting Max’s clash with the game’s antagonist Scrotus. Their encounter ends with Scrotus suffering a major wound and Max stripped of his gear and left to wander in the desert. In typical video game fashion it’s up to Max to rebuild his car, re-acquire his gear and end Scrotus’ violent reign over the wasteland. While its narrative is certainly in the spirit of the films upon which it is based, the weak supporting cast and unfocused objective make for an underwhelming narrative experienced, especially when paired with 40 hours of gameplay. Early on, Max encounters a mechanic named Chumbucket who helps him rebuild his car and suggests the next wasteland leader to ask for assistance. Upon encountering each leader not much interaction occurs between them and Max. Their trust and tolerance is easily gained and there is very little narrative surrounding them. Each leader has a handful of side missions, referred to as wasteland missions in the game, but these amount to petty errands rather than building a plot around each character. The NPCs stand around like props exuding zero personality and failing to reflect the kind of society that each wasteland leader has built. In this sense, Mad Max takes the scenic route to its conclusion, introducing you to various people of interest but doing little to make your encounters with them seem essential to your fight against Scrotus. Amidst the endless diversions in each of the game’s regions, you soon forget why you are there and what your objective is. Aside from Chum’s crazed banter, there is little reason to pay attention.  Upon receiving your bare bones vehicle and enlisting Chum’s assistance, Max’s journey begins proper and a routine is quickly established where players enter a territory, meet its leader, destroy Scrotus’ infrastructure in the area, obtain a vehicle upgrade that permits passage to a new territory and repeat. Mad Max relies on a series of mechanics familiar to those who have played open world games over the past five years. There are enemy strongholds to topple, weather balloons to utilize for reconnaissance and fast travel, loot caches to pillage for upgrade currency, races to partake in and convoys to smash. In addition to these activities there are special parts to be on the lookout for that allow max to upgrade the stronghold of each wasteland leader he encounters. Constructing these upgrades allow Max to replenish his supplies which would otherwise have to be scavenged. The problem is each stronghold requires the same upgrades and by the midway point, hunting down components for each stronghold feels like a chore. Likewise, once the allure of taking out the strongholds that dot each of the game’s regions grows tiresome after the novelty of their sometimes intricate designs ware off. These strongholds are in particular a point of frustration since in many ways they are some of the game’s most interesting set pieces but by being populated with the same handful of gimmicks and gameplay choices they grow dull long before the credits roll. Some of these strongholds are also home to bosses, none of which come close to living up to the eccentric antagonists of the films such as Toecutter, Humongus or Imortan Joe. Instead, expect to fight muscular men in gimp masks wielding polearms ad nauseam. Further hampering the game’s mechanics is the mind numbingly dull combat lifted from the Arkham series which relies on counters and timed button presses. If you have better dexterity than a three toed sloth with rheumatoid arthritis, expect to yawn your way through the game’s uninspired enemies with barely a scratch. The combat system tries to spice things up with new abilities that Max can learn, melee weapons that break after a short period of time and finishing moves executed with shivs but due to the ubiquity of its design, combat simply doesn’t stand out. While it may seem that Mad Max is another throw away game based on a licensed property it does manage to redeem itself with engaging vehicular gameplay. Your car, The Magnum Opus, starts as nothing more than an engine on a chassis, but as you explore the wasteland you can locate new car bodies, and lower Scrotus’ influence over each region to unlock more upgrades. At first, taking control of your car is an irritation; it’s slow, handles poorly and tends to spin out easily but after a few upgrades the Magnum Opus becomes a speedy death machine allowing you to terrorize your foes. What’s more interesting is that the upgrades in each category can have a negative impact on other performance categories so having the heaviest bumper may allow you to deal major damage but it’s weight also makes the car slower. You can shove a massive engine in your ride but it’s going to negatively impact the vehicle’s handling. This makes it worthwhile to have all of the upgrades and swap between them when the situation calls for it. The visual and performance enhancing upgrades prove to be the perfect carrot on the stick to motivate players to complete some of the game’s more tedious activities. You can also unlock additional vehicles by driving captured enemy cars back to friendly strongholds or by winning races.  Ultimately, Mad Max’s gameplay falls short by not featuring any gameplay mechanics that give the game a unique identity. Most of the gameplay elements featured in Mad Max can be traced back to half a dozen other games that share the same mechanics—two of which are also published by Warner Brothers. It’s easy to run headlong into a convoy of eight cars, turn them into a scrap heap in less than a minute and reflect back on both Just Cause 2 and Fury Road… Where are the massive war rigs? Why can’t you hop aboard other cars? Shouldn’t taking out a convoy be something more than blowing up a few cars? Your interest in playing mad max will likely only last as long as your enthusiasm for driving around the wasteland in a four wheel drive rat rod leaving a trail of destruction. Mad Max is a case of competency over excellence and it doesn’t help that the open world action adventure game has usurped the third person cover based shooter as the go to game design template. This isn’t the sleeper hit it could have been but it isn’t exactly a game to ignore if you are a fan of Mad Max or open world action games.

												I really think this game is underrated, people have no idea what they are missing.Mad Max is an open world game set in the wasteland, with only 3 companions; Chumbucket, the dog, and your beloved car, which is the main reason you're on a mission to get back what is yours, in a tale of vengeance and change.Now, people might think that a game that bases itself on driving a car in the desert is not fun, but they're so, so wrong. There are quite a few events, missions, and NPCs that you will never get bored. Let's start, shall we?The graphics, probably the best part of the game. You remember Shadow of Mordor, and how astounding the camera mode and the graphics were? Well, this is basically the same, incredibly good graphics, blood that flies, details in every face that will make your jaw be dropped, a desert that looks real, in which every step and wheel changes the terrain, and the best part of the game, the sandstorms. Holy.♥♥♥♥♥♥ they feel so real, so good, and so crazy that you will not want it to end for a while! Graphics are excellent, specially the lightning.Sounds are great, gunshots, hits with a weapon or your bare fists, people falling from a few feet, your car rumbling, it's all remarkably good.Story is... Wow. You'll keep thinking about certain parts of the game after finishing it, the least thing I want to do is spoil, let's just say that there's quite a few unexpected events that will change how you view things, and probably change your morality, too, try to think maturely.And gameplay. Mechanics are excellent, the cars feels real, don't expect a Need for Speed in which the car turns the instant you move the joystick or click a key, it needs time to rotate the wheel, it's realistic, and you'll need more than one stupid hit to destroy another car. Customization of your car is quite good, and unlocking items by completing certain stuff is not a bad system to keep you interested.The main missions are excellent, you will have fun in every single mission they throw at you, but... Secondary missions (Basically icons in the world map which you have to reach and then complete an objective, clear a camp, destroy a Pole with your car, etc)... There are way too many secondary missions, way, way too many, if you're a completionist you'll probably get sick of them, they're repetitive and don't add much to the game, they're good for the first few hours, but then the reality drops like a sack of potatoes, it has no end, it's too much time wasted. I decided to complete 15 side missions before each main mission, and I got sick of them by the end-game, decided to simply ignore them. The shotgun is great to use, though the chances of getting bullets are so low that you'll probably just shoot it around 25 times at best by the end, greatly unused.And well, that's about it, the game is really fun, and it will keep you entertained for more than a dozen hours, everything is great if you're not a completionist, and I'd give it an 8 out of 10. Excellent.

												Everyone knows those two same formulas:A good movie will usually translate into a bad or mediocre game OR a good game will translate into a bad or mediocre movie.Luckly, this is an exception to both rules.While the game is repetitive, since basically you drive from A to B and smash people in the face and blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up while on the road, the game is rather fun. The game isn't plagued by performance issues at least on my PC, even though I don't fully meet the recommended requirements but still am running it on high settings WITH a godly performance. The devs sure did their homework with optimizing.The gameplay is repetitive. If you played Far Cry 2 then you'll know what I mean when I say you'll need to drive EVERYWHERE. Luckly there are plenty of fast travel locations that can be quite easily unlocked. The combat in this game is repetitive, be it on foot or the vehicular combat. On foot it's very reminiscent of the batman games, you dodge, parry and beat the crap out of every single soul that crosses your path. But it is pretty fluid.On the road, the combat is pretty interesting. The cars handle about as well as you'd expect them to handle on sand and rock, that is to say, not so very well, but upgrading your tires helps! Basically, you get as much speed a possible to crash into the other guy and blow him up, before he does the same to you. Your car also has some interesting gimmicks such as side burners so you can get up close to the other cars and melt them, a post-apocalyptic harpoon launcher, that can also launch harpoons with the added "oomph" of exploding tips, a sniper rifle for taking out snipers or vehicles at long range, as well as lots of other sharp and pointy things to grind other cars to scrap, or keep people from boarding your car and beating the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you. You can also, of course, trust your shotgun to shoot the other drivers in their face, shoot their tires out, or even blow up their gas tanks, and if needed, defend against people boarding your car.Basically you'll travel the wasteland looking for scrap so you can upgrade your car and your gear, water so you can keep yourself healthy and eventually give it to thirsty wanderers, and fuel to keep your car running. While scrounging up these things you will come across some interesting objects that say something about the old world as it began to descend into madness, usually upon inspecting these, the protagonist will deliver a one liner with his views about things. Altough the gameplay is repetitive, the map is HUGE. I'm 10 hours in and I haven't advanced much into the history, as I'm focused on clearing all the tidbits on Jeet's territories. That is to say, clearing out camps, sniper towers, minefields and their "scarecrows". If you are one of those hardcore 100% completiniosts, this game will probably drain you quite a few hours of your life. All in all, this is a very good game and an interesting singleplayer experience. The graphics are good, the game runs great and the post-apocalyptic vehicular carnage is about as blood as you'd expect it to be, with people getting impaled on your car as they try to board it, cars losing a tire because of a very hard crash, and running down other wastelanders as you drive somewhere to scavenge, all followed by the classic meal of maggots or can of dog food, because that's what's for dinner in the apocalypse.

												It is quite ironic that the critics find the game mediocre while the game gets an overwhelming positive feedback from the gaming community. If there is one thing that I could say about the game is that it is really pretty. From the setting sun, to the raging sandstorm, to the colorful explosions, the visuals of the game is really well done. You might be expecting that everything is a bland hue of brown and you are mostly correct but they did splash some color in the game and I mean bright colors too. Blues, oranges, violets, are all there. Nothing is quite a giggling inducing as beating the crap out of a bright blue wasteland baddie. The voice acting in the game is good. They actually got an authentic Australian to voice Max and not the movie type Australian like you're listening to Steve Erwin, you got a proper Australian accent going on. The game has a huge map and there are tons to do. Destroying camps, scavening scraps, pulling down scarecrows, and more. There is the feeling of being a janitor as you sweep all the icons off the map. It can be tedious if you have been at it for a couple of hours. Vehicular combat is were the game shines. It is violent, primal, and full of excitement. Your car is a veritable moving arsenal. The Magnum Opus (your car) is highly customizable. If you want a rolling fortress or a speeding bullet, you can configure it to your heart's content. The game uses the same system as Batman and Shadow of Mordor. You can counter attacks with button prompts and mash the attack button to wade in a fight. If you are used to Avalanche's fighting system, you'll be right at home here. If you are looking for something else, you'll be disappointed. It's good but nothing innovative. There were some (a lot) of people that were concerned about how well the game is optimized for PC users. Well, I'm glad to say that the game works wonderfully. Being that the game was developed in house rather than outsourcing the porting to another company ensured that the game is properly optimized though I feel that I should not have to talk about that because since when does proper optimization have to be a positive of a game? This should be the norm not an exemption. With Metal Gear being released on the same day, is Mad Max worth it? I would say yes. I bought it for $30 USD so I think I'm getting my value's worth. If you are a fan of the Mad Max universe then I say play the game. If you are new to the Australian wasteland, give it a try.

												I usually avoid AAA games like the plague. They often feel sterile, clunky, and have too much emphasis and effort (read: money which translates into final asking price) put into the high-end graphics.While Mad Max has its fair-share of some of these traits, its darn good and quite addicting. It is a pleasant surprise, honestly. I find myself returning to it again and again.Essentially, this is a sandbox game where you collect-and-conquer to have bigger and better stats. The upgraded stats are mainly focused on your car and your avatar. The game plays and feels like a movie - and is fairly well done in that regard. You have a companion through most of the game which reduces how lonely the world could feel. It works quite well. There is a lot to do and a lot to look at - and oh boy is it beautiful. It runs so butter, too.Pros:+Amazing atmosphere and graphics - and it runs so great. Not a hickup in performance to be found.+Very addicting, especially in shorter play sessions. Collecting scrap and gaining upgrades that really make you more powerful is so awesome. I even recently built something that collects scrap when I'm not playing. Its going AdVenture Capitalist on me, and I'm loving it.+The storyline and characters are all well done. The voice acting is top-notch, and they all fit in the atmosphere. +The companion makes the game feel much more real and alive.+Lots of random events and gangs are roaming the world, which make it further believable.+The sandbox is huge. Over 10 hours in and I haven't even visited 60% of the map.+Tons of vehicles and they all feel different.+Metric tons of unlockables.+The difficulty level is fairly easy - which, at least for me, is a breath of fresh air from tough-as-nails indie games that I usually deal with.Meh:=Some people report camera problems when fighting - I didn't find this to be the case. I did find the camera is as equally annoying as it is in any 3D AAA game.Cons:-Like many AAA games, the core mechanic is very simple. For the most part you only need like two buttons lol. Press 'A' to do most things. This is partly why most find this game best played in short play sessions.-Missions can get repetitive, which again, is why this game is best played in short play sessions. Its fine, and definately adds near infinite replayability (new missions spawn constantly), but they can start to feel meaningless over larger time.Overall, this is a great game, that is likely worth the high price tag. You can often get it on discount, which is great. There are a lot of hours to get out of this, particularly if you like large open-world sandbox games where you grind and upgrade.

So yes, I do recommend this game, specially if on sale.

												In many ways 2015 was the year of Mad Max. We got the excellent film Mad Max Fury Road earlier in the year closer to May, and in September we recieved Mad Max 2015 by Avalanche studios. The devs behind the Just Cause series. When I first heard about this game I hated the idea of it. I didn't really think in the era of Fallout that we really needed another derivative post apocalyptic open world game. When I heard Mel Gibson wasn't involved at all that really made me less interested in it. Then after Fury Road I relaxed to the idea of more Mad Max. And I was surprised by how much I liked this game and what it set out to accomplish. In many ways the Mad Max Film series is almost the perfect concept for an open world driving game. You have a post apocalyptic sandbox filled with hostile enemy raiders. You have a core driving experience with car combat and upgrade trees to customize your hot rod. What I was surprised by the most with this game in particular was how much detail was paid attention to. There are numerous little callbacks to the previous films, and the stylistic decisions they made with the game were spot on.The wasteland of Mad Max was perfectly nailed. Unlike the Fallout games, the world feels very handcrafted. Nothing feels copy-pasted and throwaway locations like enemy outposts all look scenic enough to take a dozen screenshots of. The game also boasts an impressive draw distance and it runs extremely well on PC. The gameplay is solid enough. With car combat being a highlight in the game. There's a very noticeable focus on scavanging. Your car requires gasoline to keep going, you require water inorder to heal yourself. You only ever find individual shells for your gun and can only carry a handful at one time. I really do feel more like a vulture picking at a corpse of a dead world than a super soldier like in most modern sandbox games. But with all that said, the game isn't for everyone. I feel alone when I say this but the things people dislike about this game, like the heavy focus on sidequests, the general minimalistic storyline and lack of gunplay are things that appealed to me about it. I actually think the laundry list Assassin's Creed formula benefits this game greatly. Your grand objective in this game isn't a pointless revenge story or a pointless revolutionary story. You spend the vast majority of this game looking for ways to upgrade your car. I like how the game focuses on that rather than a more generic storyline and mission structure.As I said the game isn't for everyone. If you're not a fan of the Mad Max films and you get turned off by a heavy focus on sidequests with a game I'd suggest looking elsewhere. I'd wager less than 10% of Mad Max is actual story content and if that sounds like a bad thing, you will probably find a lot of this game very tedious.

Posted: September 6, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Mad Max [Game Review] 

			Views: 345		

			My review of "Mad Max", the new movie-licensed open-world action game developed by Avalanche Studios and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.		

Game: Mad MaxGenre: Third-person Open WorldDeveloper: Avalanche StudiosPublisher: Warner Bros. Interactive EntertainmentCopy supplied by SteamMad Max is the new movie-licensed open-world action game developed by Avalanche Studios and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.STORYIf you are a fan of the movies, the story will be right up your alley. Mad Max is driving around the wasteland, and one day he his hunted down by the evil Scrotum and his minions and his car his taken. After that he finds Chumbucket, an hunchback that sees him as the saviour who is destined to drive the Magnum Opus against the evil Scrotum. From that point, Max's begins a journey in which he helps different settlements to fight back and get revenge against Scrotum.The story isn't all that complex, and the characters are mostly one dimensional, however they are all peculiar and wacky, with Chumbucket being one of the best video game sidekicks out there, always giving you advice on what to do.Similarly to the movies, most of the Wasteland's backstory is told visually: you will see collapsed bridges, dry docks, buried cities. If you are looking for something more complex, you won't find it here.GRAPHICSFor almost every PC users, this game performs extremly well: Avalanche optimised the engine to make it work at rock solid 60fps, also thanks to the presence of the wasteland. If you are playing the game at the highest or lowest settings, the environment is beautiful. Every enemy camp you explore feels unique, every faction has different vehicles and enemies and there are enough landmarks to make you understand where you are going without always checking the mini-map.The particle effects are also amazing: the explosions are pure poetry, and the sandstorms manage to make your jaw drop the first time you encounter them. Hardly have I ever played a game about a post-apocalyptic future that looks so good.GAMEPLAYThere are two types of combat: hand-to-hand and vehicular.Hand-to-hand combat is pretty similar to the Arkham games, however it feels different: while Batman is more agile and can parry almost every attack, Max is heavier and stronger. While doing an heavy attack, you can't parry whose attacking you. You can also pick up enemy weapons, or use your shotgun for one-hit kills.Vehicular combat is where the gameplay shines the most: since the game is set in a wasteland, you will hardly ever crush into a rock or a wall. You can use a grappling hook to pull parts of the car, from the wheels to the driver himself, as well as revealing the gas tank to blow it up with a well-aimed shot. Whenever you aim, the game enters slow-motion, making things easier and less frustrating.The more you play, the more you can customize Max and the Mangum Ops: from new jackets, hairstyles, ammo belts and moves for the former, to new weapons, engines and armor for the latter. If you enjoy customization, there is a lot of it here. You can also use enemy cars to infiltrate camps without alerting anyone, adding a bit of strategy to the game.However, the open world missions can become repetitive pretty fast: you can destroy scarecrows, capture camps, explore locations for scrap, use air baloons to scout the areas and destory enemy convoys. Sometimes you will have the task to go somewhere and free some prisoners, but other than that there isn't much variety. However, the combat always keeps things interesting, especially when fighting bosses or destorying convoys.CHALLENGEThe game isn't particularly challenging: the camps feature many checkpoints and water stashes to recover health, and the car fights can be won by just pulling the driver out of the vehicle. Still, some missions are harder than others, and the bosses that you fight require more thinking than button mashing, so it all balances out.SOUNDYes, Mad Max is voiced by an Australian. And he acts very well. All the other characters are very cartoony, just like in the movies, and Chumbucket's voice actor does a great job at being funny and never annoying. However, the soundtrack is pretty mediocre, especially compared to the one in this year's Fury Road. But the sound effects make up for it: every punch you throw, every explosion you witness pack enough punch to satisfy the violent spirit inside every one of us.REPLAYABILITYAs with most open world games, you get quite a lot of content here: between completing all the missions and destorying the enemy outposts, there are many objectives that will keep you entertained for most of the game. You can also try your luck by exploring the Great Nothing, a infinitely big desert with ton of scrap to take.Overall, fans of the movie franchise and open world games will spend a lot of time playing this game thanks to its solid combat, beautiful wasteland and great performance. If you are on the fence, I recommend waiting for a sale.Story: 7.5Graphics: 9Gameplay: 8.5Challenge: 7.5Sound: 7.5Replayability: 8.5ENJOYMENT: 8.5FRUSTRATION: 5Follow me on Twitter: @nickygra97Subscribe to my channelLike on Facebook{LINK REMOVED}Check my official websiteJoin my Steam group

												An open-world adventure game, full of salt, gasoline, blood, crushed metals and souls. Bitterness prevails above all of it. Still, this one is the helluva fun ride, all the way down the road.You can finish it in 10-20 hours, going straight through quests, but that would be a waste of time, from my point of view.Like I said, the game has bitter taste, and the story line will not give you satisfaction after final screen. So I beg you: play it like open-world adventure. Don't mind major quests, until you really have to. Just get yourself a decent car, and go for exploring this land. Eroded, crumbled to dust, but still striving for survival.Some time ago, I was really fond to Far Cry 2, which was baptized as horrid and bleak by the majority of players. But I found in Far Cry 2 one thing, for it can be loved: the driving part. Here in Mad Max, the same feeling of driving through wasteland, where there are no actual roads, only directions, and it goes 10 times better than in Far Cry 2!Let's settle pro and contra:+ Graphics and optimization are very good parts. All is smooth and fine with that.+ Driving is the selling point. It is one of a kind experience, I suggest everyone to get at least some of it.+ Fighting part is very similar to Batman's games, or Sleeping Dogs - strike and strong strike, parry&reposte, combo... It goes fine, for the most time. Although some moves Max showing are certainly not fit the realistic setting the game's narrative assuming. But the same can be said about the whole game: the realism is here, but steps away to make some emotions brighter. Still, after about 200-300 broken jaws, it is finally not that fun, as with Bats or Wei Shen... The Shadow of Mordor gives much more contentment, than Mad Max, at this point.+ The gameplay main features certainly looks familiar. Fighting from Batman, scrap collecting and gear tuning from Tomb Raider... you can proceed with the list, but here's the main thing: it was blended alright. Unlike Watch Dogs, Mad Max gameplay is not seems like Frankenstein style. All things there at right places, so the final expression the game gives is pure. You're getting a fresh new game out of long-known features. A good deal.- The only strong point I have against this game is amusingly overall accolade to Death. All those skulls, achievement for eating maggots nesting in the rotting corpses... All that gore is an over-act, an over-kill and exaggeration of the Apocalypse theme. I felt disgust sometimes during playtime. So I'm certainly not recommending Mad Max to kids or to sensitive persons.- The game is open-world, but it contains almost none of any sandbox experience. After you clear the given territory from the enemy presence, there are absolutely nothing to do. So you can't play this game by hundreds of hours, like Skyrim. Unless you really like driving in wastelands over all other gaming experience, of course.In sum: Mad Max is pure and solid action game. Very brutal, and quite entertaining for some time. You ride a death car, right in the middle with the real world and hell. And while your good deeds somehow fixing something around you, your hero goes deeper and deeper on the dark side. Very nice and very grim adventure in the post-apocalypse crack of world we used to know. Give it a go, but leave any hopes before entering.I mark it as 7.9/10. I like it very much, but it hurts something inside me. Let's just pray we'll never see this dream come true.

												Mad Max is a post-apocalyptic, third person action-adventure set in australia.As in the movies with the same title, you are playing Max Rockatansky, a man who lost his family, roaming around the desert wastelands of australia, trying to find the "plains of silence".As you start the game, your car is stolen by a horde of outlaws, led by Scabrous Scrotus. You are left behind, half dead with nothing but your will of survival and your wish for revenge and the need to get your car, especially your V8 motor, back.The world is divided into several territories, each with a dedicated person which owns it throughout their outpost. In the beginning, the presence of Scabrous Scrotus lackeys is very high and you can do several things to reduce their threat by demolition scarecrows, killing snipers which are guarding the territories, destroying car convoys and destroying or freeing strongholds of enemies.Your car is your best buddy here and feels like your own fortress which, after some time and upgrades, it actually becomes.Better motorisation, better wheels, improved armor etc. Each of these does aso have an impact on your speed and handling. The better your protection, the slower you are and the harder your car is to handle.When on foot, it plays basically like every other third person brawler. Your fists are your weapon, punching your way through the enemies in combos, finishers and, if you need something stronger, your shotgun.You can also upgrade your character, skill wise (getting more loot, better health etc.) and also item wise (a better jacket with more protection, an upgrade for your shotgun etc.).Visuals are pretty amazing (watch my screenshot, watch my screenshots! :D ), the lighting is pretty good, animations are fine, details are good, the textures could sometimes be better but the details and the particle effects, especially the explosions, are superb.Overall the game is oozing post-apocalypse out of every pore. You can nearly taste and feel the dust and the dirt, the desolation and despair in this world is felt in every corner, survival of the fittest is the motto.The story itself is pretty much already told, Max is fighting his way through the wastelands, to get back his car/V8 Motor and is aided by Chumbucket, an Outcast, who will built you gladly his "Magnum Opus", a new car which will be better than everything else. He also thinks you are some godly/angelic entity from his dreams..or something. He is weird but fun and will sit on the back of your car, providing you with repair skills and he will also shoot explosives at other cars or use the harpoon to tear down structures in your way.I had a lot of fun with the game and would blindly recommend it to anyone who is interested in the setting or a good third person action game with a lot of driving.But it also has it's downsides, sidemission etc. do get repetitive and the wastelands aren't filled with anything else than the same objectives over and over again, but if you can live with that, i think you will have a blast with the game :)

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												TL;DR - Entertaining enough but doesn't justify its price tag.  Pick it up for $19.99 or less.Mad Max is a game attempt by Avalanche to leverage the legendary narrative from Kennedy-Miller with the aim of creating an action-packed open-world style game with vehicular combat and Arkham-style fisticuffs.While the game is entertaining enough - at least for a while - it gradually becomes apparent that Avalanche really don't grasp the reasons behind the design choices of other games and the importance of building complete systems rather than facades. And this is the essential problem.  Most of the wasteland's life is a simulacrum of reality where the seams are very much showing.  Now some might not regard this as problematic, however I'd argue they're missing the point.Take, for example, the convoy system.  Now taking down convoys is one of the more thrilling aspects of the game and many consider this a high point.  However standing back and taking a look at it reveals the completely shallow nature of this experience.  The convoys - the narrative tells us over and over again - are an essential component of the primary antagonist's war machine.  They take crude oil to Gastown and return with fuel for the outposts.The only problem with this is that every single convoy travels in a giant circle making no stops along the way.  The gameplay experience directly contradicts the narrative.  And worse still, the player's reward for taking out a convoy is a shiny hood ornament (which buffs the player's car in an indeterminate fashion) and the reduction of "threat" - a completely nebulous concept which supposedly determines the probability of your wasteland travels being disturbed by howling madmen screaming for your blood.  (Basically your convoy efforts affect a multiplier for Avalanche's random number generator.)This - and this is my primary impression of many aspects of this game - is a lost opportunity.  Gameplay is about choices and in particular, it's about allowing the player to make smart, innovative and creative choices.The convoy system COULD have been a network of convoys with real impacts upon the other systems of the game.  Convoy routes could be determined through observation and/or intelligence-gathering.  With that, the player would also need an understanding of the risks and rewards of attacking a given convoy.  Convoy A might impact fuel availability for roving war patrols in a specific area - thus reducing their ability to chase you - whereas convoy B might starve a fortress of the fuel necessary for defenses.All of a sudden, you elevate the convoy system from being a purely repetitive experience to one with strategic implications.  You enable the player to plan at a higher level and - more importantly - you make the convoy experience start to matter more in the strategic and narrative context of the game.The base system suffers from similar facile gameplay systems.  Perimeter base defenses consist of snipers, a wall of fire, thunderstick launchers and molotov launchers.  Each of these has problems.  A) Snipers DO NOT EXIST until you get within a specific range at which point they pop into being and conveniently shine a blue light allowing you to pinpoint them with minimal effort.  The color of the light changes depending on how close they are to firing upon you.  Now while sniping is a fun activity, this particular system requires minimal skill.  In the entire game, not once did a sniper ever come close to killing me.  I got hit about 5 times.  B) The wall of fire requires you to hunt for the attached tank and destroy it.  Not very challengine and adds little to the experience.  C) Molotov launchers can be taken out with sniper fire.  Thunderstick launchers cannot.  All of these elements detect the player whenever he moves within a specific radius.  Irrespective of line of sight.  Thus, while bases often have secret entrances, these entrances often require you to disable the perimeter defenses anyway and all you end up doing is bypassing the main gate.  (There are exceptions but these are few and far between).  Once inside, the player has no option for stealth and pretty much has to plow through the place with his fists while simultaneously searching for completely optional and zero-impact-upon-the-world collectibles.  (One of which is scrap, one is historical oddities and the other is antagonist insignia).  Sure, Max can always use more scrap - it IS the currency of the world, after all - but is he really going to care about insignia or postcards?  Those last two are pointless busy work - and I became thoroughly sick of it.  Essentially, the promise of an open-world environment is undermined by incredibly linear - not to mention repetitious - design.  And while I do have to give the level designers props for inventive use of 3D space - the levels are fairly well constructed - and kudos to whomever came up with the idea for the War Crier, the base clearing mechanic itself is a simplistic version of what it could have been.  The system for building projects inside strongholds initially seems cool - until you realise it's just a bunch of fetch quests which you repeat four times (once for each stronghold).  The idea is good but, once again, the implementation is facile and the repetition is lazy and unforgivable.  The minefields - oh dear God, the minefields.  This is absolutely the worst part of the game.  Not only must you hope to stumble across these (literally, there's no other way of finding them), but then you have to ditch your car for a buggy with zero offensive capability in order to defuse the mines.  Apparently the mine-detecting dog you've stumbled across is unable to detect mines unless he's in a buggy.  Or something.  The rationale for this was never made clear, but it - like all aspects of the minefield clearing - was intolerably stupid and inconceivably boring.  The scarecrows are more threat-reduction devices, present no challenge and require nothing more from the player than the ability to aim a harpoon in slow motion or crash effectively.  The balloons are good enough, but far too slow and the vague attempts to inject puzzle mechanics (by requiring the player to find fuel or navigate his way to a particular point) are trite and uninspired.  The wasteland encounters were largely a waste.  The intel encounters at least brought a little more depth to the base destruction system, but not much.  The others were optional and merely required the player to show up and say hello.  Boring, repetitious and unnecessary.  The long-term encounters (buzzard hole destruction, jumps, catapult destruction and gas valves) were standard open world fare but with a worthless payoff.  Ways to waste the player's time but with zero narrative payoff and an almost insulting player reward.  The voice-acting runs the gamut from good (Griffa and the stronghold leaders) to mediocre (Max himself) to the downright awful (every other Australian in the game).  In particular the female Australian voice-artist is dire.  She's not helped by the god-awful scripts she's been given, but she has no talent for voice-acting whatsoever and I cringed every time I heard her.  (I'm Australian, so more than familiar with our accent).  Summed up, Mad Max is a game of disparate experiences with elements of fun, but which fails to come together into a coherent and enjoyable whole.  It is primarily a catalogue of lost opportunities with the main issue being a lack of depth.  It's this lack of depth which undermines the open world experience.   Game played to completion, threat reduced to 0 in all areas.   Recommended buy for less than $20.  Ripper DLC has no impact on the game.  Score: 6/10.

												First off I would like to say that I am a huge fan of the Mad Max franchise, and when I first heard of this game I was thrilled. I expected a lot from the game after watching it's trailers, and I was not disappointed. Pros: Absolutely amazing vehicular combat, completely surpassing my expectations! Really fun ground combat! As a lot of you probably know the combat is very similar to the Arkham series of games, and that's definitely not a bad thing. You feel like the badass wanderer that Max has always been.Nice graphics! On max graphics the game looks beautiful, though my computer can't run it at max quality without a significant drop in framerate.Good voice actors! While some of the characters feel pretty lackluster, the majority of the characters are really brought to life by the actors.Powerful Story! I know some people might disagree with me here, as this game definitely isn't "The Last of Us". However, the game does a fantastic job of capturing the old story of Max regaining his humanity in the wasteland. Big (and beautiful) World! The world is big with plenty to explore, as well as tons of enemies to take down.Cons:The game can become somewhat repetitive as you grind away at clearing minefields or carrying gas can around trying to blow up every last transfer tank. However the game keeps things interesting with plenty of combat during these events so this isn't that large of a complaint. Overview:Really this is just a great game, and I highly recommend buying it whether you're a fan of the series or are just looking for a good open-world game.

Teal DeerDevelopers: Avalanche Studios Publishers: Warner Bros Entertainment. Initial release: Sept 2015Genre: Action, Open-world, Post-Apocalyptic #Worth/NotWorth: #AlotofContentButTediousExposition, Concurrence and Summationffs Valve give me a sideways thumb optionMad Max is an open world very run of the mill game. It has all the things you've come to expect from open world madness. Think Far Cry but a brawler. Camps and oil bases take the place of outposts. The basic gameplay loop is that of drive to location, take down camp usually by blowing something up. Or some other overdone task. Grappling hook the tower down, destroy the convoy leader etc etc. Now, the game is VERY tedious. Most things that need to be blown up to complete the objective, at least early on, you will find yourself spending a lot of time looking for gas tanks or some way to cause an explosion. And that is not fun. However I will say there is something very survivalist about it. The subtle animation of placing an extra gas tank on the back of your vehicle grounds the world in some weird way. Whether you intend on using it to refill your tank or for something more dramatic.The very tired Batman/Shadow of Mordor combat is here but is feels a little unresponsive. Even after upgrading my counters I felt the game was purposefully making me miss or not allowing me to dodge the non counter-able attacks. It became much more of a chore than it was enjoyable or what I would deem a fair or fun challenge.The one thing I will say is the driving and physicality of everything from beating thugs against a wall and pulling down towers or boosting into other vehicles feels incredibly visceral. The camera shakes are nicely done. The camera lens cracks and everything has this very realistic and heavy feel to it.   THE GISTIt has all the bells and whistles of your average triple A game. Things are being collected, things are being upgraded and all the numbers are going up. Bases are gaining more and more functionality such as replenishing water, ammo and gasoline. It's just all very repeatable and it goes on and on. The story is very weird and not that interesting. It's kind of creepy to be honest. I spent most of the time playing this with a podcast or video going on the other monitor. Additionally the game runs really great. It's very well optimized.But the game is very lackluster as a gripping adventure. It's basically some relatively fun busy work and that's not a bad thing. I just would have a hard time recommending this before almost any other open world game. By itself, its fine.Follow my curation for more

												Mad Max is an open world, third person action game.The player steps in the role of Max and has to progress through the wasteland to seek revenge on a gang of raiders, led by Scrotus, who robbed him of his possessions. Max gets help from Chumbucket, a blackfinger (a mechanic) and together they aim to build the ultimate battle car: the Magnum Opus.While not doing the main quests you can explore areas on foot, discovering collectibles and scrap metal. You will need alot of the scrap to pay for upgrades which are more or less necessary over time.Also you can clear areas from Scrotus influence by destroying Scarecrows, disarming minefields and by taking over enemy camps. Unfortunately, you have to repeat those things over and over again if you want to clear all areas.It takes approximately something between 30 and 40 hours to finish the main story, for finishing all which has the game to offer it takes something around up to 60 hours.If you are an achievement hunter, and want to achieve 100% it will become pretty repetitive during the grinding process you have to go through.Overall, Mad Max is a good game besides of the repetitive aspect, also it is not necessary to know the movies before playing this game.Sounds 9/10Graphics 8/10Gameplay 7/10Atmosphere 8/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

												Mad Max:~~~~~~~~  In a post-apocalyptic world when sand dunes have replaced pretty much everything, this world is brutal and vast! Only a skilled and fearless warrior with a knack for driving can survive this ordeal. His name is Max, Mad Max!You will be playing Mad Max (no kidding), a tough guy on a mission to rebuild a new and slightly modified motor vehicle called the “Magnum Opus!” You will be assisted by "Chumbucket", a brilliant but strange mechanic who wears an unusual jewellery piece, a spark plug necklace!This game really reminds me of a mixture of a few games:  Shadow of Mordor for how the map is laid out, and instead of climbing towers to view an area, you take a trip on a small hot air balloon to pin point locations on the map; and the Batman series for the combat system. Great story line with well-designed missions but if you are like me you will go through the entire area to pick up collectibles, scrap metal and project parts, or you could even go racing - MARVELLOUS!!Make sure to collect all the scraps you can find so you will be able to add on features to your “Magnum Opus” but also equip your favourite warrior with well needed upgrades. Upon achieving missions and challenges, you will be rewarded with tokens which you can use by having a friendly one-on-one chat with Griffa. He will use his magic to put you to sleep and then you will be able to increase Mad Max abilities.In some locations, you will find project parts. These parts can be used to upgrade strongholds so when you stop there, it will regenerate your health, fuel and ammunitions.Let’s be  honest, Mad Max is absolutely magic in regards to graphics and the game runs beautifully well. 												I like Mad Max. About 12 hours in I got a solid feel of the overall game. The important thing to know about Mad Max is that it's fun. And that's the whole point. It is far from perfect, lacks in many departements but it also has a lot of positives which make it a good enjoyable game.The over the top action makes you want to play a little bit more all the time. Completists will have their hands full.The game focuses a lot on driving and does it well, there are so many upgrades for your vehicles, and so many of them.The on-foot action is also good, fighting is a little simple (like batman) but its fun nevertheless. I do wish there was more weapons and customizations for them. It is very thin in that department, and you barely find any ammo in the game so you practically never use your shotgun. The acting is good but the story is week. You don't feel like you're switching gears between the main story and side missions, they both feel the same, so you don't get that change of pace that breaks the monotony of tasks.The game feels a little sand boxy but that doesn't take away form the fun of playing it.The worst issue of the game is the character animation and movement. It's horribly done. The jumping in particular is the worst I've seen in any game the last 10 years, super clumsy. And the falling animation feels like you're a floating leaf. They really needed to work on that departement to make max feel heavier, with the ability to jump and grab etc. All of which aren't there and hurt the gameplay.The Positives:-Great Atmosphere overall. Enviroments are spot on and so is music.-Fun gameplay, fighting, driving and effects are satisfying.-Tons of upgrades and mods.-Lots of things to do.-Pretty good acting.The Negatives:-Weekish Story. Even main mission feels like a side mission.-A Little repetitive at times.-Abysmal character movement for a current gen game. Jumping in particular is terrible.Still, you will get a good 60-70hr atmospheric fun and thrilling gameplay out of this game. I'm enjoying it to the Max :)

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Mad Max is a third-person action game made by Avalanche Studios and published by Warner Bros. Although WB are getting a lot of hate for abandoning Batman: Arkham Knight and Mortal Kombat X on PC, this game is not the case! Avalanche Studios optimalised the game for PC perfectly! What surprises you for the first time immediately, is the game world. It's not as big as in Just Cause games, but that doesn't matter, it's still huge. You'll be able to explore through the wastelands, see all 50 shades of sand, kill many mad warriors meanwhile and collect tons of scrap.Scrap is the resource (or the currency) that is used in Mad Max for everything - you upgrade your weapons, your car or even Max's clothes with scrap. And there's plenty of upgrades for everything, so if you don't plan to get 100% achievements, you won't even unlock every upgrade the game offers. But the scrap isn't the only thing you need for unlocking the upgrades, most of advanced ones also require completing a specific mission or a simple task, like: Lower the antagonist's (Scabrous Scrotus) influence in area by taking over his camps or destroying his scarecrows (pylons that should let people around know who rules in the wasteland).While you can have about 5 basic car constructions (upgradable in any way you want) there are many more vehicles in the game, and you can control all of those! You'll find use for them in racing (death runs) that offers few types of races.The combat is similar to Batman Arkham series, with many similar animations (punching, kicking and jumping groups of enemies) and practically same controls. You mash the left button for attack and when anyone in the enemy group attacks you, you have to parry the attack with right button. With exception for knife attacks and finishing moves, that's all. Anyway, it's not any significantly hard and it's fun.What's also a great pro of the game is the attention for details that aren't mentioned much when people talk around the game. There's a specific weather (random) event that'll make you impressed, but I don't want to spoil the details. Through the world you'll explore, you'll be finding photos of the old world (before the sandpocalypse), usually with something written on the back side. Those lead you (and the Max) to thinking about what in the game world is already lost.The story is not bad for a game based primarly around combat, racing and exploring, it even tries to play with your emotions. But it'll most probably fail, because Max is stonehearted, so you'll get over all bad events like it was nothing. There's few really interesting characters that have interesting backstory, but there's also characters that you meet without any proper explanation of sympathies.I think that every player will be really excited to explore everything in the beginning, every small camp with scrap. But that doesn't last forever and most players will later find the "breaking point" where they found exploring being too much repetitive, leading to sticking just with the main story missions (they'll require you to do some regular exploring few times anyway).The content recycling in the game (repeating enemies, camps etc.) is made delicately, with exception for one thing that ended up pretty bad - the bossfight(s). There are many bossfights in the game (especially for the side exploring - beating the Top Dogs) but they all are the same, the bosses even still use the same weapon! Only thing that changes is the arena where they fight and number of other NPCs that spawn around to help the boss.The world of Mad Max has a day/night cycle, which is great but feels half-baked with the fact that you can't rest until specific part of the day comes. As there are few missions that requires to do them at night, you might end up having to do something else for about 90 minutes, while waiting for night.In the end, I was really entertained for more than 20 hours thanks to Mad Max. As a current AAA game I got enough satisfaction out of it and even though I have not found motivation to complete everything that's not mandatory in the game, I still think it's a great game and definitely deserves my recommendation.

												By no means perfect, but a solid and entertaining game. 7 ~ 8 / 10 from me. Pros -1. Car combat is addictive and excellently implemented. A great many types of vehicles are in the game, and a great many tactical options to fight them. No other game has handled car-combat with such finesse.2. The game is a must buy for Mad Max fans. The atmostphere is very faithful to the movies.3. Customizing and upgrading your vehicle "Magnum Opus" is a lot of fun. There many options, most of them are meaningful and open up new ways to play.4. Production values are superb. Audio, visuals, the design and voice casting of enemies and in-game characters, all beautifully done, bring the wastelands to "life", as much as can be possible.5. Combat is reminiscent of Shadow of Mordor, with a bit of gun combat mixed in.6. The wastland is pretty massive. Quite a lot of things to do in the game - car combat, capturing strongholds, improving allied bases, boss fights, even car races. A lot more than many famous open-world games.Cons1. Some of the missions and tasks can be a bit of a chore (eg Mine clearing).2. Melee combat can become monotonous by the end, especially in contrast to vehicular combat. Car combat remains so much more entertaining that I sometimes avoid getting out of the car whenever possible.3. I wish there were more settlements and characters in the game (but given the wasteland setting, I doubt there is much the devs could have done).Overall. a definite buy at anything more than a 25% discount. One of the better movie adaptations ever produced.

												Mad Max is a game I'd highly recommend. It does so much more than most games and is obviously lovingly crafted. From a story perspective it's there and it's in perfect quantity. You can rush through the story if you want and have a nice compact experience, or you could play for 15 hours after you get done with the intro not touching the story at all and just focus on clearing camps, taking out snipers, taking down scarecrows, clearing minefields, searching for scrap, taking out a convoy, or upgrading a fortress to its completion before you decide to take on another mission. The ending while I can imagine it being divisive is my favorite since Red Dead Redemption. I won't spoil it for you but I will advise you giving it some time to sit with you and reflect on how fitting it is.Touching a bit more on those optional objectives. I've heard complaints about the grindy aspect of it, and I will admit that if you don't enjoy a grind it may be a bit tedious for you. I am the kind of gamer though that enjoys a nice solid grind with a reward at the end. When I completely lowered the threat down in someone's territory I felt accomplished, I had a much faster and more dangerous vehicle, and my Max had gotten much better as well.Visually the game is gorgeous. To me the beauty of the Mad Max movies (particularly The Road Warrior and Fury Road) is the contrast between the deep blue sky and the browns/oranges of the desert wasteland and this game pulls it off perfectly. The visuals are also somewhat varied with white sea beds, tan dunes, orange earthy deserts, black tarry oil pumps, and black/gray dumps. Color isn't muted either and when you see a brighter color from a flare or an enemy covered in paint it's a very pretty sight.The sound is very top notch. The bass of the shotgun or the roar of your engine (especially when you get a V8) is very deep and a pleasure to listen to. The higher sounds like the scraping of your vehicle against another or the screech of your tires also comes off as real and fantastic.Your gameplay is going to be split into driving and on foot brawling. The driving is a lot of fun and is quite the spectacle. Taking out a convoy is a blast as you grapple off tires, shoot explosive harpoons, or use your shotgun while driving to blow up an enemy's gas tank. Driving feels fast and fluid and is a lot of fun on its own, the combat is great and is the perfect icing on top. When you're on your feet brawling around a camp it's very gritty dirty and fun fighting that's a blast. You'll be body slamming, drop kicking, and gut punching enemies into submission, and you can even dirty it up with a shotgun to the stomach, taking an enemy melee weapon and quickly disposing of a group, or a shiv to the throat when an enemy lets their guard drop. Brawling mostly consists of parries, hits, and dodges with an indicator above enemy heads to signal what they are about to do, if you're familiar with the Arkham series or Shadow of Mordor you'll feel comfortable quickly.Mad Max is a game that deserves a lot more recognition for the amount of fun fullfilling content it provides. It had a very unfortunate release date but if you ever get a chance it's definitely a fun game that dips its toes into a lot of genres whilst also making them fun and unique to fit its tone. If putting on some music and driving and fighting around a wasteland on a quest for a better car and better gear sounds like fun to you it's a definite must buy.

Spoiler Review for the CompletionistAbout 50 hours into the game, while I was grinding achievements in a hypnosis-like haze the game had induced on me, I slowly realized the kind of man Mad Max is.Mad Max is the story of a psychologically unstable man who forces his own view of justice and order on a disturbed yet otherwise functioning post-apocalyptic society.Shortly after being ambushed by the warlord Scrotus the Immortan Jr., "the crazy eyed road warrior" Max, hellbent on revenge, goes completely out of his way: he topples down every single stronghold that probably without option declared allegiance to the tyrant Scrotus, he pillages every single isolated and obscure domicile where starving scavengers survive and get hostile only if anyone trespasses their territory and he creepily collect their private photos and diary entries, reading and cataloging every single one of them for god knows what reason. By the end of his rage induced rampage that he ironically performs in a chillingly and psychotically restrained composure, Max opts to kill a disabled and mentally handicapped man, Chumbucket, whose messianic delusions were ultimately exploited by Max to make him build his war-rig. As Chumbucket continually upgrades his life’s greatest work, appropriately named the Magnum Opus and have creepily ecstatic moments of joy as “his saint” Max drives it, he grows an unhealthy affection for him, most likely as a result of Stockholm Syndrome. The social bond that keeps the narcissistic-codependent duo together is Chumbucket’s ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic joy of having Max drive his car and Max perpetually feeding on Chumbucket’s unhealthy obsession.Perhaps falling victim to his ever building, self-mutilating, caustic hatred, Max suffers from a psychological breakdown. He becomes the sole prisoner of his rotten psyche and gets trapped in his own subconscious; his personal limbo. At the very end of his saga, every significant person that were unfortunate enough to cross paths with Max inexplicably come back to life in this timeless mental Wasteland, perhaps as a manifestation of his guilt.And Max spends his days here until eternity, where he was supposed to leave as soon as possible, surrounded by the unforgiving "Big Nothing" - the borders of his own subconscious, driving in his combustible, fire spitting mount restlessly, Chumbucket whispering praise in the wind behind him, with his inner demons only seeping out during fleeting moments as the red in his eyes.10/10 I’ve never been into cars, now I'm dreaming of building one.

												I'll try and keep it as much straight to the point as possible. First off it's not tied directly to the films as such, you are not Tom Hardy's Max and you are not Mel Gibson's Max so think of the game maybe seperate from the films, it is it's own thing here. Best part so far, it works! It's not broken, there are no game breaking bugs. In 10 hours of game play I have had zero crashes or glitches. On top of that I'm about to do all this fully optimized with a 980 GTX. However do remember this will make your GPU work, so you may want something like msi afterburner to get those fans going faster to keep it cool. The first time around my card jump from 30c to 60c and that's without water cooling. I do have the water block for it I've just been too lazy to put it in.So what's the game like? The best way to think about it is, take concepts from Far Cry , Assassins Creed, Borderlands Humour and a Batman Arkham style combat system then this is what you get. And I've gotta say so far it's a success. Is it perfect? Of course it isn't, some would argue any game is perfect. For one I personally feel my controls are restricted for an open world, I want to be able to walk and run. I also want to be able to jump over and around things like you can in Assasins Creed and the Witcher but at times you can't jump over simple obsticles because you wern't meant to. But still, it's pretty minor and by no means a reason to give it a negative review.I say Far Cry and Assasins Creed because in this open world instead of using radio watch towers and high pirches you have hot air balloons that go up and you use binoculars to scower the area yourself. If you rush it, you could miss unlocking something on the map. And Batman style combat, well because that's what it is. Fun, quick and easy to learn and really awesome to look at especially with finishers and other moves you can pick up as you upgrade Max along the way.Ammo is scarce as it should be, it's a post apocolyptic world and there isn't exactly gun factories about so you have to concerve your ammo and use it wisely. If you take your time in the game and go to all the scavaging areas on the map then you'll come across plenty of ammo, and as long as you're not a♥♥♥♥♥♥it won't be a serious issue. You can upgrade certain perks by finding this myterious traveller following you about (looks familiar to!) who gives you upgrades and you can increase the amount of ammo you find amongst other things.One nice touch here is the levellng system. Think of Max as having a bunch of ranks. You start off at the bottom and you level lets say 10 times by completing various tasks and goals such as killing x amount of bad guys this way or that way, or running so many people over. As you rank up you get to unlock more and more powerful upgrades. Naturally the final rank is "Road Warrior".The actual map is interesting, it's done in such a way where it would be really easy to knock out expansions and make additions, it could never end if they didn't want it to. Also it is quite large, after a few hours in the game you'll quickly realise there's a lot of things to do.You get to upgrade your car, you can change Max's appearence a little. There's also sections with bios for all the charactors you mean and all the badguys and vehicles you can collect and use (there appears to be quite a few).At the moment I'm finding the game fairly easy, I wasn't presented with a difficulty mode and considering I've completed the Far Cry, Assasin's Creed (well Black Flag, Rogue) and the Batman series i've found this pretty easy to get the hang of and quickly learnt what was what. Whether I'll unlock a harder mode when I complete it remains to be seen.All in all, yes. Right now I'd say the game is worth the money (just). Let's hope we get some decent DLC for this to keep it alive for a number of years at least as it has potential to do so.

Happy Birthday to your JAW! 
A Screenshot of Mad Max
By: NKato




Cons: No "New Game Plus" feature, can't carry over your earned upgrades to a new game (without story mode), any enemy content you clear is not repeatable. Basically, you can't keep repeating the stuff you love to do, and end up getting stuck with a dwindling pool of content to chew on as you build up the Magnum Opus.As of this writing, I've cleared just about all strongholds, all scarecrows, and all convoys. All I have left to do now is... *shudder*...the minefields. Such annoying, worthless gameplay that serves little more than to drive you insane with Dinky Di's incessant baying.Avalanche, a few more months of work on this game - and maybe a little bit of prudent forethought - would have resulted in a much more solid product.I would recommend this game to anyone who has no problem with a one-and-done execution on game design philosophy, as opposed to the heavily replayable content seen in many other open-world games.UPDATE, EXTENDED REVIEW EDITION: Just completed all "hostile" content (convoys, minefields, etc) and all Wasteland missions, got all territories to Threat Level 0. After just 32 hours of game time. What follows is my final impression of the game.The game is an excellent foundational game, but lacks the long term stamina to make this a game for people to keep coming back to even after they've beaten it. When you first step into the World of Mad Max, it feels very authentic, and the gameplay is top notch.


The Classic Hit-and-Run. 
A Screenshot of Mad Max
By: NKato




However, after you get through the majority of the content, it's as if the air has been let out of its tires. You don't encounter enemies as often, and you don't get to have a lot of fights unless you decide to go scavenging a lot (which is pointless after you've completed all the Stronghold Projects). Enemy encounters on the road, after all the convoys have been defeated, amount to just random roving war bands and the occasional parked WarBoy vehicle by the roadside.If Avalanche had implemented a type of New Game Plus feature that would allow the game's world map to regularly repopulate captured bases and defeated convoys with respawned enemy encounters, then the game wouldn't feel as empty at the end.In the current game design of Mad Max, as I've said before, Avalanche seems to have unintentionally turned the game into a "One-And-Done" game experience, rather than focusing their design philosophy on repeatable game content to ensure high replay value.Why do you think games like Grand Theft Auto 5 is popular? Because it's got plenty of content for you to chew on, and it's repeatable. Mad Max lacks this entirely.


Close Encounters of the Boombug Variety 
A Screenshot of Mad Max
By: NKato




In the end, Mad Max is a game with a great introduction for new players, and a fun amount of content, but it quickly becomes a very painfully average game that offers no reason for you to bother coming back once you've beaten the content. It's also very short for a $60 game, considering that I've beaten the vast majority of its content in just 31 hours. This game in its current state is NOT worth $60. I would peg it at $30.Even after all its shortcomings, if you're out for an authentic Mad Max experience, this game is recommended. Just wait for a Steam Sale that slashes it by 50%.However, if you are looking for a game that will continue to entertain you long after you've beaten all the content in it, you are going to be sorely disappointed, and I would recommend that you look for a different game.P.S. For those wondering: The War Rigs from Fury Road only make an appearance in this game in the form of a junked ride inside a tunnel. There are no actual driveable War Rigs.P.P.S. Let's be honest, if you are on a monthly gaming budget, and plan on spending $60 on a game, spend it on Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain. It did release at around the same time as Mad Max, the difference is that MGSV has much better entertainment value for your money.

												Mad Max is a really fun open world experience.


YouTube™ Video: Mad Max - 60fps Gameplay & Review - A Sheepish Look At 

			Views: 344		

			Genna plays Mad Max. An open world, post-apocalyptic game with a heavy focus on vehicle and melee combat. Click here to Subscribe ► http://bit.ly/mrwssub...		

I'll start off by talking about the world itself. It's beautifully designed. Sure the environment is just an open and empty desert for the most part, but they really crafted some interesting scenery. Cool canyon formations, rubbel from the old world like destroyed ships, or wrecked buildings. The game's graphics look beautiful, and can actually be cranked up quite a bit considering the game is fantastically optimized.There are tons of different objectives to complete while out in the wasteland, all decently unique to keep the game from getting stale. Sometimes you can compete in a race, or scavenge some ruins for scrap metal, or infiltrate a base. Something quite interesting about the bases, is you occasionally have the option to get some intel from a nearby wastelander surveying the location. It's not necessary, but they might give you some useful tips such as a hidden entrance, or the Base leader's weakness.You use scrap metal for upgrading Max and your vehicle, and you gain it by doing basically everything. You can find it scattered in buildings, or pick it from the wreckage of a destroyed vehicle, or dropped from a defeated enemy.Something I love about the game is there's quite a bit of choice when it comes to a few things. Apart from allowing you to choose how to infiltrate a base. For example, gas cans can be used to refill cars, or lit on fire and thrown to blow up doors. The world is very dynamic. There's a full day and night cycle, and occasionally tornadoes will form. They're not very dangerous, but still freaky. Sometimes gigantic dust storms will sweep the land. You have the choice of either getting to shelter to stay safe, or drive right into the storm and attempt to survive flying debris, lightning hitting the ground in order to grab some valuable scrap metal boxes flying through. I love that the game allows you to risk it for the biscuit like that.Now to get to the focus of the game, vehicles. You can upgrade yours a very large amount. You can choose between car body shapes, colours, decals, engine types, spikes to stop boarders, rams and so on. It's very satisfying to see your car turn into a badass killing machine. Apart from ramming into your enemies, you can also use your arsenal of weapons. Either shooting the tires, or exposed fuel barrels with your shotgun. You may harpoon doors off a car, and then pull the driver out, or shoot a stream of flames.The combat when you're on foot is very similar to the Batman Arkham games. although it has a few stuff to keep it unique in its own ways. The better you time your counters, the more bone-breaking opportunities you have. In melee combat you can still use your shotgun or finite knives to quickly dispatch an enemy. As you fight you fill up your fury meter, which basically just makes you stronger and gives you more chances to instantly finish off an enemy with stronger attacks. It's some very satisfying fighting.Overall, I've had so much fun with the game, and even after the main story I've continued to 100% the game. My only real complaint would be the fact that in order to unlock some car upgrades, you need to lower the threat of certain regions. In doing so, less enemies are driving around that area, but that means you don't get to have fun killing those enemies with your newly upgraded car. A new game+ mode would be perfect for this. Apart from that though, incredibly fun experience, very well polished and generally awesomely fun carnage!

												I usually avoid movie related games, as they are almost always quickly pieced together and offer nothing more than a brand name on a mediocre game. But Mad Max is something else.Similar to the film, the majority of this game revolves around driving through the wastelands of a dystopian Australia. In addition to the stunning scenery and expansive stretches of desert coated highway, are a hive of strongholds, enemy towers and sniper nests you can chose to conquer. Vehicle combat is excellent, and is similar to that of older Burnout titles, such as Takedown. You can fine tune your car, the Magum Opus, to suit your playstyle, lightly armoured speedster, or fortified tank. Using either grinding and crashes to destroy enemy cars, or your harpoon gun to rip off their tires or leave the driver exposed by removing his door and shotgunning him.Melee fighting is taken from Warner Brothers other game franchise, the Arkham series, so is polished and well developed. Max himself can be upgraded with combat maneuvers and armour or damage boosts, and Skills such as increased health and weapon durability.Though the story is not of particular merit, the one thing Mad Max shines at is fun. You often spend hours driving around the giant open-world, littered with side missions, hunting scrap to upgrade your car. During your 30-40 hours of game time, you will notice the small touches the developers added, which shows you that they really cared about the game and wanted to produce something that stands in line with the Mad Max franchise.If you enjoy vehicle combat or wasteland based games, Mad Max is a great addition to your games library.

												The apocalypse made Australia slightly more liveable, none of the wildlife tried to kill me. Traffic is still murder though.But seriously: highly recommended. I couldn't stop playing this game.It's a sandbox game with a whole lot of sand, a great atmosphere, visual design taken straight of Fury Road and made by fans of the whole series or at least people who really documented themselves, with lots of details and easter eggs about the three first movies. As a fan of the Mad Max universe myself, I had a blast.However, just as in a real sandbox, it's mostly up to you to make your own fun. The story is a bit weak, and while there are a ton of locations (over 250 I think), all of them unique, all you do is drive and fight, either in a vehicle or on foot with a Batman Arkham clone system which is very brutal and satisfying and offers quite a bit of different possibilities once you've unlocked skills. You can upgrade your vehicle to make it tougher and meaner, get a few weapons for your car and unlock fighting skills for Max, but the core experience stays the same. If that appeals to you and you like to explore every nook and cranny in a game to find stuff (it's always scrap, but you need it for everything), go right in. If you need to be poked every five minutes by narrative to stay interested, it isn't the game for you.There a over 16'000 reviews already, so there isn't much I could say that you can't find elsewhere. I'm just going to say "watch the trailer", for once it isn't just an empty cinematics showcase filled with buzzwords but it shows you most of the gameplay and really shows you the game and what to expect.Disclaimer: I am a fan of the Mad Max universe since The Road Warrior, back in the days where there was no videogames and where it was the only post-apocalyptic experience around, so I'm probably biased.
