Posted: May 23, 2016
Product received for free
IntroThis game was given to me by a colleague who had a spare copy. I put the game aside due to the general consensus that the game was ‘okay’, however when I did get round to booting up the game - I didn’t play anything else until I finished it! And I don’t get to finish many games…Story/BackgroundThe main story is a bit meh. The narrative has clearly been written to fit in with the game mechanics (you need to upgrade your car a bunch and you need a buddy riding along with you), though it does get a bit better towards the end.The side quests are nice because they have a level of narrative, don’t take too long and there aren’t so many of them that they detract from the main story. Post-apocalypse themes are always cool. The Mad Max setting is no Fallout. It is very brutal. There is death, violation, drugs and not to mention insane amounts of violence. I’m almost afraid to say I prefer this level of seriousness that almost everyone in this world wants to kill you purely for the fun of it. MechanicsCombat is truly where the game shines. There are two types; on foot and in car. Ground combat is just like the Batman games but super bloody and delightfully violent. It follows the action mechanic formula of punching and parrying, with weapons and unlockable skills thrown into the mix. Max has a gun, but true to the world, ammo is scarce so I found myself very rarely using it (much more fun to save for use in car combat).The car combat mechanics are awesome. The nature of it, though unscripted, comes across as highly cinematic, detailed skirmishes. Intercepting convoys is extremely fun, there’s nothing like scouting out a dust trail from atop a plateau with your ‘long lookers’, getting into your vehicle and T-boning the target car, shooting raiders off your bonnet in the process. Very fun.ProgressionMax and his car are the player’s main focus. Levelling up Max unlocks Max upgrades such as armor and skills. This system is very well done; rather than gathering experience points, you level up by completing challenges (blow up 50 barrels, do a 10-hit combo, etc.). Completing quests and eliminating threats unlocks car upgrades. There are many different combinations, the most expensive upgrades aren’t always the best to use. Sometimes the weaker upgrades are a better choice - they may have less mass, which allows for faster acceleration, for example.VisualsThe game is beautiful. From far away landmarks, right the way down to sand trails and dust clouds, the level of detail is impressive. There’s even a feature to freeze time and capture screenshots and videos. No loading screens interrupt traversing the huge open world.SummaryI’ve touched on the parts of this game that spoke out to me the most. If you are a fan of open-world action games, post-apocalyptic themes or good o’ violence ‘n explosions, then I highly suggest buying this. Some patience with the first introductory part is required until the game opens up and becomes much more fun. The game is NOT a survival game, Max is a very capable individual, though a bit simple and predictable - he fights like a total badass.

												Mad Max is one of those solid mid-tier games that got pushed as a AAA title and shoved out to die, and that makes me sad.I'm not going to pretend the game is flawless, hell, two times in playing it I fell through geometry and got trapped, and I'm well aware of things like the "your map vanishes forever" bug that got patched out before I began playing (I waited on that fix), Mechanically, though, it's an enjoyable game hampered by a few design decisions. The combat's a bit repetitive by endgame, but your moves basically turn into a lot of shortcuts to victory and the shotgun is a huge boon in that it'll OHKO all but three classes of enemy*. Vehicle combat is cool and you can build the Magnum Opus (your ride for the game) into a variety of different styles: I went light armor, fast movement, and a lot of harpoon/tire-spikes to take out enemies, with a massive ram for a stylish finish. Someone else could just turn the car into a tank, or take careful shots at an opponent to blow them sky high, or spit flames from the car to consume anyone else nearby. It's a decent customization level, and that's one of my biggest issues with it:You don't get a lot of toys until the very end of the game, doubly so if you're like me and do a lot of side-content before main events.Which sucks! And while the story missions do put together some nice scenarios and events, I actually think some of the side stories are better designed or more interesting than the main game. The only really, really distinct thing the game did for me in its main story was the final gauntlet, which was actually kind of unpleasant to play through even though I can't fault it from a character standpoint. Meanwhile, the side missions and some of the camps took on a whole lot of environmental storytelling, from underground oil refineries, to the almost puzzle-like nature of some of the scrap hideaways, to scaling an old power structure to take down a warlord in his own home.The thing that leaves me most disappointed in this game is that this is one of those games that would be perfect with one more revision, they take this finished engine, tweak it a little, and spend all the time of a sequel on design rather than coding, but it's pretty much guaranteed to never happen, and I don't see anyone mining this game for ideas when the next Big Thing comes around and vehicular open world debauchery is going to be forgotten. It was really fun. Buy it.* shielded, huge dudes, and one specific boss fight where the dickweed dodges shells

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Amongst a multitude of open world games with maps littered by icons for collectibles as a substitute for gaming content, Mad Max does something with the genre: it turns all of these collectibles into exploration pieces. This doesn't exactly solve the problem; exploring over a hundred of tiny settlements becomes as tedious as hunting down a hundred of other collectibles, but it does turn what would be a collectathon into a series of adventures and the resulting product is that much richer for it.Mad Max is at its best whenever it turns into a dungeon crawler in post-apocalyptic Australia. Imagine Middle-Earth: Shadows of Mordor where instead of gaining intel on orc warlords you gain intel to take down enemy bases. Scout enemy camps from afar before taking out their perimeter defenses in your V6 engine car, then battle it out inside while seeking treasure troves of metal scraps.The features are what sets Mad Max apart from other games. There are definite improvements to the traditional Batman-style melee while car combat has a range of over-the-top special attacks such as the harpoon slam, drive-by shootings, THUNDERPOONS and flaming jets of incineration. Meanwhile, the weakness in the main story actually made me wistful for the Assassin's Creed franchise! Say what you will about their game balance; you knew absurd action hero♥♥♥♥♥♥was gonna go down the minute you accepted that Story Mission! Here it's the opposite: Story Missions are quite tame and most of the value comes from investigating non-essential camps and hunting down enemy convoys.One must enjoy the greater changes Mad Max brings to the genre if they are to appreciate their purchase. This could've just as easily been a negative review if I nitpicked every little thing that went wrong: Top Dog bosses follow identical patterns, the vehicles you collect from the enemy serve no purpose, ditto the archangel "alternative car builds", some cars are deliberately rendered hard to maneuver as artificial difficulty, the greatest threat to your lifebar is an impromptu event against which you are completely helpless (OH NO, A MIGHTY DUSTER!), same ol' chore list of tasks to do ("kill 20 enemies with wall finishers." No, stop adding those), not to mention the glaring elephant in the room: you are STILL searching for collectibles! They're just properly hidden as part of your (side-) adventure rather than showcased on a map, so you end up longing for those traditional map icons whenever you're stuck searching for that one final object and be done with a particular encampment!Most games have you seek out upgrades in side quests, Mad Max makes upgrading your V6 engine into a V8 the main plot of the game. It's true! You get your car stolen in the opening, you vow vengeance, you find a substitute which you'll upgrade with better wheels, armor and such but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if Max Rockastansky is gonna drive anything with less than 8 cylinders of pure power! This is literally "Upgrades: the Game". Assault the various strongholds of Scabrous Scrotous to unlock upgrades, collect piles of scrap to pay for upgrades, perform feats of daring-do (or kill 20 enemies with wall finishers) for character upgrades. This is... "pure extract of open world game". Mind you; the upgrades are indeed wonderful, but there should be more to games than just upgrades. I don't want to play the world's most skillful scrap collector.There's just so much good in this game for it to warrant a Thumbs Down, despite my numerous gripes. However, I obviously cannot recommend this to anyone burnt out on open world games at the risk of seeing them puke map icons. Important: check your system requirements before purchasing as this game actually caused my computer to overheat when played at its highest graphical settings. If you're still on the fence, consider watching a few Let's Plays. I promise it won't spoil the story.REVIEW SLIGHTLY EDITED FOR LENGTH

I'm torn on this game, on one hand the Batman style combat is tried and true,(I have to add that after replaying Batman Arkham Asylum, the combat is a lot more responsive and fluid than batman) and the car combat is pleasant enough, on the other hand this is the majority of things to do in this game.The story what little of it there is left me wanting . There are certain choke points in the story where you are bottle necked into doing the highly repetitive "side missions" to reduce the threat level in each goofy dumb-asses territory you need to proceed through to the end of the story. The main content consists of shooting snipers off perches,with a very poor shooting mechanic only available from the back of your car. Blowing enemy convoys up with your car, which is the one of the better realized components of the game but becomes trivial after some of the late game upgrades for your car thus removing replay-ability.  Pulling down towers with your cars harpoon, also trivial but required to progress, but I had some of my most enjoyable time in the game just driving around the games world. The vehicle handing is fun once accustomed to it.The game has very few fast travel points compared to most open world games. But it can be exciting driving your death machine around the wastes.The most time consuming part of the game is going into enemy camps where section by section you use the before mentioned batman style combat to achieve a small set of simple and repeated goals. Although it is similar to other games combat it has its own unique touches that brought glee at times. The tools at hand in combat are gruesome and useful allowing the above mentioned fluidity to combat, making combat the most pleasant part of the game and consequentially the game play is what helped me push through to the end of the story. Although upgrading Max's abilities brings more tedium to the game, you are forced to drive to a roaming shaman-esque character in order to spend a skill point.Halfway through I found myself dreading the proceeding the bored cut scene pushed every time you visit this "shaman". So I took the route of letting five to ten points build up before i took the time to search out the shamans newly relocated position on the map. Which seems odd because my garage i.e the way to upgrade the car is simply in the game menu?....I found the game to be getting too tedious around the hour twenty mark, so hey I got twenty hours of funish game play out of it before i could take no more and just mainlined the story as fast as i was allowed. I decide to lean positive due to the fun I did have but fair warning, the game is VERY repetitive and i was disappointed when it was all said and done that the game gave me to compelling reason to play after completing the story.

												Mad Max is a solid open world experience, creating an immersive environment through ambient sounds and visuals from the Avalanche Engine (notably found in Just Cause series). A pre-release review labelled the game as "exhilarating, fast, violent, and fun" and I'd have to agree to that. The game puts heavy emphasis on vehicular combat, in which around 60% of the game requires the player to drive their car to fight against enemies.After a global collapse of civilisation and society, followed by an intense nuclear skirmish, Max's journey to the Plains of Silence takes an unexpected turn when a group of War Boys (run by warlord Scabrous Scrotus, psychotic son of Immortan Joe) run him off the road and steal his clothes, his supplies, his weapons, and his car before leaving him to rot in the desert sun. Traversing the wasteland in search of his prized Interceptor, Max meets a hunchback mechanic named Chumbucket, an overzealous individual that's hell bent on crafting the perfect vehicle, the Magnum Opus. After giving Max hope of exacting vengeance on Scrotus, the two form an unlikely partnership and set out in the base of the Opus in search of food, water, allies, upgrades, and redemption in a world devoid of sanity.The two downfalls to the game are the controls and the fighting capabilities. Controls make the game feel cheap, constant big HUD reminders for which key to press, and normally you have to hold the button down rather then just press it. It doesn't seem a huge issue, but gets incredibly frustrating the more you invest time into the game. Fighting capabilities are somewhat slim, with just a couple different buttons to use to fight and defend Max. I was really hoping for something along the lines of the Batman series in terms of combat mechanics, but was mildly disappointed. However, the violent nature of Max and his different styles of taking out opponents somewhat makes up for this. On a huge plus, this game makes you feel like the wasteland is alive. Constant threats driving around and notorious weather changes can drastically alter your initial plans. Its also extremely refreshing to find a game that doesn't include regenerating health, which makes scavenging for food and water supplies a nice change. The camera mode is superb and instantly reminds me of the one found in Shadow of Mordor, easily allowing you to capture your best images the way you want - with different vignettes/filters to apply and tweak your shots with. You will probably find yourself continuously busy in Mad Max, and with that said you will more then likely be rewarded around every corner of doing so, normally in the form of scrap (the games currency used to upgrade Max, vehicles and strongholds).Finally, the car combat is absolutely fantastic and really shines over the negative points mentioned. Numerous occasions I found myself wandering off of missions in hunt of enemies & loot. You will find yourself ramming, shooting and harpooning every vehicle/structure you find, not forgetting to mention lone snipers trying to pick you off at range. The ability to customise your vehicle (& character) to your liking is a personal favourite of mine and therefore lets you explore the wasteland as the Mad Max that you want to be. It all makes for a forward moving and overall fun experience.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												The question I asked myself prior to writing this was "What does Mad Max do that other games aren't doing?"  It feels like a game of missed opportunities.  There is this big, very well-crafted world set in a post-apocalypstic land with not all that much to offer an intrepid wanderer.  Yeah, you can drive around and see ruins of buildings and signs, but there is almost never a real point to doing so.  You can pick up tiny amounts of scrap (the game's currency), but after you've liberated some camps the scrap pickups become just another collectible.  Speaking of collectibles, the history relics started interesting enough - a photo, a postcard, a handwritten note of days gone by that Max wistfully comments on - but when I realized I'd collected dozens and wasn't even halfway through the list, I gave up.  They aren't THAT interesting.The story is cliche at best, the anti-hero just looking out for himself until he meets someone who reminds him of better days and then has to systematically destroy the bad guys.  It's awkward.  At least when you fight, it has real impact.  Punching dudes never really gets old in this game, but the combat has its drawbacks as well.  There is "tap for light hit" and "hold for heavy hit", and a counter button.  You unlock various finishing moves throughout the game that can be useful in group fights, but sometimes the game doesn't respond quickly enough and allows Max to take a hit while setting up such a maneuver.  When in Fury mode, he hits real hard and does some incredibly satisfying suplexes, but there is no way to do it on purpose - you just get lucky.Car combat starts off similarly, forcing you to think a little bit about your approach before you have upgraded your car.  By the time you can hurl thunderpoons at other cars, it's just not that fun anymore because everything explodes pretty easily.  As stated many times, the mini-bosses scattered around are a joke.  They all attack the same way (unblockable charge) and in most cases, you defeat them the same way - hit them with a real big wrench or something else lying around.  Occasionally there are environmental hazards that can aid you - say, but letting a boss charge into a flame burst - but it's nowhere near the extremes of something like Sleeping Dogs.After a while, you realize that reducing threat across the various warlords' regions by tackling side actitivies (read: map vomit) has stopped being beneficial, as Max is decked out in crazy gear and the car is nigh invulnerable (car upgrades are often locked behind getting threat below a certain level).  It just stops being fun.  I mainlined the last several story missions to get it over with and wasn't left very satisified by the ending.  It's probably worth a play if you dig the universe and don't mind icons all over the place (complete with hot air balloons that let you identify all the actitives in an area!), but it's not really anything spectularly different.

												"Perhaps it's not the killing you enjoy, but the moments of silence the fighting brings you".Beautiful, entertaining and intense adventure game will not only attract fans of Mad Max, but also anyone who is looking for a good open world game with a variety of content and stuff to explore, do and destroy. Before I say anything else about this quality game, hats off to Avalanche studios for great optimisation. Game runs smoothly at 60 fps, no micro stuttering, no sudden unexplained FPS drops, it has plenty of different graphical options and is easy adjustable and reconfigurable. Let's start off with the map. It's apsolutely huge! One would think that stranded in a desert would be far from entertaing, but developers managed to pull this world off beautifully from occasional wanderers that ask for a sip of water in exchange for an information, to different camps, sniper's nests and so on. There is always something going on like convoys traveling on route, war boys attacking you and trying to steal your car and so on.Graphics wise, game is beautiful. Explosions, dust storms, all those tiny particles are visible and they really create unique immersion with not only the game but the main character - Mad Max. Gameplay - I'd say this is the focal point of the game. From driving, to looting, destroying, killing warboys, this game has it all. AI in this game I feel is really on point, chasing the convoy, demolishing cars, everything feels super polished. Driving in the beginning feels somewhat stiff and weird, awkward and delayed, but as you progress and upgrade the handling, it gets only better, easier and the vehicle itself gets stronger and stronger along the way. If you've played Batman Arkham games, the combat feels more or less the same, but with more brutality, suited to Mad Max's persona. It's very satisfying and rewarding.Not only you are able to fully customize your car as you wish with dozens of different body's, parts and such, you are also able to change Max's outfit, grow him a beard, make him stronger, faster, more resistable and so on. Game offers a lot without being too overwhelming on that part.When it comes to story, unfortunately I can't vouch for it and say that it's the better part of the game, but as you know, you're Mad Max, left alone to survive, find your peace and solace. Story is as good as Mad Max's story can go in my opinion.I'd say that the negative side of this game would probably be repetitiveness. Given that there are a lot of stuff do collect, smash, dismantle, loot and so on, I can see how it can feel for stale for someone who is looking for more vibrant kind of game. I'd rate this game a solid 8.5/10. Quality title and definitely worth the name Mad Max.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												This is an absolutely wonderful game from Avalanche Studios. The same guys that did Just Cause 2. While Mad Max shares the title name and protagonist of the Mad Max movies, the world and story is actually completely non canon to the film franchise. Max here is based on neither Mel Gibson or Tom Hardy's Max Max. Completely original, and leaving the player to their own interpretations on how to play as Mr. Rockatasnky. Max starts out the game having his trusty V8 stolen, and sets off on a grandiose apocalyptic adventure through the wasteland in an attempt to get back what is rightfully his. Early in the game you meet your sidekick and comic relief for the game in the form of a hunchback named Chumbucket. Chumbucket is also your trusted mechanic, who helps Max by creating a car for him called the Magnum Opus. A vehicle which Max can customize through Chumbucket a number of ways. It is also the vehicle Max will use for a large portion of the game. Mad Max takes place in a massive and barren wasteland, that shares no settings with the movies, but has completely original areas. And though the game has a lot of what you'd expect in a wasteland setting, it still seems to have a diversity lacking in most open world games. The world is as depressingly dreadful as it is also artistically wonderful. Luckily, Avalanche included a built in screenshot tool with editing features to capture some magnificent shots of the world. The gameplay is a mixed bag. On one hand you have a combat system that is reminiscent of games like the Arkham and Assassin's Creed games as well as Shadow of Mordor, with it's attack attack attack parry attack system, with little in terms of depth. This system has been found to be quite simple in other games, but Mad Max kicks it up a notch by requiring much better timing from the player. This might be a little frustrating for some players. And others might find it a bit boring. Luckily, the gameplay has you about 80% of the time in the vehicle, and this is where the game really shines. The vehicle combat is incredibly satisfying in this game. You will find yourself ramming into other vehicles, using a harpoon to tear vehicles apart, and even shooting a modified rocket launcher of sorts to cause even more chaos all across the wasteland. And it is all executed wonderfully. What's even cooler is that while the Magnum Opus is indeed your vehicle of choice, you can steal and even collect for later use any of the other vehicles found in the game. The structure of progression is pretty simple, but the amount of content in it is still quite massive. You have your main story progression, which sends you off on various missions to do this, collect that, kill that person. Pretty standard stuff. But you can not progress through the story entirely until you start doing some stuff on the side, like clearing out the threat of major gans in different areas, by eliminating them, taking over special convoy routes, taking over bases, and more. And there are still plenty of even more side diversions, like tons of places to loot for supplies, races, and more. Though the world may seem barren, it still has quite an enormous amount of things to do. There is a good deal of customization also to be found in the game ranging from your vehicle to Max himself. You can change the appearance of Max himself with unlockables you gain through a progressive ranking system, and also equip him with new moves for combat, new armor, and more. You can also do your usual upgrades to the Magnum Opus which involve different body types, armor, paint jobs, engines upgrades, tires, and more. The game also has a gas system, which means you can actually run out of gas while driving too much. Luckily gas is not hard to come by, and I have never actually had the displeasure of running out. Water is more scarce, but you never dehydrate. You only need water when you get injured in combat. you can also even feed on maggots from old corpses to regain health. Sick! There is not much realism in the gas and water system, but it's still kind of neat. anyone looking for a realistic game (I've heard the complaints), please look elsewhere. This game does not strive to follow the movies to the letter, but rather create an extremely fun and extremely chaotic game for fans of the ACTION from the movies.

Neutral RatingReally not sure about this Game... It HAD potential, but I think a lot of it was missed. For me, the Game had more Negative aspects to it. I'd only recommend this during a Sale, and only recommended for someone who wants a Game to mess around in.The Story itself is extremely short with just 15 Missions which take no time at all to complete. Not only is the Story short, but it just bored me and not once did I really even care for it. It just felt like an empty shell. The only thing that made this Game have some length was the fact you have to complete tasks to unlock Story Missions. Complete so and so amount of Wasteland Missions, complete so and so amount of Stronghold Projects.None of the Characters were interesting, and although the Voice acting was decent, the cut scenes were just short, and quick to the point with no context.Surely the Gameplay would make up for it though. Unfortunately the Gameplay is hindered with the horrible Auto Camera [slow Manual Camera], and slow response on the Controls which felt like it had a slight lag after pushing in a direction.The Game has the usual Assassins Creed style combat, punch punch, counter when you see the Marker, but unfortunately, the Game doesn't allow you to turn the Counter Markers off, which just makes the combat so easy and boring after awhile. Infact, NOTHING in the Game was a challenge... Apart from fighting the Camera and Controls.The Game has 9 Boss Fights in total, 3 with Scrotus [the Main boss] and 6 "Mini" Boss Fights. However 4 of these Bosses is someone wielding a large Mace, ALL with the same animations, and same method to defeat [wait for him to charge, roll, start punching]. The remaining 2 are duel wielding daggers, again, same animations, same method to defeat [roll, counter when you can]. It is just absolutely lazy development.Come across a door you need an explosion for? No worries, just look 5 meters away and there will be a well placed Fuel can for you... Speaking of Fuel cans, WHY does the Game even have Fuel for the Car? The first and ONLY time I Fueled my car was at the start in the Tutorial, after that you will never really need to. I only completed my Project for auto Refueling in Jeets Stronghold [the first one which I never went to afterwards], and none of the others.Being an Open World Game though, there would be tons of things to do right? Here is what you can do;- Death Runs [Racing]- Scavenger Locations [You will encounter a max of around 3 enemies, and 2 pieces of Loot].- Minefield [Use your Dog to locate a few Mines].- Camps [Destroy either Transfer Pumps, or Oil Tanks to complete].- Scarecrows [Destroy them to lower Threat in the Region. Takes a max of 10 seconds to do].- Stronghold Projects [Complete Projects for Strongholds to give free Ammo ect. You will come across these in Camps and Scavenger Locations].This is around 90% of the Game. For an Open World, it just isn't much variety. The only thing that was half decent to do were the Camps, but this was countered with the simplistic Combat, and horrible Camera.A couple things I enjoyed were Harpooning people from my Car. As fun as this was, after your Harpoon hits, your Camera will follow your Target, even after you correct it. This will usually end with you Driving into a Wall beacuse you can't see where your going.The last 2 Missions were just great. It's the only time through the entire Game, that I felt something for the Story. The dialog, and the Gameplay were fantastic, and it really is a shame that the rest of Game was not at that level.Genre- ActionGame Elements- Open World- Day Night cycle- Weather elements- Combat- Car Modification- Racing- Stronghold UpgradesAverage Playthrough- 15 HoursLiked- Great Engine Sounds- The last 2 Missions- Great Visuals for ScreenshotsDisliked- Offered no challenge- Uninteresting Characters- Short and bland Story- Lack of variety of Side Objectives- Each Stronghold were exactly the same- Re-used Boss Battles- Slow Controls- Horrible Auto Camera [Slow manual Camera]- No option to turn Counter Markers off

												It's good, but it's not great. 10 hours in the curiosity will give way to tedium as each camp becomes a pattern of fight, loot, fight, loot, fight, loot, fight with nothing to stop one camp blending in to all the others. The driving mechanics are decent but the lack of a hand-brake is mind-boggling given much of the game is vehicular combat relying on ramming.The storyline is decent and includes some fairly brutal developments along the way that reflect the harsh world you find yourself in perfectly. Despite the negatives outlined above, I still sank 70 odd hours into it which is a testament to the underlying world. Max himself is the strong silent type you'd expect and between him and the 'Magnum Opus' there's sufficient cool to make it interesting - just. With just a little more time spent in the ideas department this could have been a classic. As it stands, it's a good game and worth it if you can get it at a discount.

Introduction:Being the first game of the series this is an amazing game. Love the fact that it was paid for by Warner Bros. who also made Tomb Raider which gave it the perfect feeling. A lot of the mechanics are similar to Tomb Raider games. This game didn't disappoint once. Pros:LOTS OF DRIVING (pro IMO, could be a con for you)Good graphicsLong storyGood plotGood selection of carsTon of upgrades for cars and MaxSo many side missions and collectiblesHuge mapExtremely optimizedMostly bug freeGreat special effects (smoke, fire, sounds)Cons:Only single playerReally hard bosses with no difficulty settingA few times certain sound effects were muteSometimes the game isn't clear with your objectiveYou can drive any car you find but can't use it as a primary vehicleConclusion:I had a lot of fun playing game especially after reading the book and watching the movie. WBs did a very good job with this game. When I saw the movie this was exactly the game I imagined. There's nothing I thought was missing except the multiplayer aspect. Especially after the story is done there isn't much. It would be cool if they made a The Crew type online mode where you see others. But other than that its a masterpiece.For more reviews check out  Original Curators Group

												I get to release all kinds of stress and anxiety with this game...Avalanche really captured the essence of Mad Max with this game, call me crazy but for some reason this game in bits and pieces reminds me of Red Dead Redemption.  Fantastic graphics, good sound, and fun gameplay for an open world driving game.  They did a decent job of balancing parts and missions unless you are the type of player that bombs for the finish line as quickly as possible, then you may run into some sticky situations.  I have been playing casually through and am about 3/4 completed with the game at around 60 hours.  Again casually playing exploring doing side missions and extras then onto the mainline missions when I felt like it.  They did so many things right but yet a few things are lacking in my eyes that yet need to be done.  For example a game+ mode to unlock after 100% completion resetting the bases, convoys, scarecrows, threat levels, etc.  Also game+ mode would be far more difficult and fuel would be far more rare and not to mention fuel consumption would be far more as well.  Sort of a "hardcore" mode after completion would have been nice touch to finish up this great game. People still play this game quite a bit even a year after release it's still picking up, not bad for a SP game.  I mean this game still has a daily average of 4 to 5,000 players.  I picked this game up on a sale and got it for 9.99,  if you love vehicle combat games not too mention a hand to hand combat system that is alot like Arkham then I would say it's worth even the full price as well if you love those types of games.  It consists of building you car and leveling your personal skills while going to war with Scrotum face's war boys. Competing in death races to unlock collector cars, raiding bases and looting, taking out convoys, building up allied bases for restock and constantly battling enemies until you get the threat levels down by dismantling bases, tearing down scarecrows, clearing minefields etc.It really is a fun game to play..10/10 Would put a chainsaw through Scrotum again...

Posted: September 2, 2015
												I will keep this review short, because I don't want to write about everything good that this game is, but rather let you experience the game yourselves.Mad Max is a 3rd person, post apocalyptic, survival, action game with large open world, brutal hand to hand and vehicular combat. You play as Max, a survivor in harsh and unforgiving Wasteland, controlled by bandit gangs.Laying almost dead, and bleeding on the burning sands of Wasteland. Beaten down by the bandit gang with all of your hard earned possessions stripped from you. Max must find strength to get up and take the Mad to the bandits.This game is basically Tomb Raider + Uncharted 2 with Carmageddon vehicular madness in post apocalyptic Wasteland. Thus you get similar movement, platforming (to extent), survival, looting and equipment upgrades as in Tomb Raider / Uncharted 2, with more refined and brutal hand to hand combat. And all the crazy vehicle madness from Carmageddon, in addition to the upgradeable vehicle parts and body modifications.Controls are responsive yet tad sluggish, but you get the hang of it fast so there's nothing wrong here. Voice acting is good, with great lip sync in cut-scenes, but not so much out of them. You drive your car mostly through sand so it's understandable it will feel a bit unresponsive, but you can modify so many aspects of your vehicle and fine tune it to the handling you need.Environment is mostly Wasteland, so rocks, sand, sandstorms, occasional dust devil, as well as some nice view distance on landscape. Once in a while you see some eye catching scenes at night or by day that make you stop the car and soak in the beauty, even though it's just barren Wasteland.Main currency in game is scrap, similar to Tomb Raider where you come across some crates with parts, here you pick up metal scrap that is hand placed through environment and also can be dropped by enemies and destroyed vehicles. You use scrap to upgrade your car, pay for Max's upgrades, modifications and gear.Main gameplay besides story is to capture, destroy different points on the map, to eliminate bandits and reduce gang presence in that area, so less bandit patrols, higher rewards from survival ally camps who take control of the camps you free.Hand to hand combat is brutal and often pleasant to the eye. You fight more than one opponent at the time with counter indicators that let you plan your attacks, defenses. The higher combo you keep, the stronger attacks are, you can combo fast and strong attacks with ground and weapon takedowns, and also with body to surface detection. So you can sprint bash someone into the wall and then beat him silly holding against it.Vehicular combat is all about ramming sensitive parts of enemy vehicle, ripping off car parts with harpoon to either get to the driver or just have fun and tear off tires from vehicle to continue the fight on foot. Enemies can jump on your car and get to you if you're not careful, so plan your car upgrades and invest in less defended areas.I already talked too much, even though I wanted to keep it short. It's very well made game, runs on Havok engine which is awesome. You can fine tune the settings to match your hardware, personally I didn't have any issues with it even being below recommended and playing on High. It looks like majority of players who bought this game are happy with it, and for the low price (not on steam) it's well worth the money spent.


Wasteland. 
A Screenshot of Mad Max
By: ANCRON




P.S. Took me 75 hours to beat everything, with 48 out of 49 achievements. Didn't bother with last one because you have to do ALL in game challenges, and there are A LOT of those. In the end (with not trying to do them) I didn't have around 20, and I don't feel like wasting time completing those. Other than that I'm very happy with the game, I enjoyed it a lot, and it was money well spent.Enjoy.

Posted: February 15, 2016
												All I remember of Mad Max was a dusty Mel Gibson, a big bad car, and feeling a connection to the desperate wanderers he came across.  In a way, it's one of the first apocalyptic worlds I'd ever seen.  It has it's appeal.  Thunderdome and Tina Turner with the crazies and bloodlust.  These days it's all post-apocalyptic hell with zombies, so seeing a wasteland in a new but familiar universe of Mad Max wasn't hard to process and a nice change for all the end-of-the-world-ness in games I see.Well then, what's it all about?  Giant open world areas, some fun car caravan takedowns, the usual batman-eque fighting, using a  fast car to destroy stuff, and mostly enjoying the world of Mad Max in a video game.  A first I thought, "Ok, Batman-junior with a car. Not bad".  There is a fervor in the knuckle-fighting that is Max.  It's not a precise brawler, yet not a hack n slash either.  I couldn't really stop, though.  Insert coin, get video game fast food adrenaline rush.  My goal was to try and take them all down without firing a shot, that made the fights extra edgy.  The fun bit for *me*, though....the open world car takedowns.  And this varies from gamer to gamer because some folks dislike open world.  Personally, I just dive in and forget to actually play the missions.  After playing for a few hours I left the main campaign and drove around the open world leveling up for 20+ hrs.  Then I got back to the campaign all uber-leveled with a wonderfully growling car only to find I could not get to the next mission. I wasted about an hour or more trying to get it to work.  Finally, I gave up and looked online. I found I had to level *down* my car to get to the next mission.  What is up with that?  At least give me a hint, but to keep it completely out of the mission description?  Weird.  Why bother making an open world if you need a linear leveling playthrough?  So, *that* kinda stunk.Next up was learning to attack cars, gates, and snipers with my grapple hook.  Soon to be upgraded to a THUNDERPOON.  Yep, it's called a THUNDERPOON.  Basically having a lightweight RPG gunner in the back of your car.  Sweet.  But I preferred the grapple personally.  Maybe it's more batman-ish, but I enjoyed aiming it at tires and stopping bad guys with a hook to the chest.  Pooning was a bit too easy and I only used it for aiming at gas tanks at camps.  Some of those camps had several flame inducing gas tanks, snipers in tight areas, and defense towers made of shooting fireballs. These were a great joy to attack.  That was the best part really.  Once you got past the defenses, you crack some heads until you get to a mini-boss with minions and usually giant blazing stationary flamethowers.  I ran my bosses into those as a fast way to finish.  The problem?  ALL the mini-bosses were like that.  It got old after awhile.  Even down to the last side mission, it was all the same attack, evade, attack.  Not much to it.  Makes me scratch my head how come they didn't add some variety to the bosses.  It would have added so much more to the game if *any* of them had some special abilities.Now I loved the driving and chasing the bad guy on their supply routes.  It was sorta GTA style and even though the car was hard to maneuver I never got tired of it.  You can add more armor and stabilizers to get better handling, but I found the armor slowed me down.  Better to stay light to keep up.  Unless you skid out of control and end up in a ditch.  But, the car could take a good beating.  The death runs were okay and just required a bit of practice to remember where to slow down and speed up. Using nitro was also a good help on a straight path with it's fast speed boost, but in general made me lose total control if I made any sort of turn.  What NAILED me was the race against Stank Gum. It was there - after a bajillion attempts - that i realized i had too much armor and needed to lighten up the car to keep up. Once I did that, i was able to complete the mission with just a handful of tries.  That can be the hardest part of the game, or the easiest.  Depends how good you are at driving games and how heavy your car is when you start.Right around that part of the game, the story *finally* gets interesting.  Before, it was mostly summer-movie-story-action filler.  But towards the last 15% of the game the story makes some good progress. Which is great because after awhile I would just get bored and chat with my buddies on steam or watch twitch while I played 10 minutes every hr.  Some nights I'd play maybe 20 minutes with the game running all night long.  I was losing my interest pretty bad.  Past the Stank Gum mission, though, you may finish the game a little faster because it's getting more varied as you go.  I will say the end mission is pretty decent and I felt like it was a good ending.  I'm not going to spoil it, but that ending was a lot better than say the ending to Shadow of Mordor.  I had to play the Bright Lord DLC to get a good ending to Mordor - which is a shame because I *loved* Mordor other than that ending.  Mad Max ends well and becomes a decent game towards the last 15%  of the campaign.Story isn't much, but it's voice acted well and frankly I liked the storyline more than the movie.  That isn't saying much because the movie was mostly an action packed sequence with little dialogue going on ( in my opinion ).  But the game has a lot more going on.  What it *is* missing is the connection to the people surviving out there in the vast dry death of a world Max lives in.  You get some connections here and there, but mostly you bounce from camp to camp and just do missions without really talking to anyone.  Where is the love?  Max is a loner, I get it.  But, wow, there wasn't anything even close to a personal experience until the end.  Art direction is a gritty gorgeous wasteland.  A perfect Mad Max open world with quite a lot of detailed landscape and nicely working physics.  I got into it.  Maybe I'm a loner too, who knows, but it appealed to me.  At least until I finished and decided I need to move on to my backlog again.  Lemme drive all over and smash into bad guy cars.  I loved that.One more thing towards the end - and here I will be critical - it gets more and more glitchy.   A few scenes had my car inside of another car, I drove all the way to the end of a mission only to get stuck on geometry for 15 minutes while i wiggled everything possible, and the occasional cutscene where the person's head disappeared.  But my biggest gripe was the last side quest.  Someone decided to make it only work *at night*.  I could not fast forward time!  I tried upgrading the camps with scrap metal which seems to fast forward time a bit, but it would miss the nighttime somehow.  So, i drove around for over 2 hrs until I got to a night scene in order to finish the game sidequests. That was *so* annoying.  Somebody got cut a check for that idea.  Arrgh.  Please WB, it's *not* fun or challenging.  *Don't* do that again.Overall, a solid entry.  Nothing spectacular, but it has it's good points if you enjoy driving recklessly beating up brighly painted shirtless dudes in an open world.  Amazing? Nope.  Bad♥♥♥♥♥  Nope.  Worth the time? Um, yeah, as long as you like the above statement on driving and don't expect much variety in the bosses.  Plus, you get to be Mad Max!  7/10.

												As some others have already written I really wanted to like the game. It was unfortunately not meant to be so, Mad Max is an incredibly pretty game, the car combat is a nice change of pace and definitely sets the game apart from others. The story is mostly interesting and well written. What in my opinion sinks the game is it's repetitiveness. Once you have completed first of the regions you have, outside of the main missions, seen everything the game has to offer. All of the strongholds are upgraded in the same way, while it was nice to see them change visually getting the same parts for the same thing for the n-th time was just plain boring. And don't get me started on clearing the regions to 0 threat, to achieve that you have to clear everything from the region (aside from scrap locations), minefields are especially annoying, requiring you to change the car, drive to the location, find 3 mines, get out of the car and dismantle each one. And you if you want some of the upgrades you have to do that.TL;DR Overall I don’t think I can recommend Mad Max, completing the game felt like a chore due to its repetitiveness.

												What you are expecting is key to the factor of enjoyment you get out of Mad Max. If you are expecting a great GTA-ish game with a full fledged story, then you will be disappointed. If you are looking out for a fun and open world action game, with a great looking world, insane atmosphere and fun game mechanics (even though repetetive), then you will be enjoying it a lot. I did enjoy it a lot so far and it reminds me a lot of Far Cry and Assassin's Creed, missing the engaging story (there is one here though with nice looking cutscenes). Mad Max isn't a great game, but it is a good game and is good at everything it does. It pains me to see such great potential "wasted" in just a good game. They could have featured an embracing story and added elements to the gameplay, but they didn't. The pricepoint is perfect, 20 bucks are worth it (the keys cost way less, even more worth). I would be heavily disappointed with 60 bucks though, since it just isn't really having lots of content (as I said, the story isn't really great and all the content is the same as in all Ubisoft games prior to Watch Dogs 2, exactly the same formula).

Posted: February 5
Product received for free
												I don't know how to play these games anymore. As they grow larger or more populated with loot, locations and activities, I get entirely lost in the monotony and unfortunately I tend to neglect the story, which I value as much as gameplay. After 30-40 hours or so I had to pry myself away from it, the grind of driving from one location to the next was having a very unpleasant effect on my self-worth, so if you're prone to mood swings I don't recommend playing it every day. The grind of looting is best illustrated by the random friendlies you encounter, because so little thought has been put into those encounters that they're often a tonal mess of mismatched writing and animations, making them utterly pointless, scrap or no scrap.I was shocked by the performance I managed to get out Mad Max using my aging laptop, without even meeting the minimum GPU requirement, so the first thing you'll notice is an incredibly well optimized game that keeps the spirit of its art design even when everything is turned off or set to Normal. I didn't have to lower the resolution to get a relatively solid 30fps, sometimes close to 40-50fps. It's even more miraculous when you drive to the very edge of the map and fall off, to fully appreciate the size and beauty of this game world. I haven't done it myself, but I watched a video. At least the people who still think the world is flat can find solace in video games.After taking a break from it I returned with missions in mind, so I completed one after another and got back into enjoying the story and being focused enough to complete it. This game isn't defined by it's story, but it does a good job keeping you relatively invested, along with upgrades that are tied to story missions. They're important if you want to get the most out of your abilities and your vehicle. Apart from Chumbucket though, the characters are forgettable and I don't appreciate it when a part of the story is spoiled with a loading screen.Despite the harsh rules of the world that George Miller created with his films, I didn't feel like Max handing over entire territories to Jeet, Gutgash, Pink Eye and Deep Friah was justified enough to run all these errands for them. Fully upgrading a stronghold provides you with all the necessities, but what's the point of upgrading all of them if you can just fast travel to the first one to restock? Is the player required to upgrade all strongholds in order to access Gastown? I just find it presumptuous when I have a map in front of me from the very start with these territories already divided among the four of them. It's not like you're going to stop seeing bad guys once the threat level in a territory is brought down to zero. The stakes aren't high enough for everyone involved and it's a relatively easy game with simple combat.The combat is fun and you'll get used to it very fast, especially when you've played other games with similar combat. The fun is extended to car combat as well and this is where I have to emphasize the importance of doing missions frequently, otherwise it will become a drag if you don't upgrade your car and weapons. That being said, scrap is everywhere and most of the upgrades can be acquired with scrap, so looting plays a big part in Mad Max, whether you like it or not. The most fun you can have looting is by taking on a camp, which are thankfully very different in design, number of enemies, etc.A part of me felt like I had to postpone a final mission most of the time, looking at the mission indicators that would appear on Deep Friar and right after on Gastown, mostly due to how they hyped up The Jaw and the territories being divided so distinctly. When seeing the indicators I was afraid that this was it, a fight with an army of vehicles and a big boss, which is why I cowered to looting and upgrading as often as I could. The game didn't even have to convince me of it, at first sight I thought The Jaw was the entrance to Gastown, but it was only the gate between the two halves of the map. Don't make the same mistake, you're perfectly safe to enter Gastown the first chance you get, as long as you can survive the trip over there.It's satisfying to explore a game world for the first time and recent years have given us great open world games. Mad Max is no different, but it's more closer to the Far Cry series, cos it has a lot to do with taking down camps or fortresses, if you like. It can be a barrel of fun in shorter bursts, but for me it's bogged down by several minor annoyances and missed opportunities. Despite it being a beautiful wasteland, with all it's limitations, they could've done a better job in making it more believable, starting with the friendly encounters. Nevertheless I recommend it, especially when you're an avid explorer and want to get more out of your aging PC or laptop.

												Mad Max The game follows loosely story of the new Mad Max Movie. Gameplay 8 of 10You play Max Rockatansky in a dystopian world full of not quite normal people. Collect metal scrap (the new currency) to update your car, a hideout or climb the skill tree that is available for Max. Fight your way through hordes of enemies, either with your shotgun or barehanded. The combat system is a little like the one from the Batman Arkham series. So a little simple, but works quite good for me. And it feels somehow a lot more realistic than in Batman. Infiltrate hangouts, race wild sand races against some quite tough opponents, do little side-missions, collect relicts of the past...and so on.Graphics     9 of 10I LOVE it! From the sandy dunes with the beautiful sunsets to the starry bluish nights. Absolutely amazing. My friend is playing it on a 4K tv screen and it's just amazing .The footprints in the sand, the incredible storms, the water. BIG thumbs up. And I might say it’s graphical wise quite a competitor for Fallout 4.Music          8.5 of 10 The music is generally quite soothing and somber. Very fitting for this post-apocalyptic world.The part where it really shines is the sound of the car engines. You really feel the V8 engine roaring. Final Verdict 8.5 of 10 A great game based on a movie. The graphics, the music and the gameplay form an overall nearly perfect game. Why nearly? Sometimes the fighting is a little repetitive and the taking of the hideout as well and the story is not that breathtaking. Still I strongly recommend it. Rarely has any games atmosphere sucked me in that much.

Posted: November 5, 2015
												Mad Max is probably the single most, 'I'll just do one more mission - still playing many hours later' game ever. Time vanishes. What you thought was maybe forty-five minutes, was four hours. I think part of the reasoning behind this is because it's repetitive in every way. I am surprised it doesn't get more criticism for this. Everywhere just about looks the same. The camps which you clear are all similar. Scavenging destinations are all similar.The really only parts that are not all similar are the main missions. However there are not many of those.Mad Max has other issues too. The engine-exhaust noise of the car is diabolical. I wear headphones and it screams albeit mid pitched (not high pitched) almost all the way through. I play on speakers too and it's as bad. Only later when you get the V8 engine is car noise acceptable.It is unfortunately nothing more than a long grind, and is possibly the grinder of all grinders. Salvage scrap, unlock upgrades, use scrap as currency to upgrade. From start to finish that is all you do. It has plus points. It often looks good. Bosses are all the same technique: wait for charge, dodge, attack for a bit; repeat. In other words there is no googling every boss encounter because you can't work out what to do. Gameplay is straight-forward. In fact all the gameplay is relatively easy. It's filled out by there simply being masses of it.Although I mark it 7/10 I could not in all honesty say to a friend, "You must buy Mad Max". Meaning no recommendation. However if you are fully aware of its format, you will have fun maybe half the time playing it.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												9/10I, like many others, was poised to be disappointed by Mad Max.  The ridiculous pre-order deals (I got it for 36 dollars at GMG), and the publisher connection to the recent Arkham Knight debacle had me worried I'd wasted my money.  I've never been so wrong.  This game is:1.  Fully functional from the start.  No stuttering, no texture pop-in, no frame-rate cap or issues, no glitches or bugs.  The optimization is the best I've ever seen for a AAA launch title - I was able to play at reasonable FPS at 4k with one GTX 970.2.  Achingly beautiful.  I said I was able to play at 4k, but I didn't have to because the game is so perfectly crafted that it looks suitable photorealistic and jawdropping even at 1080p.   Special emphasis on the lighting, shadows and particle effects (the explosions are phenomenal).3.  Raging fun.  The melee combat is smoother, harder, and way more engaging than in Batman: Arkham.  It requires attention and quick reflexes and feels intense and deeply powerful.  The sandbox world is massive and filled with violent activities.  The general goal of these can get repetitve towards the end of the game, but the devs did a marvelous job of making each and every location look and feel different to keep the excitiement to the MAX.  One issue here is that the boss fights at some of the camps are more or less identical.  There are four main strongholds that can be upgraded and expanded through what are essentially fetch quests, but still just as fun and varied as the story missions.   By far the best part of the game is the vehicle combat, analogous to the recent cinematic masterpiece Mad Max: Fury Road.  Along with random open-world encounters, there are convoys around the game world and you take them on singlehandedly using not only your car as a weapon but shotguns, harpoons, thunderpoons (grenade harpoons), and flamethrowers.  These convoy battles  get progressively more intense as the game progresses, and are a highlight of the playthrough. 4. All about the cars. They could've totally screwed it up and made a Mad Max game where the cars were a sideshow.  They did not.  Basically the entire plot centers on Max's desire to be reunited with his Interceptor, and in the meantime to build the most outrageous war machine possible with the help of his master mechanic hunchback companion Chumbucket.  Throughout the game you upgrade your car (The Magnum Opus) with body styles, engines, suspension, tires, exhausts, armor, weapons, custom paint and ornaments.  You can also collect any car you find in the wasteland for further use.5,  A sonic experience.  The car sounds are gloriously rabid, and each engine and exhaust mod makes your Magnum Opus all the more ferocious.  Play it in 7.1 surround and the vehicle combat comes alive, with earblasting explosions and roaring v6 and v8 thunder.  Voice acting for the main characters is sublimely realistic and emotional; wish there were more Australians in it though.6.  An unsatisfying story.  For me, the ongoing love story between Max and his Interceptor was enough, but they added a few mediocre plot devices which were inconsequential and didn't improve the game at all.  May have been better without so much story.7. A true addition to the Mad Max canon. This is a faithful and yet inventive new venue for Max.  His character is portrayed just right, with minimal dialogue and just enough haunted memories to make us believe we're really Max Rockatansky.  Visually, he's a hybrid of Mel Gibson and Tom Hardy, and his upgradeable clothes and weapons are legit and very cool to use and look at.To conclude, I finished the main story at about 25 hours of play, I've put another 10 in so far to complete the car upgrades and clear out enemies from the world.  The average player will probably get 20-30 hours out of this, but being a massive fan of Mad Max I'm not even close to leaving yet.  I recommend it to both newcomers and fans of the series -  its an action sandbox tour-de-force.  Enjoy.I would buy at $40 or less.

												Did you like Tomb Raider? What about RAGE? And possibly Batman? If you like all of those three games then why are you even reading this...go get it NOW!!! This is a game with a likeness to all three IMO. It has the same look and feel to Tomb Raider with very similar game play experience. You have plenty of neat little underground worlds to explore and if you dont want to go underground then mix it up like the Wombles did and go overground too. Why not try driving up to some deserted places like a crashed plane or sunken boat or deserted train stations and trains in the hills or far out in the desert. The combat is very satisfying with excellent effects and even better noises and bone crunching sounds. Visuals are fantastic on a high end rig. It has the same satisfying RAGE effect when driving a car. As in, you can blow stuff up...a lot. There are some great little upgrades you can add to the Magnum Opus car. These include flames coming out the side, spikes on the body to prevent enemies jumping on and boarding, a powerful shotgun, harpoon and rocket launcher (in essence) and some normal body and engine upgrades. You can have so much fun with the harpoon pulling building structures down, ripping wheels off cars or ripping a man out of his car and dragging hi, around like a rag doll! Combat and sound is very similar to Batman and the way it feels. Overall this was such a surprise for me this year and is easily in my top 3 games only behind GTA V at the moment. Wonderful experience and I am still no way near complete with 40 hours of game play! 10/10

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Releasing a movie tie-in game usually goes one of two ways: either it’s a rush job thrown out with the movie to get some quick bucks, or the developer actually has the time it needs, regardless off the potential loss of income because of a later release date. Thankfully, Warner has allowed Avalanche the time to make a solid, vast open-world that is a lot more fun than the colour palette might suggest.And there is an enormous amount going on in Mad Max; just so many systems operating at once. You can upgrade Max, or his beloved car, The Magnum Opus, whenever you like from the pause menu with scavenged scrap (the currency that runs the world), but there are core abilities that you can only level up using tokens received from completing challenges. These are the important ones, really, as they increase things like Max’s strength, or health, or even how long a full tank of fuel might last. But you can only upgrade these at set locations. They’re not hidden and are on your map, but it’s a little odd to have a conceit like this in play when there are so many moments that flaunt how gamey it is.Take Max himself, for example. Once the car takes a certain amount of damage you’ll have to get out and wait while your companion, Chumbucket, fixes it up. But the enemies don’t care, and will keep coming at you. The AI here is quite smart (elsewhere they will expertly dodge you as you drive around engaging them), and will just try to drive right over you, but if you have a decent amount of health, you’ll stagger a bit but not die. After a few dodge rolls and a bit of running round in circles (get used to doing this, by the way), you can jump back into your ride and get moving, harpooning a Wastelander out of his car to certain death.These moments are as stupid as they are cathartic. The way you can take damage is obscene, but all is forgiven when you enter slow-motion, harpoon a guy right in the chest and tap circle to quickly pull him from his vehicle, whereby he whips towards you, which lets you ram him head-on. The harpoon gun is a triumph, and the most Avalanche thing here. Driving around firing it into sniper towers and pulling them down never gets old, and the sniper rifle mechanic is interesting, too. Rather than giving you a sniper to run around with like the shotgun you have, it’s fired from the back of your car. Chumbucket can drive the car for you (though you control it) and you can creep up to enemy bases, slowly picking off their snipers. Again, it never gets old.Thankfully the wasteland survival ideas are well implemented. Water is scarce, sure, but most of the time you’re in a situation where you’ll need to use it to heal, it’ll be some kind of stronghold (small or large) so there will be a tap, or pool to fill up your flask. Gas is needed to keep your vehicles running, but it takes a while to use it, and again, tanks can be found at populated areas. In a nice touch, you can put a spare canister in your boot just in case you run your tank dry, but you can also pick it up and throw it at enemies, exploding it with a shotgun burst.The combat is the Batman Arkham melee method that, quite honestly, I’m nowhere near tired of. Mad Max’s world is a brutal one, and although you can happily pummel away at combos with the square button, and counter with triangle, things are mixed up with the addition of unlockable extra moves. A particular good one (early on) is simply to hold the attack button after two hits for a strong finisher. You can pick up weapons and integrate them into your move-set, too, and if you’ve collected any shivs you can finish people with them. Or, should you buy the skill, you could just get in close for a shotgun to the gut – it’s a one-hit kill, obviously. It makes for a violent, bloody system that feels damn good.Car combat is less successful at first, but not bad. Depending on how upgraded your vehicle is, you can use the harpoon to differing degrees of success, but you can also target the red barrels in the trunks to quickly blow them up. On top of that, another option is to simply ram into your enemy – which has varying degrees of success depending again on what you’ve spent your scrap on. There’s a lot of car combat, though, and the slow motion aiming is a Godsend that removes most of the frustration. But you’ll have to get used to it, as you’re a sitting duck if you leave the Magnum Opus for too long.It’s a very a-typical open-world game, in many ways, but one that’s faithful to the source material, especially when it comes to the characters. Max is an utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ but a badass with it. No matter what people do to help, he’s never nice to them. You could argue that this is because of the harsh, barren world he inhabits – everyone here wants to kill you, or use you for a deal. But the character you warm to the quickest is Chumbucket, so it’s hard to hear Max continually abuse him with his negativity. The voice acting is fine, for the most part, but the downtrodden, gruff Max is a little hard to like. It’s a very comic-book like universe, and the people are designed to match: burnt skin, tattoos, and even one guy who has razors cut into his skin – I’m not sure if that’s for effect or so he can keep his face beard-free.What Mad Max does best, however, is never, ever take itself seriously. The opening cut-scene (which I won’t spoil, obviously) is over the top, but also features a gruesome chainsaw scene. As you take control for the first time and realise the person in that scene isn’t dead, you realise exactly what kind of game this is. There’s no logical reason how he can be alive after what you saw, but there it is, and he’s the main antagonist you’re fighting back against.The story is generally fine, but nothing special. Most main missions see you have to chase something down and take someone out, and although there’s an attempt to make you care now and then, it falls flat. The fun is to be had just exploring, maybe getting caught in a horrendous storm that nearly takes your life.Technically, there are a few frame-rate hiccups that are seemingly par for the course with open world games, but otherwise the only way Mad Max suffers is because of the source material. Fire, sand, metal – the trifecta of the world. You can’t blame Avalanche for keeping to that, but it does sometimes make for a bland looking game. There are some excellent moments, though, like those storms, or when night is setting in and it gets cold. Particle effects and explosions are fantastic, and there’s a real sense of style despite the brown look, especially when it comes to the gorgeous sky.Mad Max is a fun game. You’ll happily lose an hour or two here and there, and feel great about it Nobody quite does that open-world charm like Avalanche, and the harpoon never stops being a source of mirth. The combat is great, and if you’re after an open world third-person title, you could do a lot worse.Pros:Harpoon gun is brilliant.Visually stunning at times.On-foot combat is great.Cons:Story is a bit dull.Car combat won't be for everyone.My Rating: 7.5/10

												Mad Max is the dirty big trashy sister of the Mordor series, it plays very similar to Shadows of Mordor minus the Parkour, but that isn't really a bad thing.  The game itself plays mostly without any hitches,  I had a few minor issues and one random crash through-out the entire playthrough, whilst I wouldn't say this game is perfect by any means and does get repetitive after a while, but it is something worth playing if you enjoy post apocalyptic open world driving/fighting games. Personally, I would have liked to have more varition of the activities and more bases to conquer, but for the the price I paid it was a really good deal for the amount of time I've spent playing and enjoying the game.    Now, there are some points to be made here, the game does have glitches and bugs, especially with defense which sometimes significantly bugs requiring you to reset equipment to get the stat 'working' again,  and the cars handling sometimes is strange - very easy to spin-out or lose control of the car and crash into one immoveable object in a large open world...the game loves to do that for some reason.Because of the cars handling, I'd really recommend playing this on a gamepad, especially the driving portions of the game which make up a large part of the game.   Overall, I still recommend this game even though it has a few short-comings.

 I was able to finish the main story on the lowest settings possible on these specs:      CPU: Intel Core i5 3210M     RAM: 8.00GB Dual-Channel DDR3      Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 4000                     2048MB ATI AMD Radeon HD 7600M Series  Plot  – First of all the game is not directly connected to the movie even though being released on the same year. Max’ ultimate quest is to reach the Plains of Silence, a fabled land where he might find solace from his madness. But instead, he finds himself getting his V8 Interceptor stolen by the War Boys of Scabrous Scrotus, Immortan Joe’s third psychotic son. With the help of Chumbucket, a blackfinger, Max embarks on a journey to get his vengeance and take back what is his.The main plot and some scenes may be predictable to some, or maybe even a cliché to at least. But it doesn’t mean it’s bad. In fact, I personally enjoy the story all throughout and I’m pretty satisfied with how the story went.  Gameplay  – The game showcases two types of gameplay. First off is when a vehicle, the gameplay is somehow similar to Vigilante or the Twisted Metal series. Though you have the option to use other faction vehicles, nothing is compared to what the Magnum Opus, your own vehicle, can offer you. Other than the harpoon, sniper rifle, and the thunderpoon, you also have the freedom to customize your vehicle the way you want it to. And it is actually balance and just. Not because you have all the high-tier upgrades, it doesn’t mean it’ll be the best vehicle out there. No. And that is actually great in my opinion. And the upgrades can actually be seen in the vehicle, you can style the Magnum Opus any way you want it.Second is when you’re on foot. If you have played any Batman Arkham games, you’ll most likely be familiar with how this game works out. And this is one of the most brutal games I may have played not just because of the blood, but because of what can Max do to his enemies. I’ve been hearing multiple cracked jaws and bones everytime I beat someone and it is very satisfying. I have mentioned that there are upgrades for your vehicle; well there are also multiple upgrades for Max to help him out in his fights.  Environment and Design  –  The whole map is huge, at least for me. To be honest, I am more than surprised to see how amazing the world is. Sure, in a rough glance the world may seem too flat or bland. But wait until you start exploring side quests and maybe just roaming around. There are lot of stuff to see in this game.  Controls  – I’ve played this game with a controller, I feel like it would be easier beating up enemies and driving the vehicles with a controller instead. For problems, I’m glad that I didn’t run into any major ones to ruin the game for me. Though there is a thing that may become annoying to some as you progress through the game. Most of the time, the game will require you to hold the interact button or key for you to take action. It gets annoying because you will be doing it a lot of times.  Conclusion  – I may have finished the story of this game, but there are still numerous areas undiscovered, many camps aren’t looted yet, many towers not yet taken down, some snipers are still hunting. If you’re interested in games that still offer something even when the main story is done, then this one deserves to be in your wishlist. Even with the fps that I’m getting, I really had fun playing this game. A fair warning to those with OCD, when you’re in a camp, the game will show you the total scraps there is in a specific camp or area. And guess what, I used YouTube twice on two different areas just so that I can achieve a 100% on that specific camp and move on to the next one.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												“Only the living and the dead now. No egos.”Mad Max is an imaginative action-packed open-world experience. It feeds on the mythology left behind by George Miller, and it successfully brings the Wasteland to gaming, both visually and spatially. Racing and race-battling has never been so dynamic and thrilling, and melee combat is as polished as a combo-oriented gameplay could deliver. The core of the quest design revolves around upgrading a "mystical" car named Magnum Opus, and delving into revenge against Scabrous Scrotus, the archenemy who initially assaults Max and his Interceptor, leaving the drifter for dead in the hot white desert. Thematically, pride and an apparent sense of dignity are still present in the narrative. Max refuses to eat “long pig” (basically, cooked human flesh), and instead feeds on maggots from human carcasses. Thirsty wanderers can be given precious water from the protagonist’s canteen, and a feeling of gratitude is promptly served. Stronghold upgrade projects raise the morale of the inhabitants, and their impression of Max. The Wasteland is represented as a place suited for brutality and survival, but also hope – albeit often romantically portrayed.As regards story and plotline, there is not much to be said. Well, if you are interested in everything Mad Max, you probably know that a complex and foregrounded chain of narratives is not the franchise’s emphasis (especially if considering the latest film). The game follows that premise. What it does offer is a myriad of apocalyptic motifs, from the re-domestication of nature, to the emptiness of Earth’s post-nuclear shell, to the nostalgic grief over a long-dead world. Such motifs could inspire much more immersion were it not for Max’s always-melodramatic lines when collectable pictures from before the fall pop up. Additionally, the figure of Scabrous Scrotus is forgettable at best, and just a sootier and bossier version of Rictus Erectus.  The final battle against him and his petrol-powered retinue is underwhelming, a poor attempt at reproducing the famous Mad Max ending road skirmishes that ends too quickly thanks to the almost indestructible state of late Magnum Opus and the surprisingly reduced amount of hostile vehicles. Apart from that, a few tragic plot twists, unique writing and dialogues, and creative cutscenes might somehow redeem some of these negative aspects in writing. Characters are often tragicomic representations of eschatological personalities: they are usually on the edge of their beliefs. A fume-induced sadist, a pyromaniacal prophet, a bloodthirsty tyrant, a delusional road rider. Hope and Glory show little promise from start, and never actually manage to entice any significance or emotional attachment from the player, even towards the end. Chumbucket’s permanent company may intimidate the player at first, but with some time, they will find that his persona is an inseparable part of the game, an inseparable part of Max’s quest. There were moments when I was driving along in an enemy car and caught myself missing his very personal remarks about the landscape, the Magnum Opus, the dangers around, about everything worth remarking about in the Wasteland. The rest of the characters are interesting and colourful individuals that show precisely how they have survived the wretched world for so long under those sorry conditions, exhibiting perfect doses of leadership, insanity, and sarcasm.There were some other wee things that I could not avoid feeling annoyed by: no matter how you approach the open world configuration of the game, you will never complete a task only once. Be ready to scavenge repeatedly, fight repeatedly, rescue and explode repeatedly. Repetition is not necessarily a compulsory aspect in the exploration of the map, and it may not be a problem for completionists, but it is there to fatten playthrough time. Also, ignore what the first shots of the game tell you about the scarcity of Max’s basic resources: there will be plenty of them, more than enough to get you by until the end. You will most probably never run out of water or fuel if you look decently enough. Scrap can be an annoyance, but only if spent away carelessly or if the urge to scavenge seldom arises during your gaming sessions. The structure of quest design is much standardised, oftentimes a list of identical objectives to be ticked off one by one across the available map, until the quest is finally over. Although this works in perfect unison with the background story of these quests, it does not help much to have that layout, considering the game’s already repetitive nature of open-world tasks. All these aforementioned things – good or bad – are not even close to expressing precisely how much fun I had playing Mad Max. Only when you hop in the Magnum Opus, build it up little by little, and scavenge the entirety of the massive game world, will you feel that the hours you spent were worth it. However, I have to warn those who are not fond of open-world "collectathons" to think twice and watch some vids before getting hold of this game.
