												So far I am only about 10 hours into the game so I will update this as time goes on.I must first say: This is NOT a console port! (the PC version was made in house by Avalanche alongside the other versions)... AND... This is NOT a movie game! The game was being made before Fury Road was even in pre-production some 4+ years ago, with rumors of it being made going as far back as 2008. This is a "Mad Max" game, meant to be its own thing in the "Mad Max" universe.This is how you do new game I.P.A mix of "Burnout" racing and "Twisted Metal" meets "Carmageddon", with "Batman Arkham" fighting, "Shadows of Mordor" multiple approaches, and "Just Cause" series open world fun, all in a post apocalyptic setting.This is an ACTUAL open world game! Not like GTA V was where you had the "illusion" of an open world until you did a mission and they only allowed you to do a mission in a certain way and you would fail if you did it any other way than how it told you to. Nope, in this game you get an objective and can accomplish that objective in any way you want (within the limitations of the terrain of course). You want to sneak into an enemy camp the back way and take them off guard? Go ahead... You want to snipe the camp from a mile away? Go ahead... You want to crash your car through the front gate and blow up everything in sight? Go ahead.Oh yeah, this is the first game in a long time that doesn't have "regenerating health" so you actually have to watch your health and start to worry when you have run out of ways to replenish it... Now it can be annoying at times, but it adds certain urgency to fights and exploration much like older games did back in the old "med kit" days, and it really fits with the Mad Max setting.I love the upgrade and customization system. Pretty much everything can be upgraded or customized, character armor, character stats/perks, main car "Magnum Opus", weapons, and allied bases/forts. I have to mention the car upgrades! I absolutely love the way Avalanche did this! Instead of just having incremental upgrades where the best car is always the end game fully upgraded car, all vehicle upgrades have benefits and drawbacks, so if you want a light and fast car you have to go with less armor, or if you want a tank of a car you will have a slower car. You can build the main car "Magnum Opus" any way you like to fit your play style.You don't even have to be a fan of the Mad Max movies to get into this game since this is NOT actually a "Movie Game" but more a game somewhat based on a Movie franchise, considering this game was in devlopment long before "Fury Road" was made, and George Miller actually helped with the initial outline of the game.And the writing is spot on! It actually creates characters I can care about, gives them their own personalities instead of the usual "un-interesting NPC #20". Lot of little bits and stories out in the wasteland to add a much needed depth to the game world, and I can't help feeling this is like a post apocalyptic "Red Dead Redemption" at times, and that is a good thing for me!.Speaking of the game world... All I can really justify is "WOAH! Holy crap!" If you like exploring, or taking screen shots, or games that are so amazingly detailed that you actually stop to admire the scenery, then Avalanche studios has done it again! They even included a photo mode... My screenshot folder is quickly filling up.I have been having so much fun just driving around and exploring that I have not used the fast travel feature at all.As for technical issues... This is one of the most bug-free, completely optimized, good looking, smooth running, Max settings running above 60fps stable releases, I have seen for the PC in a LOOOOOONG time!*****EDIT*****FInally beat the main story and side quests at about 30 hours. (there is still tons to do and explore even after finishing the main and side stuff) I wish it was longer because, well, I was really into this game and didn't want it to end (seriously Avalance, give us more areas and cars and upgrades! Add the Citidel and Bulletfarm and Bartertown please!). I'm already going to do another playthrough. And the ending! OMFG! This game IS Mad Max!I LOVE IT!This is one my new favorite games of all time!What a game! What a lovely game! Witness me! Optimized, shiny, and chrome!

Posted: September 1, 2015
												After playing for 30 hours, Mad Max is everything I hoped it would be and then some. That being said, I have a hard time understanding why reviews have ranged from the 5 to 8.4 range. 96% positive reviews on Steam means gamers have spoken for themselves. With a cool combination of Fallout, Borderlands, Far Cry, and Just Cause, Mad Max has stunning visuals, engaging combat in-car and on foot, and a great variety of characters. While I haven't found the story particularly enthralling, it is still fun. The open-world environment, however, is where this game truly excels. As I head towards an objective, I frequently find myself distracted doing other things, such as disarming a minefield with my trusty dog Dinki-Di, clearing out a camp, or being ambushed by a group of enemy vehicles. It is these types of fun distractions that make Mad Max shine. Everything in this game is upgradeable. Fortresses can be upgraded to give Max refillls on Fuel, Ammo, Water, and Health. The Magnum Opus has millions of possible combinations, from colors and insignia to the body, to engines and other parts. These upgrades make a noticeable difference to the feeling of driving the car, as well as to the way it actually sounds. Max himself can be upgraded in two ways: by visiting Griffa to enhance health or a variety of other attributes, or by adding armor, etc. that gives Max a boost in combat.I have not found the bleak, postapocalyptic landscape to be repetetive or dull. The graphics are extremely high quality, espcially with Nvidia SLI and AMD Crossfire support right out of the box. The sky and weather visuals are fantastic, especially when a tornado or huge sandstorm occur. Additionally, these storms never seem to be the same, with some looking like the lightning/tornado from Fury Road while others look like a sever haboob in New Mexico.There are some things I have not enjoyed about the game, and which I feel should have been included right out of the box. Despite his reputation as a road warrior, Max is not able to jump over simple obstacles. While he can jump, he will often need to find the predetermined route into a stronghold, generally marked by yellow paint. Something else that has bothered me is the low quality of graphics in Jeet's stronghold. Avalanche seems to be going for a rising heat effect, but the result is blurry textures. Despite these flaws, the game is still very satisfying.Driving is an absolute pleasure. As you upgrade your Magnum Opus, you won't want to fully upgrade everything. Putting a heavy ramming bar or armor on your car, for example, will lower your acceleration and handling, making the car less nimble. Upgrading your engine, tires, or suspension will have the opposite effect.Hand-to-hand combat is both gritty and brutal, with Max using objects in the environment to beat his opponents to a pulp. Fans of the Arkham series will be familiar with the controls, but the combat still has a unique feel to it. Anyone can button mash their way through this game, but there are huge rewards for using the special combo moves available to max. Players who take the time to learn and practice these will find their satisfaction with the combat increases greatly. Additionally, Max can build up a fury meter to unleash Fury Mode, which greatly enhances his attacks and allows for special Fury finishes.Mad Max doesn't break any new ground in the saturated open-world genre, but it is a rich, immersive game with fantastic graphics and satisfying combat. Reviews have been quite varied, but if you are looking for a new game to play, listen to the gamers themselves and pick up a copy of Mad Max for PC.Verdict: 8.9/10 A few flaws diminish the experience somewhat, but this is still a AAA title worth investing many hours into.

												I started off playing this game with a lot of suspicion.Due to the fact it's barely been marketed, I assumed it wasn't going to be anywhere near "fun". Turns out I was wrong, thankfully.Let's start off with the story; I've always thought that the Mad Max franchise would work best as a videogame, it just has that "weirdness" and exaggeration that you only find in popular game franchises. This game certainly proves--to me at least--that I was right in this belief.You play as Max (obviously), a guy who has some mental issues (though not really hinted of much). In the first hour or so, your car gets stolen and you are left for dead. Thankfully, you come across a "Black Finger" (mechanic) called Chumbucket. He's a little weird, to the point of sounding like a religious nut towards Max and the car, he even makes one liners towards... urhh... 'romantically' loving the car!Anyway with Chum's help, you set out to seek revenge and take your car back. The whole storyline is pretty much "We need a V8 engine to proceed". While it's simplistic, it works fine. Let's just say that the ending is quite obvious though.The fighting system is pretty much what you'd expect in this day and age from an "open world" action game. It's very much a Batman Arkham system, though not quite as refined (more realistic, for example you're not jumping around the screen to keep your combo going). I had some rare instances that it wouldn't even register my key presses (using a gamepad).There's not much else to say about it, it's pretty much as you'd expect from such fighting systems now days.It's the car that is the hook here.Using the various upgrades available, you can customise both the functionality and cosmetics of your vehicle. Like to go at high speed straight into people? Focus on acceleration, top speed and your ram. Like to get close? Make sure to get spikes to help prevent boarders.While there isn't a massive amount of upgrades, it's still enough to keep most people interested. Vehiclar 'fights' are quite fun, much more so than the repetitive Batman Arkham fighing anyway.The area you're in is a very, and I mean VERY, large section of desert.It would take you anything up to 10-15 minutes to drive from the furthest points, depending on your vehicle's upgrades. Doesn't hurt that the game is somewhat nice looking too.It has the 'Sync Points' that the Assassin's Creed franchise introduced, but with a twist. Enter a balloon and slowly assend. Now instead of just seeing a cutscene and that's it, you have to find everything with your binoculars. It's an interesting mini-game at first, but soon loses it's welcome.To unlock upgrades for your car, you need to affect each territory's THREAT level. This is done in much the same way Just Cause 2 did; take over camps and destroy stuff. In this case, you're killing snipers, finding and defusing landmines and bringing down 'scarecrow towers'.There's 3 territories, plus a no-man's land. Each territory has it's own set of the above things. A couple upgrades require to complete side missions too.In each territory, you have a 'stronghold'. Do side missions and collect required 'parts' to unlock projects. I'd suggest to always build the Cleanup Crew projects as soon as you possibly can. It's a godsend! Projects include health, ammo and water (which is like your 'medipack') refills.You upgrade Max in very much the same way as the car.Instead of territory THREAT levels, however, it's your 'rank' that unlocks items. Right off the bat, you should purchase the crowbar; it's required for a lot of looting. You can even get Max to grow a beard, if you're into that.Scrap is everything in Mad Max, so make sure to loot destroyed vehicles (Cleanup Crew project is useful for this) and camps whenever you can.You'll need scrap to level up Max, the car and fully upgrade your Strongholds.Lastly, do not rush through the main story.You likely will not enjoy your time playing if you do; instead try and work towards uprading Max and the car as much as possible before moving onto the next territory. Various story missions require you to grind anyway, so you may as well do so between missions!Mad Max is a game I'd recommend to both fans and non-fans of the franchise alike.You don't really need to know anything about the franchise due to this game being a standalone from both the original and recent reboot of the movies.HOWEVER, I'd suggest you wait until a sale of 30% off or more before purchasing due to it's repetitive nature.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
tl;dr -> I have Fury Road's "Escape" and "Brothers in Arms" looped while I play. 11/10 I am the Road Warrior, the Wasteland Batman, the Chosen One.Note: Link to my full review[theroguereviews.com] because I hit the word limit here.I have always been a lover of post-apocalyptic themes in both games and movies, and I was extremely excited to learn about the Mad Max open-world adventure game - especially after being a fan of the entire Mad Max franchise (Road Warrior is second only to Fury Road for me). The gameplay looked a lot like the styles seen in games like Assassin's Creed (AC) and Batman Arkham, series that I absolutely adore. I was and continue to be thoroughly satisfied with my gameplay experience.If you enjoy open-world action and adventure, RPG elements, intense car combat, post-apocalyptic themes, gritty visuals, and the Mad Max franchise (especially Fury Road), then you will love this game.For full disclosure: my top game of 2014 was Middle: Earth-Shadow of Mordor (SoM), and while I will readily agree that there are much better quality and more in-depth alternatives available, I found SoM to be the most fun; it truly captured the essence of why I enjoy playing games and losing myself to immersion. Mad Max is very similar to SoM for me, in terms of fun factor and enjoyment. I completely understand that people may not like games like this - finding them too repetitive - however, I will do my best to provide an accurate and fair representation of the gameplay you can expect to encounter if you buy and play this title; but please keep in mind that I may still be biased in my review. I would also like to quickly point out that this game is NOT a simple copy-and-paste (or "reskin") of games that I have previously mentioned - such games are definitely formulaic, yes, but they are not direct copy-and-paste titles.The aesthetics are fantastic - the amount of detail in the environment, character/car models, and special effects is extremely high. Optimization is amazing (so long as your drivers are up-to-date), ensuring that you are receiving the best possible performance while you play (admittedly, I was a bit worried about this PC port following the poor launch of Arkham Knight). The special effects are beautiful - car explosions are massive and bright with pretty fire (moving close to fires will cause the world color to take on a more orange hue), the lighting and shadow effects are realistic (the glare off of your car lights at night time is a sight to behold), and storms are majestic (I implore you to brave a journey into the heart of one once you have a stronger Magnum Opus). The music and sounds are great, however, do not expect to hear any of the tracks from Fury Road (sorry, no "Escape" or "Brothers in Arms" playing while you fight off enemies); the game's soundtrack is still very good. Following the lore established by Mad Max: Fury Road, the story is interesting and engaging - although nothing too special (much like Shadow of Mordor); I will admit that a few times I have skipped cutscenes and/or ignored dialogue.Controls are not difficult to familiarize yourself with, especially if you use a gamepad and have played game series like Assassin's Creed or Batman Arkham. Unfortunately, you cannot rebind the controller keys, and you can only remap a limited amount of actions on the keyboard - this is definitely something that could have been improved for player convenience. As a result, you cannot easily call up the keyboard controls - in fact, I had to check the discussion boards to find out how to bring up the full map (on the keyboard, it is "Tab;" I thought it was "M"). There is a series of tutorial missions that will quickly get you accustomed to the gameplay. The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with open-world adventure games in this vein. You will encounter difficulty with mid-to-late-game main missions if you are not exploring and completing side objectives - this is the "grinding" aspect of the game that helps you build experience and obtain upgrades. This element is seen in other games like the Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham series (as well as Shadow of Mordor), so if you do not enjoy that style of gameplay, you will probably be dissatisfied with Mad Max. The "boss" fights are fairly easy, especially if you are keeping up with your character/car upgrades.Gameplay consists of you roaming the wasteland, with your final destination requiring you to first stop by Gastown. The road to Gastown is a brutal, dangerous one, so you will have to first gain more experience and upgrades in neighbouring territories, which are each ruled by leaders that you will meet and help. Each territory is split into smaller pieces and littered with different landmarks like enemy outposts/camps, scavenging areas (for delicious loot), and race meets. Balloons in each territory can be taken into the air to mark important areas, as well as reveal the surrounding land in your map (this is similar to climbing the tall vantage points in SoM and AC). If you do activities that directly affect the enemy - like liberating camps or disarming minefields (the latter being extremely boring) - it will reduce the "threat" level of the entire territory. Reducing threat ratings will result in decreased enemy patrol frequency and presence, making your travel time through the area quicker and less painful.Main missions progress the story, usually unlocking more of the map and allowing you to obtain better upgrades for your Magnum Opus (your beloved car). In contrast, upgrades for Max are tied to your "Legend" rank, which is increased by doing mostly anything - like destroying enemy vehicles with your shotgun, achieving high combo chains, or killing x amount of enemies; there is no actual "experience points" system. Whenever you complete these "challenges," you will obtain a token that can be exchanged for an ability point, thus allowing you to level up. Each Legend rank (the top being "Road Warrior") is composed of multiple sub-levels, and obtaining a new one will grant you more upgrades for Max like appearance, ammo capacity, and physical damage (all accompanied by nice aesthetics). Combat is extremely fluid and responsive, albeit quite easy (as is the case in most of Warner Brothers' open-world action-adventure games) because of the counter prompt that appears over the heads of enemies about to attack. Something that balances the ease of countering/parrying is how the button input works - you cannot simply mash the attack button because each attack is a commitment, so if you are already doing an attack animation, countering will probably not work (encouraging you to be patient with your commands). Furthermore, countering right before an attack lands will execute a "perfect parry," which will help build your combos faster and even allow you to disarm an opponent's weapon (further enhanced by Max's ability upgrades). ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue ReviewsMy Website[theroguereviews.com]

What a real sandstorms!... I can´t remember better processed video games sandstorms. Maybe in Spec Ops: The Line, but in Mad Max sandstorm appears randomly in two variants.5. Ride. What a rough ride! ... feeling of riding is really enjoyable. Not only in Magnum Opus.6. Combat system. What a brutal combat system! ... simple but effective. You know his older and better brother from Arkham series.7. Visualization. What a sexy visualization! ... nice graphics, effects of explosions, mentioned locations. After 15 hours of gameplay, Mad Max caught a second wind, gets momentum and simply will not let you go. Despite the fact you´re doing the same thing all the time.I´d like to support devs by purchase upcoming Just Casuse 3. They deserved it in times of terrible console ports.

To survive, you will steal anything you can need from your enemies, kill them, and if necessary, you will eat maggots of their corps to survive. Law and rules are invalidated in this world. Those who wants to survive, will need a strong Will, and a highly customized car. It will also happen a lot that you will have to fight with your fists. In fact, Max is the good guy in this world, but it feels like that he is the baddest guy around... If you like opne world games with racing elements and a lot of explosions, then Mad Max won't be a bad choice at least.DE/ Ein gelungenes Open World Spiel im Mad Max Universum. Zum überleben stiehlt Max von seinen Gegnern alles was er so gebrauchen kann, tötet sie, und ggf. isst er Maden aus deren Leichen um zu überleben. Gesetze und Regeln sind in dieser Welt außer Kraft gesetzt. Wer überleben will, braucht einen starken Willen, und ein aufgemotztes Auto. Schieß die gegnerischen Fahrzeuge mit Raketen (ist zwar nicht 100% akkurat) ab, oder angel den gegnerischen Fahrer einfach mit einer Seil-Harpune aus seinem Fahrzeug, oder oder oder, es gibt so viel Möglichkeiten die gegner außer Gefecht zu setzen. Es kommt auch sehr häufig vor dass du mit deinen Fäusten zuschlagen musst. Eigentlich ist Max ja der gute in dieser Welt, aber irgendwie ist er auch der bösartigste.... Wer Open World Spiele mit Rennelementen und vielen Explosionen mag, macht mit Mad Max zumindest nichts falsch.JP/ マッドマックスの世界観を舞台にした中々に出来の良いオープンワールドゲーム。生き残るために主人公のマックスは敵さんから使えるものは全て頂戴し、そして殺し、はたまた必要であれば敵さんの死体に湧くウジ虫を食べたりもする。法やルールといったものはもはや存在しないこの世界。この世界で生き残るには強い意志と、ハイレベルに改造された車が必要となる。敵をロケット（紛い物だがｗ）で撃ったり、敵ドライバーを縄銛で車から引きずり下ろす等々・・、敵さんを倒す方法はそれなりにあります。拳だけを頼りに敵と殴り合わないといけない場面もかなり用意されています。本来主人公のマックスがこの世界のいいやつ役なんだろうが、場合によってはこの世界で最凶最悪の男にも見えてしまう。本来オープンワールドのゲームが好きで、それに加えレースや大量の爆発といった要素が好きな方であれば、マッドマックスを購入することにより損をすることはないと思う。Pro/良い点+Good graphics/グラが良い。+Large open world/広大なオープンワールド+Can be obtained relatively cheap/比較的安く手に入る。+A lot of different ways to fight with your car/車を使った戦闘で多様な戦い方が出来る。Con/悪い点-Relatively repeatative missions/比較的似たミッションの繰り返しが多い。-No coop or multi player/コープやマルチプレイが出来ない。-The main story is rather short. The game lives from the side quests/本編は比較的短く、サイドミッションに生かされてる印象。Example for In-game performance/パフォーマンス例Win10 64bitGTX 1070i7-6700k16GB DDR4 RAMAt 1080p, max setting: FPS 120 - 144. Most of the time constant 144. (144hz monitor)At 4k DRS, max settings: FPS 50 - 70It uses round about 33GB of your SSD/HDD space.

"I'm not crazy... I'm just mad"═══════════════════════════════════Mad Max, the critically acclaimed movie franchise, now has it's very own video game, and it's a really good one too!Mad Max is a post-apocalyptic action-adventure game, with a heavy emphasis on vehicular combat, in which the player takes on the role of eponymous character Mad Max═══════════════════════════════════Short SummaryNow, when you first think about Movie-Based video games, they're often not that good (Rambo for instance. good god that was a trainwreck). But Mad Max is nothing like that. Mad Max is an absolute gorgeous game, let alone it's optimazation is great aswell, the combat is extremly fun and the driving's fun and action packed. So witout further ado, let's review this bad boy!Pros: Story is great, immersive and really lurs you in, as Max is on his journey to find his beloved car and to find some solace.The charachters are really in depth, and has their own stories and journeys.Cutscenes are well made The game's gorgeous, one of the best Wastelands i've seen in a videogame. This game is like a mashup between Fallout (Exploring locations and scavenging for supplies) and Sleeping Dogs (Same combat system, and there's an emphasis on car-to-car vehicular combat.) Lots of customisation available, starting from Max's armor and jacket, to his haircut and facial hair. there's also an incredible range customisations available for the Magnum Opus, max's signature car along the game. Great SFX and voice acting, really gives that atmospheric feeling to it. You won't run out of thing to do! there's  alot  of activities and side quests to do. Combat system is really simple and great. Well made upgrade system. you can shoot ROCKETS FROM YOUR CAR!Cons: What would seem like a big surprise for a game that is so focused about driving and cars, there's no handbrake!The ending is really anticlimatic and short, and it just sums the whole fantastic story really badly (in my opinion of course). glitches oftenly occure, although most of them are minor and not that big of a deal.So, the final rating i give for Mad Max is -  9/10 For me, Mad Max is one of the best, funnest games i've played and is on my Top 5 Games of 2015.Heavily recommended, especially when it goes on sale for  20$ .

												After managing to purchase for only £10.45 instead of the £34.99 pricetag and muddling through the graphical settings to fix the slowmo this game has been a delight. Posted: September 5, 2015
												TL;DR - 2015's Game of the YearI'll start by saying that I knew nothing about Mad Max before jumping into this game. From what I can tell, I didn't have to. I didn't plan on focusing on the story anyway because I was purely looking for gameplay. Holy ♥♥♥♥, did it deliver. If you thought Rockstar put a lot of detail into GTA V....Avalanche put more thought and care into this game than Rockstar could ever dream of. (for example, when you're looting an area it will tell you when everything has been looted and if you're missing anything. As someone who plays games to find EVERYTHING, this made me very happy). First off, it's an amazing port (as long as you have updated drivers) aside from the menu controls on keyboard/mouse. They seem to have their querks, but it's nothing too bad. It performs great and I only encountered one crash and that's because my drivers weren't updated. The audio struggles a bit on Windows 10, but it's nothing major at all. The combat is very Arkham-ish but that's okay with me because it works and it feels good. I personally didn't even expect hand-to-hand combat, but there you go. The driving will take some getting used to; at least until you get your car upgraded and then the car handles beautifully. The vehicle combat can be a bit tricky early on, but here's a tip - level your harpoon as often as you can. You'll use that more than anything else (at least I do). There's plenty of map to explore, too. At the time of writing this review, I'm almost 9 hours into the game and I have only done roughly 4-5 story missions. To conclude, this game is beautiful and you should get it at all costs. My only problem is that Warner Bros. were involved with this game...but thank you, Avalanche, for another great title that IS NOT broken. I'm looking at you, Arkham Knight...

												I stand on top of a burned hill, watching the sun move across the sky. The sound of motors fading in and out in the distance, a zealous hunchback rambling on in the back seat of my all important four-wheeled conveyance. I wait for the sun to go down over the course of minutes, pondering the vast wasteland before me. It’s a quiet and peaceful moment, which is striking in a game filled with screaming war boys and magnificent explosions. Sometimes the best parts of an open world game come between missions, when the mechanics and controls fade away and you are just in a new place beautifully rendered before you. Mad Max has its flaws, but its wastes are highly suited for wandering the roads in search of excitement, and the game does a great job of gradually making the player understand the titular road warrior.Want to know more? My full review is now up for all to see over at TechRaptor! http://techraptor.net/content/mad-max-review-praise-angel-combustion

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												It is a hell of a ride. The game is definitely more than the sum of its parts, and it can be pretty rough in some parts, but man, what a damn ride.The game's on foot combat is pretty much just doing a Batman/Sleeping Dogs thing. Not as fluid as either, and somehow less brutal than Sleeping Dogs's. It gets old. There are nice ways to avoid it, since  the shotgun is pretty much a "end this fight" button,  and while the ammo for it is plentiful, it is scarce enough that you are encouraged to save it for  big fights. It is always great to reenact the swordfightning scene from Raiders of the Lost Ark, but just like in that movie, you can run out of projectiles at the worst possible moment. The driving is a VERY big part of the game, as it should be, since this is Mad Max we are talking about. The environments are pretty distinct  from each other, which makes travelling a pleasure. The bad part comes that for the  optional races, you generally get to use a completely different car that handles unlike your custom rig, and it gets a bit hard due to not being used to the handling of  the race cars. 	Vehicle variety also suffers, since it feels like the factions each have the same cars, but with cosmetic differences.The convoys start as an interesting activity, trying to replicate the feel of the chase sequences on the films, but unfortunately they fall flat after a while, since the experience is repeated over and over, though it gets easier when you get more tools at your disposal.Funnily enough, the closest I had  to a chase sequence from the movies was in an optional "wasteland mission", where you have to drive a big, slow  truck with resources to a relatively far away point. That felt a bit like the final chase from the Road Warrior, but not quite the same, obviously. Apparently, if you reduce that area's danger level, there would be very few enemy encounters in that mission, which is an interesting detail, there were scripted pursuers  AND ones drawn dynamically from the regular area spawns. Enemy variety is kind of lacking.  The factions each have similar archetypes. And the "top dog" fights are unfortunately, not unique. All the top dogs  behave the same, which gets fairly old. They are optional, but it would be  neat if there were differences in them besides what comes in their arenas. The strongholds and bases are quite fun to explore, often having far more going underground than what you can immediately see above ground, they  feel like puzzle platformers at times. The game is by far the prettiest of the open world games I have played. Which makes the  use of the picture mode (shared with Shadow of Mordor) a  VERY welcome addition. Both are ridiculous eye candy and worth  absorbing.The  main story itself feels fairly aimless at first, but the set of endgame missions are ramping in intensity greatly, they are honed to a point. It ends with both a bang and a whimper, but be warned,  this is Mad Max. This is not Road Warrior. This is not Beyond Thunderdome (even though it has a tacked-on thunderdome), and even though it looks a bit like Fury Road, this is not Fury Road at all.The tone  and pacing is more like the original than anything else. And it manages to hit almost as hard as that one did.	Maybe even more so, because of the interactive nature of  games.There are many things that could have been better done, but for what it is, it is an amazing ride. If you have  a chance to play it,  do so. It might surprise you.

content:
Posted: March 26
												All the mechanics work great, but this is a prime example of a game that is too big, something the developer Avalanche Studios, creators of the Just Cause franchise, seem to do a lot in their games. While Just Cause has many different methods of travel, Mad Max has only one, drive. The driving is good, it has weight behind it and the car combat hasn't been done anywhere else, but the enviroments are typical Mad Max large open deserts. Thats not to say they're bad enviroments, a lot of effort went into the world design, the entire map is vertical despite being one big desert. You start in the ocean bed and make your way up sand dunes until eventually you're driving past church steeples submerged in the sand. But at the end of the day, they're still open deserts, with the only things populating them being ubisoft icons; 100s of scavenging locations (to upgrade max and his car), dozens of camps and a massive amount of destructable collectables. The game could've benefitted from a smaller game world. The gameplay loop of exploring/fighting, getting scrap and improving max and his car (which has nice aesthetic and stat increases) is really great at short bursts. I haven't even left the 2 large ocean areas yet, since I just pop on for an hour and play until it peaks my interest. Story is alright, obviously not the focus, but I would've liked to see a bit more effort after Fury Road's decent attempt. Again, it's one of those 'Ubisoft' styled games where there're only 10-20 actual story levels in the game intermingled with outposts and repetitive side content. On foot combat is great, although it is essentially Batman Arkham's combat. Get the game if you're going to play it in bursts, otherwise it'll drive you mad.I'd probably give it a 6/10. Above average and worth a glance but the fact that I can't get myself to properly sit down with it and play for an extended amount of time on account of it being too repetitive means it's not an all-around 'good' game. If you want something similar but executed better, try Shadow of Mordor, the Batman Arkham games and Just Cause. As I said earlier however, the car combat while underutilised is definitely unique.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Mad Max is a game set in a world where careless waste, political terrorism, and general public unhappiness was permitted to boil over into full out rage, leaving the world a scarred, barren wasteland.The world of Mad Max, is completely different, from the world you and I know. The world you delve into in this game, is ruled by violence, governed by strife, fueled by crude oil, gasoline, and rig job cars built for war, and the only living one does here, is a filthy, misserable, dry-mouthed and perpually starving one, but in this world, simply being alive is a luxury few can claim to own. In this world, a car is required to be anyone or anything, including alive, and nothing but death, and dry bones await those with no car to carry them over the seemingly endless dunes of sand, which have long since covered the unfortunate would-be's who tried to survive before them. Money is worthless here, little more than tinder. The only thing people care about here, the only thing one could safely call 'money'. Is scrap metal. Piles of it, things used to create more cars, and therefore, more survival.The game is set in an obscure area in future America, seemingly in an old refinery town long since lost to the sands of sorrow. The only thing still standing, and furiously customized to grow to a sorry, pathetic excuse for a community, is Gastown, a large refinery that still stands and pumps gasoline, natural gas, and oil from the ground below at reckless speeds to fuel the governing group of lunatics, psychopaths, and bestial, carnage worshipping madmen: The War Boys of Scrotus. Much of the game happens in the southern outskirts of this town, a small 'oasis' that, upon arrival in it, seems more like a cruel joke, this area is a small space in the middle of what seems to be an endless expense of send dunes, extending for as long and as far and as unforgivingly constant as the eye can see no matter how high into the sky you go(with airballoon included). Wastelanders and Madmen alike refer to this ocean of endless death and barren dryness that surrounds their homeland as "The Big Nothing", and is routinely referred to as the place desperate people go, not to seek a better life, no matter what they themselves think, but to die. Some rumors say that the oceans which used to fill the entire area, which receeded many many many years ago, still recide far far beyond the Big Nothing, and if one survives the trek across it, they'll be rewarded with a sight of an endless ocean, stretching as far, if not further, than the big nothing, a never ending blanket of pure blue. Many have tried to seek this, and have never been heard from again, which only spurs the rumors on.Gameplay:First of all, yes, this game is an open world action RPG game with a garnish of crash car derby style gameplay.You play between driving and on-foot exploring most of the time. Long-range weaponry like handguns or rifles are a thing of the past, and extremely rare. Few rifles exist, and even few small arms. The only shotgun seemingly in existence for hundreds or thousands of miles around is Max's own.Driving is by far the most entertaining, but also the most difficult, requiring some driving skill depending on what surface you drive on, what tire type your car has on, and how much armor you wear(Cause armor is heavy and might make you stuck in the sand!). Car combat is a fine-tuned dance between excellence, and complete failure, it is almost impossible to be 'sort of successful' or 'sort of failure'.On foot is more straight forward. Mad Max is not just the name of the game, but also the protagonist whom you play. He is indeed mad, and is prone to bouts of uncontrolable rage towards those who attack him, sending him into a state the war-like factions call 'Kamicrazy'. He is, despite his lunacy, extremely skilled at hand to hand combat, and is capable of downing dozens of manic enemies with little effort(Assuming you're good at the game).The game has lots of content, many side missions, and countless things to do and see in the world. From lowering the presense of the incredibly powerful and horrificly aggressive faction called 'The Warboys of Scrotus', to progressing the main story of helping Max rebuild his lost 'Black on Black' car, which he loses in the prelude to the game's beginning. A new car, which he begins to build with the help of his newly found friend and ally, Chumbucket, the hunchbacked 'black finger' super mechanic, who knows little more than twisted, gas-combustion based religion, and making engines go vroom and wheels to spin. This car is named by Chumbucket, and is named 'The Magnum Opus'. Foretold by Chum to become 'faster, stronger, and better in every way, than the black on black, filled with holy purpose.'Graphics:Note that these graphics are based on a powerful 4k gaming rig with a GTX 980ti graphics cardThe graphics are appropriate for the game, requiring not much in the way of fauna or foliage since no plants seemingly exist in the world, anywhere. There is just dust, rock, and crude oil oceans made up of saturated sand. The graphics can be good, without being crazy, and still look amazingly detailed and more than adequate for giving a very realistic, very high caliber experience. Based on what I can tell, it appears that a lower grade rig could play this game at lower settings than highest/max, but it's always a good idea to google 'can I run it' and see what that says about your chances.Sound:It supports 7.1 surround sound, which is pretty flipping wonderful. I wish more games did. It gives an extremely realistic settings that makes you feel like you're standing in the middle of it. Of course you'd need 7.1 capable headphones, which mine are. Other than that, there's no desyncing between the voices and the animation of the mouthes, and the sound quality is very high, from both voice actors' skill, to the sounds taken for engines, and metal grinding against metal.Final word:I'm sure all of you want me to answer this question: "Do you recommend it or not!?" And yes, I absolutely do. I have little to nothing bad to say about this game. Extremely well executed, extremely well put together, an overall victory of considerable magnitude for the developpers responsible for this fine-polished diamond of a video game. If you like steampunky, violent, bitter and gorey messy games that takes unbearable living conditions, and makes them the norm for human survival and living style? Then this game will surely scratch that itch for guzzoline guzzling, oil burning, oil slicked finger licking car games that many of us have.I, for one, have been absolutely addicted to this game for the past 4 days, and I see no end to the game yet.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Rating: 8/10Overview: Open World RPGSimilar Games: Batman Arkham city/Knight, Shadow of Mordor,The Good+ The wasteland is beautiful yet deadly, it feels massive and empty yet there is plenty of things to do. Driving over sand dunes while the sun sets, exploring desolate locations,races, liberating camps, story and side missions etc. The first time you experience a massive sand/thunder storm is pretty amazing, you can either seek shelter and wait for it to pass to try to survive it and collect massive rewards. Things like that only re-enforce the perception that the wasteland is tough to survive in. The wasteland is a great example of how good art direction and design can take a seemingly boring environment and turn it into something special. + Scavenging locations and liberating camps throughout the wasteland allows you to collect scrap which can then be used to upgrade your character or your vehicle the magnum opus+ Lots of different challenges to complete, completing challenges grants you special tokens which can then be used to further upgrade your character. + Car combat is a big component of the game and destroying vehicles feels very satisfying. You can destroy enemy vehicles in a variety of ways. + Chumbucket, your loveable yet strange hunchback sidekick. The most interesting and fun character in the game. + Incredibly well optimized, plenty of graphical options  + Lots of side quests, collectables, missions, races etc that are varied and provide a nice distraction from the main quest. + Great soundtrack and sound effects. The Average:The combat is a shallow version of Rocksteady's Batman games. There isn't enough gameplay mechanics or depth tied to the combat so the majority of the time you are only punching or parrying attacks with the occasional dodge. Even when you upgrade your combat skills, it doesn't feel like much has changed. Parrying an attack isn't instant so many times you will be in the middle of an attack only to be punched/charged from behind. This is further aggravated by the camera angle which is zoomed in to close to the character making it hard to see where all the enemies are.   The story is decent but nothing really special either, it doesn't stand out but it gets the job done. The game is fairly easy especially if you are accustomed to the combat system. I never found the game to be challenging.Some annoying  glitches, nothing game breaking but every once in a while an enemy will disappear through the floor, characters getting stuck etc. If you want to do many of the optional quests, it can start to feel repetitive....like most open world games. The Bad:Boss battles are all the same which is a shame because there is so much potential here. Conclusion:A fun game that is great if played in short sessions. If you love a collect-a-thon, then you will truly love this game. The good news is you can skip many of the optional stuff and stick to the main story and still have a good time.

												Real life Australia simulator: A giant wasteland desert full of criminals and vegabonds where everything can kill you.If you like the films, or just enjoy fun open world games you will find a lot to enjoy here. A welcome feature in a world of games which release unfinished.

 Summary: Mad Max is a collection of a variety of strengths and weaknesses that range all over the spectrum, and it really comes down to what kind of gamer you are. The game's strengths comes in short play sessions of an hour as the car combat is great with the use of the Harpoon, and the strong characterization of Chumbucket as he comments about what's going around you will keep you interested. It's got a great variety of level design, and the PC performance is exactly what you'd want for a PC game in 2015: It runs smooth and can get the best out of the top-end systems. But on the flip side, ground combat doesn't play to its own strengths as the camera becomes a major problem in the counter based fighting, and frankly, the game has a lot of repetitive elements to it and can really feel like the gameplay has been extended to the point of breaking. You get your moneys worth, but in the end, Mad Max is the perfect game to get on a discount: there's nothing that forces your hand to get the game right now. Gameplay Footage and Video Review: 


YouTube™ Video: Mad Max (PC Review): The Gods of Combustion 

			Views: 361		

			Mad Max has been getting scores all over the place from outlets, and the question is: is the game right for you? It's definitely all over the place in terms of quality, and the question of whether or...		

 Lists: +: The car combat is reasonable, with the harpoon being fun to use on almost everything. In fact, just the Harpoon alone at times makes for some chaotic fun. Chumbucket, the mechanic, shines as the most interesting character by far, with his religious devotion to automobiles and his excitement about all things combustion. Base Level Design keeps things fresh over the long haul. Reuse of elements are done in a way that it never is noticed.  The world is beautiful in particular with the sand locations. Character design takes advantage of the license in terms of visuals and voice acting.  Power comes in the name of upgrades, and opens up combat and options to a considerable degree. The amount of hours you can get out of the game is high and has a bang for buck. -: Missed story elements that really could have taken the game to another level, overall the narrative is poor and doesn't do well with the license. Ground combat doesn't have enough variety to it, and doesn't understand the strengths of the system in place. The camera is a major problem.  Focus on “realism” can hurt the game at times, with it hurting gameplay pacing in terms of naturally taking advantage of the open world.  Repetitive nature of tasks really becomes more of a chore. While there's a lot to do, there's a lot of the same thing to do. Ending actually fell a little bit flat for me, despite others liking it. Very minor.

												Everyone's already probably heard that Mad Max combines elements from Far Cry 2 & Batman Arkham, while being the spiritual parent to Borderlands. I liked all of these games, but the combat and cars reminds me the most of the excellent Sleeping Dogs. Gameplay is solid. On the ground you can hold your own but you're no superhero. Even the weakest enemies can overpower you if they are too numerous or your reactions are too slow. The best part is the cars. Three of the initial 5 car bodies are reminiscent of the classic Interceptor, so you can play the campaign in a heavily customized ride that "feels" right. Max's legendary set of wheels are automatically unlocked after completion of the campaign. Depending on your level of devotion to this world you can take your time with the story or just putter around exploring the barren landscape to hunt for treasure and fight bandits. If you are a completionist Mad Max could be a grind, particularly the vehicle combat. To accomplish all challenges, it is recommmended to avoid clearing areas totally to keep enemies spawning. Movie adaptation games are usually in the "miss" category of hit or miss, so I'm very happy how Mad Max turned out. Being fond of the original film & the excellent Fury Road made this experience all the more enjoyable.edit: 100% after 80 hours roughly.

												After putting 50+ hours into this game and pretty much doing all that I can, I have to say that it was worth what I paid. The reviews online that complain about all the fun things you can do in game seems to punish you and make you NOT want to play the game are from people who havent unlocked any of the upgrades for the most part. Yes flying off high cliffs or even small jumps will heavily damage your car when you first start. Yes slamming into cars full speed or walls will make the Magnum Opus explode fairly quickly as well. When enemy cars hit you from the sides or the rear yes you get damaged very easily.So what do you do? Play the game and start to unlock upgrades. There is alot to do in game from looting camps for scrap, car bodies, unique cars, and car upgrades. Alot of collectables that give history of the down fall of man and destruction of the world. The people you interact with are as they shouldbe all on the ragged edge no hope completly untrusting....at first. When you get to your first stronhold its little more that a hole in the ground with nothing to help you other than a place to store all your cars you start to collect. The first thing id recommed doing when you can start to upgrade your strongholds is seek out each of the parts required to make the, gas tank, water collector, ammo table (in some cases this will happen as you complete story or a wasteland mission), maggot farm, scrap pallet, and scrap gathering team.The various things you can do include races for Crow, attacking camps (doing this will put wastelanders in them that give you free scrap at diffrent intervals in game), wastleland encounters that range from intel on camps, to free scrap, Legenday encounters giving you much longer missions to do. On this not alot of the encounters are avaliable at the start many others will unlock as you do story and wasteland missions.Combat in your Magnum Opus is pretty stale at the start. Harpoon doors, rip them off, then harpoon the drivers, you can shoot the fuel tanks for instant kill, blow out the tires and ramming the cars is also another way to take them out. After you get the thunderpoon upgrade to blow up cars, upgrade the harpoon to rip the wheels off, get the flamers for burning the cars on the sides of you, and of course upgrade the bumper to do more ramming damage its alot more fun. When you get access to the sniper rifle you can only use it from the car but you can thin enemy ranks and blow up camp defenses pretty easily with it. I reccomend killing warcriers ASAP they make melee combat a real pain if the get everyone amped up increasing there damage and attack speed.As far as defense in the car goes adding body armor and boarding spikes is the way to go. No other upgrades in relation do defense.Ok on to melee combat. At first it will feel alot like just block, attack, block, attack, over and over......and it is. After you start to upgrade max you can truly get to having fun with diffrent combos, finishers, takedowns, usings shivs and melee weapons. Shivs break after 1 use, you start being able to only carry shiv, your starter shotgun only has one shot before you need to reload so only use them both when you really need to. After a few upgrades you can carry more shivs have a shotgun with up to 4 barrels and can carry many more shivs and alot more ammo. Suviving in the wastes and finding water is not TOO hard to get after you get your first strong hold up and running with all the upgrades along with fuel and ammo. You can get a full reload of everything about every 15 mins. After you unlock multiple strong holds you can jump back and forth to stay replenished very easily.The story is good and really starts to explain why max is so messed up mentally, hearing voices, and makes you really feel for Max. I wont go into what happens to ruin the story for you but it is well done.I would like to see some extra areas added to the game like Bullet Farm or the Citadel so mabey WB's will release some DLC's with them in it if we are lucky and this game does well. Thats my only real complaint about this game.Thats about it I hope you got somthing useful out of this review and enjoy playing Mad Max.

												After taking my time and completing the entire story of the game along with so many of the side missions, I can safely say that this is not a bad game and it is worth the purchase. However, I don't recommend it at full price.- The AI is very basic and very predictable, all of them are the same (including boss fights). So as soon as you learn the technique, you'll rarely ever get hurt from them throughout the entire game.- In terms of gameplay, you see everything there is to see within a few hours of playtime, aside from main story stuff.- Story isn't long at all if you remove all the filler missions they force you to take.- While the layouts of each camp are more or less different, the mission objectives of each camp are always the same.- You're apparently the only good guy driving around in the wasteland, everyone else is either bad or a straggler with info / side quest or beggar.- Your car is apparently a ticking time bomb whenever it's broken and if you don't get out within 5 seconds, it explodes, but if you do get out, your helper just fixes it back up and you can continue on your way... that is if the enemy that put you in that state don't just constantly run you over and not allow you any chance of dodging them since Max is ridiculously slow at getting back up and moving again once injured.- The NPCs in the game are so very afraid of the Sand Dunes area and always hype up the area to be extremely dangerous, yet it's much safer to hang out there than anywhere else in the entire game. Even the missions in that area are really easy.- Giving beggars some water seems to have zero effect to the game at all... even running them over with the car has no effect either. What's the point of having them in the game?- Apparently you're the only person that can save the world... or do anything at all in the game. Way worse than other games.- There is at least 1 known game breaking bug. There's a door that cannot be opened in one of the camps. You either have to do an extremely difficult stunt with your car in order to have a chance at shooting the oil pumps or you have to resort to cheating. For the record, I did the stunt.- Extreme weather events look awesome! But at the same time, they're stupid and they ruin the immersion of the game. By that I mean, the very second you go indoors, the weather effects go away, but if you stay outside and try to wait it out, it'll stay there forever (unless you drive through it). So if you trying to complete a mission and there's no way to go indoors, then you're probably going to die from it. I've also seen glitches where the weather effects continue happening deep underground.- Overall, I didn't feel like the game was challenging enough. The only time the game was challenging was usually due to the limitation of the game's mechanics or they just buried you in enemies hoping that will add some challenge.- I hated the ending too. It felt so rushed to the point where it just irritated the hell out of me. I don't even care that certain individuals died in the game even though I liked them... it's just how they died and how they rushed it all to happen so quickly. The story was only starting to get good and interesting and then wham! Stuff happens and the end, all within 20 minutes (that mostly includes actual gameplay, story is maybe 3 minutes?). But then, after the credits, you go back to your destroyed car and see ppl that should be dead but aren't... all as though nothing had happened. Talk about breaking immersion.There's probably many more issues I didn't like about the game, but you get the point. And yet I still recommend the game... on a good sale price, which is what I paid for it. The graphics are nice and run smoothly. The overall game isn't frustrating enough to get me to stop playing it. It's almost like playing something like Euro Truck Simulator... there's really no point to playing it, but you do anyways cuz it kills a lot of time and you don't mind spending that time on it. I doubt I'll ever play the game from start to finish all over again though.

Regardless if you’re looking for a good sandbox game, Mad Max will definitely deliver and while it’s not PERFECT IN EVERY WAY, it’s not MEDIOCRE as the reviewers are saying.

Mad Max is an action packed 3rd person game where you play as the legend, Max, with his holy chariot, The Magnum Opus, roared through the wasteland in this post apocalyptic dystopian setting where livestock are extinct, eating maggots, rats and canned dog food are a luxury, water is a rarity, and freaky petrolhead with suicidal tendencies roam everywhere. Posted: September 6, 2015
												Mad Max is an open world game that puts you in desolated post-apocalyptic world of Mad Max universe.The thing about Mad Max game is that it goes with a "play safe" approach to everything - from world and quests to mechanics design.There's not a one new thing in this game - everything that you'll find here has already been made in pretty much the same way by a lot of companies (say, Ubisoft's open world games).But don't take that as a bad thing. On the contrary - if you do like open world game, or if you like Mad Max universe - you might easily find yourself enjoying this game (just as I did).It's true - there's nothing new in it. But all existing things are executed so well, you can almost see the competence of Avalanche Studios oozing from every polygon.The combat is very similar to batman/shadow of mordor combat, but has a little less variety (again, probably because of that "play safe" approach).The towers from Ubisoft games were replaced with balloons that you don't have to climb, just fly up (they are pretty awesome vistas though).Camps are camps - you either have to kill anyone inside or blow stuff up to "capture" them. Sadly, that's all you can do with them, no additional bonuses are given from them.And that actually goes for most of the side activities - all of them feel kinda useless (unless you are grinding for that next car part).I wish Avalanche Studios had more time (or freedom?) to try and go crazy with this game - there's so much potential and possibilities of fun things in there.And then there are those little details everywhere - like burning send left from fuel flying out of your old car's exhaust. Or like storms (that are very rare), but damn terrifying to be in.Or like the explosions that looks absolutely gorgeous. And capture mode that makes exploding things and making screenshots very fun (I wish there was a way to get into it using a hotkey, not through pause menu though).Voice acting's pretty good too. Oh, and don't forget the optimization - game runs perfectly well on just about any config that's close to recommended one.So, to sum it up - if you are OK with your typical (I just can't force myself to say "classic") open world game in Mad Max universe - go for it. It's pretty good, just more of the same good open world stuff in another universe.Watch the video for more detailed look here:

Posted: May 10, 2016
												Depending on what you are looking for, Mad Max will bore you to tears or entertain you for 50+ hours.  The game blends popular elements from other games into a post-apocalyptic open world with a focus on driving.  Fans of Assassins Creed, Shadow of Mordor and the Batman Arkham games will feel instantly at home.  You have the Batman combat, but surprisingly more brutal and less "smooth", which I think works pretty well as you aren't a superhero!  You have an enormous map, which is probably the biggest I've seen in a game like this.  Finally, you have an abundance of collectibles and that satisfactory feeling when you completely clear an area  and have it marked as 100%.  The game certainly is repetitive, but fans of collectibles and upgrading will enjoy this game and that part of the game appealed to me more than the lacklustre story on offer.What makes Max Max stand out from the open world crowd is the use of the "Magnum Opus", a car that you will do battle in, upgrade and race over the entire course of the game.  There's plenty of choice when it comes to upgrading weapons, making the car faster, getting the armour upgraded and adjusting the parts for the task at hand.  I enjoyed this part of the game immensely and I don't even enjoy driving games.  A slightly boring story and repetitive gameplay will turn a lot of people off, but the game does shine when it comes to its driving mechanics and how it gives you so much to collect and explore in its enormous map.  Graphics aren't the most important thing, but I have to say that the game is gorgeous and managed to make a game that is mostly sand look breathtaking at times.  I highly recommend this game to people who like the games I have mentioned and perhaps those who were intrigued by the driving sections in Rage.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												Even though I haven't finished the game yet, I've seen enough of it to put my thoughts in writing.Mad Max is pure bliss.The first thing you'll notice is, of course, how absolutely gorgeous it looks. This is one of the best-looking games ever made, and it performs flawlessly even on middling hardware.The sound design matches the visual quality and enhances the wasteland's hostile atmosphere.Melee combat is heavily inspired by the likes of the Arkham series and Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, which to me is a good thing, but some may find overly simplistic.But obviously what sets this game apart from other open-world action titles is vehicular combat, and it's as fun and enjoyable as you'd expect from a game set in the Max Max universe. Your car - or should I say, the "Magnum Opus" - itself is a weapon (with which you can ram and grind enemy vehicles), but as you progress in the story you'll equip it with a grappling gun, a sniper rifle and a makeshift rocket launcher, making it the ultimate dispenser of death and destruction.There is, however, a distinct lack of motorcycles and larger, truck-sized "war rigs", such as the ones seen in Road Warrior and the recent Fury Road.Open-world games have been criticized lately for excessive reliance on inconsequential side-missions and collectibles, something that has been referred to as the "Ubisoft school of open-world games". Mad Max has side-missions, collectibles, strongholds, camps: the whole nine yards. But none of them feel like fodder. Every little place you visit has its own unique design and backstory, giving a sense of immersion that is sadly quite rare these days.Throughout your adventures you'll be assisted by Chumbucket, the horribly disfigured hunchback mechanic. I won't call him a sidekick because he's every bit as important as Max himself, and is really the heart of the game.And he's just one of many interesting characters you'll meet. Friends and foes are all equally well designed and voice-acted. It helps that the dialogue is great, too.Anyway, there's so much else I could say, so let me be perfectly clear and be done with it: this is not just a recommendation. It's a ringing endorsement.Buy Mad Max.

Posted: September 4, 2015
												So let's start off with the good bits.The port is very good, I can run this on high on my not-so-up-to-date computer quite smoothly, with frame drops only now and then which don't impact the game much. The animation is smooth, such as when Max swaps positions with Chumbucket, his entering and leaving a vehicle as well as the flow of his attacks just feels genuine. There are a lot of video settings combined with the fact that the visuals itself looks pretty good and the presence of rebindable keys is even better. However, there is no toggle aim for those who like it, though this game does not feature very much shooting in general which does not really impact the gameplay for me, despite my personal preference.Now for the bad points.The gameplay in general is quite stale and at times quite pointless. The ground combat is its weakest point, and I give it a 1/10. It largely resembles the Batman fighting style where you spam left click while waiting for counter attack indicators or non-counterable indicators at which you then just dodge. With the attacks, you have light and heavy, but most of the time you end up just spamming light attacks as you cannot dodge while in the middle of charging up a heavy swing, which means heavy swings are reduced to largely finishing off opponents or when there are no undefendable attackers. And in the end, regardless of whether there are defendable or undefendable opponents, it's still a left click spam fest with very little thought input. With an added note that boss fights are exactly the same, just one big guy instead of many smaller guys. One word: Tedium.The car combat was also quite uninspiring. It had potential, but the biggest problem was that it ended up being a Harpoon Simulator 2015... on land. Instead of harpooning fish or sharks, you just harpoon buildings and people (in cars and out of them). Ramming into other cars while driving is pretty difficult, while also taking substantially longer to kill opponents as opposed to just harpooning them; though damage greatly increases if you were to run directly into them while boosting. So the easiest way is to just harpoon the people out of the vehicles which leaves you to freely destroy/ram stationary vehicles which explode into meagre amounts of scrap. Now some general problems. Fuel is something that's used to run your car (obviously), and you'd think in a post-apocalyptic world it would be a very valuable resource... except it isn't when you can basically find an unlimited supply of jerry cans at every balloon fast travel point. Added to that fact that your car also does not even use up that much fuel when it travels, means that the extra jerry can in the back ends up being more of a door opener than anything else. Capturing camps generally has three objectives, blow up x things, disable y or kill z boss. And there's only two approach to all of these objectives, force your way through via the front gate with your car, or find a side hole to just walk through. Then basically the gameplay becomes all the same because you're forced into ground combat which becomes a tedium (as described above). There are also some pointless mechanics such as: spam x to break open door/crate, or, 'this door requires explosives' when there's a jerry can basically right next to you.Overall.There's no stealth mechanic nor grabbing attacks which forces a very linear gamestyle, your guns are more or less just there to do objectives rather than supplement combat flow, car combat becomes a harpoon simulation, while the concept of fuel as a resource becomes moot. If you like the Batman series fighting styled gameplay, then this might be for you.

Although you may see positive feedback that says "it doesn't matter" you should still think twice before buying Mad Max. I didn't finnish the game because of repetitiveness and cons below. The gameplay is designed the way that you should first do the main quests and then clear everything. If you do latter first, you can get the best car parts but some quests still require worse car parts which were also annoying. If you dont mind repetitiveness and can cope with the cons I suggest you get the game when it is in discount.

Posted: September 2, 2015
												To be honest i was sceptical at first, another movie licensed title hits the gaming world and i sincerely hoped that mad max would not join the rest of the terrible titles the post movie game adaption pile of death. Humbley and happily Mad Max will avoid being classified as another movie licensed failure but instead of one of the more successful and sound examples of not onyl a good movie licensed game but a good game in general.Mad Max seemed humble and a little slow at first, until i came across the major plot sequence and central focus of the game. Customising and building your very own wasteland beast. Not only do you get to customise a pre-existing frame of a vehicle, but have the option of many different vehicles, and on top of that many vehicle body, engine and wheel modifications, that combined in different arrangements make deadly combinations to tear other vehicles apart. This is without a doubt Mad Max's strongest feature, alongside its gritty and earthy combat system in both hand to hand and vehicular. The hand to hand combat feels viseral and real, hitting someone in the face with a wrench makes a satisfying sound, and a believable reaction. The vehicular combat, can be tough but damn is it satisfying, running a car off a road into a rocky out crop and see it break into pieces and blow into a flaming heap of spoilt chrome.Mad Max is a solid game, with a great level of optimization across the board, and great gameplay. Its only setback in my Lore loving eyes of the mad max world is its realtively weak Storyline and weak central protagonist, in both voice acting and overall appearance. All in all, this game is truly exceptional and i give it a high recommendation.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												I will admittedly say that because this game was inspired by a movie, I was half expecting it to be a flop... I was pleasantly proven wrong.This game provides a nice open-world experience with plenty to do and a fun combat system that makes running around doing things that seem tedious actually quite fun.The story is relatively minimal, and the way the game lays out your "objectives" leaves a lot of interpretation up to the player as to how you go about completing your missions. Many missions will have criteria that must be met for you to start (such as previous objectives, certain upgrades, etc.) that will force you to go out and complete tasks in order to earn those upgrades and progress further into the story.The game is based very heavily on driving, specifically, your very own car that you upgrade with you like a man and his dog. The car will become your primary source of combat, means of travel, as well as the ability to reach new areas. One aspect that I thought was pretty intuitive was the introduction of the fuel gauge-- that's right, your car has to run on actual fuel. At first, it seems like the fuel supply is low, restricting your ability to go anywhere and do anything, but there are numerous ways to increase the efficiency as well as find spare fuel all over the place (you can also get special projects in each stronghold that will give you an instant full tank), so I never actually had an issue keeping the tank full.The gameplay and the controls are pretty well implemented, following gameplay style like the Arkham series and Shadow of Mordor (both WB productions), and with the detail of Just Cause 3 (same dev). The only complaint that I'd have about the gameplay, is the jumping... your character can jump, but not more than a foot of the ground. You rarely have to use it, that it just seems like it's there to keep some semblance of realism. It's more of a gripe in that it somewhat restricts your ability to go "anywhere".The music is also very well set to the game, it provides an ambience that puts you right in to a savage wasteland with some creepy inhabitants, and never feels like it gets in the way.The menu system is pretty comprehensive but I will give a summary of my pros/cons that will address a few quirks I noticed.tl;drPros:+ Fluid gameplay mechanics+ Interesting combat system (both on foot and in car)+ There's lots of content that can be accessed before completing major missions+ Upgrading your car and customizing the builds are satisfying to your type of play (speed, attack, weaponry, etc.)+ Fuel is plentiful (you just have to be observant)+ Map and fast-travel system is very useful+ Engaging story and fun missions+ You can cheat in death runs (races)Cons:- The main side content is just different takes on the same few concepts (which can get repetitive quickly)- Finding large quantities of scrap is annoying- The game can "hold your hand" in places (look for yellow everywhere to indicate where you can go)- The menu interface can be annoying when you find a new part and you have to switch back and forth to effectively compare two parts (hood ornaments mostly)- The jumping mechanic is just fillerOverall, I had a good time with this game. Give it a chance if you like open world, combat focused entertainment.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												This game is fantastic. I have said that I will never again buy an EA exclusive title or an UBIsoft Port because of all the dishonest and incompetent things they have done in the past. Well, the door swings both ways. After Shadow of Mordor and now Mad Max, I will make it my business to buy as many Warner Brothers products as I can. Seriously, they show respect to the industry and this game is yet another living testimony to that fact. Avalanche studios (the developer) has outdone themselves and Warner Brothers (the publisher) had the respect of the industry to publish it in this fashion. Excellent work. So why pay money for this title? 1)	The design is conducive to the player having a lot of varied and dynamic fun. Driving, exploring, running, fist fighting, knife fighting, car rallying, hot-air balloon riding, sliding, talking, car upgrading, character progression…you name it, this game has got it. The best thing is, it all comes together seamlessly.2)	The detail in the world is amazing and the attention and respect of the lore is equally worthy of praise. You fight someone, there’s a complete description of how that character or enemy fits into the world. You see a base, landmark or resources centre, there’s a complete description of the site’s function and strategic significance. You pick up so-much-as a flash-light, and there is a complete run down of the object. Brilliant detail.3)	The dialogue and voice acting is top-notch. I have enjoyed the characters and cut-scenes in this game more than the film on which the game is based (and I loved Fury Road). The genius incorporation of Mad Max discourse and specific idiomatic terms makes you feel part of the world. 4)	The graphics are great. Not perfect but amazing non-the-less. The fire, explosions, and smoke effects are nothing short of brilliant. It runs on my system at 80 frames per second with no lag while running fraps and Xsplit in the background. Amazing optimisation.5)	The driving is extremely cinematic as the combination of graphics, sound design and game-flow produce extremely stimulating encounters. 6)	It’s a big game. You really do feel like you are embarking on an epic adventure and you are getting plenty of content for your money. Bravo to the folks at Warner Brothers. Bravo you amazing game designers at Avalanche Studios. The only criticism I can possibly muster involves the voice actor for Max. He does a truly great job but his voice is a little too deep. Seriously, that is as negative as I can get and I append the qualifier that the voice actor still does an amazing job within his scope of ability – not his fault he has a deep voice. Keep it up WB!

Posted: September 1, 2015
												1+ hours in and I can say the following based on progression through zone 1 - that's the disclaimer for peeps who want to know what $60 will buy at release.*Watch the cinematics; they're decently rendered and entertaining, at least the first time through.  Unless you're a twitch-monkey who just wants targets, you also may be interested in the plotline, and (so far) explain the point of each phase of the missions you perform.**The E key is your primary form of interaction; controls are not difficult, and can be remapped easily.1.) Linear progression as opposed to open world/WoW, where you can literally go anywhere you want, if you can live/get there.  This is in regard to advancing the plot.2.) You can explore the zone you're in to your heart's content, provided you have the fuel or want to run (and run and run...)3.) Combat is formulaic, rather than spontaneous, and at early stages you get key-hints to tell you "block" or use other skills.  Blocking nub enemies is only practice; you can just beat the snot out of them without defending.4.) Weapon use is not yet part of the game, despite possession of a shiv and a shotgun, except for shooting nub vehicles to 1-shot blow them up.  This is on the quest to get your new car.I'm having fun so far, but tbh, not $60 worth of fun.  I considered refunding the game on the basis of cost alone, but after 4-5 hours of download time, and the realization that I will want to play the game more, I'm gonna stick it out.At this very early view of the game, I give a 7/10 review, and expect that evaluation to go UP as I play more.  Review will be updated later on.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~21 hours in; I've owned this game for ~4 days.Madness.  Great game so far.  So good, in fact, that I've temporarily abandoned the storyline because mugging convoys for scrap is more fun than driving past them (i.e., letting them get away).  There's so many locations in the world, they seem almost endless in this stage of the game, and all of them are either NPC strongholds, lootables, destroyables, or some combination of the three.The game remains linear in terms of plotline, but in order to advance it (and enter new terrirtory) you'll want to have some side missions done/locations explored.  Scrap is how you buy up your gear, both personal and vehicular - thus, you need to loot, and kill stuff to loot.This brings me to the single down point I find in the game so far, unless I'm just not yet to the point where it changes: you can collect cars you defeat (unless they are destroyed) and bring them back to a stronghold for later use... but if you want to salvage parts from them, you have to destroy them on the road.  Funny how a whole car isn't worth much but the collector value, and a destroyed car is worth ~1/10 (if that) of the value of buying an improvement to your own car.The obvioius up side to this hitch is that you have ("GET") to destroy more stuff on the road.One thing that stopped me up at first was the enemy insignia in the camps; you destroy the Scabrous Scrotus insignia at these locations to 100% clear them.  Some are hard to find, and of those, some are too high to reach.  Thus, you need a shotgun shell (rare items, at first) or some other tool to destroy them when they're out of reach.  Have a shell on-hand unless you want to come back, but always look for the alternative - a thrown gas can, or an exploding spear, conveniently placed at various places throughout the enemy camps.Current evaluation of the game is now 8.5/10.  Good ambiance, great cutscenes (except the one for putting a gas can into your car... that one is getting annoying), good character actors and rederning, easy controls, well planned plot progression, and fun combat and adventuring, both on foot and in vehicle.XD ~~Great job, Avalanche!~~ XD
