												Superb addition to the Mad Max universe & a wonderful game.This game proves that a Warner Brothers produced game can be wonderful on PC. It's a solid PC port & that's good to say. Unlike the latest iteration of Batman this game offers virtually everything you want from a console to PC port. Full mouse and keyboard integration, endless graphical settings including refresh rates of up to 144Hz on multiple resolutions all the way down to 640p. The game is stunning to explore and enjoy & so far (10 hours in) it has kept my attention. While there could be more activities to do & the looting is somewhat repetitive at this stage, the storyline is as you'd expect from a Mad Max game. If you're familiar with the franchise, this game is a solid entry, not quite as rocking as Fury Road was as a movie, but very remiscent of that title.If you aren't familiar with the franchise, this game will open up the world of the movies to you. Oil is scarce, cars are becoming a thing of the past, they are weapons, a show of power, an extension of your last remaining remnants of humanity. Which is more important to you? Water or Oil? You're constantly reminded of this throughout the game as you are in the movies.It's an apocolypse that's all too real. It turns people insane & one which unsurprisingly could happen in the not too distant future.

												Mad Max finds himself stranded in the wasteland, his car wrecked and taken away from him: soon after he finds an unexpected ally in an exiled mechanic who thinks Max is the appointed driver to the car he dreams of building: you then set onwards trying to assemble said car so that you can finally get revenge over those who wronged you.Mad Max is a competent and quite fun open world game that truly succeeds in recreating the environments, characters and events that made the fanchise famous while providing an enjoyable mix of vehicular and melee combat: a few problems can instead be found in the cliched story, simple mission design, slippery car handling, paper-thin characters and some annoying bugs.PROS:-excellent design and art style: the wasteland really looks nice and has lots of small details, different enemy factions all have their own character models, armor, weapons and cars-the graphics, while not great, are generally done well and sport a good amount of detail in character and car models-good soundtrack, even though it feels almost too unobtrusive at times-Max's character is great and truly feels like a shell of a man driven by his sense of guilt-Max's car has alot of customization and upgrade options available, slowly rebuilding it in a force to be reckoned with truly feels like an accomplishment: if you want to mix things up a bit you can also steal enemy vehicles and add them to your garage selection-car combat is pretty fun once you get a few upgrades, combat on foot is simple but works well enough-great ending sectionCONS:-some unimpressive textures-certain 3d models for buildings repeat a bit too often-car handling feels too slippery, even an upgraded and armoured hulk of a car can spin out of control if you hit a small obstacle: this makes some driving/ car combat sections less fun or downright frustrating -mission design is very simple, most boil down to drive to a place/fight on foot/pickup an object or free someone with little variation overall-side activities get dull after a bit, while liberating camps by either beating everyone in them or blowing up certain objects is fun having to roam around to shoot a sniper/ tear down a structure/ clear a minefield gets repetitive quite quickly-some camera problems during melee combat, especially in cramped spaces: the camera autofocusing on certain explosions during vehicular combat can also make you crash since you can't see the road clearly-apart from Max and the mechanic most other characters are really undeveloped and just act as quest givers or cliched enemies-some assorted small bugs with a few flashing textures, cars disappearing and reappering in front of me, died once and for no reason when exiting my car, car engine sounds not working until you exit and enter again etc: nothing is gamebreaking but a some can get annoying

Mad Max is a very good game overall and I had fun in my 30 hours with it: the story is simple and cliched but engaging enough to make you want to finish it, the side quests are decent, car and foot combat are nothing spectacular but work and are enjoyable and upgrading my car to tailor my gameplay was something I really liked. Eventually all the side activities do feel like just some extra padding and get quite dull unless you're a completionist, but to be honest that's a problem with many open world games nowadays.The car handling is perhaps the biggest problem, I honestly thought that my car generally felt slippery and sluggish...slippery as in easily entering a spin whenever I hit an object as if my car was an empty eggshell rather than a fully armoured beast and sluggish due to its generally bad turning radius and bad acceleration (upgrades that add weight makes it worse ofc). But driving around and car combat, while suffering a bit from the aforementioned issues, do manage to stay fun and that's what matters: the only exception is a badly designed and unskippable car race where the handling problems come up pretty badly, thankfully some pointers on the forums'll help you making it more manageable.All things considered Mad Max is a pretty good game and one that'll last you for quite some time before the repetitiveness sets in and you decide to just finish the story: you can already find it for way less than its full price and I can easily recommend it if you're looking for more third-person action but want something different than Assassin's Creed.

Product received for free
												Let's just start off, it's another great game published by Warner Brothers.The game definitely gives a "Mad Max" feel and really matches the movies (from what I've seen) in my opinion. Fighting is great as ever. Pretty close (if not exactly the same) to Batman Arkham. When it comes to hand to hand combat, there isn't hordes of enemies to attack unlike Batman titles, but even with less targets it is still a interesting and exciting fight. Car functionality is pretty good. A lot better than the Batmobile in Arkham Knight. Granted, they're both really different but at times I had issues driving the Batmobile. Even though it is great, it still doesn't compare any Need for Speed driving, but not bad at all. Graphics are very nice in this game. I am running at "max" settings and have no issues what so ever. Even tested on a lower grade machine and even on medium settings, it looks perfectly fine and runs solid as well. Regarding story and the open-world aspect of the game. I would say that the story was very good, and really protrayed the sadness of this wasteland and kinda wanted to make me cry at times (perhaps I'm just a baby!). Not exactly sure where it falls into place with the original stories as for I've never watched them, but even from a view of knowing nothing about the story of Max, it made perfect sense and really left you the ablity to do whatever you want. Rather you want to wait on the main story and do side-missions or even other way around, it totally leaves the choice up to you.  When you first begin, you think there is a lot of places to see in the small area you are currently at, but then you look at your map and see the miles of miles of endless driving to the very top of the map, you think otherwise! That feature made it even better, offering lots of areas to explore and left plenty of room for driving or taking down enemy vehciales. There are only about 6-8 different kind of side missions which are spread across the whole wasteland of Mad Max. While it kinda gets to be repetitive, it can still keep you interested. I however see that once your car is fuly upgraded, there will be no purpose to playing.  Quick recap!Great game of Warner Brothers, fighting is awesome and intense, driving functionality is farily decent, story was great and open-world / side missions are enjoyable but also repetitive. There are a few minor changes I would have made to the game, but honestly...they don't matter as much cause they did great everywhere else in the game. So again, if you like Batman titles, you'll more than enjoy this game. If you like open-world game with a mix of Batman / Fallout setting, this is a great game to spend countless hours on.- Captain Price

												Let me just say this game is really not that bad. In fact , its the best movie-tie-in game  I've ever played which you really do feel like Max on a post-apocalyptic wasteland . My opinion about this game is like a tug of war and it really does have its highs and lows . Highs Beautiful setting - Although it really is a wasteland , it doesn't feel that repettive . The game developers try there best to make the experience of driving around the wasteland actually more entertaining with each region have a unique character to it . Alogn with change of weather and nighttime. Gritty Combat - Akrham-y combat mechanic without the cool gadgets and kungfu moves  . When your playing Max , the only combat experience is your two fists and boy it really does feel good suckerpunch a godamn war boy in face . World - If you like the crazyness of the franchise, then this game gives that same lust of insanity and madness that we all crave with specific tribes with there own culture and beliefs . Typical Mad Max trope to survive by scavenging scraps , food and water is also the main theme for this game.Car mechanics and Combat - The soul of this whole franchise and this game is the car combat . Its basically Pimp-My-Ride with your sidekick Chumbucket as xzibbit . Car Combat is as entertaining as it gets especially when you high tail a convoy all by yourself , rampaging through dozens of cars jsut to get that head ornament as the cherry on top of your sweet Magnum Opus . Story - This is probably in the middle but like any Mad MAx movie . It is kept pretty simple with a clear objective LowsThe Grind - This is the bad apart about customizing your car , to upgrade the best parts for it you have to start doing small missions by destorying camps and clearing the region which is a chore especially if majority are almost the same . This is what BREAKS ME for this game , its tiring &repetitive and I had to take a long rest from playing this game before going at it again . THE DOG IS USELESS - At first when I saw the dog at the first part of the game you'll be like " hell yeah , Dog partner in wasteland just like Road Warrior " NOOOOOOPPPEEEE . The only thing that dog does in this game is to sniff out mines and there is no reward other then clearing the region out of doing this . It is menial and boring as heck . Mini-Boss are the SAME- THroughout parts of each region theres a mini-boss camps for you to beat to get that sweet paintjob on your crib but my god is it boring . Each Mini-boss has the same moves , body and mask and it is repetitive and lazy which makes the game almost a cakewalk . Verdict Overall , its really not a bad game but for those who enjoy a collectathon with a same-y sandbox gameplay with added car combat and collecting while experiencing post-apocalyptic franchise then you would love this game but for me it felt like chore .

I intend to update this review when I have finished a more significant portion of the gameA quick and dirty review while the game's still fresh out the oven:I enjoy this game, I really do. It's not mindblowing, or perfect. But It's good. There's plenty of proven game mechanics in this game; from the setting to the fighting, everything feels borrowed. Yet the game doesn't feel tired or old, there's enough new stuff that you don't get bored. Game mechanics are married in some very clever ways, the game feels like a coherant experiance instead of the frankenstien's monster I was expecting. The general structure of Mad Max plays similar to Shadow of Mordor, with the large open map with plenty of enemies to encounter. Of course there's the Arkham-style fisticuffs. I get the same kick from this game as I did from Shadow of Mordor, I can play for 4+ hours straight- contstantly creating new little objectives for myself. Mad Max also runs stupidly well. It's been so long since there's been a port this good for PC, it puts abominations like Mortal Kombat X and Arkham Knight to shame. The game looks fantastic as well, it's incredible considering the desert landscape. I just can't stop taking screenshots!I could go into detail about the driving being solid, the slightly wacky control scheme or the tasty little novelties. But I think I'd just be dancing around the point: Mad Max is a solid game. If it looks like the kind of thing you'd enjoy you probably will enjoy it. It's a little rough around the edges, but there's a lot love.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												(Warning: much words, such tl;dr)To start I will say this: I like this game so far, there's plenty that's good about it.That said, I'm sure everyone and their mother will be posting reviews about why it's good while glossing over the negative bits (which might not be negatives for everyone, I suppose). So I'm opting to talk about what I don't like here instead.This is, of course, personal opinion, just because I don't like something doesn't make it bad.-----------------------------The on-foot combat mechanics... I believe someone said they are "reminiscent of the Batman: Arkham series". If by 'reminiscent' you mean 'practically torn straight out', then I'm inclined to agree. The mechanics aren't bad or anything, it's just kind of disappointing that they more or less copy/pasted the brawling instead of trying to make something a little more unique.-----------------------------Certainly a more personal gripe, but I find the open-world collectible-hunting to be very tiresome. People compare it to Just Cause 2, and I see what they mean. Problem is, I gave up on JC2's collectibles less than 15% of the way through finding them all because I got bored of basically looking for the same few things over and over and over again in a colossal playable area where it was kind of difficult to distinguish one section of the world from any other save a few landmarks here and there. I'm not even quite finished with finding all the things in the first main area of Mad Max, and it's wearing thin.-----------------------------The bosses. Good god do I hate the bosses so far. See, I always imagined that if a Mad Max game was going to have bosses, they would be awesome. Like, each boss would actually have tangible importance, each would have a unique look, voice, personality, specialization. Most importantly though, they would have an awesome mobile death fortress of some kind, and the showdown with them would include a huge running battle where you have to use all the tools at your disposal to pick apart their defenses one piece at a time while dodging smaller support and assault vehicles before finally delivering the killing blow.The vehicle for each boss would be unique and require different strategies, and the baddies themselves would have enough backstory that you'd know why they need to die outside of the usual "me good, they bad, they need go boom" deal. Finally, when you killed them, it would matter. Enemies that once served under that boss would be more likely to either run from you in terror or go kamikaze in hopes of a glorious death against a worthy foe. NPCs would tell (probably exaggerated) stories around campfires of how you took down some of the scariest dudes in the wastes like it was nothing.Maybe even have a sort of Crackdown-esque kinda deal where each boss provided some important service that strengthened the final villain you'd have to face, and each one you took down would make the final challenge just that much easier.So, what are the two bosses I've faced so far? Well...The first boss was a huge dude with a gimp mask and an oversized mace that attacked by charging at me and swinging said mace.The second boss was a huge dude with a gimp mask and an oversized mace that attacked by charging at me and swinging said mace... and he had a bit of paint splattered on him and there were some random goons and jets of fire.I honestly could not tell you what the name of either boss was or what they had to do with anything. For all I know, they had nothing to do with Scrotus and were just upset because I walked into their favorite BDSM club and started murdering everyone. Considering I seem to be at least 20% through the game, and the only bosses so far seem pointless and practically identical, I get the feeling I'm going to be fighting Mr. Gimp's several other identical twins in more-or-less matching uniforms before the end of the game.Perhaps I'll be pleasantly surprised by a unique and interesting boss at some point, but even so... it's a really terrible first impression, and it makes me wonder whether fighting the bosses is really going to be worth it.I'm not looking forward to fighting Mr. Gimp VI with his fedora, and his gimmick weakness that sounds like the devs just wrote up slips of paper listing every way an enemy can die, put them in a hat, picked one at random and said "Okay, so you have to kill this boss by performing shiv executions on him over and over again. Otherwise you'll have spend 3 hours whittling his health down with those shriveled mouse testicles you call knuckles".-----------------------------On the topic of things that are terrible, what I thought was a glitch during a boss fight, I now believe be be the result of a very poor design choice (though I might be wrong). Whatever it is, I hope it gets patched out.See, the first time I fought the first boss, I died after running out of shotgun shells and dodging at the wrong moment one too many times. I respawned right outside the boss arena, and was ready to go in and give it another shot... when I realized I had no shotgun shells, despite having had a full load of four when hitting the checkpoint before the boss. The boss, of course, had full health (I expected that would be the case). I thought this was just an awful glitch. Later, I was driving around and boosted at the wrong second in the wrong place, and died as a result. Before the screen confirming that I had, in fact, not survived falling several dozen meters popped up, I noticed that the game autosaved as my corpse burned in the wreckage.Now, I know nothing about the fine details of programming a game, or how save systems work. But I am thinking that what happened during that boss fight earlier is that I used up all of my ammo and died, and the game decided to autosave the state of my resources at the time of my death, then punt me back to the last checkpoint with the same amount of resources I had upon dying. Which would be expected if this was made by FromSoftware, but it's not. Having your head splattered with a mace only to resurrect a short distance away might fit the Dark Souls lore, but it doesn't really mesh with the Mad Max universe, I think. If you die, you're dead. Ergo, when you load the last checkpoint/autosave, it ought to be as if everything after that point in time never happened.(tl;dr plz fix autosaving on death so I can find something else to whine about)-----------------------------To wrap things up, I'm going to change gears and relay the most awesome moment I've experienced with the game so far:Driving to a minefield with the turdbuggy, dog in tow and only two shotgun shells on me.A wild Scrotemobile appears!"♥♥♥♥♥♥ Just what I need right now."Get in front of him, try to line up a shot through the windsheild, but the shotgun decides it wants to try targetting his rear left tire for some reason.Realizing that I'm going offroad, I look forward to avoid driving off a cliff or smashing into something.Barely swerve left to avoid ramming into a pillar.Weird physics stuff happens, resulting in the buggy spinning around a couple dozen times at mach 10 before landing in a perfect stop on all four wheels facing the exact opposite direction I had been driving.I instantly start aiming with the shotgun in hopes of killing the enemy driver, causing the game to go into bullet time.Apparantly, the baddie hit a bump and went flying through the air.The exact instant the game slowed down for aiming purposes, the Little Scrotemobile That Could torpedo'd the pillar with all the force of a great typhoon, resulting in what I can only refer to as 'what would happen if Michael Bay was directing a car chase scene for a Mission Impossible film after having gone three months without beating it to explosions'.There was much rejoicing.Ahh, if only the entire game could bring me that level of amusement...

												So... This is your typical sandbox as well as a literal one - you drive in a box across miles on miles of sand. And that is the game's problem. Sandbox games require lots of interensting or funny content. And it requires motivation. This game does have quite some content scattered around and if you count by numbers it's not bad, but the thing is, the map is way bigger. It is true to the series, lore, which is good, but not good for the game, especially, when existing content is not really that interesting. Besides, gameplay revolves too much around the car. Again - good for the lore, not so good for the game. Even though you have a goal, like to reach a certain place, yada-yada, in reality you still are doiong all this in order to pimp your ride. For me - it's not a motivation. This should be a side show and not the main dish.Technically, the game is not that bad. It looks good. Controls, even though a bit weird are fine. Although I am having issues with counter-attacks - it seems to be reacting with delay. ANd overall the quality of the game in general is good. If it was a linear game, a smaller one I think I would have been able to enjoy it, even though dialouges are like from the b-movies. Still, in sense, true to the origin.I am marking this as recomended, since Steam does not give us much choice, but I would recomend it to fans only. It does have a proper atmosphere. But if you are into sandbox or free-roam games... Well, you can try it on discount, but not sooner. Better play Borderlands then. They have sand and boxes, too.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
 TL:DR at the end, scored 8 / 10 as of 31st October 2015 Borba likes:Genre - Third person action adventure in an open world environment. Sporting on foot and vehicular combat, progression through upgrades and exploration,with repetitive side missions and objectives.Narrative - Being a fan of the Mad Max universe, the story was spot on and the characters were distinctive and interesting. The overall plot was somewhat unpredictable, although a bit short, and the ending felt rushed and unimaginative.Gameplay - The on foot combat has similarities to Batman series' combat. You chain attacks with possible finishers and executions, parry when a visual cue appears, dodge roll and may use your firearm or enemies' weapons. Vehicular combat is more interesting, with targeted damage and several ways of destroying or disabling vehicles. Overall, its easy to learn and satisfying to perform.Interface - Obviously designed for consoles and gamepads, it performs solidly for keyboard and mouse users, despite being a bit buggish when accessing the garage to upgrade and swaping to the archangels section.Graphics - Taking into account Mad Max's apocalyptic world consists mostly of sand, rock and some metal, there are plenty details and landmarks to take in, and some interesting biomes to discover. The game is well optimized and looks great, in a grim and depressing way.Music - Both eerie and discrete during exploration, it quickly shifts into an energetic and tribal tone during combat. Borba considers it perfect in setting the mood for this universe.Sound - From simple sounds such as footsteps, to the crunchy combat and spectacular ambient effects, it adds much to the whole game experience and immersion.Polish - Going against the trend of ill-optimized triple A titles and the "release now, patch later" attitude, the game released with very few issues, and none that prevented Borba to perform a full playthrough within the first week of release. Despite a couple of graphics driver crashes that occurred, no save data was lost and the game's performance is consistent on high settings.Borba dislikes:Replayability - After finishing the story, Max gets back on the map so he can find all collectibles, get all upgrades and finish all challenges. Despite that, Borba doesn't feel compelled to do another playthrough, and feels this end game should provide more enemies to fight on foot and on vehicle, perhaps in the form of several arenas or more varied challenges.Design - This, is what separates a mediocre game from something truly special. Overall, Mad Max is pretty mediocre as an open world action adventure game due to the fact it has such repetitive side quests that provide an obligatory grind to get the upgrades needed for the main quest line. Solid and fun game mechanics ( combat ) mitigate this situation, but one can only wish there was more love put into the enemy strongholds ( fighting the same bosses in different environments doesn't cut it for Borba ) and more interesting dialogue into the encounters with friendly characters. Maybe with some DLC, introducing new things to do ( arenas and on foot / vehicle combat challenges! ) other than finding collectibles, completing the map and racing challenges.Borba feels like despite Mad Max being a solid game with fun combat and many upgrades to unlock, it could have been so much more than a wasteland grind for completionists such as himself. If unsure, consider the game when it gets a good discount, for it is still a solid game that looks as well as it runs, great!8/10

												I absolutely love this game. It's like Far Cry 3 in that you have to take camps so allies can occupy them, and it's like Rage with the way enemies come at you on the road. There are also strongholds that serve as home bases, and there are various ways of building them up so they serve Max better. I've seen some reviews claiming it's too survival heavy because ammo, water, etc, is scarce, but if you build up the strongholds, you really don't have to worry about all that and just have fun wreaking havoc.Scrap metal is a necessity if you're to upgrade your car and even yourself so you can handle the increasing difficulty of the game.I feel this game nails what it set out to do, which was put the player in a Mad Max world, and I especially love the car battles! I keep wanting to gather more scrap so I can turn my car into more of a beast, and this need is also the driving force to do favors for others, which moves the story along and keeps the action pumped.The characters are fun and well-acted, and the Batman-type combat is fluid. Buy this game and be witnessed!

												Mad Max is a great game if you love open world action games.The story was okay. Max himself is supposed to be this broken man who has given up on trust and others, which ties into his character. I found out that this made him more of a mundane character over an interesting one. Posted: September 26, 2015
												Finished this game after 56 hours. Basically most of the game consists of this scenario:You drive towards something and get attacked by some enemy vehicles. You blow them up then arrive at your location which is either a camp or a scavenge location, both are shown on the map.You kill all (very dumb) enemies at the location clicking left and right mouse button and your movement keys. And collect scrap metal (that is the in-game currency) scattered around. The game tells you how many scrap metal the location has.That's it. The redeeming factor of this game is the combat, the enemies, the cars, the locations and the scenery ooze Mad Max atmosphere. Even though exploring a location only rewards you with scrap metal it is still fun because everything is so well done. All locations have little details and a LOT of gore. It is Far Cry 4 without a stealth mechanic but with car combat.Is it a good game? No. Is it a fun game? Yes.EditOh and the minimum requirements are wrong. I have exactly the minimum required CPU, the Phenom II X4 965, and run this game with everything on high, some stuff at very high and everything enabled. I could probably turn the settings up even further but haven't bothered because the game already looks excellent.

												A shockingly good game that i avoided till last winter sale because i feared it was a movie tie in. The game is more closely linked to the old Mel Gibson movies, its a long, cold, hard look at our society and how we function as human beings...or not.Its an emotional rollercoaster that leaves you a tad sad but relieved by the credits. You will play through this game thinking your rebuilding a man's sanity, that there is the possibility for some happiness in a dying world but then reality sets in.Mixed feelings of loss and rage, a feeling of emptiness thereafter, very fitting for this setting. There are very few games, that leave me sitting after completion staring at my library list...wondering what i will play next while still trying to process what exactly just happened. The ending is very strong, good or bad depends on you.

												So,What do you get when you combine an apocalyptic wasteland with great characters, spectacular gameplay, the chaos of vehicular combat and a great levelling system?Answer: Mad Max.And so begins my review.Graphics: Stellar, with mild system requirements. Any mid-range rig (~2014) should be able to handle this title at high settings with playable framerates. At the present, there are no glitches, stutters or crashes observed while playing this title. Well optimized.Gameplay: Engaging. Nothing here comes free, not even upgrades. Prepare to maraud and survive in this titular wasteland as you sCAVENGE for scrap, come to blows with Scrabrous' minions, destroy oil rigs, disarm mine fields and upgrade your vehicle. Story: This is damn good. Characters are well portrayed, and the Mad max themes from the genre are easily carried over as a homage to the series. We see unrequited love, betrayal, greed, malice and survivalism. The Hope and Glory's arch moved me deeply; well developed characters who met an untimely end out of Max's choices and Chumbucket's betrayal at the end. However, the linearitty of it all lowers it a notch; the player has no real choice to make.Overall rating: 9/10 for the fine work, attention to detail, stellar graphics and customizability, the epic photo mode and an epic and engaging playthrough. One of the severerlyunderrated epics of 2015.You will not regret playing this. Promise.All in all, comes highly recommended.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												If devs could mix assassins creed combat with GTA racing, Mad Max would be born. The game starts with a roar and ends with the gamer wondering if doing it again is worth it.The story (which is a pretty interesting one to say the least) revolves around the gamer playing as Max, a man scavenging the desert wastelands. As you progress through the game, you unlock upgrades for your car and perform different missions for various warlords. Max does this in hope of getting to gastown, a town filled with all the guzzoline (not gasoline) one could wish for. Unfortunately, the whole wasteland is overrun by Scrotus's War Boys. Max has to clear out their camps to get rid of the threat in different areas.The gameplay is simple but has it's moments of fun. There are only two buttons required for combat : parry and strike. While it is simple, clearing out 10 to 15 guys in a in a camp is satisfying until it starts becoming redundant.  Additionally while engaging in combat, cans of gas can be lit on fire to blow up enemies and shotguns can be used to get enemies at a distance. The driving part is fun due to it's simplicity but isn't as action packed as clearing a camp The driving controls are your basic right trigger to accelerate and joystick to control the wheels. The car has the ability to ram into others with a simple tap of the button. The car, the Magnum Opus is very customizable. The areas that of the car such as engine (transmission), body armor and thunder poons, which is the coolest weapon. Additionally,  players can acquire cool hood ornaments that give the car upgrades. To take down enemies in towers, sniper rifles and harpoons can be used for extreme distances. There are many ways to keep entertained when roaming around, you may clear out scarecrows, scavenge war boy locations, and (of course) clear out gas camps.Graphics and sounds are also well done in this game. If your car takes damage, it's very apparent. Max will be bruised up and walk with a limp if he falls a certain distance. Your car can also go up in flames if you damage it too much. There is a neat visual feature in which Max's hair becomes longer over the course of the game. Max himself is also customizable. The sand looks very clean as do all the enemies. (When you bump into rocks or drive through a large pool of sand, the environment will react to you. There is a huge variation in the Scrotus War Boys compared to the many enemies that appear very different. The camps also look amazing. Many details are put into secret entrances into the camps so it is difficult to find the small opening you need to get in. The progression through camps is also what makes them special. Many small details go into making the huge world look clear to the human eyes. The water and sand look like they should but they vary in their appearance depending on which region Max is in. The enemies make noises when they fall off ledges and get hit. The sound is clear and grunts are well heard. Max seems to be in an active environment at all times.The story line/campaign could have been better but seems to be the high light of the game. As I've said, it becomes repetitive : go collect or defeat this warlord can lose its grace after a while. Clearing out minefields and scarecrows can easily become tedious (and booooring). Also, when you have to drive across the map for sulphur, that's enough to drive anyone crazy. The game is good but has the potential to be a lot better. Following missions and clearing out camps can keep only keep you busy and entertained to a certain extent. All in all, this is a decent game. If you enjoy driving around in a free world like GTA and a bit of action raiding camps, this will appeal to you. It seems everyone I talk to either quit this game after 2 hours or kept playing it. It truly is a game in which I feel anyone can pick up and learn to play easily within an hour (which isn't always necessarily bad)!I will recommend this game but with extreme caution. If one of your friends has this and their sharing this game with you, better to play it that way!RATING : Regular average 7.0/10Gameplay B- Story / Campaign B- Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music B- Replay-ability C Overall  C+ScreenShots :////to come

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												tl;dr version in the end-----------I usually don't make long reviews, unless it's a game that got overlooked and worth giving a chance.Mad Max Is an Action RPG Open-World game developed by the same studio that brought you Just Cause games.At first you would say "Another game based on a movie? Nah, it will be crap"But this isn't the case. This is really probably the best movie tie-in Video Game in long, long time.This Game feels like a 3rd person version of RAGE (remember RAGE? another post-apocalyptic game).You get a car, you upgrade it and your arsenal, gets to several areas/strongholds/camps, meets new people, gets missions and so on.Story: 6/10The Story, however isn't really that outstanding.Mad Max gets picked on by War Boys, stole his car and he want to get it back to continue his journey, instead he found a guy that offered him a "Car with potential". But Max found out that car can't withstand the harsh environment, so he need to work hard to upgrade it so he can get out of the place to somewhere else.Gameplay: 8.5/10Mad Max is a 3rd Person Action RPG. That means you navigate through the world. Loot scraps, fight random enemies and loot them, destroy threats, help strangers, take down strongholds and upgrade your companions' ones for services.The combat is a kin to that of Batman Arkham Games, you use you arms to strike down enemies and break their bones and necks and you can carry weapons to crush skulls (the game is so violent btw) while countering incoming attacks.In addition of that, you have a shotgun for quick kills but ammo is so scarce and hard to find.In Vehicles. Your Magnum Opus equipped with a Harpoon to pull enemies and objects with and a Rocket-Launcher-like weapon to destroy other cars and metallic gates and a Sniper Rifle to take down long range enemies. With further upgrading, you could make your car a moving flame thrower.During your navigation in the world, enemies will ambush you, chase you and annoy the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you.You can shoot down their cars' tires, blow up their engines and take their loot for bigger scraps.The World is that big, so many activities to do.As for collectibles. There are historic relics that give you some other people's thoughts and concerns from the world before the Nuclear weapons fell. They are really interesting to read.Graphics & Design: 9/10The game is surprisingly very detailed. The environment, the locations and in-doors places are very well-designed.like the sand hills which looks beautiful and realistic in the desert areas, and the mountainous and valleys areas looks damn gorgeous giving the perfect post-apocalyptic sight.The Character models and animations are detailed, high quality stuff.Bosses: 5/10The worst thing about this game is probably the Boss Fights. There are several Bosses (named TopDogs here)in each Stronghold and at the end of several missions. But the problem is.... They Are ALL the SAME.They are all the same design, same pattern, same animations, and the same way you have to do to take them down.It feels like it's just 1 boss that spawn in different locations. No variety at all. Good thing they don't appear all the time so it's just a matter of choice to encounter them all.Upgrade System: 7.5/10Another unique, but annoying feature of the game.The upgrade system doesn't rely on the player experience points gained from battles or missions. Instead, it rely on Challenges made throughout your actions. Like defeating enemies with specific ways or take them down within a specific time. In addition to character upgrade point which you can spend on Health Points, Loot/Ammo/Water/Food bonus,etc...That's for Max's character abilities. For Car's upgrades, they get unlocked for more reduction of threats you made in the world.Other upgrades are only unlocked for completing specific missions.Conclusion: 8.5/10 Don't really know if i can recommend it for a full price or on sale. I got it $20 and enjoyed it.So, it's depends in your budget.Quick Summarized Review: The Good:+ Too many things to do+ Combat System is well-made+ Taking over Strongholds and Camps is fun+ Collecting relics is a fun read+ Upgrading Max and the Magnum Opus is super rewarding+ Beautiful and detailed world environment + Missions and side missions are variedThe Bad:| Upgrading things you want can takes too long time to unlock| Lowering threats for car upgrades can be repetitive and annoyingThe Ugly:- Absolutely no variety for Bosses. It's just 1 Boss with different skins.- Max has an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ character.

The environment, the locations and in-doors places are very well-designed.like the sand hills which looks beautiful and realistic in the desert areas, and the mountainous and valleys areas looks damn gorgeous giving the perfect post-apocalyptic sight.The Character models and animations are detailed, high quality stuff.Bosses: 5/10The worst thing about this game is probably the Boss Fights. There are several Bosses (named TopDogs here)in each Stronghold and at the end of several missions. But the problem is.... They Are ALL the SAME.They are all the same design, same pattern, same animations, and the same way you have to do to take them down.It feels like it's just 1 boss that spawn in different locations. No variety at all. Good thing they don't appear all the time so it's just a matter of choice to encounter them all.Upgrade System: 7.5/10Another unique, but annoying feature of the game.The upgrade system doesn't rely on the player experience points gained from battles or missions. Instead, it rely on Challenges made throughout your actions. Like defeating enemies with specific ways or take them down within a specific time. In addition to character upgrade point which you can spend on Health Points, Loot/Ammo/Water/Food bonus,etc...That's for Max's character abilities. For Car's upgrades, they get unlocked for more reduction of threats you made in the world.Other upgrades are only unlocked for completing specific missions.Conclusion: 8.5/10 Don't really know if i can recommend it for a full price or on sale. I got it $20 and enjoyed it.So, it's depends in your budget.Quick Summarized Review: The Good:+ Too many things to do+ Combat System is well-made+ Taking over Strongholds and Camps is fun+ Collecting relics is a fun read+ Upgrading Max and the Magnum Opus is super rewarding+ Beautiful and detailed world environment + Missions and side missions are variedThe Bad:| Upgrading things you want can takes too long time to unlock| Lowering threats for car upgrades can be repetitive and annoyingThe Ugly:- Absolutely no variety for Bosses. It's just 1 Boss with different skins.- Max has an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ character.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Mad Max is an action, open-world game that sends you inside one of the best movie of 2015. Usually, I tend to avoid games based on movies, because more than often they are rushed titles whose only purpose is to sell using the name of the movie. So, what happened that made me change my mind about buying such a potentially bad game? Mainly, Steam reviews. With a solid 90% positive reviews I thought to give the game a chance, besides I'm also a big fan of Mad Max movies, a post apocalyptic genre lover and the game was 66% discounted during Christmas. I bought it and it was a real, amazing surprise.TECHNICAL ASPECTS***GAMEPLAY 8/10Mad Max gameplay is amazing, but unfortunately it is flawed by some aspects that may bore the gamers. As I said, the game is open-world, Max can travel by foot (not a very good nor smart idea), by car (best idea) or by fast travel (anti-boredom idea). Why is fast travel anti boredom? Simply because the world is HUGE, it's like Skyrim but in a desert with almost no life, so even with a car, but nothing to do it gets boring. The environment is really well made, don't get me wrong, I tried to avoid using fast travel (I'm not a big fan of it), but if you want to 100% complete the game, traveling, even with your fastest car, becomes a nuisance.Now, let's talk about fighting. Take the Batman Arkham franchise, strip the Bat of it's costume, grow Wayne a big bushy beard, give him some ragged clothes, a double barrel shotgun and throw him in a desert, done ? Good, you now have Max, a man that fights (kinda) like the Gotham vigilante. What is great about this in Mad Max is that you can perform some finisher moves depending on the environment. Is your enemy with his back against a wall ? Grab his head and smash it on said wall. Is your enemy the sniper in that tall tower that just blow up one of your car tires? Find a way to sneak up on him and push him over the ledge of his tower, no more sniping for you ... Baiatch ! Do you like the sound of your shotgun? Grab an enemy and gut shot him... again, and again, and again, and ... damn I ran out of ammo.Once your enemies are all dead you can go back to your car and chill out... wait no ... a war party approaching !!! Fighting in Mad Max doesn't end when you enter your car, it really begins there. If you have seen the 2015 movie you know what I'm talking about, if not go buy the DVD and then buy the game (I'm not joking). Car fights are almost exactly like the ones you see in the movie: ramming, grinding, burning, harpooning, blowing up tires, fuel tanks or drivers. The only problem about cars is that the game doesn't like to see cars upside down, so whenever you flip your car and start sliding on your hood, some mystical force flips your car back on its wheels.All of this you'll be able to do by buying the right upgrade for Max or the car, there are a lot of them. For Max there are the classic upgrades : better armour, more HPs, special combos, etc. For the car there are car bodies, tires, ramming grills, engines, hood ornaments, harpoons, spikes (to impale enemies that try to jump on your car) pipes that shoot flames and much more. Each upgrade will cost you scrap (the currency of the game), you get scrap by completing missions, looting enemies or locations and by destroying enemy vehicles. It is hard to have enough at the beginning, but doing side missions helps you a lot and eventually you end up having more than you need. Last thing I'll explain about gameplay is what made the Steam reviews drop from 97% positive to 90% : the lack of diversity for what concerns side missions. In Mad Max you have the possibility of roam free around the map doing things like destroying enemy convoys or liberating outposts. Although these things are fun and give you the opportunity of doing something other than the main quest, they are basically all the same, they just get a bit harder the more you go on. These enemy outposts for example, are different only in their appearance, one is inside a chasm, while another was built on an abandoned oil rig. The problem is that you always have to do the same thing, fight your way among enemies and blow things up or kill the boss. Here, the bosses, or I should say "big guys who look all the same except for the colour of their clothes", this is the worst thing of the game, these guys are supposed to be generals, not cannon fodder, so I expect them to be unique, to fight in different ways, to die in different ways, well... no, they are all the same, they fight all in the same way, and you kill them in the same way.***STORY and LORE 9/10It's not the main thing of the game obviously, but I guess it's noticeable by the fact that I wrote a poem about the gameplay and almost nothing about the story. However, it is good, not excellent but good enough, it follows up the event of the movie but doesn't cross them, so the game and the movie remain separated but in the same context. It also seems that George Miller, the director and inventor of Mad Max, supervised some aspects of the game, the lore in particular, I've read that he likes the idea of being allowed to explain things (in a game for example) that you cannot explain in a movie (for obvious reason of time). So, when going around doing quests you come across some "relics" that give you hints on what happened to the world. When you start the game you may think you're in a desert in Australia, but it's not just a desert it's  the bottom of the ocean, now dry due to some mysterious event, (probably global warming) .If you want a short summary of the story keep reading (I won't spoil anything important)The game starts with Max driving his beloved Interceptor, you get attacked by Scrotus (one of Immortan Joe sons) you manage to kill Scrotus but your car gets stolen and scrapped. Then, you encounter a hunchback named Chumbucket, a blackfinger (title given to those who are skilled mechanics), who wants to help you because he says to have seen you in a vision and thinks you're the "Saint" (an envoy of the goddess called Angel Combustion). He builds a new car, the Magnum Opus and comes with you to help you get a V8 engine that is supposed to allow you to continue your journey through the desert.During the game you come across other characters, some crazier than others, who help you if, of course, you help them first and you do that until you reach Gastown. What happens then, I let you discover by yourself. ***GRAPHICS 10/10Amazing, nothing less. Even though it's not perfect I give the game a 10 because it runs at a steady 60fps on (Mad)Max settings 99% of the time, I dropped under 50 only twice, but there was really a lot going on on screen. The game is so well optimized that makes other AAA games look bad. Everything about the environment is unique, each region has its unique features and look. You don't have the impression of being in the same place, even though you're in a desert with only rocks, sand and some scattered ruins, but what really shines here are the storms.Storms are random events that can occur when you are out in the open, your companion Chumbucket will scream "Storm approaching !" and will point in that direction, you move the camera and you see it : a front of black clouds of dust moving towards you at incredible speed. You may try to outrun it and find somewhere to hide, but you'll miss all the fun, so pedal to the metal and run inside the storm. Everything turns black for a second, the wind howling covers even the sound of the engine, lightning starts falling from the sky and you have to steer to avoid being hit... it is so damn fun, if you manage to find some crazy enemy inside a storm is even better.***SOUND 9/10I'm running out of space to write so I'll just say that sound is great: engines, explosions, bone breaking or dislocating, car grinding to each other. Best part of it is voice acting.OVERALL SCORE 9/10

												This is a good game… but also not a good game. How do I explain? Quick thoughts below:Just a line on the graphics and the performance of the game, both are excellent, it is a lovely ,looking game and it runs flawlessly (bodes well for Just Cause 3), now onto the game itself.Mad Max about 3 things, Driving, Fighting and Upgrading your car, everything else in the game is merely a vehicle (no pun intended) to allow you to do one of those 3 things. Tasks in Mad Max are repetitive with copy and paste quests and objectives as you explore the map, which some people, including myself would describe as busy work, or padding, or even grinding if I were to be harsh.Thing is though, they are all tasks which let you do three things;  Almost always you’ll first be driving around meaning you’ll be blowing up, ramming and dismantling other cars with your harpoon gun whilst hurtling through an apocalyptic Australian outback complete with dried up seabed’s and places to explore and scavenge. You'll then get to where you're going and you'll be Fighting, usually against multiple opponents in an Arkham style fighting system with brutal animations and sound effects, Max isn't a well-trained ninja but a brawler, handy in a fight and able to look after himself and that really comes across.After that you'll have earned some scrap to upgrade your car, as well as Max, buying new engines, tyres, armour, weapons, special moves etc etc.And... rinse then repeat. It is this pattern over and over with some slight variance here and there for story missions. Whether you like this game or not comes down to how much you enjoy those 3 things, and for me, I really did. That's why I played it for 41 hours and finished a lot of the game before doing the story.Of course it isn’t totally as simple as that, there are other things for you to do and even the above 3 activities are wrapped up in narrative driven reasoning or have a tagged on objective, but trust me when I say you’ll always be driving, fighting and upgrading. That is the meat and potatoes of Mad Max.Those 3 mechanics might not work for some and therefore they would bounce right off it and think it is an average or even a poor game. Not in my eyes, one of the most enjoyable games in 2015 for me and I hope you think the same should you give it a go.

												A great game in the Mad Max universe, more in the atmosphere of the 2015 movie than the older ones. I found myself really immersed in the gorgeous open-world with a vast amount of locations to visit and things to do. The wasteland has beautiful sights to see and the ruins of the old-world call out for exploration. Graphics are excellent and I believe this was the best optimised game for PC in 2015. Combat on foot is in the style of Arkham series with nice animations and fluid moves. Vehicle combat is a little hard at the beginning, but gets a lot more fun once you upgrade the vehicle. I left no stone unturned, so this game took me about 50h to complete. There is no replayability, except maybe for the races, but the time spent was of high-quality. Overall: one of my favourite games in 2015 and I can not recommend this enough if you are into the open-world genre.

Posted: September 4, 2015
												My life fades. The vision dims. All that remains are memories. I remember a time of chaos... ruined dreams... this wasted land. But most of all, I remember The Road Warrior. The man we called "Max." To understand who he was, you have to go back to another time... when the world was powered by the black fuel... and the desert sprouted great cities of pipe and steel. Gone now... swept away. For reasons long forgotten, two mighty warrior tribes went to war, and touched off a blaze which engulfed them all. Without fuel they were nothing. They'd built a house of straw. The thundering machines sputtered and stopped. Their leaders talked and talked and talked. But nothing could stem the avalanche. Their world crumbled. The cities exploded. A whirlwind of looting, a firestorm of fear. Men began to feed on men. On the roads it was a white line nightmare. Only those mobile enough to scavenge, brutal enough to pillage would survive. The gangs took over the highways, ready to wage war for a tank of juice. And in this maelstrom of decay, ordinary men were battered and smashed... men like Max... the warrior Max. In the roar of an engine, he lost everything... and became a shell of a man... a burnt-out, desolate man, a man haunted by the demons of his past, a man who wandered out into the wasteland. And it was here, in this blighted place, that he learned to live again.

Posted: December 9, 2015
												"Where must we go, we who wander this wasteland, in search of our better selves?"-The First History ManI just completed all the achievements for this game,  so I thought I'd drop some thoughts.  Mad Max is a solid and immersive experience, though it does have some significant flaws that prevent it from being amazing. The story is fitting for a Mad Max tale, though like the films, it's the action that makes the game fun. There is some interesting mysticism sprinkled here and there as well.  Max himself fits the reluctant hero archetype very well. His sidekick, Chumbucket, acts great as Max's foil and comic relief to the harshness of the wasteland, which itself is beautifully rendered. There are other characters scattered here and there, though not enough for the player to care for them. Ground combat follows the Batman formula; various finisher unlocks help keep it fresh. Vehicle combat is where the game shines as you can upgrade your car to have some killer weapons and defensive items. PROS:-Performance (Best PC port in a long time, looks beautiful, runs smooth)-Vehicle Combat (You can harpoon stuff!)-Environments (Lots of detail for an open world; the wasteland is filled with all kinds of scenes that tell a story of the apocalypse without having to spell it out for you. Lots of cool and disturbing imagery all around. I found myself in the game's great photo mode grabbing amazing screenshots that now serve as awesome wallpapers)-Immersion (You are Max, and you are a cold, yet broken badass. Very easy to get lost in this wasteland, much more interesting to me than the other post apocalyptic game right now)CONS:-Side quests too repetitive / too much grinding -Lack of End Game content (This is what keeps this game from being amazing; you spent a long time upgrading Max and your car, only for the game to be virtually empty by the time you are ready to be a true Road Warrior. The best vehicular combat scenarios, the convoys, for instance, never respawn. The game is desperately in need of a way to reset enemy camps and convoys, or a New Game+ mode.. not sure this will happen as Avalanche is busy with Just Cause 3)-Difficulty (It's pretty easy, and you can make Max pretty overpowered pretty fast - could use a Survival mode of some sort)OTHER THOUGHTS:I'm not a completionist usually, but for this game I didn't want it to end so I did a lot of grinding that I don't like doing.  Note: If you want to 100%, look at the challenges first and plan your attack; if you get rid of all Threat Level in the game too early, it will be very difficult/annoying to complete some of the challenges required. See End Game comments above. Where are the War Rigs? Would be awesome if the convoys had big trucks that you had to board. Imagine fighting War Boys on a moving behemoth, before finally taking out the driver and hijacking the truck. Generally this game needs more convoys and maybe even convoy escort missions.

												So my constructive review on Mad Max Game!As many of you know about my reviews, I go into more detail than needed but it works out in the end.So lets start with the basics:Graphics: This game is extremely well made on the optimize section. Maxed out graphics is super smooth on my crossfire 7950s and the game does look really nice. I played maxed out at 2560x1440p and the game was smooth as butter, even streaming game it ran smooth without a single problem. The most optimized game to date, better that GTAThe graphics in total are decent, really they are nice to look at and has some really cool effects with the glass effect on the cars, dents and scratches. Really well done!Audio: There is not much to really comment on this, you have car sounds bombing around, but the car sounds do sound pretty nice, with the grumble from the different engines. The main character looks and sounds like the guy from "The Last Of Us" Literally and the music I find annoying, so I turned it off, the overal bumps, sand poof and what not is nothing special.Controls: This is what I do not like at all! The car handles horrible, really... If you ever played APB: Reloaded then you know what I am on about here because it handles about the same! When driving and turning, it's like you are trying to ride an ice cube, down a wet iced path and hit a pin at the end. It's really horrible to drive I think, and takes some time getting used too. The way the character moves aswell is also annoying. You have to be RIGHT infront of the ladder to actually climb it, no matter if you are looking at it and beside it, up against it.. You MUST be directly played infront and sometimes you can just tap the key and the character will dart off an edge or something. The way he moves it annoying! Gameplay: So this is an open world game, kinda sandbox if you will but limited. You have a car, a man and a chum to go on your quest. Lots of missions in the game really are stupid, go here, talk to this man, go back and talk to chum, now chum wants an item, go and get it and come back, but sometimes the items are less than a few feet away, but he STILL wants you to get it, then you get it and it's done, like "THE HELL!!!"Also jumping, the character barely jumps over a book and you often find yourself running around things because he cannot get up the size of a paper back book.... I was able to jump around things and yet he could not step over something and it forced me on one path ONLY. The game is kinda linear in that aspect.Shooting.... When you press right click, your character will stop dead in his tracks and you CANNOT, I repeat you CANNOT move at all... You cannot move and shoot, you must stay still.. What the hell is with that I do not know!You spend most of the time doing the same missions back and for, talking just to build the car. This game is all about the car parts it seems. Not much about anything else from what I can tell.  So far the missions I have seen has been the same as every other one... Bored me!The combat is simple button smash, right click and back to smashing.... Literally batman fight system and it's okay for the first fight, maybe the second but then it's boring!There are no grabbing attacks, holding to counter to attack someone else, using proper fighting... It's simple button smash fighting. Taking a strong hold... (Take it sniper, take out flame thrower barrel) enter and beat more people up... Every single base is the same to take out. Nothing new in any!You can only carry ONE jerry can (Fuel can) in the car at one time, no matter if you find more, they are wasted. You can only carry one supply of water on you at a time, you cannot even store any in the vehicle! Which is a very stupid thing to do when the game is meant to be a post apocalyptic world.  (These are things that annoyed me and made me bored)There is also a lot of this fuel around, even though your car barely uses that many... You can find near enough every point a Jerry can to fill up the car, but barely using that much fuel you do not need it, you cannot store it so you just waste it. Pointless!There is also no coop or no multiplayer.. LITERALLY!!! So people may say, "Yeah but it's a wasteland and you are the last man alive" and too which I reply "So who are the other people you meet and greet in the game?" There ARE normal people in the game that are not physco and this game would benefit so much more having a team behind you, making a stronghold together, increasing the odds of forming your own alliance, but no! Would I recommend this game? Yes, but only just and I really mean only just... 51% so 49% no, because it does offer some good gameplay for a few hours but then it becomes the same thing around, scavange, talk, fix, scavenge, talk, fix and that too me is the reason plus above no coop I stopped playing the game. So it only, and I mean ONLY just gets a recommend from me!

Karakter juga audio cukup bagus dan story-nya juga ga kalah seru dengan movie-nya game ini.The Bad:Di beberapa bagian game ini bisa bikin lo jenuh, beberapa side quest dan looting scrap bisa agak membosankan kalo terus berulang. content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												So here we have it. Mad Max. Id never seen the movies until I bought this game and playing it made me watch Mad Max 1 and 2 tonight. I didn't even know about this game until a friend mentioned he was quite hyped close to release. I waited until after release to buy it actually due to the "wonderful" launch of Arkham Knight (sarcasm). But in all seriousness this game has slapped me in the face and proven me wrong. I have enjoyed 37 hours of Mad Max so far and I have not enjoyed a game this much since one of the Assassins Creed games which im not going to go in detail about as I am not here to promote AC. Every new title that comes out nowadays gets me worrying about optimization and whether the game will actually be in any way playable at launch. Mad Max is 100% playable and 99.9% bug free. A 2MB update could fix the only issues the game currently has and the best part is that the bugs aren't game breaking! The gameplay is extremely fun all the way through and even though im a guy im not afraid to admit that the main story has some emotion in it. There were moments that I actually gasped in shock lol. The driving is very smooth and I would compare it alot to GTA's style of driving but it feels like driving the Batmobile from Arkham Knight quite a bit when it comes to vehicle control and drifting etc. The vehicle customisation is great. You can change every little piece of your car to your liking but it comes at a price of course. Combat. Once again very like Warner Bros Batman Arkham combat although you do notice the difference in moves and overall let's say "gore"? Yeah gore. So ive actually completed the main story now and I was worried that when it is done will I still play Mad Max? Yes is the answer. The main story may be complete but still I had only 43% completed the game. It was beautfiul in it's own way. When it comes to character customization I would choose the word endless. You can change Max's facial hair, his head gear, wrist armor, jacket, gun and unlock new fighting moves. So after watching the first 2 Mad Max movies I would compare the game to Mad Max 2 the most. I was watching the very long car battle near the end and right away I was getting flashbacks of vehicle combat in the video game! Even the map/scenery makes me feel like im a part of the 2nd movie. Most interesting feature of the game:Chumbucket. This is a character you meet in the game. After meeting him he leeches onto you and never goes away. After 45 minutes of playing you are very thankful to have him there. 3000 pieces of scrap later you are extremely happy to have him with you because your car will begin to look beautful because of him. He is very helpful throughout the game and got me through some situations. Ive usually found that having a character like this who constantly is with you in a game gets annoying. It's like Roman from GTA IV. "Hey Nico! Want to bowling?". I know Roman wasn't physically there but he still got me trying to find subways so I could escape the world of phone signal. Although Chumbucket knows what he is doing. He knows when to speak and when to shut the hell up. That's always a great thing. Right?Sooooo graphics! Beautiful! Some may shoot me virtually for this but im gonna compare this game to the Arkham Knight graphics. I know ive compared it to Batman enough but seriously it is the best and most accurate example and it's by Warner Bros for god sake! Honestly the graphics are great. The game is very well optimized and im extremely shocked that it is due to more recent games and their examples. Warner Bros have done a great job at recreating the Mad Max world for us to free roam around in with our rumbling V8 engines. Good job. And yeah here is the gretaest part of all for people worrying if they can run this game. Im using an AMD Radeon HD 7870 with an AMD FX 6350 on high 1920x1080. No stutters no lag and 30fps+.Also on the main menu I see a DLC tab. The excitement is real and the wallet is open!9/10

												If I had to imagine what a Mad Max game would be like, it would be exactly like this game.  Graphics are pretty decent, the gameplay is solid. Not too strong of a story but it's Mad Max. Lots of violence and things blowing up. Badass cars and a well crafted post-apocalyptic wasteland. Couple of complaints I have is that the game gets repetetive, going from territory to territory scavenging scraps and collectibles, clearing out camps of baddies yet I couldn't stop playing. I also ran into bugs once in a while like clipping through objects or character body parts dissapearing and mines in the minefield not showing up properly. Coincidentally this game was made by Avalanche, same developer that made Just Cause 3 and somehow this game didn't turn out to be a buggy mess like that one but I digress.The things I liked were the cars, specifically the Magnum Opus, the pinnacle of badassery. The wasteland itself could be quite beautiful and pretty to look at too during certain hours of the in-game day. The flow of combat is pretty simple and looks great when chaining combos and counters together. You get a sidekick named Chumbucket who's just the best lil hunchback sidekick ever.I had a lot of fun with it and would definately recommend it to strangers and my friends if they like driving and action games.

												Pros:+Combat system works well with one exception+Car customization is in-depth and increases the playtime exponentially+Map is unique, not just sand dunes everywhere, there's variation and interesting landmarks+History Relics were an excellent touch, Max's responses were great+Tons of things to do+The missions are set up to make you explore, some require you to go out into the wasteland and liberate camps+Optimized amazingly+Sound design is good, it's so satisfying to punch people in the face and hear bones breakingCons:-Combat system fails when you're attacked by 2 people at once, you can only counter one of them, but even then you're usually knocked out of your counter by the other guy hitting you-Cars are somewhat hard to control, now I'm not sure if this is because of the way I customized my Opus or not, it's usually not noticeable except for this one mission where I'm racing some people through a collapsed and half-buried airport (and indoor segments in general)-Some sound glitching, when I jump off of a cliff for example, the engine sound gets stuck until I land, sometimes bombs don't make sounds-Doesn't capture the survival aspect of the wasteland, it would have been nice to have a hardcore mode-Multiplayer would have greatly extended this game's life-span, even something simple like racing with your custom cars

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Mad Max is a perfectly enjoyable game, but don't get it expecting the reinvention of the wheel for gameplay or a deep story. The gameplay is, basically, Assassin's Creed / Batman Arkham Asylum: parry, hit hit hit, evade; go to a very high place (balloons in Mad Max) to reveal maps and unlock fast travel; collectibles everywhere and so on. As you play the story missions or unlock... unlockables you get to upgrade and customize your car, your gear and your skills.The game is, to me, a lot like the new movie: something that you lean back and enjoy for the action, the "Mad Maxy" vehicles, the road fights and the craziness of the post-apocalyptic world. There's something special about impaling a guy with a harpoon fired from the back of your car, pulling him through his windshield and then dragging him across the desert. The game is as violent as the movie, perhaps even more. It's all about VROOM VROOM VROOM! BARK! BARK! CRASH! BOOM! POW! PEW! PEW! VROOM VROOM VROOM! Does it get repetitive? Absolutely, but if you're enjoying it, who cares? Bugs, I haven't encountered any after 9 hours of gameplay. The game's physics are a bit crazy, little things will sometimes send your car flying. The environment, character and vehicle graphics are all pretty good.

												Is it worth $60? Regrettably, no.Mad Max has a monotonous grind to it. But if you can see the details that make it stand out.  The story is good albeit short and the actors are great. The final showdown was simple and quick. The bosses weaknesses and methods are identical except for Stank Gum and Scrotus (who has only a slight variation to the regular bosses). Which was refreshing but still not too difficult. The map is rich in areas to explore. The airport terminal was expecially cool but quick.All in all it is designed as a console arcade game and the learning curve is very easy. There were times that I wished some fights would drag on. Early on convoy takedowns required time and strategy but as soon as you got the exploding harpoons they became easy and boring. I played 20 hours trying to clear each area then got bored and rushed through the story. I just got tired of collecting loot.  So if you would like to support the devs then pay full retail but if your on a budget then I suggest you wait for the sale. Either way you should get some enjoyment but I'm not so sure about replayability. p.s. Devs, please add some more of those great stories along with that supurb acting. I'll take story over loot any day.

It's locations of Buzzards and I'm loved how they shown in the game. (In movie it was just one scene, but there we have a lot locations where we can how they live)Plot is simple but good. Fights on foot god and fun, Batman-stylish but with lot of blood and brutality. Battle on cars also fun and cool (i'm worried about that moment). Also car design of enemy and you own car - is incredible.If u loved movie - BUY IT! If u love car action - BUY IT! If u want harsh and brutal post-apocalypse - BUY IT! This game is really, really good.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												If I had to imagine what a Mad Max game would be like, it would be exactly like this game.  Graphics are pretty decent, the gameplay is solid. Not too strong of a story but it's Mad Max. Lots of violence and things blowing up. Badass cars and a well crafted post-apocalyptic wasteland. Couple of complaints I have is that the game gets repetetive, going from territory to territory scavenging scraps and collectibles, clearing out camps of baddies yet I couldn't stop playing. I also ran into bugs once in a while like clipping through objects or character body parts dissapearing and mines in the minefield not showing up properly. Coincidentally this game was made by Avalanche, same developer that made Just Cause 3 and somehow this game didn't turn out to be a buggy mess like that one but I digress.The things I liked were the cars, specifically the Magnum Opus, the pinnacle of badassery. The wasteland itself could be quite beautiful and pretty to look at too during certain hours of the in-game day. The flow of combat is pretty simple and looks great when chaining combos and counters together. You get a sidekick named Chumbucket who's just the best lil hunchback sidekick ever.I had a lot of fun with it and would definately recommend it to strangers and my friends if they like driving and action games.

"M1, M1, M1, M1, M2, M1, E" - Max's response to anythingI had tons of fun with this game, and played it to the 100% mark.As an affictionate of the backstory/movies I wasn't let down.If you do not want to play it to full completion, the oh so bland grinding can be avoided. +The car combat feels great, even if some options for dealing damage as just not as viable as others. +The game runs beautifully, and is well optimized.+The World looks beautiful and is quite interesting.+Great overall atmosphere.+Nice character design-Ground combat feels dull and is just interesting if there is a lot of enemies. Can recommend tho.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												So here we have it. Mad Max. Id never seen the movies until I bought this game and playing it made me watch Mad Max 1 and 2 tonight. I didn't even know about this game until a friend mentioned he was quite hyped close to release. I waited until after release to buy it actually due to the "wonderful" launch of Arkham Knight (sarcasm). But in all seriousness this game has slapped me in the face and proven me wrong. I have enjoyed 37 hours of Mad Max so far and I have not enjoyed a game this much since one of the Assassins Creed games which im not going to go in detail about as I am not here to promote AC. Every new title that comes out nowadays gets me worrying about optimization and whether the game will actually be in any way playable at launch. Mad Max is 100% playable and 99.9% bug free. A 2MB update could fix the only issues the game currently has and the best part is that the bugs aren't game breaking! The gameplay is extremely fun all the way through and even though im a guy im not afraid to admit that the main story has some emotion in it. There were moments that I actually gasped in shock lol. The driving is very smooth and I would compare it alot to GTA's style of driving but it feels like driving the Batmobile from Arkham Knight quite a bit when it comes to vehicle control and drifting etc. The vehicle customisation is great. You can change every little piece of your car to your liking but it comes at a price of course. Combat. Once again very like Warner Bros Batman Arkham combat although you do notice the difference in moves and overall let's say "gore"? Yeah gore. So ive actually completed the main story now and I was worried that when it is done will I still play Mad Max? Yes is the answer. The main story may be complete but still I had only 43% completed the game. It was beautfiul in it's own way. When it comes to character customization I would choose the word endless. You can change Max's facial hair, his head gear, wrist armor, jacket, gun and unlock new fighting moves. So after watching the first 2 Mad Max movies I would compare the game to Mad Max 2 the most. I was watching the very long car battle near the end and right away I was getting flashbacks of vehicle combat in the video game! Even the map/scenery makes me feel like im a part of the 2nd movie. Most interesting feature of the game:Chumbucket. This is a character you meet in the game. After meeting him he leeches onto you and never goes away. After 45 minutes of playing you are very thankful to have him there. 3000 pieces of scrap later you are extremely happy to have him with you because your car will begin to look beautful because of him. He is very helpful throughout the game and got me through some situations. Ive usually found that having a character like this who constantly is with you in a game gets annoying. It's like Roman from GTA IV. "Hey Nico! Want to bowling?". I know Roman wasn't physically there but he still got me trying to find subways so I could escape the world of phone signal. Although Chumbucket knows what he is doing. He knows when to speak and when to shut the hell up. That's always a great thing. Right?Sooooo graphics! Beautiful! Some may shoot me virtually for this but im gonna compare this game to the Arkham Knight graphics. I know ive compared it to Batman enough but seriously it is the best and most accurate example and it's by Warner Bros for god sake! Honestly the graphics are great. The game is very well optimized and im extremely shocked that it is due to more recent games and their examples. Warner Bros have done a great job at recreating the Mad Max world for us to free roam around in with our rumbling V8 engines. Good job. And yeah here is the gretaest part of all for people worrying if they can run this game. Im using an AMD Radeon HD 7870 with an AMD FX 6350 on high 1920x1080. No stutters no lag and 30fps+.Also on the main menu I see a DLC tab. The excitement is real and the wallet is open!9/10
