content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												This is one of the most memorable games I have played. It puts you into the actual shoes of Mad Max in ways no movie can (but I wish I could see in the future).I have never felt so 'in the shoes' of a character as I did playing this game.My memories of the game are endless. Intense and lingering. I played through several times. Each time, learning more about Max and his World. This game is one of the reasons I upgraded my PC to a 64 Bit platform, and I am more than glad that I did.I've never been through more depressing runs of brutal warfare and survival in all my 30 years of gaming. I would gladly play through a fourth time.In the End... No Spoilers... ... ... ... ... ... ...It is what it is. That's the only way Max could have it in this life. Constantly trying to survive. I truly felt like a 'Saint' of the wasteland in every playthrough. Hearing the people I contribute to thanking me and telling stories of my accomplishments throughout the visiting of each Base was encouraging and rewarding as any game could deliver.I also love that this game ties into the Fury Road movie, which is in my top ten. I can't explain how they intertwine b/c spoilers, but it was very well done, in my opinion.A must play for fans of Batman games or fans of the Mad Max Universe. Lots of gory backgrounds, Brutal Combat, Mature Cutscenes. Drug use. Some minor sex references.I have over a hundred hours in this game, all well worth it. The Storms are awesome. Sieges are awesome. BEING. MAD. MAX. IS. AWESOME... Everything left me wanting more. I wish to see a sequel in the future, whether on the Big Screen or on my Gaming Rig. Hopefully both.4.9/5

100% Achievements Review (Bahasa Indonesia/Indonesian)The Good :Mad Max, game open world ini cocok banget buat lo semua yang suka dengan game adventure ditambah aksi-aksi fighting moves-nya yang brutal abis. Gaya bertarungnya mirip-mirip Batman combat system, namun di sini lebih bloody and gory. Lo bisa bertarung dengan tangan kosong, senjata atau kendaraan mobil. Mobil pribadi lo (Magnum Opus), shotgun dan juga harpoon bisa diupgrade dan mobil-mobil musuh bisa dijadiin koleksi di garage. Fitur fast travel khas open world game bakal membantu banget kalo lagi males nyetir atau mau kabur dari kejaran musuh. Pemandangan jalan tandus dan gurun ga seburuk yang lo bayangkan, pengaturan cahaya di game ini dan weather effect-nya keren abis. Badai gurun nampak realistis, petir yang menyambar saat badai keliatan jelas dan nyata, begitu juga dengan percikan dan nyala api dari setiap benda yang meledak. Karakter juga audio cukup bagus dan story-nya juga ga kalah seru dengan movie-nya game ini.The Bad:Di beberapa bagian game ini bisa bikin lo jenuh, beberapa side quest dan looting scrap bisa agak membosankan kalo terus berulang. Boss battle di sini juga bisa dibilang repetitif, dari mulai tampilan Boss/Top Dog-nya yang cuma beda warna sampai cara bertarungnya yang lo pasti cepet banget hapal setiap pergerakan serangannya. Karena serangan yang lambat dan mudah dihindari, bikin boss battle di game ini kurang menantang. Pergerakan karakter Max juga ada sisi negatif khususnya saat kita lompat, hanya tempat-tempat rendah dan tertentu saja yang bisa dilompati atau dipanjat.Detail tambahan: Grafik yang bagus cukup ringan walaupun dengan spec PC yang tidak terlalu powerful. Kisaran waktu tamat game ini 15 jam waktu main dan untuk para completionist atau achievement hunter, dalam waktu 70+ jam semua achievement bisa lo dapetin.Score : 7/10 (Semua game yang gw review gw kasih jempol, walaupun penilaian dari gw kecil. Untuk memberi kesempatan para game dev untuk bekerja lebih baik lagi.)[Dear Gaben, please make Indonesian as an official language on steam. We have a large community here. Thanks]

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Its actually the first time ever I take the time to review a game.I never had much to do with the Mad Max franchise until I saw Fury road and I was immediately sooked and almost made a salto when i heard of a standalone game instead of a crappy movie adaption for the franchise as I love cars, explosions and desert wasteland settings.Technical aspect: 9,5/10 Story:the story needs some time to get going and as im at like 20% of the game ( yes i like exploring) i havent seen much of it- however the game takes its time to introduce you into the characters, story and wasteland as much as it rushes you into the customisation and missionobjectives- overall that makes a good balance to me as the objectives are fast paced and short, rough fun but the story promises to take a deeper breath and contrasts well with the overall pace.However the story builds up more with the questions that are not asked rather than with those asked- the game gives plenty of hints if you are willing to observe characters and the world as to what happened, why people are the way they are and how everything went to♥♥♥♥♥♥ the brainchild you are producing while driving through endless dunes, seeing oiltankers and airplanes alike inbetween dried salty coral reefs and giant chasms is a sight to ponder and behold.8/10Gameplay:As most people already delved into the way the game plays ill just quickly summarize it: batman like hand to hand combat with powerful combos and finishers , but not as deep as one would like to wish... well what do you expect of a wastelander- meaty fistfights and crude mean weapons. The game doesnt do much in that regard but it does everything right that it attempts. the animations are fluid and dont evoke a repetitive sense as the enemies are plenty.Stronghold invasions can be done the mad max style or the mad max style- one way or the other you will make stuff explode, fall down and die- here and there are some sneaky bits if you dont want to bother trying to rip down a fortresses defenses but eventiually things will explode.Exploration is immensely fun, one would think a wasteland is hard to make feel alive but every time i started to get bored with the environment i got something new to look at and behold thrown at me. The game strikes a perfect balance of wasteland and living world to me and you can always spot a lovingly handcrafted wreckage or sightseeing spot around the next corner. (dont look too close tough- sometimes the graphics designers got a little bit lazy with the textures)The survival aspect does get a mention but is rather something that adds a little athmospere than anything truly survival-esque -- youll never have to really bother about water, food and gas but its just a nice immersive aspect to take care of these things- i rather eat maggots and the occasional lizard that eating one medpack after the other and never actually drinking ( lookign at you tombrider) It just fits into the game and the developer noticed its a smart move to just immerse you a little bit morescavenging is a good balance between exploring and reward- sometimes it gets a slight bit frustrating given the low rewards , but youll find story sniplets and nice vantage points ever so often- and overall the game isnt so littered with collectibles that you lose interest in picking them up  at some point *cough far cry cough*Cars:now here lies the fun- the customization options are fun and plenty, you actually have noticeable impact on the behaviour and playstyle of your car when you modify it- its an actual second character- Drawing a line to assassins creed black flag here- in Assassins creed the ship felt like a static thing to me that i would just upgrade- the magnum opus however has its characterchange for every addition or substraction you make and that brings a lot of diversity and fun- if you get bored with your heavily armored boulder of a car- how about ripping all those armor plates and bumpers off to create a fast and furious but very squishy dune racer?You can even do this on the fly so you never have to enter a situation unprepared ( even tough i would rather have the garage only accessible in the safe havens- yet i understand that would hinder gameplay a lot, given the constantly changing world and objectives- so i understand the descision to make the garage acceccible at all times)car combat is everything michael bay has to offer and it feels like the movies. Its fast, unfogiving and lots of metal will fly through the air. Shiny and Chrome factor 9/10Verdict:you like desert wastelands, survival, cars ,explosions and mutated people ? get the game, its definitely one of the best releases 2015 9/10

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Mad Max is a perfectly enjoyable game, but don't get it expecting the reinvention of the wheel for gameplay or a deep story. The gameplay is, basically, Assassin's Creed / Batman Arkham Asylum: parry, hit hit hit, evade; go to a very high place (balloons in Mad Max) to reveal maps and unlock fast travel; collectibles everywhere and so on. As you play the story missions or unlock... unlockables you get to upgrade and customize your car, your gear and your skills.The game is, to me, a lot like the new movie: something that you lean back and enjoy for the action, the "Mad Maxy" vehicles, the road fights and the craziness of the post-apocalyptic world. There's something special about impaling a guy with a harpoon fired from the back of your car, pulling him through his windshield and then dragging him across the desert. The game is as violent as the movie, perhaps even more. It's all about VROOM VROOM VROOM! BARK! BARK! CRASH! BOOM! POW! PEW! PEW! VROOM VROOM VROOM! Does it get repetitive? Absolutely, but if you're enjoying it, who cares? Bugs, I haven't encountered any after 9 hours of gameplay. The game's physics are a bit crazy, little things will sometimes send your car flying. The environment, character and vehicle graphics are all pretty good.

												This game has impressed me on many levels. It's very well optimized, it looks gorgeous and the gameplay feels good and works well. The story is not bad but it's not great either. It's pretty generic and is made up of the most common themes of RPGs. The combat feels satisfying but is most of the time not a big challenge as your enemies will almost always attack one at a time which can easily be dealt with by parrying. If there are multiple types of enemies performing different types of attacks in can get quite tough at times.The driving in this game is very good. The sound of the different types of engines are great, the handling feels realistic while still being arcadey enough to be fun and challanging at the same time and the vehicular combat works well.Mad Max looks really good. Not particularly in terms of texture quality but some of the effects are really stunning especially the explosions. The atmosphere of the whole post-apocalyptic wasteland is also very believable and authentic. There are lots of incredibly detailed areas to be explored.

												ONE OF THE BEST GAMES OF THIS YEAR --- DEFINITELY A CONTENDER FOR GOTYI wasn't expecting much of Mad Max before the release but I was blown away when I played the game. I'll start off by praising the developers for the perfection that they've put into optimization of this game. I hardly notice any frame drop, it runs at constat 60 fps on maxed settings @ 1080p. You wouldn't exepct much from a wasteland in terms of versatality but this game is unbelieveably dynamic. I mean going from town to town, you'd see the environment changing big time. Every town is different than the other in many ways. While playing this game, you'd never feel like you're stuck in same cliched location.What makes this beautiful game even more beautiful is the awesomely implemented, better version of Batman style hand to hand combat with lots of upgrades to keep the game fresh till the very end.Chumbucket's engineered Mangum Opus (Oh saint, the angel cumbustion wants you to drive it) So probably ya'll  know that this game offers great deal of cars combat but on top of that you have this one main car, called The Magnum Opus, It offers soo many different upgrades that even when you finish the game, you still wouldn't be able to have unlocked all the upgrades. You can modify the car in many different ways, whether it be in terms of its appearance or its performance.Story - I still haven't finished the game, I've been doing side quests mainly because I don't wanna finish it fast but thus far, the story has been progressing nicely and it's quite engaging. I'd totally recommend this game to everyone.

content:
Posted: April 8
An atmospheric post-apocalyptic Distraction - The GameYou're driving through the destroyed landscape and notice a pillar of smoke behind the hill. Let's check it out! Before you reach it, you are attacked by a car patrol protruding with spikes and flamethrower nozzles. After defeating them, you notice on the minimap that there is a treasure cache nearby. Let's check it out, I need some more scrap! Before the last bend, you see a big ramp beckoning you to try out the newly upgraded boost and jump wherever it leads. After jumping you are notified that you reached a new wasteland level and that you should go and upgrade your skills at the shaman/psychotherapist.Where was I and what did I want to do?This is Mad Max in summary. Just as other games in the genre, you keep getting distracted by myriads of activites everywhere. This is held together by two things: Threat level, a number representing how much activities in the region you already did, and the story.ProsGreat writing in some places, especially in the main quest line Chumbucket, your sidekick, is one of the best written characters in action games I played. Griffa has also very interesting dialogues, but ultimately they lead nowhere in terms of character developmentThere are a lot of fun small environmental puzzles. How do I get there? How do I lower the bridge? Where is the last insignia hidden? Those environmental micropuzzles are what holds the gameplay together. So soMelee combat is the standard fare brought by Arkham Asylum - one button for attack, hold for strong attack to break defenses, other button for defense, if you time it right, you have a perfect parry. Skills open up more possibilitiesVehicular combat is mostly fun, but the physics get a little bit strange the more upgraded your car is. With the strongest V8 engine, thickest armor and most offensive spikes/flamethrowers/ramming equipment installed, the car starts behaving wonkier than at the beginning. Suddenly most jumps damage you which didn't damage you before, stones are suddenly bigger obstacles than with lighter cars... It's kind of hard to describe, but a fully upgraded car wasn't more enjoyable to drive and fight with than a weaker one. Which wasn't what I expected.It's a distractathon game, so there is no one activity holding the game together. There is not one core gameplay loop but three or four. That comes with the genreUneven writing. Max has three different personalities - one in the story missions (distand and detached), one when commenting history relics (where he is much more pensive and melancholic) and another one during the endingConsA propos the ending: It made me really angry. And I don't think it was the writers' intention. At the very end, Max suddenly changes his personality and does something that is completely out of character when he kills Chumbucket. That's not what my Max would do. I helped all wastelanders, didn't harm anyone, gave water to all pilgrims. But most importantly that's not what the writers' Max would do! There is a huge discrepancy between how Max was written throughout the whole game and what he does at the end! There is no warning, no transition between those behaviors.Second, the scene doesn't make sense. Why wouldn't Chumbucket jump off the car?Third, the impact of the scene is immediately rendered useless, because you respawn back in the landscape with both Chumbucket and your car unharmed.Just like in each distractathon, there are a lot of chores here. I would normally avoid them, but many of them are required in order to unlock certain upgrades. I would never clear minefields on my own, for example.The controls are unresponsive. There are a lot of animations that must play out until the end before the game starts receiving input again. Those animations are short, but there are a lot of them: Disarming an opponent, wall bash, picking up a weapon. The game shows input hints, but doesn't receive input until these animations play out.Many (almost all) actions require you to hold a button instead of pressing it. This makes the whole gameplay a lot less responsive and slower. Looting, kicking down doors, picking up weapons, entering the car (exiting is just one button press, though)...There are also a lot of unskippable small cutscenes. Eating food, disarming minesOf the similar games in the genre, Shadow of Mordor, Arkham City, Assassin's Creed and Mad Max I enjoyed Mad Max the most. It is definitely not without flaws, but as far as 3rd-person distractathons go, its gameplay holds well together. It is mostly well written, the two combat modes are fun and the distractions hold well together for the most part.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
OVERVIEWMad Max is a third-person open world action game set in the post-apocalyptic world of the movie series.You play the titular Max, who has every right to be mad indeed! There you were, cruising the wasteland on a sunny afternoon, searching for the Plains of Silence, when Scabrous Scrotus, the local bully boy, descends upon you with his horde of try-hards. Before you know it, they've beaten you up and stolen your car, and even cutting half way through Scrotus's head with a chainsaw didn't seem to slow him down.GraphicsThe graphics in Mad Max are phenomenal. Character models are top notch, with beautiful mapping and excellent animations. Max's fighting style is brutal and bloody, and he flows well from one movement into the next. The wasteland characters are ridiculous and over the top, exactly how they should be in a Mad Max game.Environment graphics are unbelievably good, too. The weather effects are excellent, with the powerful static storms being the most obvious example. Dust clouds rise from convoys, too, and the lighting when looking out across the wasteland is a sight to behold. How did the artists manage to make such an inhospitable place look so good!?And the car models are excellent as well, full of wildly silly designs, destructible components and crude, but effective, weapons. And there's such a lovely assortment of them, too. And oh, yes, what fabulous explosions!Truly, Mad Max continues to wow me with its graphics, even after playing it for almost 70 hours.SoundSound, too, is top notch. Everything is spoken and it's mostly spoken extremely well, from the rage-filled shouts of random marauders to Hope's dulcet tones as she tries to sway you to help her. Chumbucket's wheedling is so annoying, but somehow comforting, too, after all those hours with him at my side. And Max is brilliant, sounding just like the broken, tortured, post-apocalyptic mercenary that he is. Some of the wasteland encounters let the side down, though, with outrageously broad Australian accents that made me cringe.Car engines make suitably throaty growls, Max's shotgun makes a satisfying boom, and each time I mash another Roadkill's face into the dirt I swear I can hear his bones break.Music must have fit the game well, because I don't remember it being out of place, but I certainly didn't turn it down.GameplayAfter the opening scene and brief introduction that holds your hand through the basics, you're left with Chumbucket the 'blackfinger' mechanic to support and guide you, and let go to roam around the smallish first area. After a couple of missions and getting the hang of how everything works, that then opens up and you're free to do pretty much whatever you want, although I'd recommend that you follow the storyline.Your ultimate goal is to recover your stolen car, or create one even better -- the Magnum Opus -- and doing that requires getting your hands on a V8 engine: The Big Chief, which is only available in Gas Town, at the other side of the large world map. Getting there takes many hours of work, though, and you'll make a number of allies along the way.Mad Max plays like a post-apocalyptic Grand Theft Auto with characters more over the top than Saints Row. You basically spend the whole game driving around a big wasteland, blowing stuff up, taking over enemy camps, scavenging for scrap, and engaging in plenty of hand-to-hand and vehicle-to-vehicle combat.Vehicle combat is fast and fun, and cars handle well. Melee combat is reminiscent of the Batman Arkham games, with lots of timed blocks and counters, and some very brutal moves. Water in the wasteland is a precious resource and Max can drink from his water bottle to refill his health. But never mind if you do take too much damage and poor Max bites the dust; you can always resume play at the last auto save, which happens whenever you do anything of note.I tried to do most of each wasteland area before moving to the next, and I think that decreased the enjoyment I could have had. Before I'd even reached the third stronghold I'd maxed out Max's abilities, which made the second half of the game feel more grindy than I think it should have. If there's a big complaint I have about the game, then that's it: there's not enough character progression for the amount of content available.So the game isn't perfect, and it does have a number of smaller issues, too. For a start, I don't think the instructions ever mentioned that Max can jump (by using Ctrl), and you can use the Magnum Opus's harpoon to pull down locked ladders. There are a few small bugs that still remain, too, including challenges that don't always unlock properly, character and location bios not always displaying properly, and an issue with on-screen information sometimes disappearing. But a restart normally fixes these issues. I also had one crash to desktop in my 69 hours of play, so that's not too bad.PROS AND CONSPros:+ Absolutely fantastic graphics that are optimised well+ Great realisation and extension of the movies' world+ A large map with a lot to see and do+ Excellent car physicsCons:- A few very small, niggly bugs- Can get repetitive towards the end gameCONCLUSIONMad Max is one of the best games of last year. It's long, violent, bloody, and very over the top, and I love it.9/10

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												The game is fantastic. The environments, the post-apocalyptic settings are amazing. The gameplay is solid and keeps you on your toes cause it can go very bad quickly if you're not fast enough.  I never had such a blast to just ride my car in a sandbox game. The amount of destruction I left behind me makes me smile all the time. The story could be better, that's true, but for me, the atmosphere makes up for it and I DO want to stay in the game for hours. I'm really not a completionist in games, far from it, but Mad Max makes me want to do everything and it's a sign of an exceptionnal game. I had less fun to complete GTA 5 and I thought it was really good. The game is not more repetitive than other sandbox games but it sure is a lot more interesting to do the side stuff, than let's say, Assassin's Creed XYZ. The car is amazing to use for destruction. And for those interested in the hardware side of MM. I'm running it flawlessly on a i5 4670k and a Radeon 7970 ROG Matrix Platinum. It looks so good and runs so smoothly that it makes me "mad" at other's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC ports even more. This game is an example of a PC port well done.9/10  A story a little bit more ambitious would have make this game deserve a 10/10 easily for me.

												I rarely write reviews but i salute whoever made this game, this game is Strongly RecommendedPros: - This is one of the best games i have ever played so far. It just belongs there along with epic games of the same open world genre that i played and enjoyed (like the recent installments of GTA, Fallout, Just Cause, Assassins Creed .. etc) - Post-apocalyptic (Mad Max universe, watch the latest 4th movie of it before playing to know what this world is all about) - Open world (like GTA 5 but a much bigger map), but you can't really wander off anywhere easily, you'll need enough water and gas or you're gonna die in the wasteland. - Mix of combat methods which are epic, i love how you can fire a harpoon at a sniper tower then pull it with your car to bring it down. Car combat somewhat reminds me of Twisted Metal. - Amazing graphicsCons: - Following the Mad Max movies world, the steering wheel is on the right side of the cars (australians) which is something most of the world isn't used to, this has no effect on the playing quality but dammit i keep going to the left side of the car thinking i'll reach the steering wheel faster xD, however i do underrstand and appreciate the game makers sticking to the legacy the mad max movies created. Overall:- if you enjoy open world games in post-apocalyptic settings, car customizations, cars chases & combat, survival then this game is good for you.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												A game made in support of a movie.  RUN AWAY!........An Aussie Cult Classic remade, amended and updated by...... AMERICANS!  Gaaaaaah.There's two strikes, but guess what.... it works!Mad Max the game captures the spirit of the traditional Mad Max movies, and blends them well with the current Fury Road movie as well.An easy game to get into, a little 'console' in nature, it's just a fun way to spend an hour or two.  No overt brain power required, just a good bit of escapism.Pros:   Runs well on moderate systems.Accessible and simple to learn.Atmospheric.   I feel parched everytime I play!Graphics ( esp burning cars ) is VERY well done.   Scenery is excellent on PC.Cons: A little repetitive ( but you can streamline and concentrate on the story line )GasTown not as imposing as was elluded to in the movies and lore.  Feels underpopulated, protected and generally underwhelming.Knit Picking Side Notes:   For those who do not know or even remember such a thing as Aussie Slang....   Dinkie Dye ( yes, pronounced Die, not DEE as done in the game ) means 'The Real Thing'  'The Genuine Article'  'Not fake or artificial'  'The Real McCoy'  'The Real Deal'.  You get my drift.  I'm assuming that Chumbucket pronounces it "Dinkie DEE" because he never went to finishing school, and not because Americans have no clue on how to pronounce 'Australian'.  I tell myself this because to miss pronounce it otherwise through ignorance would make this a 2/10 game for me, instead of a 7/10.Enjoy.

But never mind if you do take too much damage and poor Max bites the dust; you can always resume play at the last auto save, which happens whenever you do anything of note.I tried to do most of each wasteland area before moving to the next, and I think that decreased the enjoyment I could have had. Before I'd even reached the third stronghold I'd maxed out Max's abilities, which made the second half of the game feel more grindy than I think it should have. If there's a big complaint I have about the game, then that's it: there's not enough character progression for the amount of content available.So the game isn't perfect, and it does have a number of smaller issues, too. For a start, I don't think the instructions ever mentioned that Max can jump (by using Ctrl), and you can use the Magnum Opus's harpoon to pull down locked ladders. There are a few small bugs that still remain, too, including challenges that don't always unlock properly, character and location bios not always displaying properly, and an issue with on-screen information sometimes disappearing. But a restart normally fixes these issues. I also had one crash to desktop in my 69 hours of play, so that's not too bad.PROS AND CONSPros:+ Absolutely fantastic graphics that are optimised well+ Great realisation and extension of the movies' world+ A large map with a lot to see and do+ Excellent car physicsCons:- A few very small, niggly bugs- Can get repetitive towards the end gameCONCLUSIONMad Max is one of the best games of last year. It's long, violent, bloody, and very over the top, and I love it.9/10

												My Game of the Year for 2015 Mad Max is a thrilling joyride through beautiful terrain with brutal combat, amazing car chases / races, and an authentic look inside the mind of madness. I bought the game at full price, 60 bucks, and got every penny's worth.Done by the Just Cause guys, the world is almost overly massive. I didn't get too deeply into Just Cause because I felt like there was just too much crap I had to do. It can get a little repetetive crawling around abandoned bases trying to find that last piece of scrap metal to fully complete an area, but it manages to do the GTA thing where its fun just to drive around. The Combat is lifted from the Batman / LOTR games, but this game definitely does the style the best of those 3 titles. It achieves the rarely achievable "It's awesome to kill somebody every single time you do it". Brutal crunching sounds and primal screams, awesome animations and satisfying finishers. I found myself getting out of the car and baiting dudes just so I could punch their faces with Max's spiked gauntlets.The Car, the Magnum Opus, is the real star of the game, and yes, you do level up Max, but the car is the real main character. So many times I was supposed to play for "just a little bit" and then I kept going because I wanted to get the next engine upgrade. Cleverly tied to clearing the map, the car upgrading system - and the fact that, there isnt a "BEST" configuration, just a configuration that best suits your style of play - is the main hook that will keep you coming back.At this point im taking a slow burn on finishing it completely because I love it that much. The game is like a 6 pack of high quality imported beer - as tempted as I am to chug the rest of it, I'll keep it for when I really need to have some fun. You know what part I was always terrible at in writing class? the conclusion

Posted: March 29
												TL;DR Version:  Well, I enjoyed it more than Fallout 4.It's Batman Arkham meets Carmageddon and GTA w/ the Mad Max license.  If that doesn't entice you, I don't know what will.Don't rush through the story missions and do try to unlock fast travel spots ASAP.Always carry a spare gas can.------------------Maybe it was just me, but the game did not feel as repetitive as some others have complained about.  Yes, the landscape looks similar all over, but it's to be expected when you're in the middle of the desert.    Yes, tasks do repeat, but how many games these days don't follow some kind of grind cycle?  I never really felt bored through it, though.  Part of this may be a result of me spending a lot of time clearing scrap sites and knocking out territories as much as I could and really only advanced the story when I needed to do so.  The base story itself doesn't really have a sense of urgency (at least to me) until I start the quests specific to getting the Big Chief (a V8 engine), so in a way I felt more encouraged to take my time.  It probably would have felt like more of a grind if I just blitzed through the story missions ASAP and didn't do the side quest options.  So if there is one recommendation for playing a new game, it's take your time and explore.  I would also recommend unlocking fast-travel spots as soon as you can.  The Hot Air Baloons (which allow you to scout the area) as as fast-travel spots, but so do the Death Run spots.  Just drive right into the Death Run spot (not just passed it when gives you the bio for the place) and you have and automatic fast travel zone.  It does makes traversing the desert a lot quicker.  One thing I will note is by using fast-travel, you always spawn with your Magnum Opus.  So if you actually do play around with the specialty cars (not counting your Archangel mods for the Opus), it will reset and you will need to go back to a stronghold to re-obtain your car.The combat is mostly akin to the Arkham games, but now you have a shotgun, shivs, and can actually use the melee weapons.  Controls feel very responsive.  I don't feel “quite” as responsive as Batman in Arkham City, but I am playing as burnout ex-cop/soldier with bad knees and a death wish, so it isn't jarring for me.  It might just be me.  Even with that, the vast majority of times I died it was due to stupidity and not bad or unresponsive controls.  The camera can, at times, go a bit stupid.  That said, it's not enough to detract me from the experience.I have now beaten the game, but not 100%.  The ending was bittersweet, which is fitting for the Mad Max universe.  At some point I may go back and just scrounge around for scrap and history relics and collect the one car I am missing, but for the most part I am done and ready to tackle another game.  I will say I actually want to go back spelunking in the game at a later point, which I can't say about some other games I have beaten.  My largest gripe about the game is actually nothing to do with the overall scenery, story, mechanics, or anything else of that nature.  It's actually the pointless product placement rammed in it via the (admittedly minor) DLC which comes with purchase.  Two of the hood ornaments and one of the cars unlocked in the game are just ads for Rockstar Energy Drinks.  Kind of wrecks the immersion just a bit.  The hood ornaments are at least useful in early game (before you unlock the others), but the unlocked car is a pig's♥♥♥♥♥♥  All that aside, I still enjoyed my time in the game.  As of this writing, the game is currently retailing for $19.99 and I would consider it money well spent.  Lord knows I've bought other more expensive games which were greater letdowns.

Mad MaxMad Max is an open world third-person action-adventure game that has elements of both a PRG and a Shooter.  I have been watching this game for a long time and of course I pre-ordered it as soon as it was available but I have to admit I was a little worried after Batman: Arkam Knight.  I can honestly say that so far in I am really liking this game.  Port StatusMad Max plays great. The controls work well with the exception in the menu where I was forced to use my controller to log into WB.  Now this may only be an issue because I have a controller plugged in, but it was still an issue all the same and I should not have to unplug a controller to play a game with a keyboard and mouse. GraphicsThey have done an awesome job optimizing this game.  I did have some lighting issues with flickering but after downloading the new Nvidia driver 355.82 it was flicker free.  With Vsync off I am getting well over 200 fps with every setting maxed out.  The graphics are Next Gen and look great.StoryI really like the story, but then who doesn't like Mad Max. It is the familiar post appopolyptic story where Max has lost everything and revenge.  The open world game with side quests are great.  The environment is easy to immerse yourself in.  I just wish you had choices and consequences. Furious BugsThe game is bug free for the most part although some people have experienced issues with the map, I have found an entirely different issue.  My bug relates to an earlier quest I completed in the first zone unlocking ammo stations in the last two zones.  Unfortunately my ammo stations are not unlocked and of course there is no way to replay the quest without replaying the game so I am unable to collect an achievement I earned unless I replay the game to do so.  The game has been patched several times but my issue remains.  After 75hrs in this game, I still enjoy running around in game, racing, and destroying cars but I am not too excited at the prospect of finding all of the loot objects again.  ConculsionThe game delivers in almost every aspect and I recommend it without any hesitation.

												Excellent graphics, Very optimized, Really big open-world, Best explosion and vehicle carnage, Great special effects and so many amazing locations to discover ! Post-apocalyptic game 8/10 ********A wasteland game that is heavily influenced by the movie of the year (2015), Mad Max: Fury Road. Though the main story doesnt exceed even the least of my expectations before the game's release but it delivers a vast open world with so many unique places to discover and pillage. Which happens to be the best part of the game.The main attraction of this game is the vehicular combat and the car customizing functionality. Learn to drive like a mad man to best your opponents in the desert wasteland and you will be visually rewarded with beautiful explosions and chaos. The combat style flows closely with the Batman: Arkham games ( made by the same developers ) but IMO: they made it much better and more violent like it should be. Experiment with all kinds of weapons you can find during a battle because they will never fail to amuse you. ( My favorite was the Thunderstick ). Setting aside the main quests, this game heavily relies on exploration and side quests. It may seem that the developers spent more time in designing the entire world than focusing on its story that reminds me of some other post-apocalyptic themed games I played before ( Fallout ).Bottom line is, this was an amazing hotseat video game that I could just turn my mind off to and relax.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Mad Max... four movies... a few books... plenty of content to draw from to make a game. This one supposedly created BEFORE the the latest film so therefore should draw on that content. Let me give you a quick rundown on the game and what I ultimately think of it with about 20 hours in the game. If your A.D.H.D. wont let you read for more than 2 minutes... skip to the bottom for my final verdict. Note that this is a review from a 25+ year gamer who is just over 30 years old.  OverviewYou are Mad Max. A long time ago a lawman in the Main Force Patrol, Max has been forced to become more animal than man as he struggles through life in the post-apocalyptic wasteland of Australia, In the films we see him get more and more lost as a person, and more and more brutal while trying to cling to the past. In the game, you are trying to live and make peace with yourself and your past. Not quite the deranged killer like in the latest film.The game starts out with your vehicle getting stolen (one of the Pursuit Special Interceptors). It is stolen by the Warlord and his men, Scabrous Scrotus (who ultimately is the son of Immortan Joe). Max is stripped of his weapons, clothes, and belongings. He has to learn how to survive again while making two very important friends along the way (this is your tutorial of sorts). After a certain key moment in the game (I wont give it away), you are thrust into the open world and allowed to follow the main storyline or do side questing. GraphicsI reference graphics early on in most games because there are a LOT of graphics ♥♥♥♥♥s out there. People that wont play a game unless it is up to par with current standards. You can be rest assured that the graphics while not next-gen, they do well for the setting and are pleasing on the eyes. They're good enough, but don't tax your PC. I'll explain more on that below in the review.I did see some screenshots of blurry graphics and abominations... but didn't experience any of that myself. I only ever ran into two graphical problems:1. While getting in my vehicle in front of an outpost, I looked back and could see through the front gate and into the world. For some reason at certain angles the graphics de-rendered. 2. While jumping off of a wall climb, I could see through a cave wall into the nothingness that is below the rendered world.Not bad all things considered. StorylineAfter the pivotal moment in the storyline... you'll get the option to explore. If you stick to the quests you'll be looking for a place to hide. Continuing with that will provide you with some unique objectives. The storyline itself seems... meh... at best. Your character doesn't seem so hellbent on revenge as I would have been. He instead goes off on various side tasks that seem to take away from the main story.The storyline does flow rather well and compel you to keep going. 20 hours into the game and I'm only into my second region with many more to go (thought I have been hitting up the side quests).Side QuestingThe side quests consist of everything from providing water to parched pedestrians (say that 10 x fast)... to clearing out stronghold camps... to collecting items from scavenge camps and more. I found myself reaching the second region, and going back to make sure I got 100% of the items from the first. I've done that in AC, JC2, and other games where I need to get a 100% and apparantly that's my OCD. The side quests are repetitive. No two areas seem the same... some are above ground, some below. Some have buildings, some have tunnels. Some places you blow up, some you have objectives in. They're different enough to keep doing them, but I can't help thinking that eventually, I'm going to grow tired of it (like I did in JC2). CombatI like the combat both on ground and in vehicles. But it does get repetitive. I went from being amazed and blown away by it all... loving every image that popped across the screen... to blanking out and then coming to after it was over. Just becomes something I have to get through, just to get through. The vehicle combat is either disable/destroy their vehicle, or hop out and hope they'll eventually do the same. Then it becomes a ground fight. I did that more often than not until I upgraded my Harpoon to level 4 (where I could then rip tires off). After that, I rip wheels off, and go to ground and fight or run them over. I can also harpoon them and fling them around for S's and G's.Most of your combat will be on the ground in strongholds and such. Get used to it, and try to do things differently if you can. Skills that Max acquires later will make the fighting more unique when he can do different finishers. But that comes later.Skills, and UpgradesYou can upgrade your character from the clothing to his finishers. You can upgrade his weapons, and add skill points to his health, how much water he gathers, etc. It's pretty extensive and makes your character feel unique. A lot of the upgrading as well as with the vehicle is done with scrap. Scrap is found across the world in mini-camps, destroying enemy vehicles, and more. The first few upgrades will seem easy. They then multiply and become increasingly expensive (like 600, 900, or more scrap). If you complete the main storyline you will have the opportunity to return scrapulance (scrap vehicles) to the base for a payout around 500 scrap each. This will help you upgrade quickly. I was impressed with the amount of things you can upgrade. Especially with the vehicle. Everything from the wheels to push bumper to engine to exhaust, etc. Some content unlocking is restricted to the story however.Game PerformanceI run a PC with the following specs:AMD FX-8370 (8 core CPU) @ 4.01ghzG.Skill RAM 16GB @ 1600mhzAsus GTX 960 2GBWindows 10I can run the game at 60fps on 1920 x 1080 with almost ZERO loss of frames with the graphics settings maxed out (except shadows which are on HIGH). Only once for some odd reason did I drop to 44 frames which then instantly went back to 60. I will always hover between 59 and 60 when just running around no matter how much I have on the screen (this is also while streaming). This is probably the SINGLE BEST port to PC that I've ever seen when it comes to performance. I've only run into a couple bugs, and really splitting hairs... I only have a few complaints about the game. It's not my "favorite" game... but it is absolutely solid. I had a few people message me about how it is... and I couldn't lie... it's decent.Final VerdictRepetition aside... the game is pretty fun. I still feel like I'm seeing some new things each time I load the game up. I'm generally liking the characters and how vastly different they are. The world is bland (desert environment) but then that's the whole premise behind it. The whole world is now waterless. Don't expect Just Cause 2 where you can go from swimming in the water to snow capped mountains in a few minutes. I feel the game is lacking a bit in terms of depth (they could really do something with the gang warfare to make it feel like a real struggle in the wasteland instead of mindless killing of a vehicle that just drove by). They could have allowed you to venture off and build your own fortress... and really feel like it's YOURS. Maybe become a Warlord yourself (but then would that really be "Mad Max"?)... all sorts of possibilities are in place for this game and franchise. It'll be interesting to see what they add in DLC's (I imagine we'll see at LEAST 6 different paid DLC's if JC2 or similar games are any example).Should you buy it? I bought it at $36 from Green Man Gaming. At that price, I say HELL YES you should buy it. For $60? Probably not. Find a discount price for the game... but use a REPUTABLE source. You don't want to lose your account over this game.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Mad Max can easily be summarised by the following.... Do you like Shadow of Mordor? Do you like cars? If so - then this latest WB release will be right up your street.The game centres around the main hero of the same title - finding and progressing his way through the desolate landscape that is synonymous with the story setting. Dry, vast expanses are covered fairly quickly by means of different vehicles as well as key locations being found that allow a much needed fast travel ability.You start out with literally nothing - though you quickly acquire a close follower called Chumbucket who's main role is to repair your vehicle - but also performs the function of a 'turret' from the rear platform of your vehicle. Low-level equipment unlocks allow a basic harpoon to be fired into opposing cars tyres, doors and even drivers - disabling them instantly and allowing you to close in for the kill. Higher-spec enemies are armoured, meaning that the harpoon too has to increase in ability, in order to immobilise the enemy. Later on, thunderpoons come online - literally a crude bazooka type weapon that can instantly render an enemy vehicle into burning wreckage, or failing that - Max himself can take aim from his driving position and fire the sawn-off shotgun with highly effective results.The car driving and battling is very well done. Don't for one minute expect Project Cars levels of vehicle dynamics - but what is there is accessible and more importantly - easy to understand and make sense of. Adding beefed-up armour may solidify your vehicle (affectionately known as the Magnum Opus) against head-on collisions. But the increased weight takes a heavy toll on the performance of the standard engine - even with modifications to the exhaust and other vehicle components.There's also a nice balance to the frequency of the car battles too. Not too many where progress becomes a chore, though not too infrequent as to be lacking. Aside from other wasteland drivers awaiting to take you off-road (in a far more literal and permanent sense) - there are convoys to attack in order for you to steal their prized cargo. Convoy attacks add an extra level of fun to the battles as the Magnum Opus is often out-numbered by 5-to-1 and escort vehicles that are rammed away can quickly make a return to the fray. The carnage that ensues is usually fast, frantic and enjoyable - especially when you become the victor through your own driving abilities.Max also slugs it out on foot - and this is where the immediate comparison to Shadow of Mordor appears. Hand-to-hand combat is very similar indeed - involving fists, feet, but also unlockable moves involving shivs, shotgun blasts and brutal finishing moves against walls or the floor itself. Boss fights occur when attacking a story or plot-line target and usually after taking on his henchmen first.One key aspect where Mad Max is superior to SoM however, is with the enemy respawning. SoM was totally and utterly ruined in my opinion, by the crazy respawn of orcs. 20, 30 sometimes even 40+ spawned enemies were battled against single-handedly, with little in the way of an end being in sight. In Mad Max, you assault a target with a fixed number of enemies - and those enemies don't magically respawn behind you once you turn a corner. It's a small change, but it makes for a much more rewarding experience and one that you feel that you're making genuine progress with.Underpinning Max's travels are the strongholds - visits to loosely allied centres of opposition across the map. Although very few in number, they need Max's help just as much as Max benefits from them. Upgrading the strongholds through mission completions allows the refilling of water canteens, ammo belts, health and petrol for the Magnum - with each returning visit. They are a safe bolt-hole should the enemies outside get a little too much. However, the people that run these strongholds clearly have their own agendas to be wary of.Mad Max, although superior in gameplay to SoM - isn't without some issues. First off, the fact that with only half of the game map currently revealed to me so far - I have already maxed out Max to the one-man killing machine that he has become. Also, the fast travel ability back to the strongholds makes it easy to flee the battle as ammo starts to run dry, resupply and then go back and carry on where you left off. Blocking within the melee combat phase can be a little hit and miss too - Max being committed to the attack animation, then being unable to block, despite frequent and sometimes frustrating presses of the block key. Another slightly silly aspect, is that despite the premise of fuel being more valuable than life - Max spends a considerable amount of time blowing up transfer tanks and other oil related production equipment. Someone also appeared to make fuel within the game very plentiful too.The crown jewel for Mad Max however - is the backdrop. It is stunning to look at in the most desolate and weary way. There's a beauty in the barreness of the wasteland that few other games have managed to capture. I recall being equally impressed by a very small number of titles to the scenery that unfolds before you. The Elder Scrolls Oblivion upon leaving the jail was one - as was exiting the Vault for the first time on Fallout 3 and finally peering off into the vast distance from a hillside on GTAV - which at the time was running on the minimalist hardware of the XBox 360.Mad Max instills into you, the clear and welcome need to go out and explore. There's a small plume of smoke on the horizon - what's over there? If I drive the car up to the top of that ridge, what can I see from up there? Many a time I find myself driving about simply because I can - and admiring the Sun bleached vistas before me. Even at night - the Moon shining high in the sky and stars set as a backdrop, hidden occasionally by the wispy clouds - or the oncoming onslaught of fierce storm. It's a very nice game to look at - especially with each location looking unique and not merely a clone of somewhere else, close by.Overall, I would heartily recommend Mad Max. It's a game that you can take at your own pace and plod through. It doesn't have the depth of similar background games - the Fallout and Wasteland series immediately spring to mind. However, if they were to create a love-child between themselves and this title - I believe that game would be the pinnacle of post apocalyptic escapism, imaginable.8/10

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Mad Max... four movies... a few books... plenty of content to draw from to make a game. This one supposedly created BEFORE the the latest film so therefore should draw on that content. Let me give you a quick rundown on the game and what I ultimately think of it with about 20 hours in the game. If your A.D.H.D. wont let you read for more than 2 minutes... skip to the bottom for my final verdict. Note that this is a review from a 25+ year gamer who is just over 30 years old.  OverviewYou are Mad Max. A long time ago a lawman in the Main Force Patrol, Max has been forced to become more animal than man as he struggles through life in the post-apocalyptic wasteland of Australia, In the films we see him get more and more lost as a person, and more and more brutal while trying to cling to the past. In the game, you are trying to live and make peace with yourself and your past. Not quite the deranged killer like in the latest film.The game starts out with your vehicle getting stolen (one of the Pursuit Special Interceptors). It is stolen by the Warlord and his men, Scabrous Scrotus (who ultimately is the son of Immortan Joe). Max is stripped of his weapons, clothes, and belongings. He has to learn how to survive again while making two very important friends along the way (this is your tutorial of sorts). After a certain key moment in the game (I wont give it away), you are thrust into the open world and allowed to follow the main storyline or do side questing. GraphicsI reference graphics early on in most games because there are a LOT of graphics ♥♥♥♥♥s out there. People that wont play a game unless it is up to par with current standards. You can be rest assured that the graphics while not next-gen, they do well for the setting and are pleasing on the eyes. They're good enough, but don't tax your PC. I'll explain more on that below in the review.I did see some screenshots of blurry graphics and abominations... but didn't experience any of that myself. I only ever ran into two graphical problems:1. While getting in my vehicle in front of an outpost, I looked back and could see through the front gate and into the world. For some reason at certain angles the graphics de-rendered. 2. While jumping off of a wall climb, I could see through a cave wall into the nothingness that is below the rendered world.Not bad all things considered. StorylineAfter the pivotal moment in the storyline... you'll get the option to explore. If you stick to the quests you'll be looking for a place to hide. Continuing with that will provide you with some unique objectives. The storyline itself seems... meh... at best. Your character doesn't seem so hellbent on revenge as I would have been. He instead goes off on various side tasks that seem to take away from the main story.The storyline does flow rather well and compel you to keep going. 20 hours into the game and I'm only into my second region with many more to go (thought I have been hitting up the side quests).Side QuestingThe side quests consist of everything from providing water to parched pedestrians (say that 10 x fast)... to clearing out stronghold camps... to collecting items from scavenge camps and more. I found myself reaching the second region, and going back to make sure I got 100% of the items from the first. I've done that in AC, JC2, and other games where I need to get a 100% and apparantly that's my OCD. The side quests are repetitive. No two areas seem the same... some are above ground, some below. Some have buildings, some have tunnels. Some places you blow up, some you have objectives in. They're different enough to keep doing them, but I can't help thinking that eventually, I'm going to grow tired of it (like I did in JC2). CombatI like the combat both on ground and in vehicles. But it does get repetitive. I went from being amazed and blown away by it all... loving every image that popped across the screen... to blanking out and then coming to after it was over. Just becomes something I have to get through, just to get through. The vehicle combat is either disable/destroy their vehicle, or hop out and hope they'll eventually do the same. Then it becomes a ground fight. I did that more often than not until I upgraded my Harpoon to level 4 (where I could then rip tires off). After that, I rip wheels off, and go to ground and fight or run them over. I can also harpoon them and fling them around for S's and G's.Most of your combat will be on the ground in strongholds and such. Get used to it, and try to do things differently if you can. Skills that Max acquires later will make the fighting more unique when he can do different finishers. But that comes later.Skills, and UpgradesYou can upgrade your character from the clothing to his finishers. You can upgrade his weapons, and add skill points to his health, how much water he gathers, etc. It's pretty extensive and makes your character feel unique. A lot of the upgrading as well as with the vehicle is done with scrap. Scrap is found across the world in mini-camps, destroying enemy vehicles, and more. The first few upgrades will seem easy. They then multiply and become increasingly expensive (like 600, 900, or more scrap). If you complete the main storyline you will have the opportunity to return scrapulance (scrap vehicles) to the base for a payout around 500 scrap each. This will help you upgrade quickly. I was impressed with the amount of things you can upgrade. Especially with the vehicle. Everything from the wheels to push bumper to engine to exhaust, etc. Some content unlocking is restricted to the story however.Game PerformanceI run a PC with the following specs:AMD FX-8370 (8 core CPU) @ 4.01ghzG.Skill RAM 16GB @ 1600mhzAsus GTX 960 2GBWindows 10I can run the game at 60fps on 1920 x 1080 with almost ZERO loss of frames with the graphics settings maxed out (except shadows which are on HIGH). Only once for some odd reason did I drop to 44 frames which then instantly went back to 60. I will always hover between 59 and 60 when just running around no matter how much I have on the screen (this is also while streaming). This is probably the SINGLE BEST port to PC that I've ever seen when it comes to performance. I've only run into a couple bugs, and really splitting hairs... I only have a few complaints about the game. It's not my "favorite" game... but it is absolutely solid. I had a few people message me about how it is... and I couldn't lie... it's decent.Final VerdictRepetition aside... the game is pretty fun. I still feel like I'm seeing some new things each time I load the game up. I'm generally liking the characters and how vastly different they are. The world is bland (desert environment) but then that's the whole premise behind it. The whole world is now waterless. Don't expect Just Cause 2 where you can go from swimming in the water to snow capped mountains in a few minutes. I feel the game is lacking a bit in terms of depth (they could really do something with the gang warfare to make it feel like a real struggle in the wasteland instead of mindless killing of a vehicle that just drove by). They could have allowed you to venture off and build your own fortress... and really feel like it's YOURS. Maybe become a Warlord yourself (but then would that really be "Mad Max"?)... all sorts of possibilities are in place for this game and franchise. It'll be interesting to see what they add in DLC's (I imagine we'll see at LEAST 6 different paid DLC's if JC2 or similar games are any example).Should you buy it? I bought it at $36 from Green Man Gaming. At that price, I say HELL YES you should buy it. For $60? Probably not. Find a discount price for the game... but use a REPUTABLE source. You don't want to lose your account over this game.

Posted: October 15, 2015
												Excellent graphics, Very optimized, Really big open-world, Best explosion and vehicle carnage, Great special effects and so many amazing locations to discover ! Post-apocalyptic game 8/10 ********A wasteland game that is heavily influenced by the movie of the year (2015), Mad Max: Fury Road. Though the main story doesnt exceed even the least of my expectations before the game's release but it delivers a vast open world with so many unique places to discover and pillage. Which happens to be the best part of the game.The main attraction of this game is the vehicular combat and the car customizing functionality. Learn to drive like a mad man to best your opponents in the desert wasteland and you will be visually rewarded with beautiful explosions and chaos. The combat style flows closely with the Batman: Arkham games ( made by the same developers ) but IMO: they made it much better and more violent like it should be. Experiment with all kinds of weapons you can find during a battle because they will never fail to amuse you. ( My favorite was the Thunderstick ). Setting aside the main quests, this game heavily relies on exploration and side quests. It may seem that the developers spent more time in designing the entire world than focusing on its story that reminds me of some other post-apocalyptic themed games I played before ( Fallout ).Bottom line is, this was an amazing hotseat video game that I could just turn my mind off to and relax.

												One of the best games I've played in recent years. The car combat is very satisfying and even the somewhat simplistic arkham style ground combat is fun, especially because the game switches the two around constantly. Like other reviewers have noted the game has a lot of "busy" work but I never found it to be any more "grindy" then what you generally see in pretty much every open world game these days.Also it needs to be said that the game is absolutely gorgeous. They actually managed to make a mostly desert area look beautiful and interesting. The day and night cycles are also noteworthy. The whole game just looks like a benchmark game, but it's extremely well optimised and fortunately never feels like one.It's one of the few games I actually 100%'ed this year and that says a lot about it. I could never put myself to do so in games like say: assassin's creed, and it's mostly just because the combat and the upgrading mechanics for the car are so much fun.Highly recommended!

Posted: September 3, 2015
												I haven't played much so far, but I am VERY pleasantly surprised with the level of quality this game has. Made by the same people who created the Just Cause series, Avalance have pulled out all the stops. I was reluctant at first because whilst Just Cause 2 in particular had very entertaining gameplay, the story and replay-value was lacking. I'm happy to say this isn't the case for Mad Max. The graphics are phenomenal and the map is beautiful and vast. There is vehicle and character customization, as well as levelling. There is a story with numerous interesting characters, a huge number of side quests, a brutal combat system, and many different environments to explore. I am usually sceptical of games based on movies (even by name, if nothing else), but this stands alone as a wonderfully crafted game with a unique atmosphere, and you will often stumble upon places that give you a sense of how the world was like before the apocalypse. The game delves into details I wouldn't ever have imagined it would. You have a journal that contains details on every aspect of the world. The countless different enemies you encounter in the wasteland, the different characters, weapons, items, relics, and so forth. The one issue I have found so far, is that the game isn't particularly challenging. I haven't died once yet (apart from the one time I accidentally rolled off a cliff, but that's a story for another occasion), which I find disappointing. Whilst enemies oft swarm you in large numbers, Max is considerably stronger (even before levelling up), which means I feel overpowered even before I've begun. A difficulty level choice would be a welcome, welcome addition.So far, I'd give it an 8/10. Surprisingly atmospheric, in-depth, and enjoyable. I'd highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
Mad Max is a combat racing and beat'em up adventure game. Having lost the Black-on-Black Interceptor to Immortan Joe's son Scrotus, the Road Warrior known as Max teams up with a blackfinger called Chumbucket, who sees Max as the Holy Driver that will help him build the greatest car the Great White has ever seen: the Magnum Opus.Pros: The story is bitter, as a Mad Max story should be: you aren't a hero, you a survivor that cares for no one, grudgingly making uneasy alliances strictly if it benefits you. The game seeks to be a love-letter to the post-apocalyptic franchise all other games, from Fallout to Borderlands, were inspired from. The landscape is much more varied than you'd expect from a desert, including volcanic sulfur pits, pearl-white sea beds, rocky canyons, black sludge marshes, even storms go from windy sandstorms to thunderstorm hurricanes, making sure each regions has an atmosphere of its own. The car combat mechanics are excellent, while the hand-to-hand combat is a brutal but instantly recognizable game of block, hit, parry and combo. Car customization is pretty sweet, some upgrades go without saying while others require you to balance speed and strength to fit your play style.Cons: The game lacks interactions, you may only speak to characters (which are pretty few) when there's a main or sidequest available, with the exception of the occasional encounter with scavengers. Many world objectives are repetitive, and camp bosses are simple reskins of each other, the level design being the only difference you'll find from one camp or convoy to another. There is no personal customization except for beard, the rest being straightforward upgrades. If you don't bother with lowering threat levels, completing Death Races or collecting cars, you will find the game to be extremely short.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!I really liked this game! The intuitive car combat makes it fun, so much so that I pretty much forgot the game allowed fast travel! I really wish there was more to the story, more people to interact with, but I guess that would make it too much of an attempt at a Fallout clone, so I'll take it for the depressing world it is, and give it a strong recommendation!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
 "I am the one that runs from both the living and the dead. Hunted by scavengers, haunted by those I could not protect. So I exist in this wasteland, reduced to one instinct: survive." Genre: Action Adventure, Open WorldYear of Release: 2015Developer: Avalanche Studios Presentation The graphics are spectacular; everytime I start up the game, I find myself continually in awe at the pretiness of the environments and beautiful graphical detail. Even better, this is an amazingly optimized game, so maintaining high-end settings won't be a problem for most people. The sounds, from the roar of car engines, the fiery explosions, and even the small echoes in the wind are appropriately mixed and sound excellent. The music however is not all that great and ends up being very forgettable, which is a shame given the epic score Junkie XL recently made for Fury Road. All these elements work together to create a world that really feels like a good blend between the feel of George Miller's original Mad Max films and the visual asthetics of Fury Road.   Story You are Max. Your world is fire and blood. Chances are if you've seen a Mad Max film, you know exactly what kind of post apocalyptic wasteland world Max lives in. But if you haven't, the game provides an intriguing look into the Mad Max world that's friendly to newcomers of the series. Lord Scrotus, son of Immortan Joe (the villain from Fury Road) has stolen Max's Interceptor, so now Max is on a quest to get it back. In doing so, he'll team up with the love child of Gollum and the Hutchback of Notre Dame, Chumbucket, a lowly mechanic who will help Max build the ultimate car, The Magnum Opus. The story, in spite of introducing characters and plot points that try to imitate the madness one would come to expect from a Mad Max story, just ends up being mostly forgettable. The story's greatest strength however is the fact that it is weak; it allows you to enjoy a much greater wasteland adventure outside the main quest line, and at no point attempts to pull you away from the fun you'll have exploring the world. So while it may be far from remarkable, the story in Mad Max is certainly passable, and does feels like the type of tale you'd expect to see in the films.  World As simple as a desert wasteland open world may sound, it's actually treated with incredible care and attention to detail. Driving through the abandoned leftovers of civillization and exploring landmarks such as highways or submerged airports provide a unique-feeling open world that's never boring to explore. Unfortunately, its paired with a mixed bag of side acitivies that may provide for several hours of gameplay, but quickly boil down to an Ubisoft-style arrangement of side-content. Some activities are very fun and usually worthwhile, but begin to feel repetitive after some time playing. The thing that keeps you coming back to do more of these activities is the sheer fun of exploring the beautiful and dangerous open world. Gameplay The gameplay formula in Mad Max is probably best comparable to Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag in the sense that roughly half the game is spent on land while another is in boat/car. Your car is fully customizable and upgradeable-- engine, suspension, armor, exaust, etc. are ALL elements that can be upgraded. Not all of the upgrades progress linerally (ie some upgrades raise certain stats while lowering others), forcing you to create a car that best fits your needs. Max also has a variety of upgrades to improve health and damage, but they're no where near as useful or as necessary.The driving is a big sluggish at first, but only takes a few hours of playing to master. Car combat is amazingly fun and the most well-done element of Mad Max. Every car combat encounter can be tackled with clever use of your harpoon, shotgun, thunderspoon, or just straight-up charged ramming into other vehicles. Factor in the wide variety of enemy types and levels, and you have a fairly deep car combat system. The harpoon and thunderspoon also double as a useful tool for destorying environmental obstacles or clearing pathways. Ultimately, this game really sets the bar for car combat/encounters in video games (*cough* Arkham Knight *cough).The on-ground gameplay is not so stellar. Mad Max is yet another game that borrows its combat system from the Arkham games, though admittedly this is one of the better takes on it. Max is a dirty fighter and the combat emulates that pretty well, but it eventually becomes repetitive and a bit clunky due to an awkward camera that actually makes combat harder than it should be. There's also a fair bit of boss battles throughout, but most of them end up not being fun or all that challenging due to the combat's simplicity. On-ground combat may occupy a good bit of the game, but it's not enough to stop you from pushing on. Conclusion Max Max is a fun and action packed adventure that provides a faithful representation of George Miller's Mad Max world. The story, though weak and somewhat forgettable, sets up a grander adventure outside the main plot you're bound to enjoy. As beautiful and unqiuely designed as the open world may seem, it's paired with a lackluster variety of side content that's fun, but somewhat tedious. The car, including its combat and upgrades, is a huge truimph and the best element of Mad Max. On-ground however, Max's gameplay falls a bit short due to clunky combat. In the end, while Mad Max may be somewhat repetitive and uneven in its design, it has several moments of greatness and kept me coming back again and again to play more. Final Rating: 7/10 Worth it if bought slightly discounted or cheaper.

												I went in not knowing what to expect. In my experience, movie games tend to be poorly made cash grabs, but I had heard good things about this one. The leveling system is rather unique. Rather than being based on experience, quests or the like, you raise your legend rank by completing specific tasks, some of them repeatable. This in turn gives you "tokens" which you can redeem with the enigmatic Griffa, who I am not entirely convinced isn't just one of Max's hallucinations. Now, how many tokens you can spend on any one aspect of Max's abilities is gated- a gate which increases as your olegend rank increases. While this does prevent you from just maxing out health right away, it also encourages you to spend tokens in other attributes- and you have to spend them all. Reaching the (heh) Max level is not that hard- by the end of the game, I was 84 levels over the "max" level after I ground to around level 90 at the first stronghold. Not that you have to, but it does make the game significantly easier. The Magnum Opus, well, she's a bit of a mixed bag. On one hand, once you get fully upgraded thunderpoons there is nothing in the game that can stand in your way. On the other hand, in order to have anything resembling decent handling you have to keep her relatively lightly armored. God forbid you want to do ramming attacks as well, although with thunderpoons, the stock harpoon, and a fully upgraded shotgun you won't really have need of those. Strongholds... now there's a fun mechanic. Strongholds are safe havens which you can upgrade to give you various benefits, such as free ammo refills, water, a full tank of gas.... basically, everything you need. And the more you improve a stronghold, the more it improves visually as well- you can see the difference you are making as it gets more built-up. Getting all the pieces required to do so can be a bit of a pain, but the payoff is well worth it, and thankfully you can mark their locations on your map while you are in the stronghold. The threat mechanic is two things: first, it determines how dangerous an area is by determining how many patrols there are, and second it acts to gate Magnum Opus upgrades. This is a bit of a mixed bag; on one hand, scarecrows and snipers are easy to find, and you can find a number of them just by using the omnipresent balloons which are in every region. On the other hand, clearing camps can become frustrating if you cannot find the last objective to destroy, as these are not in any way marked on your map. Minefields are actually not that bad, though- their is a mechanic for finding them, and it has a good bit of range to it. And generally, clearing out the camps is fun. Convoys are generally meant for when you are highly upgraded- the early ones can be taken out by Max with a fully upgraded shotgun, but the later ones almost certainly need high-powered thunderpoons to do readily. Now, the story... the wstory actually made me not like Max that much, but it fits; he's trying to survive, and trying to avoid becomming close to anyone. He is very single-mindely focused on his quest to cross the plains of silence, and to build a car that will let him do so. And he does not let anything or anyone get in the way. Could the story have been deeper? Almost certainly. But I do think the story was decent.  My conclusion? The game is fun, but as with any game, there are cons. But in my opinion, they do not outweigh the pros.

Posted: December 23, 2015
												Wow... just... WOW!  I cannot remember the last time I was so violently enthralled with a game from the very get go.  I was not expecting this to fully capture the FEEL of the mad max movies as incredibly well as it has done!  Though I am not very far into it at this point, it has been pure pleasure since the very beginning!The visuals are absolutely amazing, and optimization... holy sh*t!  I don't think I have ever seen a game that looks so good and runs so flawlessly!  This is probably one of, if not THE best looking games in my library and it runs on my 3440x1440 ultrawide smooth as silk on ultra settings!They did an amazing job giving you a huge wasteland to roam and explore, yet while the area is so vast, so far it has definitely not suffered from the traditional "open world sandbox travel through miles of nothing to get to the patches of content" syndrome.  Or at least it hasn't felt like it.  Maybe that's because the gameplay itself is just so d*mn much fun!  (did I mention how well it captures the feel of the films? :D)The "on foot" combat is very very much, the tried and true assassins creed, batman, shadows of mordor formula as many have stated, with the very refreshing alteration of being more brute strength and rage based then graceful cat like ninja.  You're not leaping all over hell and back, doing fancy spin kicks and back flips, it's more the "walk up to someone, grab em by the neck and smash their face into a table" type.  Absolutely LOVE it!Vehicular combat... this is the crème de la crème feature of this game, the grand masterpiece!  OMFG it is so much fun!  It's... well... it's something you really just have to experience for yourself, but... ya... wow!  I have seen a few reviewers complaining about the driving controls, personally I don't see it.  To me the driving has been better than most I have played.  The car has been easier to handle and control for me than most other games of this type.  Granted, I do not play racing games, where the entire effort of the game has gone into the driving / vehicle handling, but I do play most all of the sandbox games that involve guns and cars, and imho this one is better than most as far as vehicle control and driving is concerned.  (or again, maybe it's just because driving in THIS game is so much more fun than the others... I mean... when was the last time you were racing through a debris filled desert mashing it up with other cars and shot the driver with a harpoon and yanked him out of the other vehicle through the window?  Come on... so brutal... I LOVE it!)There is so much to go on and on about with this title in the way of comparison with other open world sandbox rpgs, but really... at least for me... there's no need, while all of those things do mashup to equate to the overall completeness and  complexity of the game (and they do so very well so far, and I have not yet found anything lacking in the way of systems or things to do), what it really boils down to for me... is fun factor... this game is SO much fun to play!  Based on what I have seen so far, I could wander aimlessly through the desert for hours just engaging in random encounters and still feel like I was getting my moneys worth on this game.  All technical, feature, and systems talk aside, it is just plain and simple, good old fashion fun!Def recommend this title to anyone who even remotely likes the Mad Max movies!
