												This game is exactly what I always wanted from a Mad Max game. Granted, I bought a Steam key from a friend pretty cheap, so I am judging the game based on spending $25 for it, not $60.Pros:*Open world filled with things to do and some really cool locations to explore.*Cool storyline.*Awesome driving with upgrades that really change the feel of your cars.*Optimized for PC - my PC is decent but not great and it runs it perfectly on ultra-high settings.*Combat is very Batman: Arkham City, especially once you unlock the cool maneuvers.*Length: I have 40 hours in, and I am still only at 50% completion.*The world conversations react to things you have done, so you see your legend grow.*Never felt like it was a grind for scrap, unlike some negative reviews. Decent pace for upgrading both Max, the strongholds, and vehicles.*YOU GET TO BE SHINY AND CHROME! WITNESS ME!Cons:*Only being able to climb/jump in specific areas means that you will get stuck sometimes. Like, if you fall off a walkway, you may find yourself stuck and unable to climb the ONE FOOT rocks hemming you in.*Easy. Like, the game is rather  too easy, especially if you are  like me and ignore storyline to do all the side quests and scavenging. By the time you do the storyline, you're walking through boss fights. I usually only die from stupid mistakes, like falling off cliffs or blowing myself up. *The bosses that rule the strongholds are all the same, just with different amounts of health. I feel like this was a cop-out. "AAAAAAAH.... MEDIOCRE!"All in all, I am having a BLAST playing this game and recommend it heartily. 9/10 at this price, 7/10 at full price.

												I wouldn't go out my way for it if i was you, but it's not like it isn't enjoyable. Here is the major problem. The game is 90% padding. There is fun, even in the padding but the studio obviously designed it to increase the length. If you're a completionist... just ignore the game. There is too much fluff which should be ignored, but will likely annoy you if you don't complete/remove it from the map.The worst part, i can't tell if the studio added stupid little touches to pad the game out further, or if they added bits that unintentionally lowered my enjoyment and increases time taken(by a small bit). For example, in sub upgrade menus, it will kick you back to the main upgrade menu if you buy something. This is not a problem when changing upgrades already bought. Also a dialog box will appear, telling you, you bought the item you bought, but to make matters worse, it has a short 2 second time preventing you from clicking the close button. These don't sound like a big deal but i'm guessing there are over 100 upgrades, some being purely cosmetic and i doubt you'll be wanting to grabbing these 1 at a time for the most part. There is just stuff like this, which on it's own in another game, you wouldn't dare call padding, but given statements from developer in the past, and how this game plays, you could be that cynical and think you're justified.Game pauses when you alt-tab, even in loading screen (You might care). With a GTX 970, and I7 4700k i was playing on high preset with i believe bloom and motion blur turned off. I was getting at least 100 FPS most of the time, but there was one area which i saw a constant 50FPS. It wasn't a dip! this was the area itself or possibly some other bottle neck in the system. When you launch the game, When on linux OS, if you aren't using Ubunutu or SteamOS, it will give you a warning that the game isn't optimized for your system (Message can be disabled). I was getting this with latest version of mint, which is based on Ubunutu but as said i was getting 100FPS on high.Basically, i don't recommend it, but if you've had your eye on it, maybe pick it up as one of your semi-risky but cheep buys. In terms of DLC, they didn't nickle and dime like shadow of mordor which has near universal bad rating for DLC (I hear the expansion DLC is good). It's a solid game, but it's covered in padding, that the developer thinks gamers want.

Posted: September 22, 2015
												I expected explosions, I expected epic car combat, I expected brutal combat and a harsh world, I got it all. Gameplay feels very solid, performance is GREAT, you can litterally run this on max with a potato, graphics fits very well with the wasteland feel. I had tons of fun with this game with a few nitpicks which I will write below.You start out with nothing, your legendary v8 Interceptor is stolen from you and you want it back! You drive around the wasteland scouring for scraps and blueprints to upgrade your new car, the Magnus Opus. To get car upgrades, rewards and good amounts of scraps, you will have to do certain things like destroying scarecrows or wiping out camps in the different areas. This can get a little repetive but the locations all have different designs, and by doing said things you get some badass upgrades for your Magnus Opus which makes it rewarding.Pros:+Excellent Performance.+Great graphics.+Great gameplay.+Sandstorms are epic.+Races with leaderboards and different modes+Convoys are great fun, feels very much like mad max.+The world has many interesting locations, specially in a certain sandy area.+History Relics are interesting and I really enjoyed the dialogue that max says when he looks at the photos.+Photo mode for screenshot enthusiasts ♥♥♥♥♥yeah).Mixed:-+The tasks in the zones feel a bit repetive, but they are all designed differently which makes most of them interesting.-+Story is a bit shallow early on but I got very engaged towards the end, nice buildup and imo a great conclusion.-+Thunderpoon makes the game feel super easy.-+If you have the friendly camps fully upgraded, you will refill all your ammo, fuel, health, water every time you fast travel or visit a friendly camp which removes a bit of the survival feel of saving your bullets and eating maggots to survive.Cons:-Minefields.-Random people you find in the world that you talk to, they feel shallow and when speaking to them you are frozen and can't move, so be prepared for yourself and the other person to get pancaked into the dust over and over again.-Scavenging locations, there are like 3-4 locations that I remember after finishing the game, (I did them all) they just feel like a grind.-Some areas can be a maze, mountain areas in particular, where you have locations that are hidden inside a mountain and you need to drive around 10 times to find the entrance.Is the game worth a buy? definitely, I've had tons of fun with this game and would recommend it to anyone who asks.

												Supports Vulkan API on Linux now. It's in beta but my framerate went from approx. 45 to 80 with nearly all graphic settings enabled. Regardless of what you think of this game go buy it and play it on Linux (I'm running the game in Fedora Workstation). See this post for instructions on how to get into the Vulkan beta: http://www.feralinteractive.com/en/news/753/I've only played one hour and I cannot tell much about the game itself. It's your regular open world game with a pretty solid car combat. The goal seems to be building your car and tuning it. The game has that Batman: Arkham Asylum combat when travelling on foot. It gets most Mad Max things right from the get go and it is a fun game to play if you get into it.Visually impressive landscapes. The game has decent soundscape but nothing special. Music is fine, I guess. The game controls are fine. It has proper mouse & keyboard support with proper key pop-ups for them on screen. Also supports controllers. Steam Controller works fine.

Product received for free
												A mix between Batman and budget Twisted Metal. Driving feels nice and the sound design is top notch, but that's about all I could take away as positive from it.-Vehicular combat feels incredibly awkward throughout, especially early on where you lack varied means to take other cars on. -Liberating outposts gets old very quickly and there's little enemy variety to back it up.-hundo'ing strongholds/reducing region threat seemingly holds no final reward, not even a pat on the back, besides apparently eliminating all enemy patrols from that region, removing one of the reasons to drive around in the first place.-Once you take down your tenth scarecrow, and disarm your twentieth mine, you'll realize how shallow side activities can be in a giant desert sandbox.-The wasteland seemingly has no likeable characters, only ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Even Max is thoroughly unrelatable, a stoic one-faced man in his pointless quest to build a V8 machine for seemingly no reason other than to go fast until he goes catatonic or dies. The game is pretty and stable, but so is a movie, and that one won't waste your time as much as this game will. Maybe watch that instead of playing this.

												I seriously have been waiting my whole life for this game. Outlander for the SNES came close and Rage tried it's best, but this was the Mad Max game that I had dreamed about since I was a little kid. Massive and gorgeous open world wasteland that's fun just to drive around all day. The combat feels very much like Batman's Arkham series and I'm more than ok with that. The way you level up both Max , his abilities and build up the car using separate upgrade systems for all three works really well.The artstyle and graphics are gorgeous and it seems to run buttery smooth on almost every system I've come acrosss.  It's too bad that The Phantom Pain seems to be overshadowing this game because I think this is seriously the best game out this year (better than GTAV for fanboy reasons of my own) and I hope it gets it's due because Avalanche have created a masterpiece here and any fan of the movies MUST own this game. My fifteen year old self will never stop playing this game.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Well where to start. There are a lot of really great things about Mad Max and thing's that reveal themselves over time to the displeasure of the gamer. I'll detail some pro's and con's seeing that there isnt alot of usefull information out there about this game and a lack of any official forum that ive seen. *I've looked, nothing but links to twitter and facebook on the main site*Con's1. Complete lack of any moral decision making outside of killing random wastelanders that want water or are trying to share scrap with you and no effect on the overall story whatsoever, there arent any repercussions to killing the random wasteland either. This means you wont have the choice to do the right thing or the wrong thing, just whatever the designers wanted you to do for the story they wrote. 2. Lack of multiplayer in a game that would have benefitted it greatly.3. Minimal HUD options can take you out of the world fairly easily.4. Wonky camera control while first person driving, its especially irritating in combat.5. Nothing to do after completion of game besides minor random car battles that are overly easy, I never felt like I was fighting for my life and they tend to run away most of the time near the end of the game.6. Every "Top Dog" boss is essentially the same boss battle over and over and most of the times with a palette swap, very lazy considering the universe mad max is set in is very diverse with their wastelanders generally.7. Car customization isnt so much car customization as it is just upgrading stuff, your stuck with the same batch of weapons even though you see other cars with neat stuff and can use them allthough they are never as effective as the magnum opus since you can only use your shotgun do to the lack of Chum not being available on any ride except for the opus. There's no way for you to truly make the car your own either, your limited to about 6 paint jobs that are used on all the cars in game pretty much, no personal decal deisnger so your stuck with the base in game decals which are passable if you find one you like and about 6 or so car bodies most of which look like crappy sports cars with the exception of the death rattle which resemble's nux's car from Fury Road.8.Wasteland base upgrades are a neat concept but ultimately outside of refilling your ammo ,gas,health, and water *making the survival aspect of the game nil and void* they don't do anything aside from maybe open a back area where you can't do anything or perhaps add some cloth drapes to an overhang. That and I dont see myself co-operating with people that willing participate in a slave trade.9. Max's movement at times since clunky and underdeveloped especially when you realize there is a jump button and its♥♥♥♥♥♥poor and is mostly there so you can hopefully hop out of whatever broken mess of♥♥♥♥♥♥you landed in. I've had to restart the game due to being stuck at least 10 times.10. No contextual cover and movement meaning that there is no cover button in a world filled with cover. No ducking behind your car or crocuhing or sneaking. Max is more or less a wrecking ball, The opus can handle almost entire camps without having to actually do much other than torch people as you lead them to your car.11. Severe lack of character development and meaningfull interaction. In a game where the main character is known for being a man of few words you'd think the extraneous characters would recieve mass amounts of attention but after realizing the game was being made with an american voice actor before fans flipped out and they did the right thing hiring an australian I realized they didnt have a good grasp of the source material and what drives these characters.12. Lack of ranged weapon's, Okay this is something I kind of understand, in an apocalypse theres not going to be a ton of weapons floating around with normal people being ditched due to the lack of ammo. Well in the setting they used the bullet farm exists and not only that but you help a guy find sulfur and saltpeter to make black powder. So why is there a complete lack of any actual firearm outside of max's shotgun and car usuable only sniper rifle, not even a pistol is to be seen anywhere. 13. The Max menu for character customization is also just an upgrade menu with minimal choices for max's look and gear. The facial options you can take for max are things like max with beard, max with beard and bandanna, No clean shaven max's of yesteryear for the fans.  Your relegated to ending up looking lika a commando if you want to use the better gear. The knuckle dusters you make and the armor doesnt feel like anything max would have ever used. your shotgun upgrades read as such * max add's a barrel to the shotgun* add's a barrel? how? with what? where? just scrap metal? This game would have benefitted from an actual equipment system instead of just assuming you have these things like plyers and for some mystery reason the only thing you ever have to buy is a crowbar which is a completely pointless mechanic to open some doors and box's considering how cheap it is it can be bought at the beginning of the game making the doors and chests just irritating.14. Car combat is ultra repetitive and barely entertaining after awhile, using the harpoon gun to destroy pretty much everything gets boring.Pros.1. The game is beatiful if you have the power to run it maxed 2. Hand to hand combat feels brutal.3. Fun till completion of the main storyline.4. A good first try at a Mad Max game in over 20 years. Hopefully one they expand on and get right next time.5. Cruising around in crazy storms is fun but ultimately you end up sitting in the same spot for 5 mins if your on a mission or doing something where you cant be destroyed.

content:
Posted: January 21
												Hold A to Do Things: The Game.Alright, Jesus f*ck, I'll do an actual review. *clears throat* Mad Max is a game that has a lot of great qualities, but those great qualities get buried under a crushing weight of collectible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and dickish game design, which is apparently common for sandbox games nowadays. Below are my thoughts:First, the good. The car combat is pretty damn good, with ramming grills, tire grinders, rocket launchers, harpoons, flamethrowers, a shotgun, and more. It's fun to occasionally just buzz around, destroying enemy cars in various ways and trying to avoid getting destroyed yourself. It's let down, however, by the terrain. You'll notice that in the films, most car battles take place in flat, featureless desert. Because of this, the focus is on the cars' interactions, not their trying to stay on the same path. The game's world, on the other hand, is filled with hills, cliffs, ditches, and bumpy patches, so you can't trust that you won't crash horribly or go completely off course while taking your eyes off of the road to shoot at an enemy. This makes the car combat significantly less fun, which is a shame.The melee combat is basically the same as that of the Arkham games, but with a few key differences. First of all, the animations for everything, especially the finishers, are hilariously over the top. It's like Max learned everything he knows about fighting from watching Arnold Schwarzenegger films and professional wrestling. If nothing else, you can get in brawls just to have a dumb chuckle at how Max decides to dispatch someone IN THE MIDDLE OF A REAL FIGHT with a SUPLEX, of all things, and then go after his friend with a headbutt and a leg-lock (although enemies not dead after one one finisher will be perfectly happy to stand on their broken legs and punch you with their shattered arms). Second, it's generally easier overall, which there's nothing wrong with if you want to make an easier game. Third, you have the option to dispatch any enemy bothering you at any time with a shotgun blast at the cost of one shell, which is hilariously abrupt. Fourth, you can use melee weapons and single-use knives, which adds a nice bit of variety. Fifth, it's pretty ♥♥♥♥♥ily programmed. Especially near the end of the game where the enemies start piling up, you can occasionally press a button and have Max not do the thing you just ordered him to do, which is ridiculous and frustrating. Finally, you can get attacked in the middle of finisher animations, which is just stupid. It's perfectly realistic to have someone hit you in the back while you're piledriving his friend, but in a game where you can't do anything about it it's the very epitome of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tty game design.There are bases scattered around to liberate that are really interestingly designed, with catwalks, teetering structures, towers, ziplines, and lots of nooks and crannies that are fun to explore and seem like interesting places to live. At times, though, the various collectibles scattered throughout are so well-hidden that I had to consult walkthoughs to find all of them.The car upgrades overall are really neat and varied, but they can be applied everywhere, instead of just the garage. Normally I wouldn't mind such convenience, but it wouldn't make that much of a difference in this case and it doesn't make sense if you can completely overhaul your car anywhere.The game looks very good, especially the wasteland and the fire effects, but not as good as Just Cause 3. (But then, what does?)You're allowed to run over random neutral NPCs, even questgivers, which is always fun.The sound design's good. The mocap's also good. There's a nice limping animation for when you take fall damage, and there's a dog in particular who looks and acts exactly like how you'd expect a dog to act, except for the fact that he seems perfectly content to sit in a confined box for the entire game.There's judicious use of slo-mo throughout the game that adds a lot to car crashes and fight scenes.The Cleanup Crew upgrade is really convenient, as it automatically collects Scrap (the game's currency) from car wrecks you just created, but I feel like it should also apply to Scrap drops from fallen Scarecrows and enemy troops.Alright, that was all the good (although looking back, a lot of those were backhanded compliments and damning with fine praise), so here's the bad. Prepare for a lot of petty complaints.The world is outwardly the same world as the Mad Max films, specifically the same general area as Fury Road. There are a few problems with this, though. First of all, the plot has some ties to Fury Road, but none of Fury Road's characters show up and that's not Tom Hardy we're playing as, so I'm not sure what the point is. Also, the main villain is Immortan Joe's (until now unmentioned) son, Scarabus Scrotus. He's another 7-foot-tall goliath, but he doesn't have any severe physical defects (at least at first) like Joe's other two sons, which completely undermines Joe's emotional conflict in Fury Road. More generally, the world is outwardly the same Mad Max world as ever, but it's lacking George Miller's deft touch and artistry. The cars are either basic hot rods or lumps of incoherent vehicle instead of machines with personality and theme, and the insane people just speak random pidgin English instead of the natural-seeming dialect of the films. Giant lumps of muscle like Humungus and Rictus Erectus were anomalies in the films, but they're just all over the place here. It's clearly someone trying very hard to be George Miller, and while I don't blame them for not having the guy on hand at all times and having to make do without him, it's still very noticeable in-game.The story and characters are just kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Max has a couple of nice moments (laughing at a guy who thinks a fiberglass helmet will protect him from headshots springs to mind), but most of the time he and everyone else are annoying, entitled, and stupid.Fury Road's toxic masculinity overtones become just toxic masculinity...tones here. Scarabus Scrotus wears a spiny♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on a codpiece for some baffling reason, and lots of other minor villains have weird sexual backstories and fetishes that the game brings up constantly. This driving game doesn't have handbrake turns for some baffling reason. They could even bind it to RB! Why isn't it there?There's supposed to be some sort of survival element, with constant shortages of scrap, gasoline, water, and shelter, but resources are f*cking everywhere and you can quickly unlock the ability to get infinite ones every time you return to a garage, so I'm not sure what the point is. Scrap in particular is ridiculously abundant; by the end of the game I had about 15000 in reserve with nothing to spend it on.There's two different upgrade systems for Max, but both are easy to fill out fairly early in the game (making you overleveled and overpowered for most of the rest of the time) and neither make sense, as this is another game with a protagonist already fully formed at the beginning with no real room for improvement.The population density is absurdy high for the apocalypse.This game has the worst jump button I have ever seen. It's unreliable, clunky, and only necessary for a handful of optional Scrap locations. If you don't need one, don't have one.There are lots of other small problems, but overall, the game's main issue is that there's a ridiculous ♥♥♥♥ton of content for content's sake. Scrap, Scarecrows, Snipers, relics, bases, minefields (those are a chore), side missions; I felt compelled to do all of it, and got drawn into an endless pit of boring, repetitive collection. I started out thinking this game was OK, but over time those feelings dissolved into hatred of the endless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Any joys the game has are eventually consumed by the endless, meaningless  stuff . Ugh.Get Just Cause 3, not this.

												After fully completeing this game i can now say that I would not recommend it based solely on how un challenging and repetitive the gameplay is, you get spoon fed all the hidden objects, loot etc you just have to drive near it and it will be permenently marked on your map. The enemies dont increase in difficulty at all while max just becomes unstoppable within the first few hours, you can max out all maxs skills before even completing 30% of the game making the griffa tokens a pointless edition espically when they just hand them out for no reason half the time. The storyline is weak but still followable. The side quests and loot locations are repetitive and become boring after the first large territorial state is cleared fully. Minefields are just a waste of time offering no real loot value while taking the longest time to get to since you cant quick travel with the dog. Cars are quite cool as is the combat with the vehicles while the "Races" are more just you trying to reach a certain location while a bunch of slow weak cars try to ram you off the road to stop you reaching your destination, all you need to do is use one nitrus boost and you can outrun them for the entire race. Combat is basically just punching someone and pressing block button when it notifys you someone is about to hit you, you also have a shot gun with limited ammo. The fighting is redicoulously easy and i would be suprised if you ever die in combat during the entire game. Pros:Good graphicsFun cars/ car combat40+ hours gameplay with all content included in one priceCons:RepetitveNo ChallengeNo skill or tatic requiredWeak StorylineLots of cutscenesLots of pressing activation buttons during battlesLots of waiting and holding E to open things and interact with objectsBoring race tracksBoring Bland MapRepetive LocationsUniteresting Spoon Fed CollectiblesRepetitiveRepetitiveRepetitiveRepetitiveRepetitivebut i did spend over 40 hours playing it so it wasnt the worst game just not as good as other games avaiable at the moment for cheaper.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												Very under rated game.Most open world games lose my interest fast as they involve a lot of repeat content. All those side activities and missions end up feeling indentical after you have done a few.  I figured madmax would be the same. I was pleasantly surprised when I started noticing how each little side area and objective were not only hand crafted/designed to be different, but many had different mechanics from each other. No two warcamps are the same. Hell, even the balloon quick travel points are different and require a unique mechanic to complete (ie: one might require you to refuel the balloon, another has you driving your car around to remove the cables that are tieing it down).The game feels very mad max. The world is closer to feeling like the newer film than the older (which is fine, I love all of them). Driving is a lot of fun, and the batman like combat is also fun. I enjoy the combat in this better than in batman for a few reasons. 1. The rage system - It makes combat that much more interesting than in batman. 2. Unlike batman, there are times when you realistically just cant counter an attack, even if you see it coming. If you are in the middle of grabbing some guy and breaking his neck, its just not realistic to think that you can suddenly counter another attack. Dont worry though, you can still counter 9 out of 10 attacks if your timing is good, but there is a bit more realism with the system than there is in Batman (where you will go flying accorss the screen no matter what you were doing, to counter an attack).The amount of customization and upgrades in the game is pretty insane too. You have TONS of car options and upgrades, character upgrades, a skill/train system with upgrades, and a "hideout" upgrade system that lets you build things in your base of operations. The car upgrades are by far the most impressive. The sheer number of things you can add and customize is great.The voice acting is also top notch and very accurate with a Max film. The characters all have that no longer part of the reality we know behavior, much like the films. The visuals in the game look very appealing too. Sure, its not super 4k ultra mega Alpha X resolution textures and special FX, but it still looks darn good. Not only that, it runs VERY well. Smooth framerates 99.9% of the time, plenty of video options to adjust. No complaints here, and im VERY picky about graphics and graphical options.My ONLY 2 gripes about the game:1. Getting enemies OFF your car is just a pain. Even after you put spikes all over your car, people will still jump on it. If you are low on shotgun ammo (which you are most of the game), you dont have an easy way to remove them. Smashing into another car sometimes does the trick, but if you dont have another car to smash into, then the best option, believe it or not... is to stop your car... AND GET OUT. WTF?? Really? It really breaks the whole "high speed action car chase" if the best option is to stop and get out. Id like them to add some more ways to remove enemies. Especially if they are on the driver side. Let Max reach out and punch or pull them off the car. Maybe your hunchback can push them off? Maybe once you have spikes, it drains their life the longer they are on the car, until they die and fall off? Something more needs to be added. Its a minor gripe, but one that pops up every so often during car combat.2. Climbing up on things. Imagine this situation. 2 cargo storage containers. Both the same size. One has a yellow marked metal bar on top, signifying that you can jump up, grab it, and pull yourself up. The other doesnt. Er... why cant I climb the other one? Worse yet, there are things that are only 3-4 feet high that you cant grab and pull yourself up to. Thankfully, most of the game doesnt revovle around needing to get up on these things, but from an open world exploration, or even "which path should i take" aspect, it can be kinda annoying.Both of these things however dont take away from the games fun, or keep me from recommending it. The game is a blast to play and a visual feast for mad max fans. The one thing id like to see from a DLC, would be a co-op play via the net. Would be super fun to do all the racing and car combat with another person by your side. (doubt that will happen though)

Posted: September 2, 2015
												An accurate simulation of life in Australia, Mad Max has great driving physics, and beautiful graphics and sound design. Just listen to how the engine note of the Magnum Opus changes slightly with every upgrade or take Chumbucket's buggy rockclimbing and note the detailed suspension movement. This is a solid game.This game plays great with a keyboard, but doesn't support controllers other than a 360 pad. Steering wheel support should have been a consideration with a game so heavily focused on driving.Occasional UI glitches appear; Most of the time your mouse cursor will appear over gameplay, which can be solved by pausing and unpausing. Other times, the pause menu's back button will continue to be drawn over gameplay, which can be fixed by clicking it. Other than that, the game runs flawlessly.The game looks somewhat difficult to mod, with all data files being stored in proprietary archives. As a singleplayer-only game, mods and user-generated content are key to its survival.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Made by the same studio that made the legendary Just Cause 2 (best $5 you can spend on Steam, by the way - nab it in the next sale!), Mad Max is an open-world game in the Just Cause vein, but set (as you can guess) in the world of the Mad Max films. Coming from a studio that have proven themselves so capable of open-world games before, it's no surprise that the game does a great job of turning Max's world into a massive vehicular playground.The game does an amazing job of bringing the Mad Max world to life, right down to details you don't think about in the films, such as the sheer scarcity of resources. Unfortunately that attention to detail is also the game's biggest flaw: once you've spent upwards of ten minutes just scrounging for something to restore your HP and only find enough medical supplies to heal yourself by half, you begin to realize that outside of the car chases, the Mad Max world ... really isn't all that interesting. It's just a flat desert with few settlements, all of which are cobbled together from ugly junk, and populated by scattered bands of savages whose most intelligent battle strategies are to ram you with their car or punch you in the head. The movies cut the experience down to just the cool parts - in a video game, you also have all the dull stuff in between.That's not to say this game isn't fun - because it is, especially if you love the movies - but if you're looking for the next awesome open-world game to top Just Cause 2 or GTA V, this probably isn't it.THE GOOD:- Even for a game in which 90% of the world is brown sand, this game looks BEAUTIFUL. There is so much fine detail, right down to Max's tracks in the sand. If Just Cause 3 looks half this good, we have a lot to look forward to.- Even though the world is very empty, it makes up for this by making most objects smaller than a building destructible or otherwise interactive. Run over a rocky hillside and knock the rocks down. Ram a rusted-out car body and watch it shatter. Blow stuff up with gas cans, because nobody in Mad Max Land has ever heard of conserving fuel. It's fun just to see which environmental objects will react when you mess with them.- Your car, the Magnum Opus, is (somewhat) customizable, and it comes with a Jockey from Left 4 Dead 2 who performs repairs for free any time you hop out. Minor spoilers: the iconic Interceptor is stolen in the opening cutscene, but one of the Magnum Opus' body styles is nearly identical, so it's almost like you still have it. I'm 100% sure they added that just to make fans of the main car happy (like me!).- Lots of NPC vehicles, which are a collect-a-thon in and of themselves (can you steal them all and gather them at your strongholds?). They all look like the kind of crazy machines you'd expect to see in the movies.- The game and its world feel very authentically Mad-Max-esque. It feels more like Road Warrior than Fury Road, perhaps just because the action tends to be less in-your-face. The story has loads of references to Fury Road though, and the main plotline has you trying to reach Gas Town from the movie.- Some people hate the weird quantities in which you find Scrap (the game's currency), but I like it because it provides a touch of realism. You wouldn't find stacks of neatly-sorted and counted-out metal in a real wasteland, would you?- The explosions are awesome and sometimes in slow-mo!- The villain in the intro movie rides a ridiculous motorized throne in true Mad Max villain fashion.- There's a dog!THE BAD:- This game reveals the disappointing truth that life in a post-apocalyptic desert wasteland isn't all high-adrenaline pedal-to-the-metal car chases. Sometimes you have to search for food. Sometimes you have to scour an abandoned camp for car parts. Sometimes you have to kill a dozen guys with your bare hands just for a sip of water. Most of the time you just have to drive in a straight line through the blank desert, hoping to stumble across something worthwhile.- With Chumbucket the seemingly-invincible mechanic riding the storyline's Magnum Opus vehicle and providing free repairs, there's no real reason to use any other car in the game. The MO is basically indestructible (if it gets to low HP, you just have to get out and let Chum repair it), and oftentimes you'll need Chumbucket's advice in order to complete a mission, which you won't have if you take another vehicle.- The Magnum Opus' customizability is fairly limited, and chances are you'll end up with all the parts by the end anyway. None of the ones I've gotten yet required me to swap out anything except the body shell, so I don't know if I'll have to choose mutually-exclusive parts down the line or not.- Goals aren't always clear - I have to keep talking to the same NPCs to remember what I'm supposed to do. One guy keeps telling me he's getting impatient, but I forgot what his mission actually is.- Combat is awkward at best and wonky at worst. Basically all you do in melee combat is spam M1 except when an enemy is about to knock you down, in which case you press M2. Car combat is limited to ramming your opponent full-force (the quickest/best option), sideswiping them repeatedly (difficult and doesn't do much damage), or impaling the other driver with the Magnum Opus's harpoon gun (fun, but not that fulfilling).- The keyboard controls are a bit weird, requiring you to hold down keys to perform simple actions (e.g. hold E for ~1/2 second to pick something up) rather than just tapping the key like other games. Stranger still is that it isn't even done to make up for key-taps being bound to other actions - tapping E does nothing, for instance. I'm still scratching my head as to why this is done this way.Definitely recommended for fans of the Mad Max films. If you want an amazing action game and haven't played Just Cause 2 yet, go play that instead, then come back to this on a sale.

MAD MAXReleased in 2015, Mad Max Takes place in the iconic 80's style Post-Apocalyptic Wasteland where everyone is insane, and Max is just trying to get to the plains of silence, a peaceful place, when his car gets wrecked and stolen.He now has to join forces with Chumbucket, a talented mechanic, to build the Perfect car for this mad world, and get his revenge.Pros:+ HUGE and Fantastically crafted open world, the best desert wasteland I've ever seen in a video game.+ BEAUTIFUL graphics, I stopped the game to take screenshots and admire the vistas countless times. + So many different and interesting places to explore.+ Great attention to detail, everything feels used and you can see the remains of the old world all around.+ The overall world and lore take heavy inspiration from the best movies in the series, Fury Road and The Road Warrior.+ Good Story, gives you reason to go on+ Chumbucket is a nice character, but can be a little annoying sometimes (Like saying "A MIGHTY DUSTER!" every 10 minutes)+ Combat is Great, both Car combat and Hand combat feel heavy and visceral (Hand combat is a lot like the Batman Arkham series)+ Good Physics+ Fun missions+ Great Car variety, every faction has their own cars+ Max's Car is VERY customizable and upgradable+ Max himself has a good amount of upgrades and customization+ Random Sandstorms are very cool and feel a lot like Fury Road.+ Races are cool.+ Great Photo-mode, I wish every game had one like this. + Good Collectables, Historic Relics shows the old world, the fall, and max's thoughts+ Great sounds+ Very well optimized game[b/Cons:[b/]- I would like to have the dog around as a companion. (and not stuck to a single buggy)- It becomes very repetitive after a while, since you have to do the same activities over and over again to progress.- You have to grind A LOT to get the best parts.- Too many collectibles.- Looking for every scrap becomes a chore very quickly. (and is needed for 100%)- It will take you VERY long If you want to get 100% completion (75+ hours), and after all that, there is a chance the game will bug and refuse to show you 100% stats or give you the last achievement.- More and harder survival elements would have been nice.Despite the negatives, This is a great Open world game, I completed it 100% and I plan on playing it through again in the future.I really recommend it if you like open world action games, and this is a MUST PLAY if you like the Mad Max series."My name is MAX, my world is Fire and Blood..."

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												The first thing you should know about Mad Max before you buy it, is that it borrows a lot from other games.There are camps that you can capture, that pay out resources occasionally. Before you take these camps, it is ideal to scout out their defensive features, such as snipers or flame thrower traps. You do this by standing nearby, somewhere out of sight, with your binoculars which will mark these defensive features for you (much like in far cry 3, except it does not mark individual enemies). Each of these camps also has a myriad of minor objectives to complete, such as finding all the scrap, historical relics, or whatever other random things are scattered around the camp, or destroying insignias. Once you do this, you get a nice shiny 100% on that camp.The melee combat is fairly fun, though a bit more weighty than some might like. However, it is the same system as assasins creed, or the batman games. You will spam (light attacks) or hold (heavy attacks) the x button, and press the y button to parry (ideally at the right time, so you have a better counter). Some attacks can't be parried, so you will have to roll out of the way.The driving itself (aside from boosts, weapons, and other such things, of course) is fairly similar to GTA V's as far as weight goes. The vehicle combat is also pretty fun, with a fairly large variety of enemies and tools at your disposal.There are also a few survival aspects, such as a canteen you want to keep filled with water so that you can heal (you don't regenerate health), or cars burning gasoline (which can be scavenged at many places on the map).Overall, I found it to be very fun for the first few hours. However, if you have played a lot of Assasin's Creed, or any of the Batman games, the melee system may be a bit more dull for you. If you have played either, I'd suggest picking it up on a sale, as the world of Mad Max is still very fun to drive around in and experience. If you like vehicle combat in games, or generally just driving around and exploring the map, this is definitely worth considering.

												After watching some streams of the game and reading the reviews of the "critics", I was slightly skeptical of the game.I was wrong. Right from the start, the beautiful cinematics grab your attention and throw you straight into the story. There wasn't a whole lot of screwing around with the settings to be done, as it was already optimized for my PC. The controls are very easy to learn and use (as they are similar to most games). The combat so far has been fun and you feel so powerful when fighting. It's a whole lot of button mashing though and there isn't a whole ton of skill involved in the melee combat. The story line is quite linear, but I like it! It's easy to follow along with and stay on track- but at the same time you're in an open world. I don't like games where you get lost on what to do, or where to go, and this is definitely not one of those games.I feel like the post-apocalyptic look could use some more scenery rather than just boulders and desert (yes, I know this is how the movie is), because it feels bare and somewhat static at times. Although, this is the complete opposite at some points when it comes to the intense scenes with the storms and what not.My first two hours of the game have been pretty great. If it wasn't 4:30am already, I would play this game for hours.I would definitely recommend this game. It's a great way to pass the time in a single player environment.

Posted: September 19, 2015
												Mad Max is a collection of great ideas poorly tied together and capably (but not perfectly) executed.  It's shallow gameplay is outstnding fun when taken in small doses.  Just don't plan on powering your way through this game in a few sittings; if you do, the lack of polish, disjointed story, and repetition (oh lord, the repetition!)  will kill your buzz all too soon.Mad Max has been compared and found wanting to Assassin's Creed and Batman: Arhkam games (and rightly so while on foot), but the best part of Mad Max takes place behind the wheel.  The car chases (enemies chasing you and vice versa) and convoy battles will stick with you and drive you to play even more  ...at least while they last.  Unfortunately, there are only a limited number of convoy missions (and no free-roam convoys), which is a shame since this seems to be every player's favorite activity.  There are still randomly spawning enemy vehicles roaming the wastes, but they seem fewer and fewer as the game progresses, and enemies flat out run away once your vehicle becomes moderately equipped.If you're looking for a good gap filler - a game to play when the latest MMO has become stale, but before another massive time-sync game - this is a great place to start.  Just don't be in a rush to finish.

Posted: September 2, 2015
												An accurate simulation of life in Australia, Mad Max has great driving physics, and beautiful graphics and sound design. Just listen to how the engine note of the Magnum Opus changes slightly with every upgrade or take Chumbucket's buggy rockclimbing and note the detailed suspension movement. This is a solid game.This game plays great with a keyboard, but doesn't support controllers other than a 360 pad. Steering wheel support should have been a consideration with a game so heavily focused on driving.Occasional UI glitches appear; Most of the time your mouse cursor will appear over gameplay, which can be solved by pausing and unpausing. Other times, the pause menu's back button will continue to be drawn over gameplay, which can be fixed by clicking it. Other than that, the game runs flawlessly.The game looks somewhat difficult to mod, with all data files being stored in proprietary archives. As a singleplayer-only game, mods and user-generated content are key to its survival.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Mad Max has climbed up to my list of top favorite games. Considering that includes Super Metroid, Mass Effect 2 and Witcher 3, that has to mean something!I must preface this review: it's been years since I have personally had a game like Mad Max land on my doorstep. A game that is just pure fun, that is almost completely stress-free, yet at the same time is not stupid and mindless with mediocre gameplay. Oh no. This is a great game.So, let's begin (no spoilers).--Mad Max shares a lot of similarities to Far Cry 3 and 4. It's just a huge open world with a bunch of objectives to complete and places to explore. There's the story, but you kind of do it inbetween your open world rampage. That's definitely not the primary reason to get the game, but it's not a bad part of the package. You play this game to have a blast.Some of the objectives feel repetitive, a common point of recent critic reviews, but the gameplay more than makes up for it. There's nothing like ripping around a huge open world slaying man-scum. More on that later.Upgrading your vehicle feels good. The scrap system is simple, yet at the same time demands that you make choices about what equipment you really want to purchase. Speed? Buy that. Armor? Buy that! There's some complexity involved in some gear having weight, where you have to decide on whether a piece is worth its trade-off. It's a great upgrade mechanic that remains minimalistic without hurting the complexity involved.Related to upgrades: there is something called the "Archangels" system, which is somewhat like gear loadouts. Neutral towards it, as I didn't, personally, find it very useful after the first mission that required it. What you will find is that the game throws a lot of tools at you, and you are free to embrace or disregard a lot of them (such as the Archangel system). The game lets you play how you really want to play, without punishing you.Speaking of gameplay: it feels raw and powerful. In fact, stuff happens in this game - quite often - that makes you pause for a moment, regain footing in reality, and ask: did that just happen?For example, I engaged a convoy during a dust storm, and it was one of the most epic moments in recent memory for gaming. Cars got picked up and blown to pieces in a giant dust devil - while lighting was striking the ground rampantly all over the place - and, immediately after, the final cars were picked off by ramming them over a cliff, in which they exploded in a fiery blossom of pure carnage as I landed with a cool half-donut slide across the sand. This is something that occurs several times throughout your Mad Max experience.What further enhances the gameplay are the small details. The fact, for example, that you can pick up a gas can and place it in the back of your vehicle as a spare only enhances the immersive grip of the game. And there are small details like that everywhere. I'll hold back on spilling them here. They are much more enjoyable and respectable when witnessing them firsthand, for the first time.The graphics are superb. Some of the effects are jaw-dropping. There are some very neat smoke, particle and dust tricks that I just have to appreciate as a Unity hobbyist. The backdrops are some of the best I've ever seen. It can be very immersive if you let yourself get absorbed by the endlessness of the great sandy plains.The level design is out of this world. It was painstakingly handcrafted, and it's obvious that was the case. It's my personal favorite part of Mad Max, and I would argue it's some of the best level design for this generation of games (if not overall, at least in the category of open world). Dead ocean is the primary setting, and it's incredibly imaginative. The rolling dunes, cascading sheets of dead-ocean rock, mountainous crags and canyons, sulfur-spewing flats, rusty car graveyards and half-buried ruinous bandit strongholds--when you step back, pause a moment, and stare, you will find yourself silent. The world is amazing, engrossing; the world is truely barren and apocalyptic, yet beautiful in its own, twisted way.Just as the game world feels endless, the amount of stuff to do is also up there. Racing and collectibles are on that checklist of stuff to do once the main story and territory control begins to near completion. The collection system actually has gameplay-focused elements: you can drive captured bandit vehicles and the special, collectible hood ornaments actually have statistical value as car equipment. They are not big parts of the game, but it definitely beats the seemingly infinite amount of worthless collectible garbage that other companies forcefully shove into their products.The only negative tick on my list of Mad Max items is the repetitive missions. There are a few variants of outposts to capture, but the game would have been even better if there were more creative mechanics put into these, especially considering they take away from the (superior, I'd argue) car-based gameplay. That said, the level design is a spectacular solution on this front. The objectives feel the same, but the outposts definitely do not, and they boast some of the coolest realizations of beat-down apocalyptic shanty-fortresses that I've had the pleasure of visiting. A bandit fortress propped atop a decaying oil rig platform in the middle of a salt-covered, dune-laden, dead ocean floor? Count me in.Last but not least: the game runs AWESOME on PC! I'll refrain from any Batman references, heh. Look at the top reviews for those, they are pretty funny. I'm getting a solid 120 FPS at basically "Max" (hah!) everything on a GTX980/FX8350. Honestly, I don't think it's an overstatement: it's one of the best PC ports I've ever had the pleasure of playing.If you experience any FPS drops, my personal setup improved by reducing debris render distance and shadow quality just a tad.What are you waiting for? There's a lovely day of gaming waiting for you.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												Very under rated game.Most open world games lose my interest fast as they involve a lot of repeat content. All those side activities and missions end up feeling indentical after you have done a few.  I figured madmax would be the same. I was pleasantly surprised when I started noticing how each little side area and objective were not only hand crafted/designed to be different, but many had different mechanics from each other. No two warcamps are the same. Hell, even the balloon quick travel points are different and require a unique mechanic to complete (ie: one might require you to refuel the balloon, another has you driving your car around to remove the cables that are tieing it down).The game feels very mad max. The world is closer to feeling like the newer film than the older (which is fine, I love all of them). Driving is a lot of fun, and the batman like combat is also fun. I enjoy the combat in this better than in batman for a few reasons. 1. The rage system - It makes combat that much more interesting than in batman. 2. Unlike batman, there are times when you realistically just cant counter an attack, even if you see it coming. If you are in the middle of grabbing some guy and breaking his neck, its just not realistic to think that you can suddenly counter another attack. Dont worry though, you can still counter 9 out of 10 attacks if your timing is good, but there is a bit more realism with the system than there is in Batman (where you will go flying accorss the screen no matter what you were doing, to counter an attack).The amount of customization and upgrades in the game is pretty insane too. You have TONS of car options and upgrades, character upgrades, a skill/train system with upgrades, and a "hideout" upgrade system that lets you build things in your base of operations. The car upgrades are by far the most impressive. The sheer number of things you can add and customize is great.The voice acting is also top notch and very accurate with a Max film. The characters all have that no longer part of the reality we know behavior, much like the films. The visuals in the game look very appealing too. Sure, its not super 4k ultra mega Alpha X resolution textures and special FX, but it still looks darn good. Not only that, it runs VERY well. Smooth framerates 99.9% of the time, plenty of video options to adjust. No complaints here, and im VERY picky about graphics and graphical options.My ONLY 2 gripes about the game:1. Getting enemies OFF your car is just a pain. Even after you put spikes all over your car, people will still jump on it. If you are low on shotgun ammo (which you are most of the game), you dont have an easy way to remove them. Smashing into another car sometimes does the trick, but if you dont have another car to smash into, then the best option, believe it or not... is to stop your car... AND GET OUT. WTF?? Really? It really breaks the whole "high speed action car chase" if the best option is to stop and get out. Id like them to add some more ways to remove enemies. Especially if they are on the driver side. Let Max reach out and punch or pull them off the car. Maybe your hunchback can push them off? Maybe once you have spikes, it drains their life the longer they are on the car, until they die and fall off? Something more needs to be added. Its a minor gripe, but one that pops up every so often during car combat.2. Climbing up on things. Imagine this situation. 2 cargo storage containers. Both the same size. One has a yellow marked metal bar on top, signifying that you can jump up, grab it, and pull yourself up. The other doesnt. Er... why cant I climb the other one? Worse yet, there are things that are only 3-4 feet high that you cant grab and pull yourself up to. Thankfully, most of the game doesnt revovle around needing to get up on these things, but from an open world exploration, or even "which path should i take" aspect, it can be kinda annoying.Both of these things however dont take away from the games fun, or keep me from recommending it. The game is a blast to play and a visual feast for mad max fans. The one thing id like to see from a DLC, would be a co-op play via the net. Would be super fun to do all the racing and car combat with another person by your side. (doubt that will happen though)

												This game is amazing: If you don't like Mad Max, despise cars, dislike Post-Apocalyptic wasteland settings, and think the inclusion of road and Mirros Edge-esk interactable objects is "Too Linear" then stay out of this wasteland.A vast amount of people who played this game are already fans of Max or this kind of game/setting, the negative reviews i see are coming from:- those experiencing technical issues (That are few and far between) [This is one of the most stable AAA releases i've ever seen... and that's coming from a PC Port launch]- those who dislike certain SPECIFIC aspects of story/characters/settings to the point where it ruins their experience ("why can't i put the dog in every car instead of the one car with the actual dog house on its back?")- and the biggest reason to dislike the game is the Mechanics that Repeat themselves. (Combat, Camp Dismantling "liberating")First things first, THIS GAME PLAYS IT SAFE, that means no ground braking gameplay, you have simplistic missions with a few unique twists. > Much like "Shadow of Morridor," if you like the setting or series enough this isn't an issueI'm sorry to say but AAA games aren't known for new content, it's mostly reworking previously done mechanics and putting a fesh coat of pretty looking paint on it, and this game does a great job with its paint.The profesional game reviews giving this game a low score is mostly due to them being required to play it and review it as a game, rather than play it because they love mad max or Wasteland setting games (The target audience is actually very specific). It's a very common issue.Seccond, if you don't like the voice acting or plot i'm sorry, but that is more preference at this point because the writing is solid and the voice acting has no glaring faults, unless you don't like australian accents.Thirdly, I apologize if you're one of the few experiencing technical issues. This game has an amazingly succesful first day launch, as in there is little to no technical issues short of your PC is just too outdated or unsupported to play most games (this is a PC Port that works day 1 people). This game is so well optamized the minimum specs is actually surprisingly low. (the fact that the game not being broken day 1 is a notable PRO is dissapointing, but in light of other companies just phoning it in on the first day of release and using day 1,2,3 patches to fix a product they ultimatly released broken, this is comendable.)Summation time> If you like Mad Max, post-apocaliptic settings, great story & characters, then get this game.> If you don't, dont.> And if you have the most highest of expectations of anything you play, and your positive game experience is as fragile as a glass jaw, hinging on everything be just right or it shatters, then don't get most things

												Ratings and scores make no sense to me in accurately describing both the value and experience a game has to offer, so I will just say that this game is worth the buy, and here's why:+ Atmosphere: It looks, sounds, and feels like Mad Max should. It fits within the universe and doesn't ruin the character.+ Graphics: Impressive weather effects (especially the sand storms, which are epic), detailed and high quality textures and models (for an open world), the physics are the most impressive (how cars explode and how debris gets knocked around or breaks into pieces). No visual disturbances to speak of, a very good looking game.+ Sound: The engines, the punches, the shotgun and sniper, explosions, storms and hurricane-like winds are all fantastic. + Gameplay: Batman combat system (melee) meets twisted metal and burnout (vehicles) meets a standard open world Ubisoft game (collect loot and hidden items at locations around the map). It's nice to have a game where collecting loot actually matters, in the sense that you can upgrade Max's vehicles and abilities, and history artifacts give the universe some depth.- There isn't that much gameplay variety here; collecting loot, ransacking and liberating strongholds and bases, races, driving around, BUT at least the driving and vehicular combat is fun as hell, otherwise I wouldn't recommend this game.- This has been said on every review, and it's true, the story and characters are lacking. You won't find memorable or compelling characters here, even Max kind of falls short, but the experience of driving through the wasteland and blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up like in the movies is like none other. Still a fun game to play even if you aren't totally invested in it's plot.I usually wait for sales for games and I hardly ever preorder or buy day one release, but this game was worth every penny. I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
 The story of a broken man... Mad Max is a third person singleplayer action game which takes place in a post-apocalyptic version of Australia - After humanity burnt through it's resources, such as water and oil, chaos enveloped the world and let to the downfall of society, passing the power to warlords who were able to force as many of the remaining resources under their control as possible.It's needless to say that this is a cruel and merciless society - And the game manages to convey the feeling of this pretty darn good! If this setting genereally intruiges you, you should check out the Mad Max movies which inspired this game - they are purchaseable on the steam page as well!Now to the game itself: Mad Max is a game which lays a strong focus on racing and car driving, as well as brutal melee combat. Personally I don't like racing games, but somehow this game managed to make the expection... Wether due to many costumization options or due to the general set up - I found the racing/driving to be very enjoyable. The quests were fun and varied enough for up to 30 hours but got repetetive after this point, mostly due to the large focus on the quicktimevent based combat for which I had to use the same pattern over and over again - this was fun for the first few hours and felt really forceful and good, but bored me after a while due to it's simplicity. The main quest is unique and interesting enough to keep you playing and there are plenty of rememberable characters aside of the main character Max - who is a broken man with almost nothing to live for. All characters are strongly influenced by this harsh and unforgiving universe, which made them more remarkable if you'd ask me.The graphics of the game were of a good quality and the game preformed really well on my computer, with no crashes and no framedrop throughout my entire playtime... The voiceacting was supherb and the soundtrack underlined the most stressful and important parts of the game well enough!All in all I would recommend Mad Max to anyone whos taken an interest in racing, hand to hand combat and post apocalyptic games... If you don't like cars or (partly repetetive missions/combat) but the whole setting intruiged you, you should check it out - If you don't enjoy it after playing for an hour you should probably get a refund...

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
 Mad Max Mad Max is loosely based on the world built up in the Mad Max: Fury Road movie. There is Scrotus (Immortan Joe's son) and his hordes. There are Buzzards and there is also the Roadkill faction. Each faction is uniquely identifiable by their garb and veichles of choice. This is one of the places the game falls flat though. Each faction whilst looking and sounding different are basically the same sorts of people you'll fight but reskins of each other. No faction has a unique fighting style. This lazy design choice also filters into the bosses, where every Top Dog mini boss has exactly the same fighting style despite "intel" saying they each have specific weaknesses and such. This is a let down because the mini bosses having their own unique fighting styles and designs would've improved immersion in the game. The game is also very easy, you can block your way through most fights and there's hardly any times you'll find yourself in trouble. Where the game excels though is exploring the land presented to you in the game. Despite it mostly being nothing but sand each area has its own style and helps makes the drives throughout this post apocolyptic wasteland less of a bore. Whether it's driving through sulfur pits, garbage mountains, decrepit motorways or canyons each location is fresh and encourages you to dive around. Each location typically has the same amount to do in it. So 2 minefields to clear, a few scarerows to rip down, snipers to remove and camps to raid. This sounds dull and can get tedious at time I do admit, but I was having a blast 90% of the time. Especially when sieging the camps, most of them are pretty different from each other in terms of aesthetics so it doesn't get boring to explore and it gives you incentive to fully scout out every crevice of the camps for scrap and insignia signs to destory.Each major non enemy leader who hands out missions will own a stronghold. Each stronghold will have projects for you to do (basically mini fetch quests). The projects at each stronghold give bonuses and change the aesthetic of the stronghold too. At first the stronghold will be run down but with each project you do, it'll not only give you a bonus such as refueling your car or rearming you with fresh ammo but it'll transform the look of the stronghold from rundown slum to a place which is relatively nice to live in. It's nice to see your actions having a profound effect on the people living there.The sound design for this game is excellent, with thumping engines, ear shattering explosions and cool australian accents. It almost never lets you down, they've really excelled here. My only complaint is the NPCs dotted around the map you can talk to, they sound as if they got someone off the street to do a fake accent and babble some rubbish. Only part of the audio that's a let down. These NPCs are visually a letdown too because they all look very similar so the developers obviously didn't put too much effort into them.The story isn't very compelling, but then again Mad Max isn't famous for excellent story telling. It's mediocre, except my main problem with it is that it ends too early. Just as the story missions start to get interesting the game ends abruptly. It took me 20-30 minutes to finish Act 5. Max can have his items and car upgraded and his skills unlocked via Scrap. You can find Scrap all over the world, on dead bodies, in forts and in scavenging locations. The upgrading system is very satisfying and you can definitely see yourself and your car progress in strength and capability. You can do up your car however you want, so you can have a fast but fragile car or a slow but tooled to the nines car and all inbetween. The choice is yours! In conclusion:+ Lots to do+ Lots of places to explore+ Art / Sound design is fantastic+ Car combat is fun + Upgrading your car is very satisfying- Very easy foot combat- Car combat can get tedious- Story ends abruptly- Mini bosses all have the same fighting patterns- Factions don't have unique combat movesIn conclusion Mad Max is a fun open world game with nice enviroments to explore. It will get repetitive at times, which can be dull for a lot of people. It's easy but don't let that put you off. This is a great game to buy.

												After watching some streams of the game and reading the reviews of the "critics", I was slightly skeptical of the game.I was wrong. Right from the start, the beautiful cinematics grab your attention and throw you straight into the story. There wasn't a whole lot of screwing around with the settings to be done, as it was already optimized for my PC. The controls are very easy to learn and use (as they are similar to most games). The story line is quite linear, but I like it! It's easy to follow along with and stay on track- but at the same time you're in an open world. I don't like games where you get lost on what to do, or where to go, and this is definitely not one of those games.I feel like the post-apocalyptic look could use some more scenery rather than just boulders and desert (yes, I know this is how the movie is), because it feels bare and somewhat static at times. Although, this is the complete opposite at some points when it comes to the intense scenes with the storms and what not.My first two hours of the game have been pretty great. If it wasn't 4:30am already, I would play this game for hours.I would definitely recommend this game. It's a great way to pass the time in a single player environment.

												This game is amazing: If you don't like Mad Max, despise cars, dislike Post-Apocalyptic wasteland settings, and think the inclusion of road and Mirros Edge-esk interactable objects is "Too Linear" then stay out of this wasteland.A vast amount of people who played this game are already fans of Max or this kind of game/setting, the negative reviews i see are coming from:- those experiencing technical issues (That are few and far between) [This is one of the most stable AAA releases i've ever seen... and that's coming from a PC Port launch]- those who dislike certain SPECIFIC aspects of story/characters/settings to the point where it ruins their experience ("why can't i put the dog in every car instead of the one car with the actual dog house on its back?")- and the biggest reason to dislike the game is the Mechanics that Repeat themselves. (Combat, Camp Dismantling "liberating")First things first, THIS GAME PLAYS IT SAFE, that means no ground braking gameplay, you have simplistic missions with a few unique twists. > Much like "Shadow of Morridor," if you like the setting or series enough this isn't an issueI'm sorry to say but AAA games aren't known for new content, it's mostly reworking previously done mechanics and putting a fesh coat of pretty looking paint on it, and this game does a great job with its paint.The profesional game reviews giving this game a low score is mostly due to them being required to play it and review it as a game, rather than play it because they love mad max or Wasteland setting games (The target audience is actually very specific). It's a very common issue.Seccond, if you don't like the voice acting or plot i'm sorry, but that is more preference at this point because the writing is solid and the voice acting has no glaring faults, unless you don't like australian accents.Thirdly, I apologize if you're one of the few experiencing technical issues. This game has an amazingly succesful first day launch, as in there is little to no technical issues short of your PC is just too outdated or unsupported to play most games (this is a PC Port that works day 1 people). This game is so well optamized the minimum specs is actually surprisingly low. (the fact that the game not being broken day 1 is a notable PRO is dissapointing, but in light of other companies just phoning it in on the first day of release and using day 1,2,3 patches to fix a product they ultimatly released broken, this is comendable.)Summation time> If you like Mad Max, post-apocaliptic settings, great story & characters, then get this game.> If you don't, dont.> And if you have the most highest of expectations of anything you play, and your positive game experience is as fragile as a glass jaw, hinging on everything be just right or it shatters, then don't get most things

												 Finished it last night. Not sure about the story. Can't say too much about it without spoiling it but it was either pretty good or just an excuse to make you drive to a place, talk to a person and kill some more guys. That said, I expect it was all intentional, it falls in line with the feeling of the movies and has some fun call-backs here and there. It doesn't really bring anything new to the table and the best way I can describe the whole thing is an enjoyable mix of the Batman games and the Just Cause games. The vehicle powerups are kind of an odd duck. The ones I thought were going to be useful were actually generally crap compared to the ones that I thought were going to make me a god. It sure doesn't suffer from the same "issue" that Shadow of Mordor did, where by the end of the game you're basically a demi-god traipsing around killing orcs like it's going out of sport. Even towards the end of the game I was finding it difficult to take on even 2 other vehicles at a time if they were sufficiently armoured. One mistake I think they made with the upgrades is either they're really minor and generally inconsequential or a total game-breaker. It's the difference between doing an extra 5% damage per hit with your car or tearing a wheel off for a one hit kill basically. The ground combat fared much better. It's basically the Batman combat. Block with one button, counter with the punch button. Get funky powerups along the way to unlock better combos and counters. You actually feel more powerful as the game progresses on the ground. I didn't get that with the car. Maybe it's because the car powerups have tradeoffs. Bigger armour and bumpers mean you're slower and have♥♥♥♥♥♥handling. No armour and bumper means you're zippy but have to rely on your powerup weapons rather than the car itself and will get rekt quick in a fight. You have to find a balance lest ye fall victim to crippling overspecialization.All in all I enjoyed the game, but I'm not sure if i'll keep playing to do all the side crap, it's mostly drive here, clear out a camp, do it again. Enjoyable in doses but tedious and irrelevant in the scheme of things.Recommended for everyone if you regularly drop 50 bucks or more on games. Recommended when it goes on sale for cheap people like me. 25 bucks or less would be a buy for me if I didn't have it already.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
 Mad Max Mad Max is loosely based on the world built up in the Mad Max: Fury Road movie. There is Scrotus (Immortan Joe's son) and his hordes. There are Buzzards and there is also the Roadkill faction. Each faction is uniquely identifiable by their garb and veichles of choice. This is one of the places the game falls flat though. Each faction whilst looking and sounding different are basically the same sorts of people you'll fight but reskins of each other. No faction has a unique fighting style. This lazy design choice also filters into the bosses, where every Top Dog mini boss has exactly the same fighting style despite "intel" saying they each have specific weaknesses and such. This is a let down because the mini bosses having their own unique fighting styles and designs would've improved immersion in the game. The game is also very easy, you can block your way through most fights and there's hardly any times you'll find yourself in trouble. Where the game excels though is exploring the land presented to you in the game. Despite it mostly being nothing but sand each area has its own style and helps makes the drives throughout this post apocolyptic wasteland less of a bore. Whether it's driving through sulfur pits, garbage mountains, decrepit motorways or canyons each location is fresh and encourages you to dive around. Each location typically has the same amount to do in it. So 2 minefields to clear, a few scarerows to rip down, snipers to remove and camps to raid. This sounds dull and can get tedious at time I do admit, but I was having a blast 90% of the time. Especially when sieging the camps, most of them are pretty different from each other in terms of aesthetics so it doesn't get boring to explore and it gives you incentive to fully scout out every crevice of the camps for scrap and insignia signs to destory.Each major non enemy leader who hands out missions will own a stronghold. Each stronghold will have projects for you to do (basically mini fetch quests). The projects at each stronghold give bonuses and change the aesthetic of the stronghold too. At first the stronghold will be run down but with each project you do, it'll not only give you a bonus such as refueling your car or rearming you with fresh ammo but it'll transform the look of the stronghold from rundown slum to a place which is relatively nice to live in. It's nice to see your actions having a profound effect on the people living there.The sound design for this game is excellent, with thumping engines, ear shattering explosions and cool australian accents. It almost never lets you down, they've really excelled here. My only complaint is the NPCs dotted around the map you can talk to, they sound as if they got someone off the street to do a fake accent and babble some rubbish. Only part of the audio that's a let down. These NPCs are visually a letdown too because they all look very similar so the developers obviously didn't put too much effort into them.The story isn't very compelling, but then again Mad Max isn't famous for excellent story telling. It's mediocre, except my main problem with it is that it ends too early. Just as the story missions start to get interesting the game ends abruptly. It took me 20-30 minutes to finish Act 5. Max can have his items and car upgraded and his skills unlocked via Scrap. You can find Scrap all over the world, on dead bodies, in forts and in scavenging locations. The upgrading system is very satisfying and you can definitely see yourself and your car progress in strength and capability. You can do up your car however you want, so you can have a fast but fragile car or a slow but tooled to the nines car and all inbetween. The choice is yours! In conclusion:+ Lots to do+ Lots of places to explore+ Art / Sound design is fantastic+ Car combat is fun + Upgrading your car is very satisfying- Very easy foot combat- Car combat can get tedious- Story ends abruptly- Mini bosses all have the same fighting patterns- Factions don't have unique combat movesIn conclusion Mad Max is a fun open world game with nice enviroments to explore. It will get repetitive at times, which can be dull for a lot of people. It's easy but don't let that put you off. This is a great game to buy.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Mad Max is a collection of great ideas poorly tied together and capably (but not perfectly) executed.  It's shallow gameplay is outstnding fun when taken in small doses.  Just don't plan on powering your way through this game in a few sittings; if you do, the lack of polish, disjointed story, and repetition (oh lord, the repetition!)  will kill your buzz all too soon.Mad Max has been compared and found wanting to Assassin's Creed and Batman: Arhkam games (and rightly so while on foot), but the best part of Mad Max takes place behind the wheel.  The car chases (enemies chasing you and vice versa) and convoy battles will stick with you and drive you to play even more  ...at least while they last.  Unfortunately, there are only a limited number of convoy missions (and no free-roam convoys), which is a shame since this seems to be every player's favorite activity.  There are still randomly spawning enemy vehicles roaming the wastes, but they seem fewer and fewer as the game progresses, and enemies flat out run away once your vehicle becomes moderately equipped.If you're looking for a good gap filler - a game to play when the latest MMO has become stale, but before another massive time-sync game - this is a great place to start.  Just don't be in a rush to finish.
