content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Mad Max has climbed up to my list of top favorite games. Considering that includes Super Metroid, Mass Effect 2 and Witcher 3, that has to mean something!I must preface this review: it's been years since I have personally had a game like Mad Max land on my doorstep. A game that is just pure fun, that is almost completely stress-free, yet at the same time is not stupid and mindless with mediocre gameplay. Oh no. This is a great game.So, let's begin (no spoilers).--Mad Max shares a lot of similarities to Far Cry 3 and 4. It's just a huge open world with a bunch of objectives to complete and places to explore. There's the story, but you kind of do it inbetween your open world rampage. That's definitely not the primary reason to get the game, but it's not a bad part of the package. You play this game to have a blast.Some of the objectives feel repetitive, a common point of recent critic reviews, but the gameplay more than makes up for it. There's nothing like ripping around a huge open world slaying man-scum. More on that later.Upgrading your vehicle feels good. The scrap system is simple, yet at the same time demands that you make choices about what equipment you really want to purchase. Speed? Buy that. Armor? Buy that! There's some complexity involved in some gear having weight, where you have to decide on whether a piece is worth its trade-off. It's a great upgrade mechanic that remains minimalistic without hurting the complexity involved.Related to upgrades: there is something called the "Archangels" system, which is somewhat like gear loadouts. Neutral towards it, as I didn't, personally, find it very useful after the first mission that required it. What you will find is that the game throws a lot of tools at you, and you are free to embrace or disregard a lot of them (such as the Archangel system). The game lets you play how you really want to play, without punishing you.Speaking of gameplay: it feels raw and powerful. In fact, stuff happens in this game - quite often - that makes you pause for a moment, regain footing in reality, and ask: did that just happen?For example, I engaged a convoy during a dust storm, and it was one of the most epic moments in recent memory for gaming. Cars got picked up and blown to pieces in a giant dust devil - while lighting was striking the ground rampantly all over the place - and, immediately after, the final cars were picked off by ramming them over a cliff, in which they exploded in a fiery blossom of pure carnage as I landed with a cool half-donut slide across the sand. This is something that occurs several times throughout your Mad Max experience.What further enhances the gameplay are the small details. The fact, for example, that you can pick up a gas can and place it in the back of your vehicle as a spare only enhances the immersive grip of the game. And there are small details like that everywhere. I'll hold back on spilling them here. They are much more enjoyable and respectable when witnessing them firsthand, for the first time.The graphics are superb. Some of the effects are jaw-dropping. There are some very neat smoke, particle and dust tricks that I just have to appreciate as a Unity hobbyist. The backdrops are some of the best I've ever seen. It can be very immersive if you let yourself get absorbed by the endlessness of the great sandy plains.The level design is out of this world. It was painstakingly handcrafted, and it's obvious that was the case. It's my personal favorite part of Mad Max, and I would argue it's some of the best level design for this generation of games (if not overall, at least in the category of open world). Dead ocean is the primary setting, and it's incredibly imaginative. The rolling dunes, cascading sheets of dead-ocean rock, mountainous crags and canyons, sulfur-spewing flats, rusty car graveyards and half-buried ruinous bandit strongholds--when you step back, pause a moment, and stare, you will find yourself silent. The world is amazing, engrossing; the world is truely barren and apocalyptic, yet beautiful in its own, twisted way.Just as the game world feels endless, the amount of stuff to do is also up there. Racing and collectibles are on that checklist of stuff to do once the main story and territory control begins to near completion. The collection system actually has gameplay-focused elements: you can drive captured bandit vehicles and the special, collectible hood ornaments actually have statistical value as car equipment. They are not big parts of the game, but it definitely beats the seemingly infinite amount of worthless collectible garbage that other companies forcefully shove into their products.The only negative tick on my list of Mad Max items is the repetitive missions. There are a few variants of outposts to capture, but the game would have been even better if there were more creative mechanics put into these, especially considering they take away from the (superior, I'd argue) car-based gameplay. That said, the level design is a spectacular solution on this front. The objectives feel the same, but the outposts definitely do not, and they boast some of the coolest realizations of beat-down apocalyptic shanty-fortresses that I've had the pleasure of visiting. A bandit fortress propped atop a decaying oil rig platform in the middle of a salt-covered, dune-laden, dead ocean floor? Count me in.Last but not least: the game runs AWESOME on PC! I'll refrain from any Batman references, heh. Look at the top reviews for those, they are pretty funny. I'm getting a solid 120 FPS at basically "Max" (hah!) everything on a GTX980/FX8350. Honestly, I don't think it's an overstatement: it's one of the best PC ports I've ever had the pleasure of playing.If you experience any FPS drops, my personal setup improved by reducing debris render distance and shadow quality just a tad.What are you waiting for? There's a lovely day of gaming waiting for you.

												After playing it for 5 hours,you get a good grip of what the game is all about and what it's going to be about for the remainder of your gameplay time. I will say this: this is so far the most fun i've had with a game since Max Payne 3 came through. The story is present,and it is quite decent,but it's main reason of being there is to guide you along the car carnage and mayhem,the "juicy" combat (best word to describe it) and the ridiculousness of the whole Mad Max universe. Every element of this game feels consistent and thematic with the rest,from drinking water and eating to regain your health to acquiring fuel,to adding spikes to your car against enemy boarders who might try to hop on your ride to get you. Besides the impressive and extensive car customization,you can customize the look of Max to enhance his stats and unlock new abilities. All this ensures you have plenty to do in the open world Avalanche Studious have created. Not needlessly cluttered with pointless stuff,but not barren like an actual wasteland itself,it isnt enough to make you stop at every kilometer,but it is enough to make you stop at every 3-5 kilometers,and that's for sure.While there are a few bugs i have encountered,those consist of mere funny ragdoll physics and....that's it. To be honest im surprised how WB managed to get it this well optimised. There are reports of people with 5 year old GPU's who are running this game silky smooth on ultra (or in this case MAX) settings,and the graphical settings are shockingly extensive for a console port,to the point where one might say it is the definite edition on PC.In the closing paragraphs i can only say this,if your on the fence about buying Mad Max,dont be. It is a very good game in all aspects. I got it from♥♥♥♥♥for only 20$,and i honestly feel ashamed i didnt pay more for it. At that price,the deal is a steal,probably literally too (lol). If i were a profesional reviewer i would give this game an 8/10,considering 6 is above average and 10 is a masterpiece.

												Mad Max, the game where if you live in America, your going to try and enter the car on the wrong side every single time.Really a great game, it worked with how they made the game separate from the movies timeline and instead just borrowing things like characters and locations from all the movies. Runs like a dream and gameplay was really solid, car mechanics were great and the upgrades and player progression were amazing. You really feel like your in the heart of George Millers desert wasteland! The only real problem was that Max Rockatansky wasn't in the game? Anyone who has seen the movies would know that max was the real strong silent type. Max was always a Neutral Good, he didn't have grudges against the scum that filled the wasteland (except the gang that killed his family), he just simply did what he had to to survive, but if someone truly needed help he would put himself aside and help whoever needed it, either for something in return or as a true act of heroism! This max although strong and silent, is not that. I never felt like I was roaming the wastelands as Max Rockatansky The Road Warrior! I felt like I was taking the backseat to this self centered prick. Really he was just this total f***ing a**hole. Yeah he did end up going back and attemping to "save" the damsel in distress but for all the wrong reasons, and in the end he ended up purposely killing chum bucket, this poor tortured soul who had helped you do everything mechanic related for you along your journey. Again great game, amazing story, awesome gameplay, ♥♥♥♥ing terrible protagonist!

												Thank you Avalanche for a great game!  Well made PC game that captures the essence of the vast wasteland.  Kill or be killed, bloody and gritty. Brutal combat thats easy to pick up with tons of customization.  The car combat is jarring and dirty, with fire, explosions, blood and broken parts flying all over.The story is not the best, but I love the characters, esp Chumbucket. A gang of vicious killers bent on taking your life and car?A blast to play, with tons of optimizations for optimal performance on PC.  8/10*EDIT*  Just finished the game at 51 hours playtime.  I have not completed all the acheviements or 100% complete the game.  I have done all the story missions and all the sidemissions. content:
Posted: March 23
												In the short time I have owned this game I have learned three things.1. Chumbucket is the best traveling compainion I have seen.2. Raming things with your car after some bumper (ramming prow) upgrades is absolutely fun to do.3. I very rarely use fast travel for some unknown reason.You will see that people mention a lot of grinding, well they are not lying.Best thing to do is enjoy the absolute slaughter fest that you cause in melee combat and act like a serial killer shark when you drive. Trust me, it will make the grinding much more enjoyable.You will spend quite a bit of the game going from warcamp to convoy, destorying everything that you don't like the look of. You decide wether or not that pitiful warboy in his little buggy gets to live or not, but most of the time it will be not.***WARNING SOME SPOILERS PAST THIS POINT***Now your two biggest limiting factors is going to be threat level and scrap. As such i suggest that at your first oppertunity you get a cleanup crew at each stronghold as that will allow you to do hit and runs on random scouts without stopping for the scrap they drop. This will also be useful when you take down convoys as they have quite a few vehicles in them (Which respawn if you don't kill the fuel truck).As for region threat level, try and enjoy the fun that is killing all the warboys in each camp. I suggest using whatever equipment you have to weaken the defenses at each one before going in (AKA kill that damn war crier before hand). If you find a warcamp a bit too hard go out, do random crap for griffa tokens, get better equipment from leveling, see Griffa for upgrades, and go murder some armies inside that camp.Last of all, THE CAR! That is your everything in the game, it will end up with harpoons, a sniper riffle, EXPLOSIVE harpoons, as well as better rams, armor, engines, wheels, anti-boarding spikes, wheel spikes, nitros, and some other interesting things to make it your own. Seriously, the armor and ram will affect the weight of the car meaning you will need a better engine and suspenstion for it to work, and you can work all that to your benifit. A long time back when this game came out someone I knew let me mess around and I constructed a car with no armor, best engine and suspenstion, and a MASSIVE RAM! Needless to say it could ram the scrap off a war-rig if they existed in-game.So before you get this game remember that you will be grinding and improving your stuff before you can progress. This game is LONG and you will have a lot of time in this game before you finish it. Even then you can spend more time getting the last few parts for your car and getting 100%. As such game at the risk of your already limited social life and say goodbye to your cousins and other family members that do not live within a mile of you if you do get this game.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
My name's Max...Fans of the old and new movies alike will instantly recognise the setting and (art)style, largely copied from the third movie (Fury Road). You play the protagonist Mad Rockatansky, or "Mad Max", in a post-apocalyptic wasteland at some former coast of Australia, looking for his homeland which he mysteriously calls "the Plains of Silence". Already at the start of the game, in the intro, he gets robbed of his V8 car "Interceptor" and posessions and over the coarse of the game he tries to get back his car (or build a new one as he soon discovers), avenge the man responsible (Scabrous Scrotus) to then continue his journey. On his way he encounters the many War Boys of Scabrous Scrotus, and a fellow war lord Stank Gum with his War Boys, and also some allies whos help he can use all too well.A beautiful desertThe graphics in this game are pretty well done and optimised. Although of course this game is not full of lush bushes, animals and other stuff that can burden your graphics card a lot, it still feels like a beautiful vast outstretching desert full of artifacts of a past history that runs really well and smooth. Scattered around the landscape you find, next to rock formations and tire tracks, the remnants of a lost world: rusty shipwrecks, former oil drill platforms, crumbled bridges, ruins of factory buildings, docksides, harbour cranes, so on and so forth, reminding of a life long gone where there was still plenty of water and food to go around. Collectibles scattered throughout the world will hint you to it and what might have happened.It's a fun driveSo how does it play? After meeting your first few characters you find yourself quickly driving around a LOT in your newly acquired ride looking for scrap, the main currency in the game. Scrap is used to upgrade your car, lovingly called the 'Magnum Opus' by Chumbucket whom you meet at the start of the game and likes to express everything in a religious but car related fashion, and scrap is used to unlock some abilities and gear on Max. By completing activities like achievements, do x times this or x times that, or races you will earn Griffa tokens. These can be spent when you visit Griffa to upgrade some perks. These perks will add extra scrap ontop of what you pick up, or makes you consume less fuel, et cetera.Of combat in this game are two kinds: on foot and in the car. That's right, car combat! Early in the game Chumbucket will fabricate a harpoon for you on the car that enables you to rip off doors, tires, bumpers or snatch the driver right from his seat! Despite the limited tools you get for the car to use, car combat in this game is the most fun. Chasing down Scrotus' convoys going high speed, picking off cars left and right watching them tumble and turn into big balls of fire (Michael Bay would approve!) feels exhilarating!On foot the combat is much the same like the Batman games, for those familiar with it. Max can pick up a few weapons but they always have a (very) limited lifespan. This can be elongated by the perks at Griffa, but you'll generally be fighting with your fists. Even the little shivs Max carries can only be used once for a finisher and not always be looted back from the corpses. Max also carries a shotgun, but the ammo is rather limited, even with all upgrades unlocked. All-in-all the combat in the beginning feels powerful, it feels as if more could have been done to make it more interesting and less repetitive in the long run. Every boss fight of the Top Dogs in the world is almost completely the same and requires no imagination. Once you figured out one, you know how to beat them all. Such a pity!Story wise this game is as dry as the world it plays in and as shallow as the water collectors. There is very little character development, of either Max or anyone he encounters. Then again, Max is a rather selfish man with little empathy for others. At least that's what he wants to make himself believe. Griffa, the fella Max visits to upgrade his perks every now and then, sometimes puts question marks at his deeds to make him rethink, but that's about all the hints Max (and the player) gets.TL;DRThe game is a good looker, runs very well, and fun to play if you like to drive an aweful lot through miles and miles of desert land in a world fueled by the atmosphere from Mad Max: Fury Road. Car combat is most fun, combat on foot is a little too familiar and not much depth. Story is very short and paper thin I'd say, compared to games like Witcher 3. If you like the car bit, it can be worth your money. If you seek something full of story and rich hand-to-hand combat, you will be disappointed.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Picked this up when it was on sale, and probably wouldn't otherwise. It's an enjoyable romp, but it's not without its flaws.PROS:* Non-vehicle combat is pretty fun, even frustrating at times, for the right reasons.* Vehicle combat is similarly fun and occasionally frustrating. You'll find quick though that both of the above get kind of repetitive, and the difficulty spikes up and down for a lot of areas/missions/whatever.* There's usually something to do. You can spend time on side quests and exploration for quite a while before needing to progress, plus there's random(ish) events.* Strongly reminiscent of the Batman games, both in the way it's presented and how the ground combat is... well, basically identical to Batman, let's not kid ourselves there. But that's a good thing!* Everything's well animated. Everything feels crisp. Overall it's just a pretty game that's well-optimized and has plenty of customization. You will find yourself thinking "that was pretty cool" a lot.*Admittedly, the level design in the enemy forts is pretty solid. You might spend a while in one looking for everything after you've cleared it out. But that also brings up the first con...CONS:* Repetitive... stuff. You might find yourself bored at times just because, yeah, while there's a lot to do, this isn't exactly a scenic environment we're talking about here. In otherwords, the novelty wears off.* Characters aren't all that interesting. However, they have plenty of spoken dialogue, and the acting itself isn't bad, they're just all kinda one-sided.* The mine field side quests are annoying, especially because you *have* to bring your pupper, and you *have* to bring a certain vehicle to bring him. The range at which he detects mines just feels off, and it just seems more like a chore than a minigame.* The level-ups on Max himself... well, they feel like they don't really do much. They're so minor you kinda don't notice them.NEUTRAL:* The whole survival element is cool, but never very threatening. Food is just your health, water is pretty easy to come by, and fuel you can keep spare tanks of in your trunk (and they're plentiful). All in all, pretty fun game, might revisit since I never finished it.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												Mad Max is an open world action game set in a post apocalyptic wasteland. It features a blend of various gameplay mechanics into what I think is a really solid experience and worth your time if you are into these sorts of games.The game has a lot of high points and a couple of low points. The best part of Mad Max is the vehicle portion of the game. The driving is fun with a great sense of speed and the vehicular combat is a blast. The rush of racing through the wasteland battling against a gang of vehicles in a car loaded with rockets, flamethrowers, nitro, harpoon gun, spiked rims, etc. is thrilling. The sense of speed and impact of your weapons makes every encounter a fun and engaging experience. My only criticism (and that goes for the rest of the game) is how easy it is once you upgrade your vehicle. Once I had my rockets maxed out the challenge was gone so I forced myself to mix up my weapon use in order to keep it fun.You can upgrade your vehicle the way you want. You can have a speed demon, slow but tank like vehicle, or a mix of both by adding/removing parts such as armor, bumpers, spikes, etc. There are aesthetic upgrades available as well but it's not as robust as I would like. You only have the choice of a few decals/paintjobs/body parts.While the hand to hand combat feels brutal it feels a little clunky. It's not as smooth as say the Arkham series or Shadow of Mordor. Maybe that's on purpose because it does feel a little 'heavier' and it could be due to design. But the problematic camera can be frustrating if you are in closed spaces. As you would have guessed from my Arkham comment the game uses a combat system similar to that game series. If you are not familiar with it it's based on pressing the attack/block/counter buttons at the right time in order to flow freely and rack up your hits. The longer your combo goes on the faster your 'fury' meter rises. Once it is filled you hit a lot harder than you normally do. The map itself is large and filled with a lot of activities. Unfortunately, the variety is scarce and it does feel old by the time you get near the end. The tasks are really simple; destroying an enemy camp, killing snipers, destroying scarecrows, talking to random NPC's, and finding loot locations. The loot locations allow you to find scrap, parts to expand your bases, and collectibles. Scrap is used to upgrade your character and vehicle but at a certain point you are going to have an incredible amount of it so you don't need to worry about saving up.The graphics are gorgeous and the game is very optimized. The developers did an incredible job with the PC version of the game and they should be commended. One thing you should know is people have reported heavy stuttering when playing the game on a HDD so I recommend installing it into a SSD drive. Ultrawide screens are supported and you can re-bind your keys as well. I really enjoyed my time with Mad Max. I really hope they make a second game and I cannot believe how underrated this game is. I believe it will be a cult classic and I for one am very glad to have experienced it.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												This game is probably the single largest surprise I've ever experienced through a lifetime of gaming.  Prior to release, all the gameplay footage I saw looked incredibly boring.  I hate Avalanche's other games (the Just Cause series) because they are incredibly boring, repetitive, and generally low quality with an incredible over-reliance on cheap gimmicks.  I can hardly stand to watch 5 minutes of the original Mad Max and thought Fury Road was an over-hyped over-indulgent action movie with lousy characters, a mediocre story, and little meaning, the kind I'd expect from Michael Bay (albiet with significantly more style.)Despite all these things, I found Mad Max very enjoyable - to the point where I put the time in to complete every achievement and was still enjoying it at the end.  Somehow Avalanche produced a game that doesn't feel like it relies entirely on a single gimmick, doesn't feel incredibly padded to fulfill some quota for the size of the game map, has a decent story with interesting characters (I was amazed at how well-written Max's mechanic's character is,) has solid gameplay, and also runs incredibly well.  I say this as a person who is very intolerant of games that feel repetitive and grindy.So to the gameplay: You play as Max, driving around in the post-apocalyptic wasteland in your muscle car (obviously.)  It takes the typical open world game route of scattering objectives around the map that you can complete at your leisure, along with fast travel locations that reveal nearby locations on the map and story missions.  There are only a couple types of locations but they vary significantly in size and structure which helps prevent the game from feeling repetitive, even though you're doing the same thing at each location.The game features both car and hand-to-hand combat.  The hand-to-hand combat is similar to the free-flow system found in other games like the Batman Arkham series and Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor.  While Mad Max uses a simplified system with only a couple enemy types and abilities, but it works well for the most part and is satisfying to engage in.  It's not without its problems though, with some moves (that you have no control over whether execute or not) prevent you from blocking attacks from other enemies, and being hit will interrupt the move.  The prompt timing for blocking attacks also feels a bit off, similar to Batman: Arkham Asylum before they got it straightened out in Arkham City (and then broke again in Arkham Origins.)Car combat though, is where the game really shines.  Your car is equipped with a harpoon to grab and pull pieces of other cars and hostile objects in the game world and you can upgrade your car with various equipment to make ramming more effective and add other ways to inflict damage or protect your car from damage.  Battling other cars is a lot of fun and flows very well, though fights can get quite hectic against multiple enemies and can end up devolving into jousting.The really brilliant part though is when you go up against convoys.  Convoys have set routes on the map, and are composed of one main vehicle along with a number of guard vehicles.  They continuously drive in a loop on the convoy route and you have to destroy the main vehicle to clear the convoy and get a reward.  The continual driving keeps the pace up and taking out the guard vehicles as they split off to deal with you while maintaining proximity to the convoy (the guards will respawn if you get too far away) is incredibly satisfying.  It was so much fun that I was really disappointed when I cleared the last one on the map and realized there weren't any more.The only real problems I see with the game besides the aforementioned hand-to-hand combat issue is that some of the map locations can feel pretty pointless.  Driving up to a pile of rubble just to pick up one pile of scrap on the ground?  What's the point?  Luckily those locations are in the minority and don't really pose much of an issue.And so I have to conclude that Mad Max is one of the best games released in 2015.  I never thought I'd ever say that.

The Angel of Combustion be praised!Ground combat is smooth and engaging, carefully timed counters and well-executed combos are very rewarding (much more so than Batman, for those who have played WB's Arkham series).Some downsides to note:1. Gameplay gets very repetitive in the end, especially if you focus on clearing sidequests and scrap locations.i) Other than hunting for scraps and hitting camp objectives, there are not much to do during exploration. While immersive, there are nothing interesting to interact with (always the same old water filter, scrap, Dinky-D's lying around etc) and requires the players' own imagination to fill in the gaps in the rich world left by the developers.ii) Car combat is kind of disappointing - enemy tactics are as follows: bang you till you die one way or another + some cars can drop mines + some cars can lit themselves up and attempt to blow you up. That's it. 90% of enemy cars (who can't drop mines or lit themselves up) will only use the same tactic over and over.iii) All camp bosses are just re-skinned versions of the same enemy - a heavy weapon-wielding brute the size of a half-giant, with identical HP, fighting style and weaknesses. One of the total let-downs of the game.2. The developers don't want you to feel that this is a racing game and they are doing a good job at it. Seriously - you are driving half of the time and they don't even throw in a speedometer for your cars. The only way any driving/racing or car combat sequence can be interesting is when it happens during one of the freak thunderstorms during the game.3. Some annoying issues such as not being able to keep your current car when Fast Travelling (always reverts to the Magnum Opus - this makes mine clearing missions with the weak buggy absolutely tedious); game not telling you which cars have what ability (spent a long time to figure out which buggy can spot mines); 4. Some serious FPS drops when walking around in camps and strongholds, even at low graphic settings with good PC.Tips to enjoy:1. Finish the main quests first to unlock all upgrades for your magnum opus.2. Don't try to clear all sidequests (incl. scrap locations, scarecrows, minefields etc) at one go, it will make the gameplay extremely tedious and kills the fun.3. The real fun happens when driving through thunderstorms - try actively hunting for them!4. This is not a RPG nor racing game, so don't expect them to be such.Currently on Steam for a low low price, recommended purchase.

												Mad Max is something every post-apocalyptic adventurer wants to explore. It's pretty fun and mildly entertaining for few hours. Although it has some minor imperfections it proves itself to be a quite good game. Personally I didn't get much out of the story, it was a little bit clingy and it had was just a typical video-game plot #192.The combat system of the game appears to be somewhat similiar to Batman and Shadow of Mordor. Very well animated intense combat with multiple enemies is fun and you can actually feel the power of Max's punches. Basic combat moves are easy to learn and easy to execute when the keys that you have to press are X and Y. One of the most important part of this game is driving. Building your own "Magnum Opus" so to speak. You can choose what body type you want to use and customize your car whilst you roam your way through the territories and cause havoc. Car handling is hard to learn and to master in the beginning of your journey but it'll get better when you actually evolve your car.The game has some minor imperfections as I mentioned earlier. The NPC behavior for example. The NPC cars may just drive at you out of nowhere, ram you twice when you are parked and looting and try to kill you by driving over you. Well, at that point you should rush to your car and battle with them, but, sometimes this occurs: The NPC's actually dissmiss you at the exact moment you step in to your car. Then they'll drive away and try to get as far as you as possible without even noticing your existence.Summa summarum+ Great graphics with magnificent framerate (60 stable @ Max settings)+ Enjoyable combat+ Size of the continent+ A lot to do (loot, scavenge, discover)+ Magnum Opus+ Strongholds- NPC behaviour from time to time- Enemies with big weapons might hit you when the animation isn't clearly even close to you- Car driving can get a little bit irritating when you have to do something carefully (watch out for bombs i.e.)- You can't really jumpIt's a nice game to lose twentysomething hours with, but I wouldn't pay the full price.7.5/10

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												I was a little bit concerned that my machine might be under-specced for a game of this magnitude, being that I only have a GTX660, but I switched the GPU Tweak into its game-mode and the only performance issue I have noticed thus far is an ever-so-slight-so-as-to-almost-be-unnoticable jitter in some of the cut-scenes. When I checked the in-game settings, I was happy to see that the default High setting was in use, but - even more astoundingly - it was also running at 2560 x 1600!I've noticed a couple of bugs in the sound; Sometimes you get back into your car and race away, but the car noises are muted. They're there, but only at 10% volume. They come back eventually; Comments on missions play randomly even after the mission is complete; but overall, the sound is pretty great. The music moves with the action, without dominating. The car sounds are nicely done, with lots of variance for the different machinery. The voice acting for the main characters is well done, with ability seeming to coincide with the level of the characters' importance.The playability is slightly marred by two things: The camera, and the vehicle controls. The camera is controlled with the right thumb stick, but you also need to use your thumb for fighting moves. I've had a couple of bad experiences where I've been backed into a wall and the viewpoint hasn't allowed me to see what is going on. It's cost me a few crucial hits at times. The car controls share a bit of the camera grief too at times, although only at low speeds, but my main frustration is with the steering. It takes forever to re-center, let alone swinging to opposite lock to catch a slide. If you let go of a steering wheel irl, it will (read: should) automatically rotate to the direction of the car's travel, and quickly - it may, in fact, over-rotate, which is where over-correction and spins happen, but that is for another type of game engine. Max seems to work the steering at the same geologic time-scale whether moving at 10 or 210kph. Maybe that's something to do with the car's 'handling' stat, I don't know yet. I'm still rolling around in The Jack, so maybe time will tell.The rest of the game mechanics work very well, especially the fighting - both on foot and vehicular. I'm really enjoying wading into groups of warboys with the parrying and combo system used in the fist-fights, whilst regularly unlocking new moves and finishing combos as I progress. The vehicular mayhem presents just as many ways to convert cars to scrap, whether you go with the classic ram-them-until-they-become-a-screaming-fiery-mess approach, or a surgical mindset where the use of tools such as the shotgun and harpoon can quickly remove a threat, but leave the car intact if required. Or both. There are a lot of different enemies, and each needs a different approach, so your tactics will need to evolve constantly. It doesn't get boring or repetitive very quickly at all. And the storms - wait until you see the storms. The environment varies just as much as the enemies, and can be just as deadly. Even when you're in a semi-safe area, you still need to watch out for everything from twisters and tornadoes, to full-blown force-5 hurricanes - and even they come in all sorts of different forms too. I was a little bit disappointed that cars weren't more lootable - I mean, you've done away with the warboys and now you have their car at your disposal, but your only option is to drive it back to the stronghold to add it to your collection if you haven't already done so. It really needs the option to scrap the car, either on the spot for some quick scrap, or back at home for increased returns. You can't even syphon the guzzolene... fortunately, or oddly, there is quite a lot of it about, so not a big deal.There is a lot to get through in this game, and even with the small frustrations, I think I'll be playing it for a good while yet.

Posted: September 26, 2015
												This is one of those games that will divide people. You'll like it or hate it. The game is loosely based on the recent Fury Road movie though the story and characters arent. (The Max in the game isnt modelled or voiced by Tom Hardy either). The game starts with Max being attacked by the warlord of Gastown, Scrotus, who steals Maxs Inteceptor and leaves him for dead. Max finds a hunchback mechanic called Chumbucket who helps Max to build a new car to get back at Scrotus. The Magnum Opus. Good points: -The Wasteland of the game and all the bizarre characters who inhabit it really capture the look and feel of the recent movie. The map is huge and your let loose to try and attack Scrotus' camps and structures to weaken his influence over the Wasteland.- The Magnum Opus can be customized with different weapons like flamethrowers or a ramming grill for example as well as improving things like wheels and engine. Which is great because the Magnum Opus feels more like your own vehicle than some generic vehicle. The vehicle combat in game is a lot of fun too.-The graphics in this game are great though you'll need a powerful rig to get them at their max. (No pun intended)Bad points: - This game has a lot of collectibles and you'll spend a lot of time gathering scrap to improve the Magnum Opus and Max.   This gets very repetitive and while i didnt mind it so much at first i was sick of it towards the end. Unfortunately since you need certain upgrades for some of the story missions it'sunavoidable to some extant.- The combat is similar to that of other WB games like the Arkham series and Shadow of Mordor. It does feel a bit too easy at times as it's just one button to attack and another to counter. There isnt much enemy variety either.The one thing i liked about the combat was how visceral and real it looks. Rather than fancy acrobatics or martial arts the fights look more like a pub brawl and just as brutal.While some might see the freedom to explore as you will with occasional story mission as a plus, i felt the game could have done with more structure as it would have helped it avoid becoming a repetitive experience. I have decided to recommend it because i did really enjoy the game for the first 15-20 hours and it still is a decent game overall. However if you cant stand loads of collectables and repetitive gameplay this might not be for you.

Posted: September 23, 2015
												Follow the story of our hero, Max, as he seeks revenge against the bandit clan leader who stole his life away.  Mad Max has a lot of entertaining and fun aspects, but also contains a lot of boring and repetitive actions.  The story is decent, the controls are good, the graphics are very beautiful, and the environment is very well done.  The gameplay is rather simple, and even without upgrading your character's abilities or gear you can do very well in a fight with minimal experience, but the true enjoyment of this game does not occur on foot, but in your car.  With your trusty mechanic and harpoon shooter in the back, you take the wheel and fight head to head against other drivers, often with tricks up their sleeves.  The car combat is very fun, and it's worth upgrading your ride to handle some of the difficult challenges that await you in the wasteland.  Overall I would recommend it if you can find it for less than $25, but I would not say that it is worth much more than that unless you enjoy exploring a vast and open wasteland picking up scrap metal for hours on end.  A scavenging location can yield anywhere from 2 pieces of scrap to 50, but you need thousands of scrap to get a few of the upgrades for your car, and that takes a lot of time to grind out.  TLDR: Overall, a good game, but be prepared for a lot of grinding if you want 100% completion on it.7.5/10

The game is also similar to Mordor and Far Cry in the way that you unlock what's in a region. You do this by climbing your way up to a ballon and assend and discover what's out there. The Graphics and Mad Max are very good, nothing amazing or groundbreaking but very good. They work well, actually the do look amazing when you get caught in a lightening storm, it's extremely immersive when that happens. The game is also very well optimised. I have everything on max and haven't experienced any lag, I'm getting a constant 60 FPS. The vehiculer combat is fun and very satisfying. You are able to ram cars to pieces at high speeds, you don't feel overpowered as you can easily be smashed to pieces as well. You have a few weapons you can use while driving to help you such as the harpoon, Max's trusty shotgun and thundersticks. The game makes you want to play it and collect scrap just to upgrage the Magnum Opus.

												I first played this on my friend's PS4, and I decided I had to buy it.My computer doesn't even meet minimum specifications for this game (AMD Phenom II X4 3.2 GHz, GeForce 560Ti), but it still ran at 60 FPS on default (high) settings until particle physics jumped into the game. I basically turned down particle physics and the game's running a solid 60 FPS again. Someone mentioned this is the same studio that made Just Cause, and JC2 ran at 60 FPS on a GT 430, so they must be doing something right.I really enjoy the vehicle customization aspect of the game, especially as it's basically an RPG progression. The combat feels pretty good, although sometimes you can't cancel your own moves to counter like in the Batman: Arkham series. Additionally, enemies will come at you much more quickly and you have to line up counters much faster than in Batman or Middle Earth series. It's much more challenging and I'm okay with this - it doesn't feel cheap like Sleeping Dogs feels from time to time.As far as things I don't care about, sometimes the pace of the fortresses/camps feels a little stilted - there'll be a lot of action, and then there'll be a lot of running around trying to find relics/scrap/symbols for 100% completion. I suppose if you're not a completionist this doesn't bother you.I really, really like the vehicular combat and I hope it gets more frenzied as I get into the later game. My car right now is decently equipped and it's still tough as hell - not to mention that the enemies do things I wouldn't really expect them to do which is cool.All in all, I highly recommend this game - if you love the Mad Max brand, buy this right now. If you like vehicular combat and levelling up your vehicle, buy it RIGHT NOW.EDIT AFTER MORE PLAY TIME:Gotten farther in the game, made it to Gas Town. Getting slightly annoyed at the V8 carrot being dangled in front of my face then yanked away repeatedly, but we'll get there... I can deal with the twin turbo V6 for now.Combat still holds up, though there are little "dog-like" enemies which have a nasty habit of attacking at a time when you cannot counter because you're already countering someone else.Action in the camps feels better after playing a bit more, and running around and figuring out where stuff's hidden gets a little easier as the game goes on. I also like the cast of this game a fair bit, except the drug addict you encounter later on - but I just met that character, so we'll see.A little disappointed in the way car combat goes occasionally, as recently I'm more or less ripping off rims. I do have a fair chunk of shotgun ammo but 9/10 times it's going into the tire. I'd like to see more bashing of the enemy cars.

Posted: September 8, 2015
												This is a fun game by Avalanche. It has all the aspects of an Avalance game: great optimization, fun gameplay, nonexistent laughable storyline, great graphics, intoxicated physics and LOOOOAAAADS of grind.Just like all their games, it does outstay it's welcome by constantly pushing you to be a competionist, whether it be to unlock upgrades that make certain missions less than insufferable, by constant reminders of everyone around you that you have to do these activities or just plain old UI pestering and game currency collection.While the brawling is good and has some amazing bone cracking sounds, the car combat is far from perfect. Your car - the Magnum Opus is incredibly squishy, regardless of whether you put armour on it or not (and armour makes the car nearly impossible to control well, so there is no reason to ever use it in my opinion) and while that would be fine under different circumstances, they decided it would be a great idea to add 2 more lifebars to enemy vehicles that block your harpoon attacks until you deplete them. Thing is: by the time you do deplete them 2 things happen: First their basic health is basically nothing, they will likely die in one hit or you can pull a wheel/driver off them.Second you will be dead bored by the time that happens (or just dead, if you ran out of rockets or physics sent you in a spin for no reason). In short: the best way to deal with enemies in vehciles is to stop the car and force them out into melee combat. That's not what you want for your car combat part.Otherwise it's a fun game and if you are a completionist who can endure the same tasks for many many hours to unlock everything, you will love this game, because it really REALLY wants you to do it and rewards you a lot for it. The question is: once you complete everything and there's nothing to do, what do you do with all these unlocked upgrades? I guess the devs didn't think about that.I recommend it based on production quality and mellee combat. The game does outstay it's welcome and I did rush the last 2 story missions without doing anything in-between because I couldn't be bothered (and not because of the story, please don't expect any good storyline from this game), but for the most part I enjoyed it's explosive ride across the prettiest of lifeless colourless, empty and monotonous deserts I have ever seen in a game to date.I also ate maggots from a corpse to replenish health. Just so you know: corpse fly maggots eat rotting flesh with bacteria happily festering inside. If you were to eat them, you'd most likely die within the next hour.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												This review is a bit biased as I'm a huge Mad Max fan.That said, this game is still amazing. Maybe you've read other reviews that say it's the most open world open world action adventure action adventure trope game. Yes, it's open world, yes, it's an action adventure game, but let me ask those reviewers one thing? How else would you have preferred a Mad Max game? The primary focus in Mad Max is vehicular combat across the vast open terrain of the wasteland. Yes, Max has free flow combat similar to other WB published games in the past few years, but he isn't Batman or the guy from Shadow of Mordor. Max is, to an extent, a regular ol' dude with some emotional issues pertaining to his past and the fact that he is a shell of his former self. Point is, Avalanche made the Mad Max game that Mad Max fans had always wanted; so f * * k the reviewers that say the game is repetitive or lacking. Have they even seen a Mad Max film? The stories aren't exactly as complex as Metal Gear Solid, which I think is another reason why Mad Max is being overlooked, the fact that MGSV came out the same day. The Mad Max stories are rather simple with an even simpler context, global economic crisises and nuclear warfare.Now that I got my little rant out of the way, I can actually talk about the game. Max is driving his beloved Interceptor through the Wasteland, trying to reach the Plains of Silence in hopes of finding a more civilized society. Unfortunately, Scaborous Scrotus, son of Immortan Joe, succeeds in vehicular combat with his mighty Land Mower and Max is forced to jump out, ending up fighting Scrotus himself. After apparently killing Scrotus, Max finds himself somewhere unknown and befriends Scrotus' dog. Together, they find Chumbucket, a hunchback mechanic. This is where the story really takes off as Chum and Max plot to build a Magnum Opus, a car better, stronger, and superior in each way to the Interceptor. Chum and Max travel throughout the Wasteland, assisting faction leaders and progressing throughout the story to upgrade car parts and Max's own gear. The story is actually more interesting than just that, but I don't wanna spoil it.Gameplay, as noted in my rant earlier, is similar to recent action adventure games. Besides comparing it to recent WB games, I could also compare it to Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood, as you invade camps (Forts) and complete a primary objective in order to take control of it where your allies will then be there. Also the strongholds where you meet various "community" leaders. You do favors for these leaders (i.e. side missions that actually have plot) and are then able to upgrade these strongholds by collecting project parts at various scavenging locations or camps scattered throughout the wasteland. These locations could be massive forts or hidden caves, or underground passages below a hatch. There is so much to do in this game, it can actually be overwhelming. Anyway, I wanna focus on the vehicular combat gameplay, I shouldn't have to explain what action adventure is. Vehicular combat is pretty rare in modern games, so having vehicle combat in Mad Max was astounding. You can use side burners, t-bone or rail cars head on, use a harpoon to rip off doors and tires and bumpers, or the thunderpoon to blow stuff up. And then the beloved shotgun, which can be used for a variety of things while driving. Not to mention that much of this will be occurring at high speeds. Basically, Avalanche did a splendid job with the vehicular combat.Graphics; jeez. I could tell you about how great and stunning the graphics are, because they are. But I won't bore you with that, instead, I just want to mention that this game is clearly set sometime after Thunderdome as there is sand practically everywhere. In the first two films, we got to see a side of Australia comparable to Arizona where there was a lot of small cacti life and dry ground. But man, Thunderdome really struck home field with the sand. And so does this game. The sand is awesome. Your tires leave imprints, as do your feet, whether driving or running along, on top of it. The vibrant skies are perfect. Graphics.Let me also just add that there are side quests in this game that are not just fetch quests. They might seem menial and menial side quests have become a modern thing to complain about since I guess The Witcher 3 perfected the side quest formula. But here, in Mad Max, the side quests actually lead to upgrades and are integral to the character's leveling system. You'll get more griffa points which can be used to upgrade Max's stats. Plus several of the side quests actually have stories to them, as you'll learn with Hope and Glory who later become a main point to the main story.Ending on that, Mad Max turned out to be a great great game that will be overlooked at the end of the year due to being shadowed by the release of MGSV and not being Mad Max: Furty Road The Game. It's just Mad Max, a game. It's its own thing, and works well as its own thing (although it does lead well into Fury Road except for a few minor details).9.1/10

content:
Posted: April 11
												Short version: Excellent sandbox game that is faithful to the atmosphere of Mad Max Fury Road.  Interstate '76 + GTAV.Playtime: ~60 hours to finish the storyline (but I had done every side mission, every scavenge location, collected all the historical relics, lowered the threat to zero in every area, and had almost every achievement and probably 95% of the legend challenges done.  I was a level ~120 Road Warrior).  I'll likely play a bit more to unlock the last few achievements.I normally avoid movie tie-ins like the plague, but I took a chance based on great reviews and a love for this style of game.  It reminded me a lot of Interstate '76 - desert car wars, upgrading your car with better weapons and armor, scavenging for parts among the defeated enemies, and so on.  The basic premise is similar to all of the Mad Max movies.  Max loses his family or car and is forced to help out a bunch of people before he can continue on his journey alone.  After losing your Interceptor in the opening scene, you spend the game scrounging for scrap to build a new car with the help of a mechanic that rides along with you. This allows him to repair and upgrade on the fly, so dying is pretty easy to avoid.  If your car becomes too damaged, you have to exit the vehicle while the mechanic puts out the fires.  Since you usually have enemies in vehicles around you, it's a matter of dodging them, shooting out tires/gas tanks if you have some (scarce) ammo, or getting them to get out of their vehicles to fight hand to hand.The combat system is a page right out of the recent Batman games - punches and kicks paired with parry/counters.  You chain hits together to fill your Fury meter which allows you to hit harder.  As you progress, you can unlock new finishing moves that can be ground attacks, using your shotgun or a shiv to instant-kill, or using the environment to finish them off.In addition to being able to unlock new clothes (armor and melee power), shotgun upgrades, and your ammo belt capacity, you can also unlock upgrades to customize your appearance.  Similar upgrades and can be purchased and earned for your car - better armor, better tires, etc.Starting out, you'll find that food and water is pretty scarce, and they're the only way to replenish health.  For that reason, the early part of the game is a bit tough when find yourself outnumbered.  However, this is an open-world wasteland, so you can leave the storyline idle while you seek out various tasks to do that will allow you to complete objectives and tasks that will earn you both scrap metal (the in-game currency for all upgrades) as well as tokens that you use with a wandering mystic.  This mystic will allow you to upgrade your health bar, your ability to scavenge, your skill with melee and weapons, and more.  As you visit strongholds and complete improvement tasks for the leaders there, the game becomes exponentially easier.  You'll be able to set up food and water sources, create crews that pick up the scrap left behind when you destroy an enemy vehicle (so you don't have to stop), a crew that scouts all the scavenging locations in the area, a crew that gathers scrap while you're offline, and an armory that fills your ammo belt.  All of this plus the scrap you earn from dismantling enemy camps and populating them with allies makes your life a lot easier..  You can add cars to your collection by stealing them from enemies or by winning races in the numerous "Death Run" races scattered throughout the map and then driving them to a stronghold.This leads to the one drawback - because the game has so many things you can do, it is very easy to out-level the story.  For example, I was about 3/4ths of the way through the storyline and had to do a race.  The race leader turns me away saying I can't race in the heap I'm driving.  I'm given an objective to come back after I upgrade to make the car faster.  The problem was that I had already unlocked and purchased every upgrade available, so I ended up having to downgrade my car in order to compete. Later when I finally got the V8 Engine in the storyline, I had enough scrap to immediately buy every upgrade for it. Huge fights near the end of the game were much easier with every melee, armor, and ground combat ability unlocked.  They should have scaled the enemies with the player level.Customizing your car is something you'll do a lot - you can upgrade bumpers, armor, spikes (to keep people from jumping on your car), spiked wheels for grinding against other cars, suspension and lift kits, and so on.  Some have trade-offs (better armor makes you slower and have worse handling) and some tires are good on sand, others on asphalt, but the rest just get better with each upgrade.  The main reason they have all the variation is that you can select a ready-made builds called an Arch Angels.  Each requires certain types of each component, so as you progress through the game you'll be able to make more varieties of them.  There are in-game legend achievements to complete that are specific to some of the builds.Lastly, once the game ends you are back in the wasteland and basically have free play to do things you missed.  As I said, I had already cleared the camps, the scavenge locations, etc so I've got just a few achievements to get for racing in the Death Runs.

												After watching Mad Max: Fury Road for the first time, I left the theater with a great desire to play a Mad Max video game.  Unfortunately, this game wasn't out yet.  So I looked for substitutes, none of which scratched that itch completely.Fallout: New Vegas?  It certainly has the "survive in a post-apocalyptic world" element, but there are no vehicles to drive, plus the pace of the game certainly isn't frenetic like the Mad Max movies.Rage?  The game definitely has the "drive powerful death machines through a desert wasteland" feel, but it has none of the survival elements.  Plus the game is surprisingly short; you can beat it over one or two weekends, which I did years ago.So I was left with no game that could fulfill this need.Now that Mad Max is out, I have exactly what I was looking for.  Fast-paced vehicular carnage?  Check.  Brutal, hand-to-hand combat against desert-dwelling degenerates?  Check.  Playing a character that has to struggle to survive in a post-apocalyptic world while simultaneously struggling with his own sanity?  Sure, there's some of that, too.  Forgive me for stating the obvious, but nothing captures the feel of the Mad Max movies better than the Mad Max video game.  Who'da thunk it!?!?Perhaps my favorite thing about Mad Max is the amount of detail and respect the developers paid to the source material.  This game was clearly made by folks who understand and love the Mad Max world and mythos.  While playing this game, I'm reminded of Rocksteady's Batman: Arkham Asylum games, which were also chock full of details that fans of the source material should appreciate.TL;DR: If you like the Mad Max movies, it's highly likely that you'll like this game, too.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
PresentationReleased only a few months after the movie franchise reboot "Mad Max: Fury Road", Mad Max isn't just another one of those movie-adaptation video games to follow the same background and story, but instead it takes inspiration from the entire movie franchise to create a unique experience, as the game is more like prequel to Fury Road, introducing you to the world of Max Mad without the need for any prior knowledge about the series. Mad Max aims for a story about a pointless existence of murder and regret, which does have its moments in situations where your actions will end up messing up other people's lives as well as your own, but just like many other games of its kind the stories that will stay with you afterwards are the ones you make yourself on the road to the finale. The story follows Max, who is once again left with nothing after Scabrous Scrotus took his car, on his journey for revenge accompanied by Chumbucket, a lonely blackfinger whose only goal is to build to ultimate ride. Along this journey you will meet all different kinds of insane people, starting with the Stronghold leaders, which will give you different side quests to complete across the wasteland and ending with all the stranger encounters that will sometimes give you scrap as a token of their gratitude for your fight against Lord Scrotus or useful information to help you take over a camp, such as the location of a secret entrance or different weaknesses in the structure that you can take advantage of. The story missions are only a small part of what Mad Max has to offer, as there are plenty of things to distract you along the way and on that side of things, the game gives you plenty of things to do to spice up your adventures, with camps to take over, scavenging locations to complete and many more; the order in which you complete those is totally up to you and completing different activities along the way is what makes Mad Max an enjoyable experience, even when it does come with its flaws.Rating: 9GameplayIf you have played some of the major open world games released in the past year such as Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, you will most likely find similarities in Mad Max's gameplay mechanics. On foot, the main combat element is brawling, as you will use simple attack and counter attack movements to defeat various types of enemies along the way, as the only weapon in your arsenal while on foot is your loyal shotgun, which does have limited ammo, so using it carefully between punches to defeat a more dangerous enemy approaching you is key. Driving your Magnum Opus things change, as the ultimate goal is upgrading your car to make it the best ride across the wastelands, as you will unlock new car bodies, engines, suspensions and many more customizable elements; with that being said, your Magnum Opus is equipped with a Harpoon that can be used to drag and pull different objects or structures, as well as a Thunderpoon and Side Burners. In addition to the weapons that can be attached to the Magnum Opus, the car itself can be used as a weapon, as different upgrades such as Boarder Spikes, Armour or Boost will come in handy if you want to be more aggressive and slam into other vehicles. While the main missions will give you an idea of how harsh the world of Mad Max is and introduce you to different elements of the game, the best way to experience what Mad Max has to offer is by going out to explore the different events and locations on your own, as there are numerous races to complete, camps to take over and scavenging locations filled with scrap and upgrade parts for your projects in the Strongholds. As large in scale as it is, Mad Max feels really limited when it comes to movement freedom, as you will often head for a cliff that looks easy to reach only to find out that there is no way for you to get there, as the movement mechanic only allows you to climb marked locations. On top of that, the game does come with the occasional bugs and glitches, but those are minor enough not to influence your experience too much.Rating; 8GraphicsFor a deserted wasteland, the world of Mad Max is quite beautiful in its own gloomy way, with detailed locations and memorable places; contributing to that world are the insane characters you will meet along the way, each with its unique personality and level of madness. The weather effects have a significant impact on the world, as nights will make the desert look even more lonely and storms will reduce the visibility to a point where looking ahead of you will become your main objective. Animations can be a bit clunky at times and there are some texture popping issues, the number of them varying from one platform to another, but those are only minor issues that barely distract you from the massive world that lies ahead of you.Rating: 8AudioBren Foster is the voice of Max and does a great job narrating every dramatic moment of Max's adventures, accompanied by other noted actors such as Travis Willingham voicing Lord Scrotus and Jason Spisak providing the voice of Chumbucket. The sound effects are okay and even though they can feel a bit repetitive at times, there is enough variety in action to make sounds feel distinct and take you on an emotional ride from one dramatic moment to the next one and straight back into the chaotic action afterwards.Rating: 8.5ExtrasYou can probably finish the story within 15 hours if you go straight forward from one mission to the next one and complete only what is necessary, but with so many things around you that will probably not be the case, so with all the races, camps and locations to explore you can easily spend 50 hours with Mad Max, add even more if you're willing to complete every challenge.Rating: 9.5VerdictMad Max is an excellent open world adventure no matter if you're a fan of the movies or not, as the game does a great job introducing you to the world of the franchise and tell you an interesting story without sacrificing too much on the fun, chaotic gameplay that will keep you hooked for hours. If you want a game to keep you preoccupied for a long period of time, Mad Max is definitely a must try as it provides more than enough content and variety to entertaining you for a couple of days.Rating Overall: 8.6Check out the full review and a lot more about Mad Max at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=371

												Mad Max just as fury road took me by surprise, as I have just like many on the day of release picked up Metal Gear Solid 5; however, that was a grave mistake. Metal Gear Solid 5 is really something special but it does not outshine the diamond in the rough that is Mad Max. Mad Max is a game drive by two game play style first the weaker of the two is the hand to hand combat which is very similar to the Batman Arkham games, but lacking all the recent upgrades those games have gotten and resembling more of the first game. I find it simple fun and easy to play especially using the mouse and keyboard. Where this game shines more is the driving combat which start with the feel of driving. Driving in this game is very solid and has a vibe of "Driver" from the original PlayStation. The games driving has this heavy feeling to it, and you really feel the weight behind all the impact. The road rage combat is great and very creative in how many different ways you can take out your enemies while on 4 wheels.A lot of Mad Max roots seem to stem from other games from the past from its combat to exploration. This game has a very late 90's feeling from the sense of the collecta thon lists. This game is riddled with check boxes and areas to complete and collect 100% to clear these areas, so the OCD in any of us will be very happy. However, this does more than just feed the hunger of ones OCD, but encourages progression within the game. You are always rewarded and progress is constantly made. Performance is a big deal now of days with gaming, and I am happy to report that this games runs very very well on my gaming laptop and PC. While both my stations are on the high end spectrum I did notice that everything ran smooth and no bugs to report. The game launches with out any issues, updated, and performance was rock solid. The visual fidelity is great and reminded me again of another game which was RAGE by it. Rage was a very similar game sadly it focused more on the technology than the gameplay where this game does the opposite luckily. Sound is great the music and ambient noise suites the game just right, and the voice overs while disturbing were all a pleasure to listen to and hear more about this world.Overall this is very much a must play game; needless to say I am sure most of us have other things on the burner right now. However, see to make some time to visit the world of Mad Max and you will be rewarded for yoru time and patience with it. The game is a fun, simple, and can be picked up when ever you feel like it.

Posted: January 9, 2016
												A solid 9/10 for me. Delivered (almost) everything I wanted from a Mad Max game. Pros: -	Super pretty skyline and environment (even if it is a lot of… wasteland, they did a bang up job making it something worth looking at)-	Hand to hand Combat is solid (Arkham styled if you didn’t know already, but don’t fix what isn’t broken and that system is good to begin with)-	Car combat is intense, satisfying, and cinematic. I especially loved taking out convoys!-	Upgrading the toggling the Magnum Opus (Max’s car) offers lots of options to fit your needs-	Exploring the wasteland and what it had to offer was genuinely fun (to me), and collecting History Relics offers a glimpse into how things used to be prior to the world descending into madness, diving into the Mad Max lore and world-	Raiding camps felt awesome, particularly breaking in by destroying the camp’s defenses.-	Collecting things outside the car made the wasteland much more terrifying. This is something I see listed as a negative a lot, having to get out of the car and manually collect scraps and such things, but I appreciated it. It was a risk getting out of the car to collect that stuff, knowing a War Boy party could be just over the horizon-	The story makes for an excellent prequel to the 2015 film, even if they’re not officially (source needed?) linked by any means-	Chum Bucket-	The desert storms were legitimately terrifying, both in appearance (hard as hell to navigate do to SAND and lightning strikes) and in sound (roaring winds)-	LOTS of stuff to do. I dumped nearly 60 hours into the game clearing regions of threats and doing the main story. That doesn’t even include all the side stuff you can do. Cons:-	Water, food, and gasoline hardly matter much. Ideally, the theme of it being a harsh wasteland should be felt more strongly through the scarcity of such things, but they’re easy to come by even early on in the game and only become more common to the point of being irrelevant later-	Getting hit by a car or a boss? Pshaw. Bring it on. Getting punched by a War Boy? OW FUDGE THAT HURTS.-	Second to last final boss difficulty was insane. Final boss was way too easy (cool, but easy).-      Top Dog "bosses" could use more variety-	Thunderpoon makes car combat WAY too easy toward the end game.-	Searching for Insignias and Scrap piles within a location, camps in particular, could be one of the most obnoxious chores at times-	Crow Dazzle’s noise wagon-	Disarming Minefields was an overly tedious chore that required the use of Chum Bucket’s MEDIOCRE buggy and the dog’s (annoying) barking-	Auto aim of the sniper rifle. I could not for the life of me figure out how to turn it off. Granted I didn’t google it, so there might be a way. If there is, then ignore this.Overall for me, it’s a great game. Not GOTY material in my opinion, but an incredible game for those wanting to delve into the Wastelands of Max’s world and experience it for themselves or even a fan of sandbox style games.

												When i saw the waving flames of the car i just destroyed as the sun was setting behind the wasteland dunes, something moved inside me. When i caught into a sandstorm, i knew it was love at first sight.If you want to play a game with a vast open world (do not expect many changes of scenery. Its a wasteland), car chasing, scavenging (yep, maggots are back on the menu boys), car upgrading and brutal fighting (batman fighting gameplay) this game is for you. Honestly, the way car reacts on the sand, the sound of the engines, everything is wonderful. The way the scenery changes inside a sandstorm, is something that you have never encountered before. In general what do you do in the game now (in case you wonder)1) you scavenge small camps and abandoned vehicles like ships (i guess there was a sea over there) and you also find relics of another time that reminds you how it was once, and they really add to the feeling2)Destroy larger camps with enemies. 3)Destroy big camps where you have to beat the local boss of the area4)participate in death races (while in open world, you can steal other cars in order to use them in these races)5)Help helpless people by giving them water, in exchange for information6) as you cross the wasteland, random gangs will attack you, or an enemy convoy will pass, that you could attack and destroy in order to gain materials and  parts.7) Game has soft borders. Means that there isn't any invinsible wall that will tell you "its over". Want to drive into nothingness? Go ahead. More wasteland for you. You might find something useful, or you can die there. And yes, you can find something useful outside of the map. Well done Avalanche!8)I almost forgot. Enemies in cars are not stupid. If they see they loose, they will run away. Its surviving afterl all is it not?Want to know the best part? I play this game for 7 hours and i haven't even unlock the half of the map. I am just inside a tiny part of it. Do you like the concept of Mad Max? Buy it.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												Mad Max is a completely competent open-world action game with a story that is  short and shallow, but very Mad Max.Mad Max ticks all the open-world action check boxes. You destroy towers (scarecrows) and take over forts to gain influence in each region. You fight against other factions in a Batman-light-style hand to hand combat and an excellent vehicle-combat that includes harpoons, thunderpoons, flame-throwers, depth-charges, ramming bars, boarding spikes, and wheel-shredders.In addition to playing through main missions (of which there are only a handful - really, by the time you realize there is a narrative, the story is in its last few missions), there are a lot of side missions that you will run for various demented characters throughout the wastelands.The game is beautiful. It also performs very well, showing what you can accomplish when you put effort into your platform optimization. On an i7-4790k with 16GB RAM and NVIDIA GTX 970 SLI system, we see consistent framerates in excess of 140fps at 1920x1080. Even with almost every setting maxed-out and while doing a live streaming session (usually disastrous for framerate on an SLI system due to the way streaming applications capture frames), we hit well-above 100fps.Other than a shallow and fairly short story, Mad Max doesn't suffer any great failures on any one aspect. Yet, it does not quite seem to be greater than the sum of its parts. It is very entertaining. It has a lot of thoroughly enjoyable aspects, of which vehicle combat is probably the best. But it is also wears out its welcome, by the end. You've eventually had enough sand, screaming crazies running at you, and flame-shooting cars side-ramming you. You've had enough scrap collecting and busy-work -- which this game is riddled with. It is competent; not groundbreaking.But this should not be a bad thing. And it also does help us to understand why the reviews have been all over the place for this title. It isn't mind-blowing, but it isn't bad. I bought this game for just over half price, just before launch. Due to the discounts we saw everywhere, I was certain they were trying to dump the game while they could and had low expectations. Instead, I found a thoroughly good game for which I have no quarrel having paid half price. At full AAA launch price? Well, I'm not sure it would quite have lived up to that . . . but I wouldn't be disgruntled over it. I would be interested in a sequel to this title, if they make one. They have a solid foundation, here.It is difficult for me to say that I do or do not recommend this game. I enjoyed it and feel it was worth what I paid for it. I would not be upset, but perhaps a little disappointed, if I'd paid full price. So, ultimately, I'd have to suggest that if you are a huge Mad Max fan and you can't stop playing open-world games, it may be worth full price. If you just love Mad Max or just love open-world games, then pick it up for half price and you'll probably be very satisfied and surprised.Below is the first of a nine part 31hr live-stream playthrough of Mad Max:

												Mad Max is one of my favorite film series, and this game really feels like Mad Max to me.  There is plenty of stuff to do although it gets really repetitive really fast.  You spend most of your time grinding for scrap for the numerous upgrades for your car as well as Max himself,  these come in the form of demolishing enemy camps, searching old wrecks and buildings, clearing minefields, etc.  The story is good but short and it forces you to complete a lot of these scrap grinds in order to upgrade enough to advance.  The melee combat feels a lot like the Batman games, and the whole game plays a lot like Shadow of Mordor.  The game is really repetitive with it's tasks but it is very satisfying driving around in your overloaded car getting into road battles and fist fights.  I would highly recommend it for fans of Mad Max but I could see how some people would get bored with it easily.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												It is quite ironic that the game which everyone was expecting to fail miserably, ends up being the "Surprise of the Year." Of all the WB games that were released on the PC this year, only Mad Max didn't crash and burn in terms of performance. The game's well-optimized state is a huge contrast to the Arkham Knight disaster. As a game, Mad Max succeeds in doing what the devs (Avalanche) and distributor (WB) set out to do, which is to recreate the Mad Max experience in a video game. And boy they did. The car combat in Mad Max is fantastic and the foot combat, while it looks like a cheap copy of the combat you see in the Batman: Arkham series manages to hold it's own well enough. Every time you see Max break someone's arm or German Suplex him into the sand, you can almost feel it. While there isn't much variety in terms of enemies and the gameplay does get rather repetitive after a while, you're still guaranteed to have one hell of a time.Surprisingly, Mad Max The Game does have a decent story. While it's pretty straightforward, you do find yourself caring for a few characters including the ever-spouting nonsense Chumbucket. Which makes the ending even worse. Most players aren't happy with Mad Max's ending and when you finally played till there, you'll know why. But I won't spoil it, it's something players have to experience for themselves but I can say it's very very typical of a Mad Max story.If there's anything I dislike about the game, it's that the open-world is way too bland. You'd be expecting something like the Fallout series, considering the post-apocalyptic setting but the world design is just vast and empty. You'll find a few tiny camps here and there, then there's the bigger camps where you carry out objectives and get more scrap, upgrades and blueprints to upgrade the strongholds of the allies you'll meet on Max's story. But, that's all. There's nothing really exciting to find in this world.Mad Max is a game to pick up if you're one for intense car combat and plenty of driving. If you're the type that complains about driving too much in a game like GTA for example, then this is not the game for you. If it's up your alley, try playing it in first-person mode. It's difficult but it makes for a very interesting experience as well. Mad Max is no GOTY contender but it's a solid game through and through.
