												If I was to describe this game it would be like playing Shadow of Mordor but it was in a wasteland demolition derby starring Mad Max! The reason I say its like playing Shadow of Mordor is because both games were made by Warner Bros. games. You can see the similarities between the two mostly just by the type of game it is. What I mean by that is both games have a map divided into regions that you can conquer, the combat in both games are VERY similar and fluid (What I liked most from Shadow of Mordor), and its an open world to explore with alot of enemies. But that is where the similarities end. Mad Max is a COMPLETELY different game far and beyond.+The Map is VERY large in Mad Max and you can expect to finish the main questline in probably about 30+ hours of playing but it depends whether you clear regions out or do alot of side missions too+Combat on the ground is similar to Shadow of Mordor except instead of a sword you have FISTS! But you do also have other things like melee weapons you can pick up, your shotgun, Shivs, and the use of the enviornment which can be quite "explosive"+Car Combat is extremely exciting and challenging especially when you haven't gotten all the high-end upgrades for the Magnum Opus yet+The Upgrades for both Max and especially the Magnum Opus are very satisfying and cool to put on+The story was very enjoyable and trilling as you moved deeper into the wastes+Very well optimized for PC+/-The amount of lootable areas in the game was a bit overwhelming to me especially since alot of places are minor and have 1 or 2 boxes in them which made it so it almost isn't worth the time to go and get them. However, no place is same so if achievement hunting or exploring is your thing it's not bad+/-I wasn't fond of the many death races you can do all over the map, compared to doing the story, side missions, or getting map control it never appealed to me. But it is an extra and its there. I know some people who would enjoy doing themI would highly recommend this game and I would gladly pay the asking price for this game. No regrets. I bought both fallout 4 and Mad Max at the same time and I beat Mad Max before I got very far in Fallout 4 so theres that.

												Mad max is another massive open world game full of loads of different tasks to complete...So Firstly let me start this review off by saying that this game is VERY well optimised and for me personally it runs at 40fps on my over clocked 3 year old laptop. So Thank you whoever made this for not leaving us pc gamers out of the equation.The Story in Mad max is pretty bland as you might expect, if you are interested in what little one it is then here is a brief explanation for you- Max gets his Precious Car stolen by a Bad guy named Scrotus- You meet a guy called Chumbucket who makes cars and parts with scrap-You team up and over time build yourself up to get Revenge on Scrotus.Okay thats enough of the story... Go play it for yourself if you want to find out more :DThe graphics are outstanding on this game and it is easily one of the best looking games I have ever seen especially when the sandstorms come into play.The campaign will take on average around 15-20 hours to complete excluding the side missions and it was also very fun to play but others may say that it gets a bit repettive with all of the driving and fighting you have to do.The world like I said at the start of this review is full of things to see and do. The attention to detail on this game is unlike no other I have seen this year.My downsides would be that all of the boss battles are pretty much identical with the mehods you need to kill them which is pretty sad because I like a bit more variation with these things. When playing them it reminded me a hell of a lot like the Wolf boss battles in the Order 1886 which is not a good thing in my book.Another downside is the extremely bland fighting controls, All you have is punch, block and a couple other "special moves".My final downside would be to do with the extremely bland ending which I will not spoil here.Overall, Since this game is on sale it is a must buy!My rating is a 8/10UPDATE 1- Have a look at my Profile for some screenshots :DUPDATE 2- I recommend installing Windows 10 as it gave the game a 3fps boost for me :D

												Down right one of the most gorgeous games in existence today. Gameplay is a mix of Arkham Asylum with mostly Shadows of Mordor plus Twisted Metal/Burnout - all set in a Fallout esque open world that is true to whats portrayed in the films, especially the most recent one.. The vehicle combat is a blast, the hand to hand is visceral, the story is compelling if sometimes a bit schitck-y. It offers an interesting plunge into a contemporary story with the film Mad Max: Fury Road. If you love the movie, and love action rpg games, and love beautiful open worlds, you have to play this. It is an absolute steal when on sale. There are a few bugs, but sometimes its seriously the most beautiful game I've played. The visuals and art art style are unreal, and it keeps that abstract yet intense feeling from the  Fury Road. A must play for genere of film fans. About 60 hours start to finish completing 90% or so of all side content. 8.7/10

												Highly recommended!!I purchased the game six days ago, during the Steam Winter sale, having no expectations whatsoever. The game literally popped up on my main screen and I thought to myself "Why the hell not". Six days later I can only say that this is one of, if not - the best game purchases I've ever made!  The game mechanics and progression are really well made. It felt very natural to me - seamless and flowing. It might not be as charming for some people due to the kind of repetitive game style (doing the same things over and over) but for me this is the first game in a while that just made me sit down, let go off everything else and just finish it. Even more so, I felt compelled to complete as much of it as possible. After the first couple hours I liked it so much that I knew I had to go on the good ol' 'completionist' spree (still getting there though). I don't want to spoil the story, but I have to say that for the past few days I was able to build such a personal connection with the main character that the events in the last several missions made me shiver and tremble with hate and anger as I was driving through the wasteland with tears in my eyes and a lump in my throat. You just don't see that in games nowadays or at least I haven't for quite some time.MAJOR PROPS to all the people involved in the creation of this game!**** EDIT ****I was so overwhelmed that I forgot to mention few other qualities. The game is mighty-well optimized. It runs smoothly and consistently. It is also beautifully made. Even though the majority of the environment is commonly reffered to as a 'wasteland', you will not get bored while wandering around. Each location has a very distinctive styling in my opinion and it helps a great deal to add up to its 'character'.  I was blown away by the areas which were primarily dark. They really do require the use of the flashlight in order to be able to see somewhat decently. The only 'con' I'd mention about this game is that I cannot magically forget the story and re-live the whole experience all over :)

 MAD MAX is one of the better games based on a movie franchise Title: MAD MAXGenre: Adventure, beat em up, blowe em up, RPG, driving.Developer: Avalanche studiosPublisher: WB games IS IT ANY GOOD? Yes it is good. What I mean by that is that it aint great but it aint bad either. still confused? Well let me explain to you why I said this.Im basing my review on how well it plays, how the story is, the driving  and fighting mechanics and ofcourse how the game handles in general ( performance, glitches and bugs) PROS Shooting other people out of their cars with a harpoon has never been so satisfyingEating dogfood once in a while is apparently good for your healthBatman arkham series inspired hand to hand combat which aint badRamming cars, harpooning cars, blowing cars up.Lots of explosions ( like a M.Bay movie)Big sandy world to exploresome intresting side objectives called wasteland missionsDecent voiceactingA lot of customization on max and the Magnum opusProgression system (griffa tokens)Ragdoll glitches are hilariousgame is optimized aswell which is rare these days THE CONS:  The short average storyNone of the characters were really that intrestingCollecting relics and such is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥because there are around 200 locations to loot.Clearing camps, vantage outposts etc takes a while and you can say its pretty repetitive.The game gets a bit dull and repetitive at times Dont get me wrong. I do recommend this game. But there are some points on which Mad Max falls short. So we have to talk about that. I was really excited when they announced the game after seeing the movies. I got ready to have myself a great time. Did I have a great time? at times.. yes but..1: the wasteland you drive trough doesnt have a lot to offer in terms of eyecandy. Now I know that thats what they were probably going for but it made me personally fast travel to everything as much as I could.2: What I didnt  enjoy in this game is the fact that you have to clear all the vantage points, convoy routes, minefields and camps to unlock upgrades for certain items. As I said earlier. the Map is kinda big. there are a bunch of areas. but after clearing 2-3 areas the taking over of camps and clearling minefields becomes repetitive and boring at some points. Conclusion & Final verdict To sum it all up and keep it short(ish). The core of the game is great. the ramming the shooting and the fighting is very well executed. the voiceacting is good enough and the wasteland does have enough things to keep you busy. While some of them bore me you might enjoy yourself clearling camps and minefields all day but thats completely up to you ofcourse. Overall I did enjoy the game and the story was decent enough to make me go trough it entirely. The customization is well done and did I mention that the game is  DAMN WELL OPTIMIZED?! I salute the developers for bringing out a game that works from day one, Has great graphics and just the occasional bug to make you laugh (ragdoll glitches). It is rare these days that games actually work from day one. I appreciate that a lot. My final verdict for MAD MAX is a good 7.7/10 I recommend this to everyody who's a Mad Max fan and loves to blow stuff up.(If you get bored fast because things can get a bit repetitive I suggest you buy it on sale)You will have a good time regardless. Posted: November 5, 2015
												Absolutely adore this game. It kinda suffers from that problem that a lot of open world games these days suffer from (mosdtly from Ubisoft) where it basically just gives you a laundry list of things to do. In concept, it doesn't sound fun, but in actual gameplay it is pulled off surprisingly well, considering how wonderful the mechanics of the game flow with oneanother. This game has a lot of really good design choices that are so discrete most people wouldn't notice them. Things such as when you're taking down an encampment, when you get to the end and finish it, they always make an easy way to get back to your Magnum Opus rather than making you backtrack through the entire area, I love that. Little details like that go a LONG way towards enjoyment. There are also a few very bad design choices, such as the boss fights which are very tedious and generally annoying. Luckily they're fairly far enough between that it doesn't get in the way often. The driving is perfect, not much to say there. The weapons feel powerful and have a very satisfying animation when they are used. Also not much to say about the on-foot combat, it's been done before, and better, but it's solid and I relish any opportunity I get to beat the heck out of some War Boys. Customization of your Magnum Opus and Max I also feel are a stroug point, because of how tangible the benefits of upgrading each are. With each upgrade there is a noticeable change in how the game plays. For example, changing out the tires od the Magnum Opus dramatically changes the way you approach driving. Some specialize in dricing on sand, off road, or on asphalt. The feeling of progression is wonderful. The story isn't all that great, but that's alright in my book considering the newest entry to the Mad Max thatrical series (Fury Road) was also lacking in story, but that seems like a strong point. There really isn't such a need for story in games like this because I would rather be ramming cars with my beautiful Magnum Opus or beating bad guys into the ground. And considering how solid the gameplay mechanics are, the lack of story is welcomed. PC performance was absolutely wonderful and I feel that this game should be a role model for other games releasing to follow as far as optimization. I tested the game with multiple setups, even one with an integrated GPU. The game ran beautifully on every setup (with the settings tweaked accordingly of course). I did notice a bit of stutter where the game would freeze for about 1/3 of a second every 15-20 minutes or so. Nothing game breaking, on fact, it was hardly noticeable, but something to keep in mind. It happened on every setup including my 980 with a 4790K. There's also a few performance issues in Gastown later in the game where the frame rate will drop to about 40fps even with my settings turned down on the high end system. Also not too noticeable,but can get annoying, especially considering that area is literally the worst. There's a whole lot more to talk about, but even after 70 hours of play time I still am itching to get back into the game.

content:
Posted: March 16
												Work in Progress:It does indeed take some time getting used to the controls.. Both on foot, and in the car.. Im finding myself(now 13hrs in) still frustrated by the controls.. Im playing with a 360 controller, and the layout is just nonsensicle: FootRT to run, RB to evade, A(Hold) for EVERYthing, which screws you up alot.. (try to climb a ladder, or open a door, loot something, and it will drop your weapon)X to attack, ignite gas can for explosion, and fueling vehicles.. Try to Fuel something, and accidentally explode the tank..Shooting, is extremely annoying.. Hold LB to aim, and B to shoot..You are stationary, and clicking B has a full second or two delay, before firing! 2/3 times resulting in you being interupted by a melee attack.Car:RT gas, LT brake/Reverse, and again the stupid Hold LB to aim, and B to fire weapon, or other( I wont spoil) Y to enter/exit you can get out while in motion.. For whatever reason seats are on the right, instead of left.. But you can enter either side..You car feels slightly weak at first, but only against certain enemies..This gets complaints from others, but after an hour or two, I actually like it.. the cars feel very realistic, and the ONLy complaint that I have, is that the Right analog (Steering) isnt quite right.. It requires barely touching it for turning, but if you start to fishtail, its pretty much done, until you regain control.. It easily over turns, or over corrects, and it just feels off.. You do get used to it, and the cars handle nicely.. Especially once upgraded.. On the subject of upgrades.. For the car, they are noticeable, or moreover, each one has a new physical appearance for the car.. And there are plenty! Max upgrades were less noticeable, and the Tokens felt too powerful.. I went straight for gas, water, and ammo, and in no time at all, I had all available ones maxed, before the next tier would unlock.. Im now on tier 3..The game, is extremely easy, though I guess what majority of this open world game type is.... Just a few hours in, Ive got all tools, multiple upgrades for Max, and atleast rank 1 of all car upgrades..  10 hrs later, and I have a few car items rank 4, before Ive even unlocked rank 3.. The Spikes for example.. Theres no need to ever use rank two when it unlocks, now that I have 3! Hand to hand combat is easier than Assassins Creed, or Arkham, by a long shot.. After some more time with the game, and having to combat multiple types of enemies at once, I became more, and mroe annoyed with the control scheme.. But It can get used too.. What I cannot get used too, is the type of enemy that can only be dodged (Red Lines above the head) as they are already within a split second of you, by the time the indicator pops up, and Ive had a difficult time avoiding it.. Especially when fighting 6 or more enemies! Its very stale combat.. Its much easier BEFORE you unlock "moves", as trying to use RT to run and X to charge, X to punch, Hold X to power punch, A to shank, Hold A to pickup weapon, RB to dodge, LB to aim&B to shoot.. It becomes too much when youre in the heat of combat, and need to try and dodge.. It is atleast fun.. Cars sound awesome, and though I dont like the steering control, they react like a real automobile.. Jumping might as well not be in the game.. Its completely useless, as he only jumps as high as his ankle, and you have bright yellow ladders, and ledges to indicate where to Hold A to climb, open door, break, loot, etc.. I can see why some say it gets repetetive, as youll be doing alot of driving in bland environments, with nothing of note.. They really could have done SO much mroe with the vast world.. Im quite disappointed with "Scrap" everywhere, as it just feels lazy, and looks so out of place.. Guess much of the budget went into graphics, and map scale.. Still, I cannot complain.. I got it for under $7 on Steam sale, and am a little sorry I listened to soem of the negative feedback.. I likely wont play it a second time, but i can see myself playing it through fully once.. PS: the map, SCREAMS Ubisoft.. In EVERy conceivable way.. Radio Towers (Hot Air Ballon), Enemy Camps, Collectibles, Main missions, Side Missions, broken into multiple zones!  Straight out of Ubisoft play book.. No doubt!

Posted: September 2, 2015
												Game Informer gave 'Mad Max' a 7.5 out of 10 and I'd say that's about right from what I've played so far and is pretty much what I was expecting. This is a solid action game that maybe follows the WB formula a little to cloesly. Anyone who's played one of Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment's 'Batman' games or 'Shadows of Mordor' pretty much knows what to expect from the ground combat more or less. While this is in no way a bad thing 'Mad Max' was also developed by Avalanche Studios , whose biggest claim to fame is the 'Just Cause' series, and I would've liked to see a little less WB and a little more Avelanche in the game play. The biggest complaint I see on negative user reviews is the driving, which is a little funky and takes some getting used to; but it's servicable and far from a deal breaker. The 2 cars I've driven so far, Chumbuckets Buggy and the very early Magnum Opus, both handle pretty much the same but aren't quite as good as most games where driving is a big part of the experience. I'm hoping that as I unlock improvements for the Magnum Opus the car will start to become a little more responsive because right now the driving is a little sluggish. If not I'd hope that a patch comes out to address this. I will give an extra "thumbs up" to the vehicle combat; it's pretty spot on and so far I have no complaints. I'm barely a few hours into the game and so far I have to say that this game delivers and is about what I was expecting, maybe a little more, but definitely not what I was hoping for.*edit*This was written after my first play session. I completed the main story and can only say that the game starts ot good and gets better and better as you play it.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												★★★★★ - "Do not miss this game" PROS:- Huge content, there is just so much to do. Including Story Missions, Wasteland Missions, Death Run (Races), Scavenging (Looting), camps to build, camps to take down, mines to detect, objects to destroy and much more.- Combat, yes it follows the mould of the Arkham games and Shadow of Mordor but its even more satisfying in my eyes. Theres no gadgets, just your fists, a shiv or other enemy weapons. Its brutal, you feel every blow and it makes for many satisfying moments as you activate fury mode or improvise with your environment.- Magnum Opus, by far the best part of this game is the desire to grind look in the way of scrap to build up the ultimate battle machine. Ive never felt this in any racer or simulation I've ever played but here your car counts for everything and customisation is very detailed.- Racing, most of the games moments result in you trying to survive in your car as you pass patrols or take on the story/side missions. This is fast and frantic. At first its hard but once you build up your car you feel like a total badass.- The game is very clever at making the most of all its options as you must meet requirements to continue the story. Some people might not like this but it helped immersion for me as i can lose interest in these open world games.- Chumbucket, he's a delightful character who accompanies you, fixing your car and giving tips.- Optimisation, like many I put off this game due to WB recent messes but Avalanche have done a fine job and runs smooth as butter.- Beautiful environment, the wasteland is ugly but its vast and ultimately stunning as a result. An odd beauty.- Storms, these raid you game and unpredictable moments. They are intense.- Camera mode, this mode is  really detailed. It brings out the games beauty and the photographer in you.- Max himself has a pretty decent levelling system in two ways also.CONS:- So the story is okay, its pacing is strange. Its sudden and didn't feel very long, I preferred the wasteland missions to be honest.- Characters, another minor moan that the characters were pretty dense. They're bold but other than Max and Chumbucket they failed to provide any real solid moments.- My only major gripe is that some of the meetings with friendly wastelanders are totally pointless. They are meant to serve a few purposes, give you loot, give you intel on camps and to ask a favour in order to gain secret loot. Now the interactions are all very samey and feel like a total after thought. The characters all look the same and are poorly detailed. The voice actors are pretty much the same for each and there reasoning is daft. I would have preferred if they were left out!VERDICT? Mad Max is my game of 2015. Caught me by surprise. Its immensely satisfying and very immersive but above all its value for money. Im nearly 50 hours in at this point and still have side missions and camps I want to finish completing.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												This is a very tentative recommendation, but I did enjoy myself.Pros:- First time the Batman combat system has really felt solid (see notes)- Reasonably good driving- Reasonably good storyCons:- Tedious camps and other wasteland encounters- Uses the Batman combat system (again, see notes)- Story requires you to complete tedious side missions- Checkpoints are not placed wellNotes:Batman (Arkham) combat system: I loved Batman: Arkham Asylum, but it most *certainly* wasn't for the combat system.  To me, the combat system invented for Arkham Asylum felt like an afterthought, thrown together in an attempt to make Batman look badass while fighting without forcing an overwhelming amount of effort into the combat system of what was essentially a stealth game.  It worked very well for a stealth game.  In most action games, it still looks pretty cool ... but it's an overly simplified combat system that takes practically no effort to master.Mad Max expanded upon the system well enough to hold my attention most of the time.  That's impressive.  That doesn't mean, however, that it was an interesting combat system that engaged me particularly well - it felt pretty mediocre and required very little effort on my part.  Still, it felt more engaging than Arkham City or Shadow of Mordor.Wasteland Encounters: Generally, most of the encounters are fairly engaging through the first couple of areas, and some of them later expand upon previous ideas to keep things entertaining.  However ... the stupid mine fields ...In order to fully clear an area, you need to drive around that area until you drive past every mine field - you can't spot mine fields from the hot air balloons.  Then, once you've found a mine field, you need to go back to a stronghold and choose another vehicle (Chum's Buggy), which you *cannot* fast travel with.  Then, you need to drive back to the mine field and carefully drive around watching the direction your dog's nose is pointing to find out where the mines are; for each mine, you need to get out of your car, walk up to it, hit 'E', watch a cutscene, then go back to your car.Tedious.Checkpoints: Overall, the checkpoints are okay, but there are a number places where you get a checkpoint nearly a minute from a very difficult section of the game.  When it takes a good 10-15 seconds to load a checkpoint, then another *minute* to get back to the difficult area, it means the checkpoint was not placed correctly.Again, tedious.All that said: I enjoyed my time with Mad Max.  I've finished the story and a good number of side missions, and it's pretty rare for a game to hold my attention that well.  I don't have any plans to play out the rest of the game, but the main story and the wasteland encounters and side missions that I *did* finish were fun.

Posted: March 22
												Let me start this off by saying that I'm not a die-hard Mad Max fan. I've seen Mad Max: Fury Road and I enjoyed the film very much, but it wasn't anything worth ♥♥♥♥♥♥ing over.   Category Comments Score   Graphics Probably one of the most beautiful games I have played. It does a great job of capturing the feel of the Mad Max world with endless sandy wastelands, large explosions, and the scrappy, makeshift machines of death that were once someones commuter car.  10/10   Story The story is relatively short, and nothing to get too excited about. I feel like it does do a good job though of allowing the player to take a deeper look into Max's past and get a feel for who he is and why he does what he does. The story's end goal is to retreive the prized Big Chief (V8 Engine)  7/10   Performance By far the most optimized game that I have ever played. In fact, my framerate was so high at 1920 by 1080 on max settings that my GPU was producing a NASTY coil whine. After changing the resolution to 4K and keeping the settings on max, I was able to hold a constant 60-80FPS and the coil whine dissapeared. (I am using an OC'd i7-4790k and an OC'd 980Ti). These framerates are a first for me on any open world game. 10/10   Combat The combat in this game has two different forms. There's foot combat which is very similar to the combat in the Batman games or Shadow of Mordor, but still has some unique aspects to it. I wouldn't go so far as to call it a rip-off of the other games, but it certianly has it's similarities. Regardless, the foot combat is very fluid and my only complaint is that on rare occasions the camera clips behind a wall while you are fighting and makes it impossible to see anything. The other form of combat is vehicular combat. Mad Max has, hands down, the best vehicle combat of any game I have ever played. Its fluid, exciting, and doesn't have a huge learning curve to be able to use properly. Harpoons, explosives, shotguns, flamethrowers and more are all at your disposal to crush your opposition while you are cruising through the dunes at high speed. 9/10  Gameplay I enjoyed how the game is open world, so you are free to complete main missions, side missions, or scavange for scrap (to upgrade your vehicle) in any order you like. I also like how you are able to build your vehicle however you like depending on the situations you expect to be getting into. For example, you can build a heavily defended car that that can take quite a beating, but you'll suffer heavily on your speed. Or, you can build a car that can zip across the wasteland but has little to no protection from hostile vehicles. The biggest downside on this game, that many others have stated, is the grinding. Alot of this game, especially after you finish the main story, is just hunting for scrap so you can buy better parts for your vehicle. If grinding is your thing, then you'll love this game. Otherwise you may want to give it a second thought before purchasing. 7/10

So do you remember the best part of Borderlands 2? That one desert zone with the white trash clans, and the bandit trucks running around, and you could hijack convoys and steal loot chests from them? Imagine someone just took that zone, made it an entire game, and then filled that game full of hilarious toys for you to murder australian skinheads with.ALL THE CRITICS HATE IT.Yea, and Kojima's next sixty dollar movie about an old one eyed dude in a bandana is gonna get editor's choice and game of the year. The difference is someone is gonna pay those ♥♥♥♥s to like Metal Gear, nobody paid them to like Mad Max. Read all these reviews from people who bought it, the fan response to the game is unanimously positive.I'M A MAD MAX FANBOY, CAN I GET ALL THE ICONIC MAD MAX♥♥♥♥♥♥Yes. The game starts out like every Max movie ever- You're driving along minding your own business and then some dudes ♥♥♥♥ up your♥♥♥♥♥♥and wreck your car, and you're♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥because your car is badass. But it doesn't take long for you to get back all your original Max gear. You always have a shotgun, you can choose a Ford Falcon XB body to be your car, and you unlock the leather jacket pretty early.  Also, the reward for beating story mode is an unlock for the pristine V8 interceptor completely canon from the films.I'M NOT A MAD MAX FANBOY, WHY SHOULD I GIVE A ♥♥♥♥?Even if you're not a Max fanboy this game is just fun as ♥♥♥♥. It should be called NEED FOR SPEED: PSYCHOPATHS. It's an Australian murder car simulator. There are hotrod driving skinheads all over the desert and your job is to run them over with flamethrowers, harpoon guns, and spiked wheels. You can rip the doors off of cars and harpoon guys out of the driver seat and pull them through the windshield. You can ram the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything until it explodes. When guys jump on your car, you can just blow them into meat confetti with your shotgun. The people who made this game are truly sick. It's WONDERFUL.You will chase down and murder a dozen human beings and blow up their cars just for the sake of grabbing a can of dog food, some shotgun shells, and a hood ornament.WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥, NO MULTIPLAYER?This game should never have multiplayer. The amount of death and destruction one person in one car already causes in this game is beautifully horrendous. If they let us all into the world in our murder cars we'd all be harpooning each other and exploding. The devs at Avalanche would be arrested and put on trial for war crimes.

You can easiely compare this to Metal Gear Solid V. MGSV has almost always the same objective but offers many different approaches. Mad Max offers to slaughter everyone and everything either by blowing them up or beating the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them which makes somewhat boring.As I have stated I played 20.8h . If my playtime in this game grows by more than 5 hours I probably changed my mind but if not than I tell you this: After 20 hours I am done with the game. I unlocked pretty much everything and don't see a point in upgrading anything else since there is no challenge whatsoever in it anymore. Other than with Shadow of Mordor for example where it took me 24 hours to get to ~90% completion I am not really satisfied with the time I spent.Do I recommend it? Yes!Is it worth 50€/$ ? Not at all.I got it for 19€ and I think it is worth it but I would not recommend you buying it at 50€ for such a simple and repetetive game.Final Rating: Reluctant 7/10Feel free to ask questions in the comment section if you have any and feel free to discuss certain points with my if your opionion differs.Final Note: What mostly pisses me off is that it was said that ammo would be rare but since it is not fights get even easier and you mostly use ammo because you just want to get over with fights faster. I suppose they did it because fighting would end up in constantly bashing the same buttons and while driving you would have to constantly ram the opponent which is annoying and boring.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Well, there's been some discussion about wether or not this game is worth your time, and I think it's time to throw in my two cents.Let's start off with the most obvious part: the story. Not a great one for a large part of the game. At first (and probably for 75% of the story) your only objective is acquiring a V8 engine for your car. Yeah, not the most intense set-up you've ever heard. In order to get a V8 you have to look in Gas Town, a dangerous place, so before you can even go look for a V8 you need to acquire various upgrades from a few characters in the wasteland. For a long while the story doesn't really move forward and you're just kinda wanking about not really doing anything real. At the end though, once the V8 gets in reach, suddenly things shift into fifth gear and there's suddenly all these things going on. I won't spoil anything, but I actually started relating to Max and his journies for the last little bit of the story. There were some interesting characters in play all of a sudden, and Max had some motive I could understand. There was depth too, as you could see Mad Max struggle between doing what is right and doing what is best for him. That is actually a main point in the movies, too. But that doesn't last and just as you're having fun the story ends. Quite a shame since it shows so much potential at the end there. So, in total, I'd say the story is bare-boned and empty, with a glimpse of a proper story at the end.Off to the next big thing then: cars! This game has a metric ton of car upgrades, and unlocking new upgrades is probably the most rewarding thing in the game. The cars feel and handle well too, and there's actually quite a little room for different builds. Some linear upgrades are a little boring, there's for instance no reason not to take the best engine, exhaust and weapons (they have no downsides), but there's also stuff like armor and rams, which will offer more protection and damage but will also slow you down. Having the option to create either a slow, rusted, hulking heap of death or a shiny fast fragile little thing is pretty cool, though I kinda wish there was more thinking involved. For instance, it'd be more fun if you had to choose between a roaring fast engine or an economical one, the one meaning more performance in battles and the other meaning more time to drive around without stopping and having to murder 12 guys over 4 liters of fuel. Again, it seems like they could have made it more interesting, but it serves its purpose very well in this state. Building your own death machine is still a lot of fun.Now, in this game, most time will be spent doing side-objectives. This is a real completionist's heaven. The map is stuffed to the brim with objectives, small and big, to keep you busy. The main reason for doing these is of course the aforementioned car upgrades. They will only unlock when you clear a region of threats. Now to me, the objectives were certainly fun enough to keep me busy. My favourite are these convoy-routes, where you have to engage in car-battles and ram and tear a whole convoy of cars apart in order to recieve a shiny hood-ornament (doubles as an upgrade) for your car. Other objectives include beating up leukemia-camps (guessing they all have cancer) and tearing down statues. The fighting itself is a lot of fun by the way, you get to see Max bust out some really cool MMA/wrestling moves, and they do have a real punch to them. Though fighting is simple (block/attack), I can't help but enjoy every double-leg takedown or tombstone piledriver Max dishes out. Though again, I see squandered potential. The fighting system would be oh-so-much better when the awesome moves Max sometimes does were special combos, also unlockable through leveling. It'd make them feel more special. And another thing I would have done is give the hood ornaments special perks instead of increased speed/health/handling of your car. Have the hood ornaments give you special abilities and it'd be so much better. And also, there's not enough car-fights. This is an absolute problem I have, almost every quest is done on foot. This is Mad Max damnit, you can't venture through that desert on foot! Where are the car-chases, the car-battles, the car-escapes, the car-parkour, everything! I am truly dissapointed by the lack of car-stuff in a Mad Max game. And then my final gripe, there are these Boss-camps that give you paints for your car. You might have guessed that there's a boss in them. Now the first time I saw one I was pretty impressed, he had attack patterns and stuff and he had a weakness that I had to figure out, it took some doing to get him down. So after that I couldn't wait to see the next one. Then it turned out the next boss was exactly the same guy with a different color! EVERY BOSS IS THE SAME! Bosses could have been so amazing if they gave them a little more effort! Such a waste!But alas, the game is what it is, and even though I think there was a LOT of room for improvement, I still enjoy Mad Max. Everything in the game is decent, it is *very* well optimized, and the game is just fun to play. So my conclusion: not all that special, but a solid game nonetheless. If you have less money to burn than me, I'd wait until it drops to about 30 bucks and then give it a shot. It's fun, really, it is.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												I am very tempted to give this game a positive review. If there was a neutral option, I'd take it.My biggest problem with the game is that many of the tasks feel empty and hollow. Tearing down a scarecrow or a sniper's nest isn't really that much fun, but it's there to be done, and it stands between you and the upgrades you want.The on-foot combat is easy to pick up, but has very little room to raise your skill in. You basically smash the left mouse button until everyone is dead, and occassionally block or evade. Weapons you temporarily aquire just dumb the combat down even more, as you now just have to smash the left mouse button. Shadow of Mordor, a game published by the same company with similar combat system, offers so much more variety in terms of skill, that it baffles me how they could make this so similar, yet fail so hard.The vehicle combat is a lot better, but it has its own set of flaws - some of them critical. At first, it feels really satisfying to crash into enemies, pull them out of their car or shoot their tyres, but it gets somewhat boring soon. As soon as you aquire the Lv. 4 Harpoon, you just pull everyone's tyres off instantly, thus making you win every fight. Upgrades, on the other hand, seem to do very little in terms of combat. The improved ramming grills barely make you deal more damage, while the armor only seems to make your car go more sluggish, while offering no real incresed protection. After you get the thunderpoon upgraded, you can just one-shot every enemy you engage.The story feels non-existant until you reach gastown (which was the majority of the game for me), and then turns somewhat nonsensical. The next part will discuss some characters, so it'll naturally contain spoilers: Tenderloin's character feels completely wasted to the story. She just exists so Max doesn't have to kill Chumbucket after the race. Max' relation to Hope and Glory make no sense either. He doesn't want them to come with him, so he leaves them back to die, but gets extremely mad (no pun intended) when they die. All in all, this game might have done just as well without the story.As for the good parts, the game does offer a lot of content, even if the content itself is rather dull. If you are looking for a game into which you can sink 20-40 hours, then I would recommend it. If you're looking for "the action version of New Vegas", then this isn't it.

												Alright. 48/49 achievements down. Full story beat. Play time isnt accurate to my steam account as a friend plays when I'm not. The above save (mine) sits at 99.3 hours total for anyone curious and the final achievement is... one that could take an hour or another ten heh.Fun game, open world. Grappeling hooks, thunderpoon(rocket launcher), nitrous, fully upgradeable vehicles, over fifty vehicles ingame btw.On foot combat is melee focused, your only ranged weapon is your shotgun but ammunition limits plus overall use steers you towards melee combat which feels like any of the batman titles.The story itself feels set aside all the way until the last 15% of the story play at which point it goes knee deep and becomes more engaging. Sadly though it dosent answer some popular questions amongst this franchises fanbase such as a, where is fury road timeline wise with the original trilogy and b, is this the original mad max or someone else and c, is he married before the game or during the game only.Thankfully the story isnt the main focus of enjoyment. There are hundreds of places to explore/loot, vehicles to collect and upgrade, talent points, races, convoys to chase everywhere, strongholds to build, relics to collect, it rocks!I walk away from this game now (until some sort of dlc of course) satisfied that I got my money's worth out of it. I'd like dlc, I'd like more lore depth explored, more non hostile groups out there in the wastes to encounter, more exploration in to ruins of the old world, there's lots of potential here. I have no hope that this game will match fallout 4 when it arrives but there is ALOT that can be done to this game to put it on a level near F4 when it hits in november :)

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												This game... GOD how much I've waited for such glorious post-apocalyptic carnage, for such brutality and overwhelming feeling of actually BELONGING to this desolate place called "The Wasteland". From the mayhem behind the steering wheel to snapping the vertebrae of numerous Wastelanders competing for survival under the scorching sun of this world, this game has it ALL! Avalanche Studios actually succeded in creating a beliveable world, set in the Mad Max universe, full of secrets and things to do. And we can all now safely conclude that the publisher ISN'T the one at fault (other than picking up the wrong date for release, which is entirely based on individual opinion of people - some may think that releasing Mad Max at the same date MGS5 is released was a huge mistake, others don't), since Avalanche did an outstanding job on the optimization of this game - it runs buttery smooth on 60 fps, 1080p resolution and everything "MAD MAX"-ed out :)While arguably the game isn't for everyone (those that didn't like Just Cause 2 or don't enjoy an open world game done in this style, or that aren't in love with the post-apoc setting or Mad Max in general may not like or enjoy this game), it certainly raises the bar in terms of how a game, set in the post-nuclear universe, should look and feel; then there is the fantastic vehicular combat, and the outstanding performance of the actor portraying Chumbucket - his religious, almost fanatical fervor resonates with me in the same way as the Inquisitiors (from WH40k) make me all giddy and excited.All in all - another sleeper hit, which can be safely called that way since the game critics and gamers have split opinions on it, which is always good. Mad Max was never too mainstream, often considered a cult classic (until Fury Road - that movie is already raising an army of fans new to the universe, and for a reason), so it is only natural that some people will hate the game while the others will talk of it as if it was the Second Coming - I, obviously, belong to the latter, and consider myself lucky to have the opportunity to ride eternal on the Higway to Valhalla...WITNESS ME !!!

I was greeted with an error "Unable to connect to servers, please try again or contact support."  It then had a link to paste in encoded data.  I should point out that it did this during install ALREADY, so this is a re-check at random time. How often will these checks happen?  Who knows?   In other words: *INTERNET CONNECTION REQUIRED AND SERVER CHECK DRM*  I no longer recommend this game and would have not purchased if I had known it required internet access to play a single player only game.-- Below is my original review, before the above. --If you like Batman/Shadows of Mordor style combat, mixed with car combat then you should enjoy this.  The survival aspect is not really there as water and food are very common.  The upgrade system is a bit weak and the "player customization" is really just upgrade to the best item as each has stats for both Max and his cars.  It can be a bit of repeat and grind so you must like the 1v5+ combat before you go into it.  Death races are so frustrating I just didn't do any of them.  And clearing minefields are tedious and boring.  But that said, the rest of the game makes up for it.  Story is not bad, voice acting was mostly good.  Cut scenes were great and the landscape was amazing.7.5/10 (Recommend getting on sale 40-50% off)+ good melee combat+ good car combat + great atmosphere+ convoy battle is awesome- death races are stupid- minefields are boring- can be repetitive - ui can be buggy

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												How you feel about this game is entirely based on what you consider to be "entertaining" content and how much of said content you are willing to consume in a single game. We'll start off with the pros:- Graphics are downright gorgeous in a lot of places, particularly when it comes to the cars and the Gas Town environments.- On foot combat system is cinematic and entertaining at the start (more on that later), with a lot of the animations remaining realistic and brutal in a lot of cases.- Car customization is pretty cool, although more bodies would have been nice considering three of them are very similar anyway.- Game is an amazing PC port with an extensive array of graphics options.- Optimization is pretty damn good with frame rates being far higher than what you would expect when considering how good the game looks, although there are some relatively significant frame rate dips in a lot of the later environments such as Gas Town. - A lot of interesting characters and well done voice acting, I'm impressed by how they managed to make Max the miserable git that he is supposed to be.And now for the cons, which may be more significant to some people than to others:- I would say roughly 85% of this game is just busy work. You spend the majority of your time looting tiny locations, pulling down scarecrows, collecting somewhat useless "project" parts with no real rewarads at the end. If you aren't doing any of these things then you are most likely doing smallish missions for group leaders, and althought these missions have some story to them, they almost always end up being a boring fetch quest like the project parts.- Bugger all reward for completing the tasks above, the most tangible reward I have seen is lowering the threat rating gets rid of a lot of those god damn annoying war boy patrols which get in your way of completing your fetch quests. The rewards from completing projects are almost pointless since it is hardly difficult to restore your health and ammunition anyway. - Gas tanks are far too large and the sheer amount of fuel laying around is just strange. The cars you are driving are supposed to be insanely powerful, over the top beasts of engineering, and yet they seem to chew through fuel slower than a Prius. You could probably finish the majority of the storyline on a single fuel tank, and even if you did need to refuel it's not like there isn't a thousand fuel cans in your general area. - No real survival mechanics in the game. Max goes on and on about survival, but for some reason he never needs to eat, drink or take care of wounds. All food and drink does is restore your health and give you an easy achievement. - The combat system is mundane and, in my opionion, far too streamlined. Although the animations look really cool the combat system itself is nothing more than a left-click rolling fest. There is no need to time your attacks properly, getting into a 10:1 fight doesn't matter since all you have to do is wait from a counter prompt, strong attacks are almost useless since they do bugger all damage and just leave you exposed, no real attack combinations to speak of. "Fury" mode is far too easy to activate, only requiring around 6 hits to activate while also restoring your health in the middle of combat.- Boss fights are just slighlt longer normal fights, again just waiting for the right prompts and spamming that left-click. - Vehicle combat had a lot of potential to be great when you consider all the upgrades you can do to your car to increase survivability. The number of things you can use to destroy the enemy is fairly solid, ranging from simply smahing into them, or by shooting them with rockets. However none of this matters when you discover that the harpoon can literally end a fight in about 3 seconds, especially when you start to get the later upgrades to it. Vehicle combat goes from something that had a lot of cool features to nothing more than a harpoon simulator. Obviously you can limit yourself on how much you use the harpoon, but that is just an example of poor game design forcing the player to gimp their own playstyle for the sake of making combat more interesting. - Story is your typical Mad Max type where from some reason the most important thing in the world is an engine, which is fine. The problem is that the story is held back by your typical RPG style events which make no sense and are nothing more than padding for what is a pretty short story. Why, for example, do I need have very specific car parts (which are worse than what I already own) simply to progress the story? The "Archangel" system seems so pointless and eventually became another obstacle for me to grind out. Conclusion:If you are a die hard fan of the Mad Max series I would be cautious about buying this game. Take a step back a minute and understand that sometimes it is better to skip a part of a series you like in order to preserve your opinion of it, Bioshock fans probably understand this quite well. While the core feeling of "Mad Max" is present, it is just plauged by so much boring nonsense that it made this game a chore to play, which as everyone knows is a terrible title for a game to be given. At no point during the game did I feel like any of this busy work meant anything, and it eventually got to the point where I said ♥♥♥♥ it and just tried to finish the game. Believe me I have not missed out on anything by making this decision.Some people out there are fans of busy work games, they like doing the same repetitive task over and over again, and for them this could possibly be the perfect game. However in my eyes this game just isn't fun, and the biggest part of gaming for me is the fun factor, everything else comes second.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												Much like the cars in it Mad Max looks good but is a bit creaky underneath. This review will probably contain SPOILERS, but only for like the first five minutes because the games a bit repetitive.First, the good:This game feels so much like the Batman games I originally thought it was the same developer. Which means the combat is pretty fluid and visceral, you feel like a total badass and it never feels far-fetched that Max is more than capable of taking down ten guys at once.The driving is nice, takes a little getting used to and the cars feel doughy sometimes but flying down the dusty tracks in your hand-built monster is a fun experience.The customisation is spot-on, I was eagerly anticipating having enough scrap for some of the personal or vehicle add-ons and they all make a noticeable difference.Now for the bad:Mad Max _feels_ like the Batman games but it doesn't look like the Batman games, mainly because the camera is so poor in close quarters that you can't see anything at all. This can lead to getting hit in fights you should be walking simply because the camera decided showing Max and the dude he's fighting is too much work so it points somewhere above their heads. Considering half the combat is in close confines this can get very annoying.Also the enemy design is lacking inspiration. For general mobs there's weak dude, melee weapon dude, fast dude with a knife and shield dude. OK, so there's the occasional suicide bomber and some weird "ferals" who come at you like dogs but mainly you will have a mix of the first four. Bosses are even worse, there is only one type: big, muscley dudes with melee weapons. Oh, one is weak to knives, one is weak to fire, the usual, but you end up beating them all the same way.The vehicle combat is ridiculous. Either you will get ganked super-fast by some dude rubbing up on you or you will be wasting the enemy in seconds. There is no in-between, no long, ongoing games of cat and mouse. If you are in front, no matter how fast your car is, you will be caught. But if your car catches on fire you can bail out and be as dangerous on foot as you were in your vehicle. It makes you wonder why Max needs a car in the first place.The in-game races are very strange, the other racers show little amibition to reach the finish line first, they would rather pick a fight with you. Just you, not each other and certainly not with the other cars you might meet on the road which will be drawn to you like you have a magnet as a hood ornament.There are a few more quibbles like Max using his shotgun to bust stuff when he has a crowbar right next to the holster but that's more of a logic flaw then an actual problem with the game itself. In short, the game is fun 80% of the time but the other 20% will have you throwing your gamepad at the wall.

Posted: September 28, 2016
												This game has too many good reviews for its own good. I can't honestly recommend it. Have doubt about all the good reviews, as this game is sadly too much sandbox and too much about graphics, anything else didn't got the proper attention. The bad things are outweighing the good things.Good:+Graphics: Even rocks are looking good.+Cars: Yeah, yeah, it's Mad Max alright.+Fighting: Have Batman/SoM style of combat, with a Shotgun and Shivs!+Sandbox: Have the sandiest Sandbox you can imagine and give it Mad Max style, done.+Mad Max: Most of us know it, most of us love it.+Controls: Simple and easy, sadly.Neutral:~Sandbox: Yep, it keeps going to be sandy with Mad Max style.~Weapons: Yeah, nothing bad, nothing good.~Mad Max: They try to fit it into the Mad Max Universe with collecting History Relics.Bad:-Sandbox: At the end are you just tired of this, with Mad Max style! Feels like you are on a island.-Mad Max: They don't even try, sometimes you can tell, they are forcing to fit into the Mad Max Universe.-Fighting: Yes, it is good, and it is bad too.-Enemies: Copy-paste Enemies in different looks in different Factions. "Top Dogs" are literally all the same actually.-Cars: Why take other cars?-Unnecessary Challenges: Yeah, if you manage to use the game mechanics against your enemies, its going easy mode.-Territories: Reducing the threats to get all the Upgrades, not really fun after half the game. Especially the damn Minefields, that have actually no impact, but yet are a Threat, for whatever reasons. Even enemy patrols are caring for Minefields.-Stealth: There is no stealth, the Enemies know, you are there, even if they are behind a thick wall and you have your lights off in a dark tunnel, you being in complete darkness.-Enemy awareness: The enemy knows, that you are there, don't try to hide or going around them.-Enemy cars spawning: You can keep looking around and stare on your minimap, you don't see them coming until Chum tells, what kind of enemies are appearing and then they are magical there.-Simple controls: Yep, bad point there too. Because too much is bound to ONE button. That ONE button opens doors, loot the corpses, pick up weapons, putting Finishers on enemies and to climb marked stuff. Yep, best part, the actions overlap each other. Top Dog fight, you want to finish him and...loots the corpse instead, because Reasons!-No combos: Yes, there is a lack of combos.-Scraps: EVERYTHING UNLOCKABLE is brought with Scraps. Just take Scraps to get a better Jacket! Or Scraps to get better Tires! Oh, you found the best Tires? Still spent Scraps to install it! Seriously, they tried to put Grind into this Game and that Grind is actually just a joke.-Upgrades: You must earn Tokens to upgrade Max. Sounds good, but after half the game i already have a full buffed Max, taking away the actual difficulty of the camps.-Difficulty Spikes: Yep, even fully buffed and unlocked all the Upgrades of your Car, there are missions, you hate and are FORCED to play. Best Example, the Big Chief Race, you have to change your Car to be fast and agile, and yet does the game not tell you, that you have unlimited ammo, while you try to save ammo for Gum.-Nice Start and Terrible Ending: Sounds complicated? Well, you are forced to watch a little move at the Start, that gives you the Mad Max feeling, but it is a movie, you have to wait. Then finally, after the movie, you can start playing, the tutorial, which you can't skip it as it unlocks the stuff you need to be able to do. And the end finishes off with a movie too! But that ending...terrible.-Yellow Marked stuff: Want to climb and interact with the world? Look out for yellow marked stuff, because Max refuses to touch anything else!-Unnecessary stuff: Jumping, why is jumping in the game when Max doesn't want to jump? And the forced Jimmybar, which is actually a Crowbar, just feel unnecessary and forced. What were the Devs thinking?-Sound Bugs: Yep, this exists too in the game.-Story: Won't spoil it, but to be honest, go watch the Mad Max movies, they are better.-Literal Screenshot places: Yep, there are spots, where you are thinking: Best place to make screenshot with the graphics and the special option to do so. I don't even try to find them but the game is full of them, i started to think, that the Devs wanted a Mad Max Screenshot game instead of this.-No DLC: In SoM atleast had DLCs, one in particular which gave us wonderful content to play with. But this game, no DLC, no reason to keep playing it.I played it through, i got all the Upgrades and upgraded all the Strongholds. And this game gets mediocre after half the game, as you really have nothing to fear actually. All these good reviews must had their Honeymoon phase as this game just offers Mad Max, in a Car, in a Sandbox with Objectives. Sounds like a Mad Max Movie? Atleast the Movies are nice to watch and enjoyable.In all honesty, i'm dissapointed. The start feels good, really. But at the half of the game, are you starting to wonder, why there are so many stones in the way, not obstacles, because obstacles would be atleast challenging. With the stones, you are just forced to stumble over them. And the end, UGH, so dissapointing, so stupid, so foreseeable and no challenge at all.

Posted: March 14
												No apologies button masher (it even directly tells you at times to “mash button”).  Gameplay is long if you want to complete all the given tasks.  You can skip by a lot of things but you end up at more of a disadvantage as you go along.  Lots of grind to make the game seem long.You’ve got only a couple buttons to worry about in the button masher and that is incredibly frustrating at times.  Want to open a gate that the game tells you to kick open? Hold “E”.  Want to open a gate that the game tells you to use a pry bar on?  Hold “E” until it tell your to “mash button” then keep hammering “E”.  Want to pick up loot?  Guess what: hold “E”.  Want to pick up a weapon, hold “E”.  Want to drop the weapon?  You’d think it’s another button but… just… hold “E”!  Want to climb a ladder?  Hold “E”.  You can probably guess you’ll be dropping things sometimes when you want to climb while holding it.  It happens way more than you’d think to the point of annoyance.  Just really uninspired gameplay controls, shameful even.  Oh yeah, want to get in a vehicle?  Hold “F”.  (You thought I was going to say hold “E” right?)Fights go the way you think.  Just keep hitting that attack button (mouse1) till it tells you to either hold “E” for a special move or repeatedly hit “E” when it doesn’t explicitly say to hold.  When you want to block it’s the other mouse button, but be careful that button also starts the targeting cycle for the shotgun so if you hold it too long you’ll start the targeting cycle for the shotgun leaving yourself exposed for some other enemy to make a swing on and you’ll never block that once the target cycle starts.  Sometimes in fights you'll get into a fight animation with one enemy and another one will start an attack and you can't block because that action doesn't follow the animation you already triggered so you'll get hit.  Happens very frequently if you're on higher difficulty to the point that you'll get killed often by enemies with no way to stop it from happening.You get the point I hope.  Lots of repeated button mashing and holding like you’re some kind of lowly console user that can't handle more than 4 buttons...I'd have no problem with it if it allowed more buttons to be used for different tasks.  If "drop weapon/item" wasn't the same as "climb" and if he'd pick up the enemy-dropped items without a 3 second animation that'd be a great start.I know it's a console port, but dang.  Just so much time wasted in fluff that wouldn't need to be there in a "great game", so it's a "meh" game.

Posted: November 8, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Desert is the hottest game of 2015! In it you play a man known as "The Saint" (Saints Row easter egg or reference to the amazing Val Kilmer movie, you decide) driving around the Mojave wasteland in a car which possesses the magical ability to defy all laws of physics! You will be entertained for hours as you battle hordes of enemies who have the exact same models and skins as each other using your bare hands, Bruce Wayne's signature shotgun, and four whole melee weapons that are useful for MINUTES before they either break or aren't needed anymore.How about engine features?! They have you covered: any time you tab out of the game and then come back to it, your resolution will be reset to whatever your desktop is at... EVERY TIME! But oh wait there's more! The only way to change your resolution is to escape to the main menu. Is that not enough for you? It gets better.... there's no save function in the game aside from the unreliable autosaves!Some more of the exciting features in Mad Max: Beyond Playtesting are being able to decimate your vehicle upon clipping a wall yet surviving a 200 foot drop off of a mountain, combatting a handful of mini-bosses who are exactly the same save for a different colored skin (unique enemies confuse me so I'm grateful for this), and being able to capture vehicles from the enemy factions which you will use in the game AT LEAST ZERO TIMES!Oh and let's not forget the minefields! Throughout the game there are patches of minefields placed in fields of dirt that you would never in your wildest dreams need to drive through and the only way to get rid of them is to SELECT AN ENTIRELY DIFFERENT VEHICLE WITH NO COMBAT CAPABILITIES AND THEN GET OUT AND DISARM THEM BY HAND! OVER AND OVER! TWO TIMES PER REGION! That is replayability, my friends!Don't hesitate, dear reader! Pick up a copy of Fallout: Sydney today and enjoy the kind of repetitive gameplay that can only be brought to you by the short sighted development and rushed production that we've come to expect from Warner Brothers!

But mad max also borrowed tons of gameplay mechanics from other games, in fact the game doesn’t have a single ♥♥♥♥ing unique mechanic. The devs only included tried and tested mechanics from other games like Batman (melee combat) but without batman’s intensive amount of tools/gadgets making the combat very shallow. Ubisoft’s Assassins’ creed and far cry 3’s watchtower replaced by a hot air balloon to view legends on the map. Repetitive encounters in ubisoft open world games replaced with scavenging locations where most of them you only need to get 1-4 actions/scrap to finish which are pretty meaningless since you’ll be overflowing with scrap anyways. I don’t get why this game has such a high rating since everything was done in mediocrity and the map is only filled with repetitive tasks. Even the ♥♥♥♥ing bosses are not unique! They are all the same with very minimal changes on the terrain you are fighting with. The skill tree and upgrade tree for you and the car is very shallow, the archangels serves no purpose but to put prefabricated cars with specific parts which is most of the time weaker than your custom car (they didn’t even put a ♥♥♥♥ing bonus for using a prefabbed car). Only 3 modes in the races and they are so boring. It is such a ♥♥♥♥ing chore to finish with its hundreds of checklist to finish, I think out of the 54 hours I’ve played, the story is only 4 hours and 50 hours was spent doing all those chores to 100% the achievements and challenges. And the story line? Easily ♥♥♥♥ing forgettable, I won’t spoil but the side characters aren’t fleshed out to get the treatment that the game had given them.Now that I have finished my rant, let’s see some of the pluses on this game. Game is well optimized, most of the time 120fps on all settings on max @ 1080p on my 980ti, but I guess it’s easy to run this game since it’s empty (desert setting remember?). Cool♥♥♥♥♥♥camera filters for screenshot and in-built recording (I know I said mad max didn’t have a unique gameplay mechanic, this is a feature not a mechanic). Andd uhhh, that’s it I guess?This game could have been amazing, they could have put survival aspects where you need to eat and drink to survive making the game even longer, they could’ve added more cars and unique weaponry and♥♥♥♥♥♥ they could’ve make each boss unique and racing duels different. But no, devs have made a very safe decision to only put simplistic designs and gameplay to it.For this, I cannot recommend the game since this is easily forgettable. If you really want to get it, get it @ 75%, you probably can get it the next summer sale since it was already on Humble monthly for $12

												Mad Max is one of the most fun 3rd person open world RPG's that I've played in a long time. It has a nearly perfect settings menu with almost any keybinding and graphics options you could want. The gameplay both in and out of the car is also handled extremely well due to Avalanche giving you a variety of tools, weapons and ways to kill enemies throughout the game. Even though the enviroment is just a desert, it is full of life, beauty and fun things to do in your spare time such as colecting scrap, destroying camps, using hot air balloons to scout the area around you and so much more. The story is a classic Mad Max one, revenge, I wont go into more detail than that becuase of spoilers, but it is done well with many oportunities to upgrade Max and your car if you run into an area you can't beat. The voice acting is done well for everyone except for Max who is a little lack luster and doesn't feel close to his film character even though the game strives to be like the film. Other than that Mad Max is a very fun and entertaining game that will drag you back for more every time you turn it off. I hope you enjoy it as much as I did

Posted: September 7, 2015
												This not so popular release is pretty dam awesome and really shines a light on the Mad Max movie franchise. The vechicular combat is fast paced and fun with random encounters around the massive open world. The main goal in the game is to build the magnum opus a car worthy of travelling across the lands to find a place only know as "silence" where Max will be at peace with his past. The melee combat is very diverse and quite similar to that of the batman games which games it pretty cool and protrays Max as an absolute badass when he can single handedly takedown a whole camp of angry attackers. The camps in the game are similar to that of far cry , they are found all around the map and are not part of the story but you can play them just to gain scrap or ammo for weapons. Scrap is found around the map in thousands of different places that include specific scavanging sites marked on the map where the player explores a unique building or wreckage also scrap can be found in the campaign , usually hidden in corners or buildings , but to be honest there are loads of ways to find scrap and this is it a guide. I have heard many people critise this game for how its only a desert and the landscape is boring however i believe that is complete crap, the map is a baron desert that sets the realistic tone of a true apocolypse enviroment and that fact that it is boring is absurd there are so many secret locations around the map for the player to explore and enjoy without having to stick to the campaign all the time. The campaign its self is unique and different to anything i have ever seen before and it really makes the player what to spend hours enjoying the fun it has to offer. Inconclusion I believe this game is a must buy and it is a shame it was released on the same day as MGSV which sort of killed Max's hype but still you could buy this game at anytime and enjoy it i think people will be buying this game for years to come as it is diffenatly and underdog of this years top games so finally i would give this game an 9/10 as it really does stick to the narative of the movie franchise and lets the player explore what the Mad Max world has to offer without being pushed into completing specific story lines. Note this review was written 9 hours into the game and i am sure there is a lot more to offer :P Thanks for reading, hope this helped youBlade

content:
Posted: March 6
												Mad max takes inspiration from Arkham, Shadow of Mordor, and even games like Far Cry 3, and fuses it with fast paced, brutal car combat and an addictive progression system that absolutely NAILS the Mad Max feel and kept me engaged from start to finish.Combat - This is nothing new, if you've played Arkham or Shadow of Mordor, you'll be right at home.  The combat here is less flashy than Batman, but much more brutal and intimate.  A variety of weapons, enemy types, and combos keeps it fun throughout the game.Open World - Make no mistake, this is an open world game (think Far Cry 3), with camps to liberate, 'watch towers' to unlock, etc.  But I think this may be my favorite iteration so far.  It is a huge map, but is quickly traversed in your vehicle.  Camps, outposts and more all give you currency to unlock upgrades for Max and his car, so there is always an incentive.  And the towers, in this case they're hot air ballons, aren't just "scale once and forget" like they are in Ubisoft games.  You actually have to navigate to them, get them up and running, and then ocne you ascend in one, you use your binoculars to survey the land and manually scout the area.  Much more immersive IMO.Vehicle - It is a BLAST to upgrade Max's car, the Magnum Opus, and engage in vehicular combat. The cars all look incredible and the combat has a surprising amount of variety and is really fine.  It is honestly the stand out feature of this game.It does get a bit repetitive (you're essentially constantly cycling through: liberate camp, collect scrap, upgrade Max/his Car, progress main story, repeat repeat).  HOWEVER, all the activities I found to be fun and engaging.  Even at it's absolute worst (tracking down a mine field, tediously clearing it to 100% a portion of the map), the game gives you incentive in the form of a huge car upgrade that makes it so satisfying.Overall, I'd give Mad Max an 8.5/10, and I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun I had with it.If you liked the Arkham games and Shadow of Mordor, you should definitely pick up Mad Max.

												Awesome game! Great, very solid, entertaining and polished (& plenty!) gameplay! Well done open world and sooo atmospheric, especially if you like the movie(s). Nice mix between RPG/driving/openworld and a good part of 3rd-persion-action game!*Aboth all great combat-systems i kind of enjoy in every encounter:-> on foot, the feetback of the hand to hand-combat is as good as the choreography is brutal and convincing, without being too brutal or too martial-arty. The wrestling-moves and the implementation of makeshift meele- and ranged-weapons are immersive, lore-firendly and well designed. Looking good.-> in the car - great explosions and the way how you get more and more options while proceeding in the story and in the upgrades and design of your car. Quiet balanced too and especially because of that also very entertaining and sometimes quiet challenging. Action-packed and a good variety from intense to entertaining, giving u a good feeling.<-> also there are a few things that combine ground combat with driving-combat like the "mounted" sniperrifle in the back, the harpoon and so on. Many ways and options to bring to a fight, on foot as well as in the car.* Exploring is very rewarding and getting stuff done like looting the locations to 100% is not always easy but its also not unfair or a pain in the ***. Good mixture between not to easy but also not that hard to get annoying if u want to get the "maximum" out.* Technically it feels quiet good developed, looking very nice on even lower settings and running well enough on older systems (w7, nvidia gtx460m, 3gbDDR3). Graphic-settings give you good (standard) options to configurate stuff.* Controls are also well done - on keyboard like on the controler, on foot and on the car.* Great sounds! The wasteland ambience, the car/engine-noises, the massive explosions and thundering shots sniper-rifle and shotgun...and so on. Soundtrack could be a little bit more present but this is complaining on a very high level.<- only downsides so far are for me:- the "top-dog" boss-enemies are quiet similar to each other- the character-perks of Max u can upgrade are maxed out quiet fast, and with that the cool meetings with the mysterious guy are done quiet soon (~after completing the bootom half of the (quiet big)map). At least if you play quiet thoroughly. ! On the other hand they are all quiet useful, what is in my opinion much more important.Payed like 7€ on the wintersale. Worth this price many many times!

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												This game is not "original" from a mechanical standpoint, but from a setting it is one of the most original "wasteland" concepts I have ever played and captures the feel of the Mad Max universe as shown in The Road Warrior, Beyond Thunderdome, and Fury Road in the most complete way a game could.This game is not based on any of the movies, but is an original story using the concepts, characters, and settings from the Mad Max universe of films. It has been helped in "authenticity" by George Miller wirking with the developers and if you are seeking a game to play after watching any of the Mad Max movies this is the one.If you enjoy Just Cause 2, car combat, wasteland settings, brutal fighting, and an interesting world full of over the top characters, then you should play this game.As of writing this review, the game does have many minor bugs, but most of them are minor visual things and not game breaking as well as a couple minor audio bugs. They are annoying (as all bugs in a game are) but I have only had the game crash on me twice and I think that has more to do with my old PC than anything else.Graphically this game is beautiful. I play on "high" settings (it also has very high, ultra, and max... heh) and it looks like a modern game should look. You might think a game that is nothing but desert would be boring to look at but they have done a great job making each area unique, yet still giving it all a desert wasteland feel.The sound is great with the engines being the most important thing. Each engine upgrade changes the tone of your car and each car that is not your own sounds different as well. The punches have that classic Indiana Jones "crunch" to them to give a satisfying viseral feel to the combat as you fist fight your way through your foes. The music is atmospheric and haunting when things are peaceful and dynamically switches to a pumped up rock theme when combat begins.The driving is actually quite good, BUT each car handles very differently and your own Magnum Opus needs... NEEDS to be upgraded in order to handle well.My only complaint is the mid game is so difficult due to the events as they occur that the entire difficulty of the game feels off. It reaches a cliff, shoves you off, then you relax for the last half of the game. Not balanced, and more than a little frustrating, (especially considering how long the middle sequence of the story is) but overall the game is still fun and worth a little time investment.Play it. You won't regret it.
