content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												I was hesitant about picking up Mad Max simply because it's one of my all time favorite movie series, well, except that POS Beyond Thunderdome. It's typically hit and miss when a Developer tries to adapt a movie franchise as a video game (anyone remember The Thing?) so I thought I'd wait for others to influence me on this one.What video I'd seen prior to purchase made it look beautiful (as beautiful as a wasteland can anyway) and fluid from a gameplay standpoint. Around this time a fellow Member at Band of Others picked up the game and was raving about it so I thought I'd give it a try. Not expecting much, I was  completely blown away by Mad Max. It's an exceptionally well done port, plays very fluidly, has great sounds, terrific environments and in oddly fun. Vehicle combat is very satisfying particularly when you're trying to take down trade routes and the Arkham style combat is done well. The game is a bit light on story but given the fact Max isn't exactly what you'd call a story driven franchise it doesn't seem to detract from the game much, if at all. The environments are absolutely amazing and surprisingly diverse as are the camps you'll need to infiltrate to complete objectives. The one area I'd like to address though is the critique toward the looting system. Reviewers have been a bit negative toward this citing that you don't get a lot of scrap for completing loot areas or destroying vehicles (for example). I just don't understand this critique as how much scrap do you think you can get off a destroyed vehicle, it's destroyed?Also, it's a post apocalyptic wasteland so can you really expect there to be scrap lying around everywhere? I feel those reviews completely miss the point about what this story is about so don't let it guide you into not playing the game. In fact, the game does a good job of helping you collect scrap once you build up certain projects within strong holds. I'd go as far as to say that at this point the scrap system goes too far because it becomes too easy to collect scrap. Of course one can also pick issues here and there such as the game having fetch quests and that some elements are repetitive. Personally I think this is also reaching a bit as it's the recipe most Open World Games use so it's little different in this regard. Honestly, this is a very well done game that is overall just a blast to play.

Posted: March 6
												Okay I skimmed through the other reviews real quick and I have to clear this: this game IS repetititve. There is just no going around it. You do the same stuff all the time, with minor variations in enemy types and vehicles. And it is especially repetitive if you're completing every side objective, liberating every camp etc.. It's like a huge grind. Plus, it's very easy. Once you master the fighting, upgrade Max to the max (or even before that), upgrade the car etc., you just hop from one location to the other, feeling godlike with no real challenge and you just need to grind, grind, grind.. You can make the game harder by not doing or not equipping certain things on purpose, but that's not the point.Also, if you're thinking that this is a survival type game, don't even bother looking at it. It's anything but survival. If you're doing all the side tasks, you're never, ever going to find yourself starving, without water or precious guzzoline. The resources are scarce for everyone but Max, who is living like a king, eating canned dog foot, maggots and sipping fresh water from his cantine all the time like a bawss :D.However, I generally love all things Mad Max, and I was looking for a repetitive, casual game like this to play and relax with in my free time. I didn't have any expectations, I just saw a couple of gameplay videos, seemed like fun and I got it. So the game is honestly fun and enjoyable for me. It's even fun just driving around the wasteland with your bad♥♥♥♥♥car. The combat is satisfying no matter how many times you've done it. I've probably beaten thousands of war pups, destroyed hundreds of vehicles and I'd still do it all over again. The atmosphere and the graphics are amazing, the vehicle design is awesome, the story was fun (although felt a bit short), the characters are very interesting and unique.. So in short if you're looking for a great looking, fun, casual game to play, you're not gonna go wrong if you pick this one.I leave you with a short gameplay clip showcasing some vehicle and ground combat. (the occasional frame stutters are because of a buggy recording software, the actual game runs buttery-smooth).

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Now that I've hit the 12 hour mark, I feel like I can give a meaningful opinion. I echo the rest of the positivity in saying this game is absolutely amazing with the technical performance standing out amongst all the other great elements. While Avalanche Studios is known for quality, the abysmal state of PC versions of games have dismayed and caused many, including myself, to be cautious of any new PC release, especially those with WB as the publisher. There is nothing to worry about with this game. Mad Max runs flawlessly on a wide variety of hardware specifications with even middling and low tier setups able to achieve high settings and fps. I myself play at 1440p at max settings on a GTX 970 with solid 60fps. Due to that, the graphics really shine as the game is about as beautiful as they come. The gameplay is another high point for me personally. I will say that the degree of your enjoyment of this game could hinge on how much of a Mad Max fan you are. I wouldn't say you NEED to be a fan to appreciate it, but liking the franchise will increase your appreciation for how the various mechanics at play meld with one another and how the overall gameplay is presented. The setting is a post apocalyptic wasteland devoid of traditional towns and cities. While it sounds barren, the large map is dotted with enemy camps, strongholds, and ruined areas to explore. In true Mad Max fashion, you're tasked with scavenging for scrap--the currency of the game as well as the material needed to upgrade--fuel, ammo, and water. Everything save for water is relatively scarce in the beginning, but upgrades make fuel a non-issue and ammo, if used intelligently, can last for a good while as well. Ground combat is mostly hand-to-hand with the odd weapon thrown in every once in a while. It's the same as Arkham and Sleeping Dogs, but closer to Sleeping Dogs if we're being technical. It's true that it's one button to attack and one button to parry, but between perfect parries and the upgradable moveset, there's actually more than meets the eye to fighting. In the very early hours it's so simple it's repetitive, but as you upgrade Max's moveset, it begins to become varied and a lot more rewarding. Punches feel weighty, Max feels more like a brawler than a martial artist (as he should) and the overall fighting is gritty and visceral. It's never truly complex, but it more than suffices especially after upgrades. Speaking of upgrades, all the important things are upgradable in this game--Max and his car, the Magnum Opus. You can customize Max's look, his clothes which double as armor, and his moveset in combat. For the car, you can customize your Magnum Opus to drive and perform the way you want and you can even build from preset blueprints called Archangels that compose different playstyles. I will say the driving is absolute trash in the beginning, but that is only because your car is yet to be worked on. Once you begin adding parts and acquiring scrap to upgrade, the handling becomes much better. Car combat is the other star of the show here. Since Mad Max mostly revolves around vehicles, this is appropriate. Car combat is similar to the movies with high speed chases during convoys and all the ramming, grinding, and explosions one can handle. You have various weapons to take advantage of and you can even drive in first person view if you wish. Overall, Mad Max is an excellent game for fans of the series and an equally excellent action-adventure game for those who may not be familiar with everything. It can become a little repetitive, but so can any game. Try it out for yourself!

Posted: December 28, 2016
												I'm going to start this review off by saying that Mad Max is an extremely enjoyable game, while also an incredibly beautiful one.  This is also coming from somebody who played through the story on a GPU that looks like a potato in comparison to many modern cards (aka the Radeon 6950).  If you have any card that is at or higher than mine, you'll be able to run the game at a pretty consistent 30fps or higher on Normal Settings, with hiccups only occuring in areas with large amounts of clutter.  Now, lets get into the good and bad of Mad Max. THE GOOD - -Funny and interesting characters.-One of the best looking games I have played.-Vehicle Combat is addictive and has a lot of awesome mechanics.-Overall, a compelling story arch.-Climax is amazing, and one of the strong suits of this game in my oppinion.-Lots, and lots, and LOTS of explosions.-Australian Wasteland doesn't feel nearly as empty as I went into the game expecting it to.-Progression feels meaningful, something that other games I've played fail to hit on the head.-Customization is done well, with all of Max's equipment and around 3/4ths of the Magnum Opus' parts being tied to progression.-NO MICROTRANSACTIONS WOOOOOOT THE BAD -9 -(SPOILER)  The ending was cool, with Max driving off into the sunset in the Black-On-Black, but left a bitter taste in my mouth when Chum and the Magnum Opus came back from the dead. -The ending boss battle was balanced poorly, and felt excessively easy in comparison to other fights.-Game became much less compelling to play after the story ended.Overall Verdict - 8.5/10

Posted: September 5, 2015
												If you like open world games in the style of Shadow of Mordor, Batman and Far Cry, you'll love this game. It does feature most of the same mechanics as all those games (in addition to crazy vehicle combat), but improves on most of these systems. The world is expertly crafted, extremely large and features bases that individually have more flavor and design to them than any similar games. You'll probably never get the "yet another outpost"-feeling that you could with the FC-series, because every outpost is truely unique.Make no mistake, this game will probably not appeal to people who are not fans of the genre or have grown tired of open world games (which can explain why the press were luke-warm in their reviews), but for people who like these style of games it is probably the best one out there.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												A few months after the release, it's time for a late review about Mad Max. I've heard it said that the Mad Max films are less about Max as a conquering hero and more about a passive protagonist, someone who has no real control over his own fate, someone who events happen to. In that respect, at least, the videogame version of Mad Max captures the tone of the films perfectly.Mad Max is competent at everything that it does. It has all the elements you'd expect from a game based on the franchise — violent combat, intense vehicular chases and battles and a grim world where everything that can go wrong will. It checks all the boxes for a modern open-world game too, from a sprawling 30-hour campaign to a giant map littered with hundreds of sidequests and bonus objectives.Yet there's a feeling that pervaded my time with Mad Max, a sense of everything in the game being ... okay. The films that developer Avalanche Studios are ostensibly drawing from are driven by ambition. They build visions of a world shaped by off-the-wall absurdity and chaos. This Mad Max, by comparison, feels safe and, frankly, boring.Those inevitable wins felt empty, and that's really the biggest problem with Mad Max. The film franchise has always transcended the summer blockbuster genre, providing worlds and characters and scenarios that have stuck in my mind. Mad Max the game is the opposite; it's got chase scenes and big explosions and bloody fights, but nothing to remember it for. In spite of some annoying technical issues and questionable design, Mad Max is functional, but it's fluff, plain and simple.

												Awesome game! Great, very solid, entertaining and polished (& plenty!) gameplay! Well done open world and sooo atmospheric, especially if you like the movie(s). Nice mix between RPG/driving/openworld and a good part of 3rd-persion-action game!*Aboth all great combat-systems i kind of enjoy in every encounter:-> on foot, the feetback of the hand to hand-combat is as good as the choreography is brutal and convincing, without being too brutal or too martial-arty. The wrestling-moves and the implementation of makeshift meele- and ranged-weapons are immersive, lore-firendly and well designed. Looking good.-> in the car - great explosions and the way how you get more and more options while proceeding in the story and in the upgrades and design of your car. Quiet balanced too and especially because of that also very entertaining and sometimes quiet challenging. Action-packed and a good variety from intense to entertaining, giving u a good feeling.<-> also there are a few things that combine ground combat with driving-combat like the "mounted" sniperrifle in the back, the harpoon and so on. Many ways and options to bring to a fight, on foot as well as in the car.* Exploring is very rewarding and getting stuff done like looting the locations to 100% is not always easy but its also not unfair or a pain in the ***. Good mixture between not to easy but also not that hard to get annoying if u want to get the "maximum" out.* Technically it feels quiet good developed, looking very nice on even lower settings and running well enough on older systems (w7, nvidia gtx460m, 3gbDDR3). Graphic-settings give you good (standard) options to configurate stuff.* Controls are also well done - on keyboard like on the controler, on foot and on the car.* Great sounds! The wasteland ambience, the car/engine-noises, the massive explosions and thundering shots sniper-rifle and shotgun...and so on. Soundtrack could be a little bit more present but this is complaining on a very high level.<- only downsides so far are for me:- the "top-dog" boss-enemies are quiet similar to each other- the character-perks of Max u can upgrade are maxed out quiet fast, and with that the cool meetings with the mysterious guy are done quiet soon (~after completing the bootom half of the (quiet big)map). At least if you play quiet thoroughly. ! On the other hand they are all quiet useful, what is in my opinion much more important.Payed like 7€ on the wintersale. Worth this price many many times!

												I like this game and yes I recommend it especially if you’re a Mad Max fan. I think the issue with some of the negative mainstream reviews is that we have non-Mad Max fans expecting the wrong things from a Mad Max game. Mad Max should be filled with brutal, fast paced action and that’s exactly what I’ve experienced so far. Sure it’s not perfect and it’s true that there’s nothing new or innovative here at all but that doesn’t mean the game is trash. The driving is decent (better than most), the gun combat is ok (par for the course) but the hand-to-hand combat is GREAT (above average for sure). So far the story is decent but again it’s not groundbreaking. The marks of a good game are how well the core mechanics function. If you have a great soundtrack, graphics and storyline but poor gameplay mechanics you’ve realistically paid $60 for some cool tunes with pretty pictures and some neat voice acting and that’s not the case here. The devs did a good job at nailing what makes Mad Max, Mad Max. For non-Mad Max fans I give this game a 6/10 (just a bit above average) and for Mad Max fans I give it a 7/10 (above average).

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Loved every minute of it! And the scenery is gorgeous if you can handle the graphics. The gameplay is sort of a Far Cry style where the territories are controlled by the tyrant, and you can free territories by capturing camps. Also gave me a Wind Waker-ish feel traveling across the sea of sand from place to place. You gain scrap and parts along the way to upgrade your car, the Magnum Opus; and yourself, Max. You can also use any other car you find in the game, but sadly no bikes or war rigs. This is only singleplayer, however you can compare race times with friends. On-foot gameplay is in third-person, but there is the (suicidal) option to use first-person while driving. Vehicle combat feels great! Fast-paced and intense like in a movie. and the on-foot combat looks and feels just as brutal and intense! There are a few bugs like occasionally having the cursor stick around after being in the menu which can be easily fixed by quickly opening and closing the menu; another is very rarely (twice in 92 hours for me) being stuck in the menu, where I would have to turn off the game. This wasn't a big problem though since the game frequently autosaves. I've heard complaints about the game feeling repetitive, which I guess just depends on the person because I never got tired of exploding cars, chases, shooting, looting, surviving storms, and just exploring. Plus a great bit of story if you're an interested Mad Max fan. Definitely worth the Steam price, though you can find it for much less on other sites like I did :) Would recommend anyday!

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												If you've played and enjoyed the Arkham series and Shadow of Mordor, picking up Mad Max is pretty much a no brainer. It features the same close combat and upgrade system as the two other games.The world and the visuals are extremely well crafted and provide the perfect Mad Max atmosphere. The game is mechanically very sound, which is no surprise considering the games it borrows elements from.For actual criticism: the game gets very repetitive. If you're a completionist, you're going to spend dozens of hours looking for that last piece of scrap in a camp that bears an eerie similarity to another camp you visited ten minutes ago and beating basically the same 4-5 varieties of goons all over the place. There is SO MUCH to do in the game that I could easily see someone spending 100+ hours to loot every camp, finish all the races and so forth. Odds are though, unless you have superhuman persistence, you're gonna get burned out after completing half of the looting objectives and will just finish the story to be done with the game.The close combat is not quite as satisfying or tight as in Arkham or Mordor, as the special moves are more generic and limited to things that counter a certain enemy type, such as Melee Reversal or Shield Shatter. If nothing else, it does make the game a touch more gritty and realistic. The countering mechanic is not quite as responsive and it is harder to read enemies. Getting hit doesn't reset your combo counter in Mad Max, so missing a counter is not a huge deal, but it takes away that certain satisfaction of getting a 'perfect combo'.The story is great; however, it is sprinkled throughout the game rather unevenly. Of my 50+ hours of playtime, I'd estimate roughly 5 hours is actually advancing the story. It is mostly focused in the beginning and the end of the game, with only a few short missions placed here and there to keep you in the story and also gate your progress by tying up access to new zones and upgrades to beating the story mission. During the majority of the game the presence of the main villain is merely implied by the presence of his lackeys, and it was not until the last hour or so of the story that I felt reconnected to the events at the very beginning.In short:+It's as close to Mad Max as a video game can get+Good Batman-style combat system+Vehicle combat provides a nice change of pace+Lots to do+Excellent visuals that lend to a great atmosphere-Optional objectives are repetitive-Combat is not as responsive as in games it borrows from-Story gets a bit thin during the middle part of the game

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												What's not to love about a game where your main course of action is putting fists through faces of some weird wasteland psychos, pumping lead from a makeshift shotgun through metal, flesh and bone alike and pulling guys out of moving vehicles with a friggin' harpoon at high speeds!?...Oh yeah. And blow stuff up, of course.  Big time. And just imagine you can do all this in the most beautiful wasteland! Yeah, I mean it. It really feels remote and empty, but incredibly detailed at the same time. And even when some content may get a bit repetitive: there's really lot's of stuff to discover in nicely placed locations in a vast open world.A game that idolizes, no, openly worships motor cars as true saviours in this harsh world. That makes fun of some roaring monster of a modified V6 engine, because it will forever be inferior to the most sacred V8 block. And the way, the vehicles are presented and used here, is so incredibly over the edge, that all those friggin "don't try this, always wear your seatbelt" need for speed warnings don't even DARE to show up anytime on the screen. If Max had a seatbelt, he would rather fasten someone else  behind  his Magnum-Opus.Car crashes have never been so aesthetic and satisfying. You can almost feel the flames! 11/10 Pyromaniacs AND skilled cameramen would recommend.Only downside for some people may be, that in spite of it's awesome post-apocalyptic setting, this really isn't some kind of survival game. Even though food is rather scarce, you do just fine with your water canteen most of the time which is only used like a refillable med kit. No dehydration / hunger / bleeding whatsoever. Just refuel your car and take a sip of water from time to time. Pros:  Easy combat and overall controls. Blowing stuff up in incredible detail (even on slow machines, like...V6 engines). Vehicular combat done right. Really nice driving physics and insane combat maneauvers at the same time. The cars really handle a lot different and you can feel the overall performance. AND: First Person driving. May be unwise in some combat situation, but the camera also does a decent job, when riding your wheels in third person. No speed limits, no guardrails, just some paths for faster travel, but always the ability to go fully offroad and discover stuff on the way. (There are even fast travel locations but...b****, please. Who need's them anyways?) Nice character upgrade system (which extents to your Magnum Opus Car, which is like a character itself and totally modifiable) Lot's of stuff to do that keeps you busy. Really catches the visual style of Fury Road. Cons  Combat is fun but not that varied like Sleeping Dogs' for example. Overall a bit too easy at the moment I write this. No difficulty settings. (22 hrs. of playing. You can boost Max' skills and his car quite fast, even though West Coast Customs wouldn't be proud of you. But why not tear through a fortress like a real man, without even a shirt on? Putin would be proud..) Not really a Con for me, for this game really is fun, the way it is, but stuff like a Survival or Sneaking system might have made the experience even more interesting at certain points, but this one sticks to the action and facing the wasteland head-on, Mad Max style.In my opinion, if you are not looking for a survival game but love postapocalyptic settings, fast and loud cars and a whole lot of explosions, this one is a must-have.. especially  when on discount like the moment I wrote this review.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												A SURPRISINGLY good, SERIOUSLY underrated, and FANTASTIC exploration and evolution of the beloved Mad Max universe that's BURSTING with content!The 3 elements that makes this game shine are world design, exploration, and combat. The wasteland is a vast environment alive with dangers and secrets waiting to be unlocked. The combat takes what made the Batman Arkham games work and adds a gruesome and brutal flavour to it. Top it all off with an OVERWHELMING amount of activities to do and collectables to get, and you'll be playing this for DOZENS of hours.But the game is not without its faults:The main story, while closely following the formula of the films that came before it, doesn't really add anything to the character of Max himself. Granted, it's always been the world that's the main focus with Max the role of the observer, but the interactions of other characters during exploration and side missions focus more on Max, especially with Griffa. However, the story really picks up in the last half of the game.It can get pretty repetitive at times, especially with little to no variation on taking down the Top Dogs in camps. With the amount of things to do in this game, the repetitiveness can really stand out, making this game better in short sessions as opposed to long sittings.I experienced a few crashes, but they were infrequent enough to not ruin the overall game.One BIG gripe I have is how you can't fast travel with any other vehicle other than your Magnum Opus. If you want to drive any other car, you need to drive all the way over to your destination, especially when you need to use your dog for disarming mines. It's a baffling design choice to say the least.All that said, I was surprised how much I enjoyed this game. I liked this game WAAAY MORE than Shadow of Mordor, which I thought was a collosal dissapointment. With the amount of things to do in this game, the recently reduced $30 price tag is an absolute steal.If you enjoy the movies that came before this, you'd have to be absolutely mad to pass this underrated gem up.

Yeah, the names are ridiculous still, and that's awesome, but it does regard itself like a 35 year old franchise rather than an indie upstart. It does employ a much larger group of people, so the level of polish is higher, but without taking as many risks. I think the voice actor that plays Max sounds better than Tom Hardy. The guy voicing Chumbucket is great though, like, Gollum / Serkis great in my opinion. The character was obviously a focus for the team and feels alive. I haven't customized my car much yet, but the vehicular combat aspect of the game feels like a survival game meets Rage so far. I'll add more as I play as I'm sure the game is just starting to open up. If you like open world Assassin Creed style games and want to be the reason that War Boy's head crossed the road, it's a safe bet you'll enjoy this.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												I will write about the following:- Introduction -- Gameplay -- Difficulty -- pros & cons ----Introduction---Mad Max is an open world game that gives the player complete freedom over what he/she wants to do.The game is basically somewhat of a racing game where your goal is to build a new racing vehicle build out of scrap and components found in the Wasteland. While you do this, you follow a storyline where you build your vehicle part by part, adding new contraptions and tools to your vehicle. The wasteland is a warzone and your vehicle is made to participate. There are various allied factions around the wasteland that you need to help in order to get access to services which you need to progress further into the game and thus build your vehicle. Each faction/stronghold is different and offers you quests and building projects, you basically help the stronghold advance and eventually rebuild. You will take the advantage of getting a free water source, free food source, oil source, fuel source and much more.Mad Max has the Far Cry, Shadow of Mordor and pretty much the main open world aspects applied.---Gameplay---You play as a driver, you build your vehicle. As you enter the wasteland you encounter various hostile camps that you need to sweep out and take over so your allies will take over and provide you frequently with supplies. There are also plenty of sidequests and interesting locations out in the wasteland. There are various enemies and aspects in the game, you can scout a camp out before you enter, think of a tactic and take a camp over with stealth, or you can go rambo in.The main goal is to follow the main storyline, to build your vehicle.What i did most of the time is chasing wastelanders, plundering and causing chaos. It's fun as the game plays in a rather fast way. You drive, ram, and fight. However it's not like any shooter at all. You don't fire any weapons actually, most fights are done by fist fighting, while you can use your shotgun for other objectives or to help you out. Ammo is scarce, and so is water and fuel. ---Difficulty---I noticed that the game is challenging at first, but after you clear camps, remove snipers, destroy convoy's and basically control the zones. The heat will go missing and you will happen to find yourself driving around doing nothing more than stunts and drifting. I am afraid there is not much replayability, unless you start a whole new game.I hope they will release DLC soon with new areas and perhaps new objectives. Once you finish your killing machine you basically have nothing left to kill.---pros & cons-----pros--- The game is quite relaxing.- The world is pretty big- Tons of sidequests & treasure locations- Proper system optimizations, smooth gameplay.- Keeps you busy- Gives you lots of goals to choose from.(at the start mainly)--cons--- The game is rather easy- Once you pass the main storyline, there isn't much left to do.- A few bugs here and there.- There are not enough enemies.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												I listened to the Fury Road soundtrack in the background while playing this. That makes almost 72 hours of non-stop Fury Road soundtrack. I don't actually know what the soundtrack for this game sounds like; maybe it's cool? Regardless, I enjoyed almost every moment of this game. The plot is awesome, too.And hey, if George Miller doesn't wind up filming more excellent Max movies (like the Furiosa one he discussed briefly) he could just turn the scripts over to these guys and let them make another excellent game! I'd play the hell out of a Furiosa-led sequel to this.Only downsides with this game? For one, they apparently took a few of Shadows of Mordor's systems (never played it) in the base capturing, but neglected to put in the groundbreaking Nemesis system. Damned shame, because having a Warboy or somesuch become your rival and gain power and stuff every time his war party defeated Max or scored a victory against you would have been crazy awesome. As-is, you the player are generally unaffected by the world.Second, but you get the V8 engine waaaay too late in the game. The plot runs out shortly thereafter and it's unfortunate because... V8!!The last thing is that you don't have big fights on vehicles like in the movies; you fight in a vehicle against other vehicles, but never on them. It would be brutally hard to implement, but fighting atop a War Rig or something would just be... ahh. So cool. Especially dovetailed into the Nemesis system. As-is, there's a bit too much disconnect between the fighting systems and driving systems; your only recourse while driving and being attacked is to shoot or bail out... Damned shame.Still, minor quibbles on an excellent run.

content:
Posted: January 17
												Lets start by saying that I haven't finished the game yet, but I'm pretty confident in saying I've played enough to see most of it. "Repetitive" is a word you'll see used in almost every review so let’s just get that out of the way first, yes it does get quite repetitive, moving along.StoryYou are Max, you're beaten up and left with nothing and through some Deus Ex Machina you are given another chance for revenge. The rest of the story involves you helping out stronghold leaders so they can get you closer to your goal. You see Max wants to drive far away with his big engine and find peace. He won't find peace however until you've taken control of Max and punched and exploded your way through lots of dudes, oh and looted lots of scrap, don't forget the scrap.Gameplay - CombatIt’s pretty simple, you mash your attack button until the guy falls over, or if you want to be really fancy you can roll out of the way or parry an incoming attack and follow up with a counter. The sound effects are pretty visceral and it feels pretty satisfying to punch the first 20 or so dudes into the dirt after which it’s kind of the same thing over and over. Oh and there is a couple of 'bigger' dudes with big club weapons that all have the same attacks so even though there's so few of them it’s surprising that Avalanche couldn’t be bothered to have them be different to each other, a wasted opportunity.Gameplay - Vehicles & Driving Your "Magnum-Opus"  is Max's signature vehicle, this is the one you'll be upgrading and customizing as well as driving it 99% of the time. You can also steal and store enemy vehicles to use in races or drive around. I'll have to say that I can't help but to feel sorry for the artists who spent all that time creating all the 'other' available vehicles as honestly they are absolutely worthless. Your "Magnum-Opus" has all the equipment and then some to deal with anything while the majority of the enemy vehicles don't even have a nitro boost, a total missed opportunity to integrate all these cool cars into the game much better.The vehicle customization is 'meh' with an attempt at 'balancing' your stats. This means that you can't just install the biggest and shiniest bulbar without also increasing your car's weight and in turn make it handle worse. It’s very basic and unimpressive. I would have liked to mess around more with the car side of things. The visual customization is just as bland and there’s a lack of even choosing your own colors, you're relegated to the presets which have to be unlocked by punching a big guy in his big tower or oil rig or wherever big guys make their home.I'll put this in the vehicles section as it does sort of belong here, but there is a mechanic which involves using a buggy to scout out land mines. This buggy is apparently the ONLY car in the wasteland capable of having a dog in it so you have to use it to do these insipid landmine diffusal missions. The buggy is terrible and has nothing in terms of weapons or even nitro boost, its sole purpose is to haul the stupid dog around so it can bark when it sees a landmine. Luckily these activities optional and you can skip all of them but the mechanic has absolutely no value, the landmines don't block any path they are just in the middle of nowhere and you can just drive around them.There's a bit more in terms of vehicle combat than the on-foot combat with more weapons available at your disposal. Your "Magnum Opus" comes equipped with several deadly weapons to deal with enemy vehicles and other environmental targets like big scary towers and the snipers which live within. The handling of the vehicles is pretty much what you’d expect, they handle much more poorly on the 'road' as opposed to going off road but are surprisingly difficult to roll over as the game takes over your dumb♥♥♥♥♥trying to ramp off a cliff and corrects the orientation of your car.I'd personally prefer much rawer, difficult handling cars as opposed to the arcade feeling ones we are presented with but of course that's not for everyone.Gameplay - General FeelYou'll be mixing up the driving and the combat a lot, and when you're not driving usually you're punching a guy. Mostly the game consists of driving from place to place, punching guys and looting their camps, oh and lots of explosions. Avalanche has at least learned something from their previous endeavors with Just Cause 2 and that is making all the camps you need to punch dudes in be unique from one another. The problem is that the things you need to collect in each camp are still the same so while all the camp layouts are different you'll still find yourself looking for the same old insignia and scrap pile over and over.Graphics & Performance The game looks really good, from the particle detail to the sound effects to the near-flawless performance its all there for you to enjoy. I really do enjoy the massive draw distance and the feeling that you are ever closer inching your way to that goal you can see over the horizon. The enormous dust and lightning storms are really well done and the first time you hit one it can be genuinely terrifying.Nitpicking  The steering wheels don't turn, come on guys Engines aren't animated in any way, as a massive car nerd this ticks me off Can't turn off the DOF, this makes the in-car camera totally worthless. Enemy vehicles are worthless and can't be customized, also a lot of copy pasted vehicles with extra 'armor' Lack of bodies for the Magnum Opus, only six are available meanwhile there’s so many other bodies used on enemy vehiclesIs it a good game though? I'm giving it a positive review because I'm still playing it and I aim to finish it. Personally I quite like it if just for short bursts of time. I don't know if I have the patience to complete everything in the game 100% because it will get old really fast. I don't see this game having any replay value either, it really is a one and done.So yeah, those are my thoughts, pick the game up when its on sale and punch and drive over some dudes.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												The game is simple:Build your carGather scrapImprove car with scrapGather more scrapImprove moreGather more...It's practically a giant collectathon for scrap.But the thing is, I'm okay with that. Even though the whole world is filled with the same camps and objectives to complete and the repetitiveness sometimes gets a bit much, the game is well crafted with some actual love for the Mad Max franchise behind it, which is more than I can say for other movie-based games.Everything in this game in the area of mechanics and gameplay has been done before, the game brings nothing new to the table but what it does bring is a refined formula, if a tad dated.I will say though that my largest gripes were with the music and the story:The music is practically nonexistent except for very particular moments, I just expected a lot more after coming off the back of Fury Road with all those drums (and I'll be adding that kick♥♥♥♥♥♥flame guitar to my wishlist for Santa) and with this I either didn't pay much attention to the soundtrack or my expectations were too high. Either way, I always enjoy hitting up a convoy with the Fury Road ost playing in the background, adds a hellava lotta umf to the game.Storywise, it was pretty bland for the most part. After the beginning Max just feels like a very average character when compared to the dialogue of everyone else. Maybe this was done on purpose to make him stand out, I don't know, but either way I didn't really care about the story or Max until the second last mission of the storyline, but boy did it feel like a proper Mad Max ending. Left a real bitter taste in my mouth it did.All in all, 7/10. A solid game even if its mechanics have been done before. Definetly one of the best movie-games to come out in the last few years.

content:
Posted: January 5
 8.5/10 Now, the reason I did not rate this higher (it would've probably had a 9 or 9.5/10 in my opinion) was because some aspects of the game were quite glitchy. There were times where I would be running around defusing the minefields scattered around the map (you have a dog which can sniff out the bombs) and the mines sometimes wouldn't appear for me to defuse. Other times, enemies would seemingly disappear completely, and I'd have to reload my save in order to actually complete the mission. But, other than that, it was a very amazing game. Amazing Story, captivating characters, cool background, a lot of diversity in how you play (my car was pretty decked out by the end) and a surprisingly massive open world to explore. There are a few characters that are incredibly influential to the game: Max Chumbucket Jeet Gutgash Pink Eye Deep Friah Hope Scrotus Stank Gum GriffaAnd, last but not least, can't leave out the good old Dinky Di, your trusty dog.These are all pretty important characters, Scrotus and Stank Gum being the two main faction leaders of the game (  Scrotus being the main boss  ), Jeet, Deep Friah, Gutgash, and Pink Eye are all leaders of their own respective territories, and I have to say that Gutgash was the storyline I enjoyed the most, closely followed by Pink Eye. Griffa is another really crucial character. You meet him early on, and throughout your journey, you collect Griffa tokens, which give Max special abilities, like being able to gain extra scrap from looting. He teaches you that the  Plains of Silence are all in your head, and you will always be there Chumbucket is your loyal Black-fingers (Mechanic) that resides on the back of your car and will repair it when it is damaged, shoot the harpoon whenever you need it, and even transport your car to you if you find that you are away and can't get to it.  He's also a lousy excuse for a friend, valuing his "magnum Opus" over the lives of Hope, and Glory, Hopes' daughter. MAJOR end-game spoiler Below this is a massive end-game spoiler that basically tells you the ending to the game. I highly encourage you to play the actual game instead of reading what is below. It's an amazing game and deserves the credit.END-GAME SYNOPSIS: Chumbucket is scared for the car, and goes and hides out at his sanctum. What he doesn't know is that Stank Gum and Scrotus have followed him back to his hideout and forced him to tell them what he knows, thus jeopardizing the lives of Hope and Glory, who are ultimately killed. Chumbucket is scared for the car because Max intends to take the car and drive off with it, which is not part of Chumbuckets "divine plan." You ultimately end up chasing down Scrotus and his War Boys out of revenge, and you get to his convoy, take it down, and at which point your car and Scrotus' car are both heavily damaged, and you use the Magnum Opus to ram the car off the cliff, which ends up killing Chumbucket, as he was on the hood at the time that you rammed it. As Scrotus' car falls off the cliff, at the last second, Scrotus bursts through the back of his truck with your car from all the way back at the beginning of the game, the black on black, your V8 Interceptor. You eventually kill him, in a bloody, gory, amazing cinematic cutscene that ends with you sitting in your car, with the picture of your wife and kid, alone in the Plains of Silence.

												I originally picked this up to play it for the day before MGS V: Phantom Pain came out, only to find the silly UK release dates meant it came out on the same day. So, it got left on the backburner for a while. About 6 months on the backburner in fact.Nevertheless, I finished this over the weekend with about 46 hours spent. My review is positive.The storyline is about as much as you'd want out of a Mad Max themed game, probably more so in fact.The driving is decent enough, although vehicle combat never really felt great to me until quite a few upgrades and extra weapons had been unlocked, then it became a lot more interesting and enjoyable.The hand-to-hand fighting. Ok, it's not Batman. I've personally got Arkham City as my 'this does fighting best' game, and judge everything against that. This does a fair stab, and is probably on par with Arkham Origins. There's some 'cheapness' with some of the tougher enemies, who will merrily ignore the fact you're in a canned animation doing a particular special move and hit you out of it, which led to quite the blue language at times. But aside from that, you do get some genuinely nice fights where Max really does feel like an unstoppable bad♥♥♥♥♥The open-worldy-ness. It's a bit dragged out at times. Some of the objectives to liberate areas (think Ubisoft / Just Cause style liberation) can drag on a bit. Running around a sprawling base with Max's only medium-fast sprint to find some secluded oil tanks to blow up can get quite repetitive after the first few.So compared to some other games. I enjoyed both Just Cause 3 and MGS 5 more than this overall, although MGS 5 did its level best to make me hate it later on. Max started ok and generally got better over time, never really standing out amongst the top of the class, but making a decent shout for itself.

												Is Mad Max a perfect game? No. Is it a fun game? Most definitely. If you enjoy driving around the desert and blowing stuff up, you'll enjoy this game. content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												I bought this game on a whim. Although was expecting it and had seen pre-release material, I wasn't too hopeful, given movie tie-ins and was planning to wait reviews. After a weekend of a music-festival-turned-unplanned-Mad Max-cosplaying, I decided to buy the game, my face still covered in chrome spray. Just like Fury Road to original three Mad Max films, this game follows its own continuity of sorts (although the ending suggests it might actually be a prequel to Fury Road). First off, the game looks *amazing* and is incredibly well optimised to PC. This is a statement I had seen in reviews before I bought it and thought it was just people struggling to find compliments for a bad game ("Damned by Faint Praise") but it really looks good and runs very smooth. The distances show very well, there is little to no flickering, I have not encountered any obvious glitches. I had only one spot where the framerate dropped significantly. Flames and thunderstorms in particular look sublime.Gameplay is fairly solid. Nothing too exciting if you have played AC or Batman, as elements of both are readily apparent. Controls are a bit off. Some of the default key mapping puts commands in odd places but you can re-map them. As a whole, the gameplay is fairly shallow. Most commands are reliant on holding the E button. Or mashing the E button. Or mashing the E button while mashing mouse keys if you're fighting. Controls are stable and it is fun to fistfight, use your gun, shiv or weapons. No real issues stick out.Car controls vary but overall tend to lack handling, though nowhere as badly as the cars in Watch_Dogs did and they depend on the car you pick too. Still, without dedicated handbrake buttons and the like (though the vehicle slam button can substitute as one in some situations) the vehicle mechanics feel fairly shallow. Nitro boosts, harpoons and other abilities on the Magnum Opus make this a bit more enjoyable, almost to the expense of other vehicles. I honestly fail to see why you should even step in any other vehicles if Magnum as around. Given the abundance of interesting vehicles around, this is bit of a shame.The pre-release material touted the game's survival element quite a bit. You would need to make sure you eat and drink to avoid starving/dehydrating and would be on the hunt for guzzoline like in the hunt for Mad Max: The Road Warrior. These never really come into play. You come across food (in the form of dog food cans with a reference to The Road Warrior, lizards and rats you can kill and eat or maggots on corpses) but they are all effectively static health pickups. There isn't a real hunger mechanic or picking up and hoarding food or spending hours in the wastes looking for it. Same with water. You can carry it in a canteen and it replenishes your health. Max will comment about thirst if canteen is empty but doesn't actually suffer for it. Most camps tend to have some gas canisters and locations where the gas is part of the objective they regenerate. Bullets are rarer and easier to run out and is effectively your only resource to keep an eye on. However if you fully upgrade allied camps, you will rarely be lacking resources. Both Max and the Magnum Opus can be upgraded and customised, using scraps as resources. Most of the customisations improve abilities but some are purely cosmetic. Throughout the game, you also come across a wastelander called Griffa who has some cryptic conversations with Max, which lead to additional upgrades for Max's abilities. This allows for a degree of customisation and especially on-foot sections will challenge you even if you are fully upgraded. On vehicle, most of the fighting is fairly balanced, if prolonged. Once thundersticks are unlocked, they become a cakewalk.Thoughout the game, there are many small camps/ as well as a number of bases belonging to Gastown. Most side missions involve taking these out for scraps, history relics, upgrades for friendly fortresses. Destroying Gastown bases also reduces the threat level in the region, reducing Gastown patrols and enabling you some of the upgrades. Taking all of these out can get a bit tedious and repetative. There are many camps that are just mooks + loot with nothing specific to flesh the world a bit more (other than some history relics). The more interesting places don't really appear until later in the game (especially in the Buzzard territories) and are still rare and in between. Most Gastown bases follow the same formula with no interesting sidequests (rescuing people for instance. There are many corpses in cages. Why can't some be alive to be rescued?) The %100 completion chase can sometimes kill any momentum, as the devs seem fond of showing how clever they are by putting things in really obscure spots. As a whole, this is the weakest part of the game and I enjoyed it a whole lot more once I got them out of the way. Outside these, there are the occasional wasteland encounters (mostly wastelanders with something to tell you and occasional questgivers with very simple quests) and a racing circuit that makes things a bit more interesting. The setting and locations are a bit more interesting. As stated before, you play around the Wasteland surrounding Gastown and despite it being a desert wasteland, the creators went to some effort to make things varied. Jeet and Gutlash's territories used to be the ocean and there are plenty of reminders as you drive into a cave and notice all the dried corals or take shelter in grounded ships, giving a clear idea how messed up the world is. Heading inwards, you see go through old highways and abandoned towns. Eastwards, there are dunes which look empty but have a whole city that was buried beneath. Finally, the area around Gastown is a polluted wreck. So, kudos to to making the different locations a bit more varied. The history relics you collect give a sense of how things became the way they did and probably go into more detail about the nature of the apocalypse than any other Mad Max production so far. After a while, they don't say anything you didn't already know and could be a bit more detailed but are still a nice touch. I initially didn't have much hopes of the story but it actually didn't turn too bad. As his is getting ready to travel to the Plains of Silence, Max is waylaid by Warlord Scarabus Scrotus (son of Immortan Joe, introduced in a Fury Road tie-in comic) and loses the Interceptor, gravely injuring the Warlord in the process. Max then comes across Chumbucket who is looking to create his own vehicle, the Magnum Opus. Believing Max to be a Saint of his strange religion, he enlists Max who only helps him looking after a new car. As they look to build it, they encounter settlements that have come under attack from the Warlord scouring the wasteland, gradually leading up to Gastown itself in pursuit of a V8 engine. The earlier parts of the story are fairly standard but as it develops, it goes more and more into Max's demons and his fears of attaching to people in fear of losing them just as he lost his Wife and child and these issues come pretty heavily later in the story. Between that and the optional encounters with Griffa, the game actually goes into a lot of detail regarding Max's solitude and survival guilt. Not going to spoil a lot more but there is a reason why I feel the game is a prequel leading up to Fury Road.You won't find the charm and crazy-fun of Fury Road here. I doubt even the film sequels will have that. The characters aren't as memetic or memorable either, although the makers clearly tried to and Chum, Crow Dazzle and the Outcrier shine among the rest.As a post-apocalypse game taking place in the Mad Max universe, this is a good, solid game that will keep you busy, so definitely buy it, though you may want to wait for a discount if you have doubts. I almost regretted a Day 1 purchase but it grew on me as I progressed, so I am glad I bought it then.

content:
Posted: March 7
												What we have here is a classic open-world action game, at a reasonable price. If that's not the type of game you enjoy - with its collectibles and outposts and map clearing bonanza - then you will not enjoy this game.Despite the setting, there are no genuine survival elements; aspects like health and gasoline are included in the game simply because you expect them to be. Combat is fairly simple but fun, and once you start clearing the map and upgrading, you'll quickly become a wasteland god.The game looks great and plays great. It utilizes an autosave system that is triggered when you make certain actions, such as picking up scrap (your upgrade currency, in abundance). You can bypass this when you wish to exit the game by changing the autosave slot in the menu. This type of save system is not for everyone. Speaking of exiting the game, you will have to exit to the title menu and then to desktop I'm afraid.The map is large but easily crossed in your car, and driving will probably be where you get the most enjoyment out of this game. There's nothing quite like zooming off the top of a cliff, or mowing down some enemies.There are an awful lot of controls in the game, and whilst the game is very friendly to keymapping, if you're an arrow-key player like me, you might struggle to find a remap setup that's comfortable. Story wise, the game is disappointing. You're going on an unexplained journey to this unexplained place. It seems lazy and the ending is anticlimactic and frustrating. Nobody likes a game where your progress has been for naught, especially when it's in a 'oh wait, changed my mind' fashion.To conclude: decent price, probably 30-40 hours for completionists, weak story, definitely appeals to a certain type of gamer, a very Far Cry like map system (camps, towers, etc).

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Mad Max. What can I say? A fantastic game. Let’s go into a little more detail shall we.The game itself is fantastic. The environments are brilliant, the cars are fantastic, and the fights/car battles are what make this game. Your car, the Magnum Opus, starts off as little more than a frame, your suspension is little more than mattress springs and your tires are so bald you often wonder if you think you should offer them hair plugs. But as time goes on and you collect scrap (The in game currency) you start to slowly but surely upgrade it into a formidable opponent built to see the war boys tremble and drive away at top speed in fear. The world is great. You can go anywhere on the map and do anything you want. What's that? You just saw a bunch of War Boys cooking people on a BBQ? Go and beat them up. What's that? You just saw a partially damaged car with a War Boy trying to fix it? RAM IT IN THE FU*%ING SIDE AND BLOW THAT SH*T UP!As for the characters. They're fine, nothing ground breaking. Apart from Chumbucket, that guy makes the experience. Most of them are bland and boring, but the ones that aren't are the ones you speak to more often, so the publisher obviously put more effort into these.The campaign is good, but too short. But then it does come down to how much you want to upgrade Max, Max's skills, and the Magnum Opus. If you want as many hours as I have, and I’ve pretty much upgraded everything, you'll need to put a lot of time into destroying bases, looting areas, and blowing up cars for scrap. But the end result is well worth it. The levelling up system in the game unfortunately, is flawed. You have to go to this guy to assign yourself skill points that you unlock from levelling up, but by the time you remember to go to him, you have about 20 odd points to assign, and my Max was top level at about halfway through the game. It doesn't take away from the fun in any way, just a game mechanic that just didn't fit in I think.Is this game worth £35? No, I wouldn’t say that it is (I wouldn’t say many games are). But if you look around on the internet, you can find it much cheaper, or wait until it is in the sale. Other than that, I hope you enjoy this game as much as I did. Well done Avalanche, I shall be keeping an eye out for your games in the future.

												On the whole, not a bad game.Orginality is scant here, particularly if you have played any of the Batman Arkham series (not surprising as it is a WB game), although the world is much more open.The openess does come with a downside, as sometimes it can feel that the game has, as a victim of it's open world design, been forced (almost slavishly) to have the need to travel great distances to accomplish a task. I'd suggest getting a few of the fast travel points unlocked as you will benefit greatly from them, especially during the latter stages.The missions are engaging, but can be repetitive, and once you have upgraded Max to the...max....you will find it incredibly easy to beat even large numbers of enemy. A small tip is to bust as many camps as you can early on so that the scrap tribute will mount up quickly. Also, choose at least one stronghold to upgrade completely to help you out if you are low on fuel/ammo/health/water etc.Without wishing to give too much away, the ending is a little depressing. However I really would have much preferred to fight Scrotus hand to hand in the final battle.A small, but annoying (for me) part was when you fast travel, you always end up with the magnum opus. Don't fast travel with scrap cars from camps, or you will NOT get the scrap. This goes for archangels as well. You don't fast travel with an archangel, even if you were in it when you entered fast travel.On the whole, the game is good, and there is enough left after you finish the main story to keep you occupied for a while.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Heyyo, BIG RECOMMENDATION for this game. It's definitely a surprise hit of 2015. I wasn't expecting too much from this game until I did more digging to find out that Avalanche Studios is behind it... the people who brought us Just Cause 2 and the decently fun original Just Cause. I decided to get it and I was pleasantly surprised. Definitely among the best Movie to Video Game adaptations.The open world is everything that should be a Mad Max game. It's violent, lots of scavenging (even for gross food types to refill your health) and lots to do. The areas aren't super unique minus changes in enemy vehicle appearances and combat characteristics which is plenty fine by me as you constantly evolve the Magnum Opus, the vehicle that Mad Max uses for most of the game sections.The vehicles are the best part of the game which is good since what kind of game would Mad Max be if the car combat sucked right? lol... but they definitely focused a lot on getting the vehicle handling and physics right combined with the combat and it makes it so enjoyable to wreck enemies... the only gripe I'd have? Late in the game? You get barely any scrap (tbh I think it's the same amount of scrap as the beginning of the game lol) for destroying enemy cars that I found it a little tedious instead of a good way to get more scrap to keep upgrading.On-foot combat is quite smooth and it varies between basic attack, weapon attacks, countering, dodging and fury mode which makes Max really strong and can make swarms of enemies a little more bearable without making it too easy which is good… my only gripe? Mini-bosses… they’re all just reskins. Some have their own Biography in the “Bio” menu… but the exact same attacks and all that…. Wish there was more variety other than just textures. Even the Buzzards have the same thing but a different NPC model.The Avalanche Engine used in this game btw? VERY well optimized. The game looks great at max settings and can do 60fps without issues and I don’t get any dropped frames. It might also be due to less things to render since it’s a barren wasteland, but no matter where I was it ran smooth with the game making good use of my i7 CPU and two-way SLI GTX 680 2GB setup. Oddly enough? There isn’t a graphical preset for maximum graphical settings so you’ll want to manually go through the settings to max the graphics out.There isn’t much for story much like the movies but what is here is still decent and it did want me to see how the game ended. Same goes for characters. There isn’t a large cast, but the cast that is here are all quite different from each other and the voice acting for all of them was pretty darn good overall.So for fans of open world action games? Definitely play Mad Max. It’s worth it. I had about 47 hours of playtime with doing the majority of side quests and beating the game so it's got good length to it too.

												This game really suprised me.  This is one of those games that would have been off of my radar completely had it not been part of a sale that I saw.  I've ended up with over 80 hours in the game up to this point to get 46/48 achievements and will continue to work on the last two.In short, if you're a fan of the Batman Arkham series of games, this is a lot like those, just in the Mad Max wasteland environment.  A lot of criticism comes from the hand-to-hand combat system, which is a watered down version of the combat in the Batman games because the primary focus of combat in Mad Max is the vehicle combat, which is quite a bit of fun.I tend to be on the fence about open world style games because I'm so goal oriented but this game has lots to do and lots of goals to drive those seeking achievements.  The gameplay can end up getting repetitive but for folks like me there is that constant drive to get to the next goal despite that repitition.  The game also looks amazing and I had almost zero technical problems with it, which is impressive in today's games that tend to ship and fix later.Did I get $60 worth of gameplay from it? Yes.  Would I have paid $60 for it, probably not even though I'm making a contradiction.  The primary story can be completed in short order and the bulk of my 80+ hours comes from going after every tiny little POI and achievement in the game, which for many can get tiresome.This game is part of the May 2016 Humble Monthly subscription and I can't recommend it enough for that.  Besides that, if you can get it on sale for $30 or so it's well worth it, or if you're a big fan of Mad Max then you'll probably feel like you got your $60 worth.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Mad Max is the first game inspired by the hit post-apocalyptic franchise of the same name.  An open-world, action, adventure, with some RPG elements, it really isn't that "unique" of a game to be completely honest.  There is no dialog trees, and no branching storyline.  The combat is very Batman: Arkham-like, but the saving grace, the identifying feature of the game, if you will, is the importance of the car.  If you know anything of the Mad Max universe, you know that Max drives an Interceptor, named the "Black-on-Black."Let's just say, in this game, you aren't driving that car for some reason, and instead you build your own machine from the scrap, up.  You can customize the color, engine, weapons, suspension, tires, boost, etc... to your liking, per your completion of some aspects of the game.  You can also customize Max himself.  Outfits, hair style, shotgun, gloves, fighting abilities, etc...The story itself, I think, does so well because it is not a copy of one of the already-told Mad Max universe stories, it makes a completely new story (as far as I'm aware).  The story isn't phenomenal, or ground-breaking, but it is good.  There are a few moments that genuinely squeezed some emotion from me as a player, which proves that the game is successful in getting you invested in the characters and the story if you try and let it (this will only work if this source material is your cup of tea).The gameplay is pretty good and refined (BTW devs, what's with never telling the player there is a damn JUMP BUTTON? on an Xbox controller it's LB).  The combat system is just as good as Batman: Arkham or the standard Assassin's Creed combat system.  The graphics are pretty good, nothing groundbreaking, but good.The world size is enourmous, one of the better parts of the game.  The map size essentially requires the use of the car you build, this is part of what makes the car so successful as such an integral part of the story.  There are plenty of locations to loot (too many, honestly), mini-bosses to defeat, locations to discover and expore and strongholds to upgrade.All-in-all, the game is good for those interested.  If you aren't into Post-apocalyptic settings, you won't like it.  If you aren't into that combat style, lots of driving, big worlds, linear stories, or any combination of those, then I can't guarantee you'll like the game, but otherwise, I would most certainly recommend the experience.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												An Immediate Classic for a franchise and game in it's own out shined by games of equal quality and different genres that were released during it's release and afterwards.Max Max is a fairly standard Car Combat game a little akin to Twisted Metal, but only to the extent of moving and fighting other vehicles, and with it's polish and focus on car combat, it's focus on speed and customization makes it it's own game and keeps it unique enough to be memorable while using a story and world that promotes all the idea and basis for it's car combat all the way while having a second portion where you leave you vehicle and enter into extremely brutal hand to hand combat and occasional melee combat.Hand to Hand: Since this is from the same Publisher as the Batman series it uses a lot of what they've learned from them about Character Action and use it in the game's on foot side to grand success, I personally don't enjoy Batman, the impact isn't really there for me, but in Mad Max the game and universe where death is harsh, slow, and fast all at the same time Max goes around kicking people while their down then stomping on their head until they stop moving adding the brutality and impact that batman misses out on since he's a non-lethal Hero, in addition, Max is a borderline feral-man whole uses everything he can to win and outsmart his opponents from Shanks you collect to skills you gain to disable, hard counter, hard hit, and overall ♥♥♥♥ people up real good in a way that actually scares the warboys of the land that you will be fighting throughout most of the game.Impact can go a long way and carries the hand to hand combat from the beginning in the cinematic where it shows you from the start violence is the lay of the land and to the end that violence is all Max knows and can use to get him out of almost anything, if your interested in a good Character Action game with a lot more impact than Batman this would be ideal since it spins the formula and methods of the Batman series to advance it for the better towards a direction that gives the player a lot more enjoyment from the absolute spectacle that is Max when he starts throwing fists, handling his shotgun that they make into a Utility with limited ammo, and just gives it his all and goes balls out.Gun Combat isn't a major thing in the game, but it's there used as a one shot kill with very limited ammo that you rarely gather from people you kill, but more likely pick up from stashes and at your outposts that you help build up throughout the game, it's good, it works, not much else to say, it's competent, but not the focus of the game on foot, it can be used in a lot of ideal situations and sometimes as a solution to an issue at hand which they will kindly offer a few shells nearby for said issue every time, but not enough to use to exploit the area.Car Combat: In a vehicle you get the feeling of being defenseless early on against the drivers of the land that will throw explosives, fire bombs, and other things at you to try and take you out early on, and even in the end game you don't truly make a tank that can take everything that the world has to throw at you, so you need to fight, you need to get better, you need to build your Magnum Opis with the help of a few friends along the way, driving will get you a long way, but they can keep up, but the game offers you the ability to side ram, front ram, but not back ram but you can maneuver easily enough to get behind others and get at them from behind, you get to use your shotgun on the inside of your Car with the same ammo you carry on foot keeping it a utility across both sides of the game, along the game you'll gather more information about where and how to make your car better and gain access to new weapons, almost all the weapons can be built from the starting point as well as upgrades, but at a certain point almost all upgrades need you to progress in the story where it weaves the access to them into the story and makes sense, you won't encounter guys throwing explosives, or other things from area one, but you will as you get deeper in and closer towards your goal rightfully set from the absolute beginning.The Car Combat works out really well using the open sands, created roads, and roads from before to vary up where you'll fight and find other drivers with different gear on each one that seems to be fairly randomized in addition with their vehicles, you hit hard, but they hit hard, so you need to move fast and be agile on the open roads staying safe and slamming into them when you can, the Slamming system is comparable to Burnout where you could manually ram a car at the sides sending them into the environment causing them to crash, this isn't in Mad Max, but you hurt them weakening their car, slamming is only a smaller part of the combat where your on board weapons that Max uses and finds from the story and world are used to their best ability from a grappling hook, to a car destroying explosive rod that you both aim while driving at the same time that the game helpfully adds a lock on, and free aim system to best aim while you focus on driving, you can either dwindle the car down over a short amount of time, and destroy it that way, or take out the driver and let it roll to a stop with a corpse inside, or pulled out depending on if you use your grappling hook.Now, I'm a person that respects a game with great combat and mechanics, but the game offers progression through collecting materials [IE Scraps]from the land at various stations, outposts, strongholds, and just by-gone buildings either empty, or inhabited most of them will carry something Max and yourself has an interest in seeing, taking, or knowing about, so there is a reason to explore the land beyond just to sight see, but now the sight seeing isn't much to see, but uses it to boost it's visual fidelity and design, since this is Mad Max your not entering the streets of a city blowing civilian cars out of the way in a Muscle car, your driving across dunes, across ruined highways, and rolling over the used to be cities beneath the sand that occasionally poke up and out of giving you something to see and most of the time go to and explore, the sand is beautiful, the effects on the sand work great, the smoke that billows out of the Engines from the cars creates a disgusting fog mixed in with dirt and sand kicking up from your driving and other drivers of the land makes it feel a lot more filthy and captivating to look at, it looks and feels like a desert from Max sweating during the day, and him drying off at nights, to the open clear skies to the sand storms that roll in off the ocean bed bringing with them scrap boxes from a used to be military that offer grand reward for those who risk themselves out into the violent and often explosive high winds of a sand storm.And the story is a Mad Max Story, it's harsh, dark, and doesn't pull any punches, Max is a hard lost man and he's in a world that fits him just fine, diving too deep into the story would spoil a lot that goes on with it, the story doesn't go out beyond what we've already seen from the universe so it's not terribly unique since it's also based off a series that is in the universe that was written before this game existed so it's solid, works out, and makes sense, nothing to complain about there, it's nice and enjoyable.Overall the game is great from the UI, visuals, customization on max and his car, and just the combat overall is great, I grabbed this game for about 15 dollars a year ago and I still treasure having it in my library, while replay ability isn't something it does well since it's the same story all over again it makes up for with a great once through experience, I beat the game and lingered about at the end for about 39 Hours, so it's a decently sized game on sale and even off sale if you catch yourself pining for a game like this, it offers a lot to fans, and just people who like good games with variety.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												Great game that runs great on PC.The driving is good & works fine with keyboard & mouse. You can customize your car in looks, and ability. Make something suited for speed, or make a tank. You have a buddy who can aim & shoot missiles, grappling hooks, and repair your car for you, giving you many more options when it comes to car combat than usual.You can customize Max as well, mostly in terms of linear upgrades & abilities, but these all add new cosmetic changes to Max along with being able to customize his beard & hair.The world has a great size, with lots of little things to do in it. Side quests, upgrades for you, your car, and civilian settlements, along with finding water & fuel to stay alive and stay driving. In terms of graphics, it all looks very nice. Heatwaves over the horizon, & explosions that look great.The on foot gameplay is good too. You can fist fight enemies very similar in style to the Batman Arkham games, & you can pick up weapons to do special moves and do more damage. You block, parry, and eventually get into 'fury mode' I think it's called, which lets you break through enemy blocking & do more damage along with special finisher moves. If you have the ammo, you can always just shoot your way out of a melee combat situation since you have your trusty shotgun at all times, along with some other gadgets.This game is pretty well done, & is a great representation of the Mad Max universe in game form. It's not perfect, & there are plenty of silly, weird, and unrealistic things in this game, but Mad Max was never known to be without all that. I definitely recommend.

Upgrading Max makes the game really easy- which makes the hand-to-hand combat tedious, and if you decide to thunderpoon every vehicle you see, the car fights are also boring.Sounds like I'm ♥♥♥♥♥ing more than praising-- sorry.  The game is PRETTY and has a camera mode which is fun to play with.  It's also optimized AMAZINGLY for PC-- kudos for Avalanche/WB for this, it's not a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port.  I have a GTX 960 and was nearly at 60fps all day long on the highest setting, the only time it dips is when you're inside a small dark area and using the flashlight.The story's not bad and fills in what happens right before Fury Road (the movie.)I'll liken the game to Assassin's Creed II-- a bit more varied than AC1 for sure, but there is a lot of repetition.Also, the boss fights suck.But who cares, you can upgrade the Magnum Opus into a sexy dune basher and burn all over the desert-- as speedy or as tanky as you personally like.I didn't really understand the point of the Archangels at all-- by the time I could build one, I had gear better than what it provided.  Meh.I recommend Mad Max if you like open world, car driving, face bashing, apocalyptic kill-em-alls' and don't mind grinding to improve your car for the sake of posting sick screenshots of you setting♥♥♥♥♥♥on fire.Buy it when it goes on sale.
