content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												What, a movie tie-in game that's actually really good at being Mad Max-y, and good at being a game?The good:-Manages to faithfully capture the atmosphere (and weirdness) of the Mad Max movies down to fine details while also being a fun game. It's like they watched the films and thought "oh wow, that bit would be really fun to do, let's figure out a way to work that into our game" - I imagine the convoy bits are one of those, as when I saw the films I always wanted to play something like that... chasing after a big dust cloud in the distance, closing in on it, taking out each car one by one as the situation allows (some of their cars are weak enough that you can yank off their tyres, or take out their doors then charge up and shotgun them in the face, or just ram them off the road at oppurtune moments) or just dashing up to the lead car to take it out while being bashed and honked at while guys with bizarre face paint leap onto your car, with the roar of about 10 V8s in the background. Glorious!-Oh, and the several other parts of the game which are basically all the bits of the film you'd want to do (hint: TWO MEN ENTER, ONE MAN LEAVES!). Half of the car upgrades are tied into side quests or challenges too, of which there are many, so there's plenty to do (though little variation, but i'll get to that).-The environments are surprisingly mixed for what's basically one big desert so it doesn't look samey after an hour or anything.-Car customisation is very good, and fun, with thousands of possible combinations. Mods for armour/defence add weight (so hurt speed, grip and handling) so it doesn't always make sense to just max out everything unless you're happy with a middling all-rounder (which looks badass though, so there's that).-As others say, it runs really well for a console port (sad that this has became something of an exception), my computer's showing its age but runs this on medium settings with no problem (apart from very rare 4-5 second freezes, oddly).The bad:-The story kiiind of meanders a bit and isn't much, but then none of the Mad Max films had deep stories, more of a... I don't know, a backstory that told itself (from the freakshows that are the characters, hints in dialogue, and the general scenery) while the events on screen played out? That's not to say they're shallow, all-action films (i'm sure it's about 30 minutes into Mad Max 1 before there's even any dialogue), just that if you're looking for a story to follow, you won't find much of one. It's not noticeably *bad* at all, just meanders a bit, but that's Mad Max (as a series, or "franchise" to use that dreaded word) for you.-Combat (hand to hand) is a bit... samey. Even if you're surrounded by bad guys it's easy as you just have to parry when you see the symbol and you can almost avoid getting hit entirely (unless there's tons of them, in which case it's hard work keeping up as 2-3 of those can be trying to hit you at once) - despite several enemy types with different strategies, it still mostly comes down to 'parry when you see the symbol, a couple light hits then a strong hit to finish'. You're invulnerable during finishing moves too. So yeah, fights are mostly an obstacle rather than a challenge, but not unenjoyable.-The missions are pretty repetitive - pretty much all you'll be doing is drive somewhere, blow something up, beat up some bad guys, job done. Sometimes there'll be a boss. Otherwise you'll just be pulling down sniper towers or scarecrows with a harpoon. (That aside, it's strangely addictive, "i'll just clear out this enemy camp then go to bed..." [5 hours later] "...oops")-Possibly a nitpick, but slightly awkward menu system that was clearly designed for consoles, PC-ised as an afterthought. The controls ingame reflect that too, so take a little getting used to, but not really a problem after you're familiar with them. Funnily enough there's controller support but you can't use both without third party software.-Oh, one last thing, really minor, but don't waste points upgrading fuel efficiency. You're blasting a V8 around full pelt in a heavy armoured car, yet a full tank lasts over an hour of abuse. And fuel is fairly plentiful despite the films making a point of it being a sought after commodity.That's about it really. I should stop since I've already written too much. Had to try hard to come up with bad points (they're mostly bit nitpicky, as admitted) so on balance, I really enjoy this game and have been recommending it to a few people. Have 31 hours in it currently and can see myself happily putting in another hundred, or however long, to 100% it.TL;DR - Yes.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Mad Max: Fury Road was my introduction into the Mad Max Franchise and I have enjoyed all the movies (Thunderdome had it's moments too). I picked up this game because I wanted to be Mad Max and the thought of making my own car sounded very fun. Now, there are better reviewers and reviews out there, this is one of those "just some random fan" reviews. If you want to get a very thorough review with lots of brevity, go find one of them. Making the car just gave me all sorts of joy in my heart, each engine upgrade gave the purr that machine made another depth, like a lion as it grows older has it's roar deepen. I opted for speed and maneuverability over power and strength. I think the game did a really good job of balancing car combat with physical. If you liked the Arkham games combat, then you might like this game. Not really as many gadgets, but you can take on a group of guys and still make it out on top if you're on your game. Setting up ambushes with gas tanks was super fun. I enjoyed the acting and dialogue, some of the characters annoyed me to no end, but some people annoy me to no end. Like many games, it can get repetetive at times, take a break and come back! In a strange way, however, this is one of my complaints: there is no new game + option or any option to reset some forts, caravans, etc. THAT was what made this game for me. Chasing down a caravan with my souped up car was just ALL sorts of madness and mayhem with a little bit of bedlam mixed in. Clearing out forts was another of my favorite activities. Should I sneak in and go all secret agent style? Or ram open the gates and start unloading with bullets and explosions? Or make it all about my fists of fury?! I freely admit, I avoided one character: Griffa, so I had none of the health or water/food upgrades. That made fights a lot more about wits and smarts as opposed to health attrition. I enjoy games that make me work. So all in all, if you enjoyed Fury Road and you like the idea of beating war boys into a bloody pulp, or racing along the oil slicked roads and pulling tires off of cars or drivers out of the driver's seat at 150 klicks per hour, then buy this game. If it's on sale for $15 or cheaper and you haven't purchased it yet, then you must be mediocre.

												In truth I both recommend this game and don’t. You see for every good mechanic there is a negative, here are some examples: -	The game has a lot of side activities to keep you occupied, but these are repetitive with laughable variety.-	Extensive customisation of your magnum opus, but you can only achieve this be completing many aforementioned repetitive side quests.-	An okay story, but some missions are locked away until you complete some side quests and only the ending is really that memorable.-	The game is well optimised with impressive graphics, but the whole game is set in a desert and graphics shouldn’t be a defining feature of a game.-	The game features survival elements such as water, food, fuel and shotgun bullet, but food and water are only for health, fuel is plentiful and every one of these items can be immediately restocked at any upgraded base.-	You can enter and collect enemy’s cars for fun and to become disguised, but why use an obsolete car when yours can be upgraded on they fly, equipped with all weapons, be summoned from anywhere and is invincible.In conclusion and considering the low price I would have recommended it as there is nothing noteworthy but nothing disappointing, but upon my attempted 100% completion I ran into three separate glitches which prevent me from achieving such a thing:A outpost would auto last improve, a character won’t register in the bios and a quest won’t complete, because of this I cannot recommend.

content:
Posted: March 27
												Excellent Game! Picked this up on sale and was really surprised at it's quality. I didn't hear a lot of hype around this one, probably because it was associated with a movie. I too thought, "Meh, movie games suck", but figured it looked mindless and fun to drive around in.  As I played through, I kept saying 'Oh that's really neat', or 'wow, that was awesome'. There are a fair amount of polished mechanics, all playing together nicely in a beautiful little sandbox. I play on a medium rig and it played great, no crashes, only a few scenarios where I had any slowdown even. Graphics are top quality. I think the art team and level designers did an epic job of creating a living world out of a bleak wasteland. There are always amazing vistas and cool locations to find and explore. There are details scattered around everywhere bringing backstory, context, and a lived-in feeling to the world. Oh, and storms. Yeah storms are impressive, and dangerous. There is no gear or car you are going to get that'll make them less-so. It's a gamble staying out in one, but visually, it's pretty great. There are also loot crates blowing around in storms that you can hook with your car's harpoon gun for scrap metal. I put in some extra time doing objectives and exploring before really getting into the main story. All of the above are fun and while there is a little bit of grind, it's really not that noticeable if you're enjoying the basic activities of driving around and surviving. You'll run across all sorts of situations that provide resources and introduce you to the local political bodies. There are plenty of missions to run, factions to align with, and 'bad dudes' to bring the hammer down on. The major factions have fortress-like bases that can be upgraded for further functionality.  In terms of games, it feels like Just Cause 2, Borderlands 2, and GTA 5 had a really good looking baby. The sense of mobility is pretty high, especially once you upgrade your primary vehicle. The various tools and weapons you can use often invoke a 'Max Payne' style slow motion mechanic that allows you to pull off some pretty wild stunts and combat moves.  I can't really complain about too much. I'd have felt my money was well spent for 30$ and I spent way less than that, so I'm happy. Even the story was decent for what it was. There's enough of a characer arc to be engaged, but vauge enough to still just be Mr.MaxWhoever guy. He's emotionally struggling and busy surviving. The characters in the world are more defined and most are well played, animated, and scripted. The little 'black-finger' mechanic guy who rides around on your car fixing things is a great example. He's funny, a little unsettling sometimes, and actually usefull to the gameplay in a number of ways. The story is there, but not overplayed. You wont be spending hours in extended cutscenes. There are some, but they're short and in context. I'd really like to see a larger follow-up. The tech and the team produced solid work here, and it would be cool to see what they could do with another project. All said, I can fully give this one a thumbs up and say it's worth the purchase. Good for driving enthusiasts, desertified terrain specialists, makeshift weapon hobbyists, meteorologists, and gamers who like action games with a large world and lots of vehicles.

												I'll give Mad Max a thumbs up, but the predominant sentiment that I take away from it is that it could have been so much better.There are moments of brilliance here padded by many hours of rote tedium. Mad Max's open world is filled with many things to do, but too many boil down to the same thing.  Past the half-way point, the game increasingly felt like it was populated more to meet some quota of "things to do" than to be an engaging game first and foremost. This wouldn't be too terrible if the side missions were largely avoidable, but the main storyline progression is fairly reliant on the resources and upgrades they provide.Beyond the lack of variety in the general gameplay, there are several little annoyances, such as unskippable mini-cutscenes that occur for basic tasks such as filling Max's canteen or eating (which is equivalent to picking up a medkit).  These are short, but even so, they will happen many dozens or even hundreds of times of the course of the game, and even the tenth time I saw Max go into the same exact mini-cutcscene of him scarfing down some dog food, it was already too many.The combat too, has problems.  It's "Batman combat", but unlike every other implementation of this combat I've seen, you can get hit while in the middle of an attack animation and counters are not an immediate interrupt.  This has the effect of making it somewhat more challenging, but in a way that feels cheap.  When every other game featuring this style of combat lets you break out of an animation for a counter, it feels broken when one game doesn't.  While I enjoy this style of combat, it is inherently repetitive, so the fights needs to be relatively quick to resolve and not too frequent.  Mad Max breaks both rules, you'll get into likely hundreds of fights over the course of the game and the enemies take quite a lot of hits, making them drag on too long.  This signiciantly contributes the game's feeling of tedium.So what's good about the game?  The car combat for one.  Your car is a bit fragile at first, but building it up into a viable combat machine is rewarding and taking down conveys was always my favorite part of the game.The game also does a great job of capturing the setting and making everything feel a bit unrealistically outlandish in a way that's quite intriguing, just like the films.The success of the setting is also helped by the excellent graphics, which can be maxed out on a GTX 970 at 1080p and still maintain a solid 60fps. (Feels like a while since I've played a major title where you can do that...)All said and done, I certainly don't regret the time I spent with the game, but I feel it would have worked better as a shorter, more focused experience.  Still, if you have any affinity for the Mad Max movies or its particular flavor of post-apocalypse, it's worth picking up on sale

content:
Posted: February 26
												All around, this game was better than I expected it to be. I will admit, I saw the movie, "Mad Max: Fury Road" and fell in love with this series. So much so, I was really worried this game couldn't live up to the Mad Max legacy. I can and will honestly say, I readily stand corrected. Driving around the numerous vechicles, driving the customizable Magnum Opus, destroying Scrotus Camps, beating the living hell out of anyone who stands in your way, it all felt smooth and fun. The combat is rather close to that of the Arkam series and manages to add that "Mad Max" grit to it. I will say, the narrative is well a bit lack luster. However, the Mad Max movies and series has never been defined by their great story and plot development. Therefore, I think the story actually falls in line well with the theme of the movies; just be aware that you won't be getting LOTR quality story telling. Despite the lack luster story, the characters aren't half bad. You surprisingly grow attached to your hunchback mechanic, dog, Max, dude who blows sand in your face, and so on. To end this review, I will highly praise this game for the open world they built into this game. They managed to take a lifeless barren desert, and turn it into a lifeless barren desert with a lot to do. The desert is beautiful and has a good mix of gruesomeness to it. You can see the story of what was there before the water went away. This is a very well done open world map and will surely keep you busy and exploring. I would definetly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of Mad Max. This game will easily give you a good amount of hours and good memories. One last detail I am adding in now, as I just found out about it myself, is that there is a photo capture mode. A very smooth and detailed system that allows for a lot of versatility in taking screenshots.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												17 hours in and I am loving this game!   I definitely recommend it, but only to a certain type of person..I am concious that I:  - Love Mad Max (since the original films)- Am a petrol head who enjoys the visceral grunt of a V8, lots of smoke and flames- Am not bored of Batman style fighting games - only dabbled in Arkham and didn't buy Mordor- Have enough OCD to feel compelled to collect stuff, but not every last little scrapIf you fit the above, then this game is amazing and you probably shouldn't worry too much about the negative stuff people are mentioning.  The driving, fighting, sound and graphics are all so gritty and heavy hitting that, for me, the endless "busy work" - go collect stuff here, is a good excuse to drive & batter my way through the environment - with the random encounters adding more happy carnage.  The cars are excellent, there are some very nice little details and if you're a purist, you can choose to look just like Max of old - with a clunky Interceptor and leather jacket.The design, artwork and audio assets are extremely good - as is the variety of the mini levels you complete on foot - at least for the most part.  Compromises - for me, so much HUD clutter does hold back from the immersion  .. as does the ability to fast travel, but being an old PC gamer, I'll hold on to hope that someone can mod this kind of thing in the future.  The other thing I'd like, if modding becomes an option, is less ammo, water, food etc.  I never really feel like I am scrabbling for precious resources like the game suggests you should be, but maybe this comes in later in the game.  The missions aren't too bad I thought, Mad Max the movie isn't exactly well known for it's intricate script, but the characters fit the bill with their simple crudeness etc and some of the banter is very Mad Max-esque and amusing.  There are a bunch of gamey unlocks with little narrative - eg.  Do this epic jump - why?  Just because you can.  Does it make me think badly of the game? - no.  If (IRL) I had a raging V8 practically immune to fall damage and a giant ramp in the middle of the desert - I'd jump it just because it was there too.Concerns - being only about 25% of the way through, my main concerns are - upgrades come pretty fast in what is already a fairly casual friendly game.  I'm no hardcore insta-kill fan, but the lack of difficulty and speed of upgrades is a worry.  Note that you can probably avoid taking skills & upgrades that speed up progress to increase difficulty, but it's not a particularly immersive solution.Performance - I had a GTX 650 and while it ran ok and looked nice, fights in detailed areas with storms going on would slow the action down to slo-mo.  It's not unplayable, by any means, actually rather cinematic, but I saved up enough scrap for a GTX 960 and it runs like a supercharged V8 on ice now (very very slick on maxed settings).

Posted: September 19, 2016
												If you're a fan of the franchise and the MM world, this game is a must get. Just like how Rocksteady made the perfect Batman experience with their games, Mad Max creates the perfect post-apocalyptic wasteland-drifter gasser-crazed western experience. Set in canon with Fury Road, you have a vast (and truly huge) wasteland to explore, hundreds of things to do, a wide array of customizations, and a world to discover which lives and breathes and feels real.If you like post-apocalyptic games, hot rods, the Batman Arkham series, Mad Max, sandbox games with a huge immersive world and plenty of things to do, this is the definite game for you.If you like story-oriented games with a tight plot but have little interest for the things mentioned above, you should skip. The game is lighter on story (just like Fury Road was) but is V8-pedal-to-the-metal-polished-in-chrome heavy in the details and the small touches (just like Fury Road was) that can make all the difference.What a game, what a lovely game.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												I'm driving into the middle of the desert, I know a heavily armoured convoy is coming from some direction but not which. I place a single gas canister from the back of my Magnum Opus on the dirt road. I drive off, parking on a nearby cliff and switching places with Chum Bucket as I load my sniper rifle. I can see the convoy coming, the large dust clouds trailing six cars. I train my sniper on the center of the gas canister and BANG, just as two cars drive past they explode in a cloud of shrapnel seconds later. I switch players with Chum, the wheels turn tearing up dust behind me and I'm off. I cut across the desert planes and intercept the rest of the convoy, shooting my harpoon into once car as another drives straight through it hits the harpoon wire, flipping over and on its top. The last guard car spins out in a rolling dusty blaze of glory as my double-barrel shotgun removes its tire. With the guard gone the convoy car is easily destroyed with some old fashioned ramming and two shotgun blasts.

												Good game, would easily give 4 of 5 stars.The good:Much like the movie, it is unapologetically fast-paced action, vehicles smashing, vicious jaw-breaking punches and many things exploding. A good violent romp around the wasteland.Vehicle upgrades are fun, and the various characters that you encounter are quite cool.The less good:It reminded me a bit of Shadows of Mordor in a lot of ways- particularly in the sense that by the time I had a good few interesting upgrades, I was already most of the way through the game, so quite soon I was buying them just for the sake of it rather than to progress through the game, and overall the further I got into the game the less challenging it became- it should be the other way round in my opinion. Also, the Top Dogs (bosses) are all exactly the same, with the same bodies and faces, same weapons, and exactly the same tactics to defeat. (Wait....Dodge...Punch hard while he gets his balance.) This was disappointing. The camps get pretty boring too- snipe, fistfight, blow up transfer tanks, and repeat.On balance, well worth acquiring.

content:

Product received for free
 A great game for a great movie! Mad Max has been know for its plethora of movies, with Mad Max: Fury Road being successful, and now Avalanche Studios has brought more to us fans; producing a game that is much grittier and provides many players with a lot of gameplay.StoryMad Max takes place in a post-apocalyptic world, where people struggle for resources such as water and pride themselves in their vehicles that they use as a means of defense and transportation. You play as Max, a man with who wants to leave all the chaos behind and find the "Plains of Silence"; unforunately you can't easily find this place and Max has to fight in order to achieve his goal, you must build the greatest the greatest combat-vehicle with the help of your partner in order to fight back.GameplayWith my playing this game, I've had lots of fun with it! The whole world itself is really beautiful, from the massive hills of sand to all the waste and other post-apocalyptic looking environment, Mad Max does it well. What really stood out to me the most was the combat system, being really similar to the Batman Arkham game (especially with the chance to upgrade your character), I enjoyed the combat a lot and had fun with it. Another thing that stood out was the car combat, at first you may find the controls for the car being a little bit clunky but you'll soon get used to it while you also get a chance to modify it. The world of Mad Max is vast and there's a lot to be seen. This game is greatly optimized, I run the game high with a GTX 750ti.OverallMad Max is a great game and although the story lacks (such as character development) it's made up for by great gameplay that has many people playing it for hours (I'm not even done yet)8/10

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												A SURPRISINGLY good, SERIOUSLY underrated, and FANTASTIC exploration and evolution of the beloved Mad Max universe that's BURSTING with content!The 3 elements that makes this game shine are world design, exploration, and combat. The wasteland is a vast environment alive with dangers and secrets waiting to be unlocked. The combat takes what made the Batman Arkham games work and adds a gruesome and brutal flavour to it. Top it all off with an OVERWHELMING amount of activities to do and collectables to get, and you'll be playing this for DOZENS of hours.But the game is not without its faults:The main story, while closely following the formula of the films that came before it, doesn't really add anything to the character of Max himself. Granted, it's always been the world that's the main focus with Max the role of the observer, but the interactions of other characters during exploration and side missions focus more on Max, especially with Griffa. However, the story really picks up in the last half of the game.It can get pretty repetitive at times, especially with little to no variation on taking down the Top Dogs in camps. With the amount of things to do in this game, the repetitiveness can really stand out, making this game better in short sessions as opposed to long sittings.I experienced a few crashes, but they were infrequent enough to not ruin the overall game.One BIG gripe I have is how you can't fast travel with any other vehicle other than your Magnum Opus. If you want to drive any other car, you need to drive all the way over to your destination, especially when you need to use your dog for disarming mines. It's a baffling design choice to say the least.All that said, I was surprised how much I enjoyed this game. I liked this game WAAAY MORE than Shadow of Mordor, which I thought was a collosal dissapointment. With the amount of things to do in this game, the recently reduced $30 price tag is an absolute steal.If you enjoy the movies that came before this, you'd have to be absolutely mad to pass this underrated gem up.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Guys, this is one of the best games ever made. Here's why:Pros:1. The game world is enormous and full of interesting things to see. You know how Far Cry 3 / 4 tends to recycle a lot of content to pad the game? All of the small, relatively unimportant locales where one finds scrap and other things are uniquely designed. They are all different from one another.2. In Mad Max the side jobs are tied to the main quests and the weapon and vehicle unlocks.3. In Mad Max all collectibles are tracked, so it's easy to know where to find them, yet they are not simply dots on a map. You still have to search.4. The vehicle and character customisation are extensive and really give you an edge.5. All combat is interesting. The stronger Max becomes, the more enemies are thrown at you. There are loads of enemy classes with different patternst and behaviours. Try spamming the attack button many times, and see how many times you die. You have to think quickly and efficiently to fight proficiently. Also, you cannot heal during combat. :)6. The game has an amazing way of making you feel weird in certain areas. For instance, there is a slum-like shanty town where you can "feel" the sickness and squallor as you go through. I don't want to spoil so I won't go into too much detail.7. A surprise to me, but the story is fantastically well written and well paced. The characters are great as well.8. The storms are proper intimidating the first time you encounter them, and awesome.9. Well contextualised mechanics: food and water are used to heal Max, gas runs vehicles and generators.Cons (this is me knit-picking!):1. A few audio and UI bugs that break immerision a little, like when you don't see some HUD elements cause they vanished, or like when audio entirely disappears.2. Annoying fall damage and respawn system. You'll see how sometimes you'll slip off of a cliff to your death because of the on-foot locomotion being so meh. While this isn't too aggravating per se, it's terrible when you spawn country miles away from where you last were.3. Some vehicles you have to use in races are annoyingly poor in the handling department, which can cause you to have to restart said races multiple times.Conclusion:This is one of the best games I've ever played, and it's clear that most of the game reviewers gave a very superficial look at this game. Play it,

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												Mad Max: The Video Game. I don't normally do reviews but on the occasion I play a game worthy of a review, I will.First thing to say about this game, do not be afraid of the minimum requirements!Straight after checking the graphical settings and finding them all to be set to high, I clicked the 'new game' button and began to worry as I thought my pc would struggle to play this game. Oh how I was wrong.It runs superbly on my pc (athlon x4 750k, gtx 760) with what i think is 40-60fps no matter what you are doing in the game or how intense the cutscenes are. My rig barely heats up more than what it is at idle, or that of playing something like csgo, which is very reassuring.The gameplay itself is very fun with war boys to kill and camps to destroy. the more you progress in the story and the more missions you complete, the more upgrades you can unlock and purchase with what I presume is the currency in Australia, scrap (joke!). Scrap is acquired from detroyed cars or found in camps or loot sites. The game itself is quite similar to Just Cause 2 (if you've played it) as allows you to carry on after you've finished the story and try to achieve 100%. The combat for both vehicles and hand to hand is very satisfying with very pretty explosions from wrecked cars and a combo-like system similar to the arkham games where you can continue fighting everyone around you by blocking their counter attacks and then unleashing fury mode which allows you to give much harder hits (again, very satisfying!).All in all, a very good game that respects the original films aswell as the new one. However, as a fan of the films, the abundance of 'guzzolene' in a land where i thought it was a rare occasion to find any at all, ruins the survivor aspect of the game. I assumed that finding fuel would be like christmas but there seems to be full jerry cans everywhere. Thats probably just me but overall a brilliant game with endless replay value.10/10 would mad max again

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												17 hours in and I am loving this game!   I definitely recommend it, but only to a certain type of person..I am concious that I:  - Love Mad Max (since the original films)- Am a petrol head who enjoys the visceral grunt of a V8, lots of smoke and flames- Am not bored of Batman style fighting games - only dabbled in Arkham and didn't buy Mordor- Have enough OCD to feel compelled to collect stuff, but not every last little scrapIf you fit the above, then this game is amazing and you probably shouldn't worry too much about the negative stuff people are mentioning.  The driving, fighting, sound and graphics are all so gritty and heavy hitting that, for me, the endless "busy work" - go collect stuff here, is a good excuse to drive & batter my way through the environment - with the random encounters adding more happy carnage.  The cars are excellent, there are some very nice little details and if you're a purist, you can choose to look just like Max of old - with a clunky Interceptor and leather jacket.The design, artwork and audio assets are extremely good - as is the variety of the mini levels you complete on foot - at least for the most part.  Compromises - for me, so much HUD clutter does hold back from the immersion  .. as does the ability to fast travel, but being an old PC gamer, I'll hold on to hope that someone can mod this kind of thing in the future.  The other thing I'd like, if modding becomes an option, is less ammo, water, food etc.  I never really feel like I am scrabbling for precious resources like the game suggests you should be, but maybe this comes in later in the game.  The missions aren't too bad I thought, Mad Max the movie isn't exactly well known for it's intricate script, but the characters fit the bill with their simple crudeness etc and some of the banter is very Mad Max-esque and amusing.  There are a bunch of gamey unlocks with little narrative - eg.  Do this epic jump - why?  Just because you can.  Does it make me think badly of the game? - no.  If (IRL) I had a raging V8 practically immune to fall damage and a giant ramp in the middle of the desert - I'd jump it just because it was there too.Concerns - being only about 25% of the way through, my main concerns are - upgrades come pretty fast in what is already a fairly casual friendly game.  I'm no hardcore insta-kill fan, but the lack of difficulty and speed of upgrades is a worry.  Note that you can probably avoid taking skills & upgrades that speed up progress to increase difficulty, but it's not a particularly immersive solution.Performance - I had a GTX 650 and while it ran ok and looked nice, fights in detailed areas with storms going on would slow the action down to slo-mo.  It's not unplayable, by any means, actually rather cinematic, but I saved up enough scrap for a GTX 960 and it runs like a supercharged V8 on ice now (very very slick on maxed settings).

The driving is pretty good, it takes getting used to though and a controller might be better as it's not often you need to aim and even then it's in slo-mo (except sniper/shotgun). Car upgrades are pretty powerful, but in harder sections the more difficult cars need some serious gear to take down easily (upgrade the sh*t out of the harpoon).There's loads to do as well, multiple sectors of increasing difficulty to play with by destroying oil camps, legions, top brass or scarecrows. What's good is it doesn't feel that repetitive, not sure why but I actually feel like I want to go and 100% everything, never been like that before. Combat is mostly melee which works like batman or AC, parry and attack, dodge that, shoot them if need be. It's fun but not as fluid as batman and doesn't have as many moves. Still works great though, although there's a move I just learnt where you snap their arm, like fully it goes backwards, and they just get back up and are fine?? Doesn't really make sense, would be better if they just used other limbs instead or just stayed on the floor in pain. Health is replenished by water/food which is kinda easily found, same for ammo although you can hold like one shell to begin with... Also fuel is used up by driving which needs replenishing after a couple hours-ish. Again no big problem. The story is like most open world games in that it shows you being all badass, get f*cked up and have to rebuild. The end goal is to get to the plains of silence or something, basically just have peace. It's decent enough but don't expect Metal Gear level. Overall it's a great game.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Mad Max is the first game inspired by the hit post-apocalyptic franchise of the same name.  An open-world, action, adventure, with some RPG elements, it really isn't that "unique" of a game to be completely honest.  There is no dialog trees, and no branching storyline.  The combat is very Batman: Arkham-like, but the saving grace, the identifying feature of the game, if you will, is the importance of the car.  If you know anything of the Mad Max universe, you know that Max drives an Interceptor, named the "Black-on-Black."Let's just say, in this game, you aren't driving that car for some reason, and instead you build your own machine from the scrap, up.  You can customize the color, engine, weapons, suspension, tires, boost, etc... to your liking, per your completion of some aspects of the game.  You can also customize Max himself.  Outfits, hair style, shotgun, gloves, fighting abilities, etc...The story itself, I think, does so well because it is not a copy of one of the already-told Mad Max universe stories, it makes a completely new story (as far as I'm aware).  The story isn't phenomenal, or ground-breaking, but it is good.  There are a few moments that genuinely squeezed some emotion from me as a player, which proves that the game is successful in getting you invested in the characters and the story if you try and let it (this will only work if this source material is your cup of tea).The gameplay is pretty good and refined (BTW devs, what's with never telling the player there is a damn JUMP BUTTON? on an Xbox controller it's LB).  The combat system is just as good as Batman: Arkham or the standard Assassin's Creed combat system.  The graphics are pretty good, nothing groundbreaking, but good.The world size is enourmous, one of the better parts of the game.  The map size essentially requires the use of the car you build, this is part of what makes the car so successful as such an integral part of the story.  There are plenty of locations to loot (too many, honestly), mini-bosses to defeat, locations to discover and expore and strongholds to upgrade.All-in-all, the game is good for those interested.  If you aren't into Post-apocalyptic settings, you won't like it.  If you aren't into that combat style, lots of driving, big worlds, linear stories, or any combination of those, then I can't guarantee you'll like the game, but otherwise, I would most certainly recommend the experience.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Mad Max is a third person (with and option for first person in car), open-world, single player game. Gameplay focuses on action and exploration, both on foot and in car.The biggest thing Mad Max has going for it is the world. Avalanche Studios have crafted a wasteland that feels seamless, alive, and genuine while still maintaining faithful to the source material of the movies. This game is in fact treated as a prequel to the movie "Fury Road". For all the violence and terrible things that happen in this place of squalor it is almost always shockingly beautiful to look at. The map is absolutely giant and filled with different things to do.With the help of your sidekick, Chum Bucket, your journey revolves around finding scrap to build your car, "The Magnum Opus" into the perfect road warrior machine. Chum Bucket is probably my favorite video game sidekick. He was always entertaining, particularly when he starts spouting lines about his crazy religion and praying to his angel of combustion. If you have an understanding of mechanics and car parts there is a lot to enjoy here and will enhance your experience. Your car, The Magnum Opus, feels like a character itself and the more you build it the more you will get attached to it. I'm not sure if that was intentional game design or not but I thought it was really cool that it happened to me because that's how most characters in the game world are. They worship all things mechanical and are attached to their rides.In addition to collecting scrap through exploration, combat is other core pillar of this title. Combat is split pretty evenly between on foot and in car. On foot, the game uses the Arkham Style fist fighting that you know and love. No complaints here. Its fun and rewarding. My favorite though is the car combat. I can't think of another title that delivers on this more. It's exciting, and at times even heart pounding. This is where you actually get to feel like Max from the movies. It's incredibly cinematic when you take on a convoy in first person view.The game also offers a photo mode that you can activate at almost any time. Its a great addition and I used it often, given how beautiful the game is. I wish every game had an option like this.The game isn't without it's shortfalls though. The main story is extremely short and underwhelming. I feel like you could complete it in under 8 hours. In contrast, if your're a completionist you can easily spend 50 hours in one play through. To me, that's a little unbalanced. Just like other reviewers have said all the filler here can become repetitive. For me though, it was more cathartic than anything. I was just so enraptured by the game world and loved exploring every nook and cranny to get my precious scrap.In my opinion, the biggest offense here are the missed opportunities. You never get to drive a huge war rig in anger. And there's never a giant chase scene that lives up to the ones in the movies. And most disappointingly, "The Big Nothing" (the maps boundary), never panned out the way the developers said it would. They said it would be a kind of procedurally generated area that would have high risk, high reward exploration that you could drive around in for hours. In an interview with GamingBolt, senior producer John Fuller said, "There are no finite limits to the map… in other words, there is no ‘one side’. You can continue driving into The Big Nothing until you get bored or killed." Sadly, none of this is the case. It's simply not in the game. If you enter The Big Nothing you will see an onscreen message that tells you to turn back. If you don't, you are killed and your last checkpoint is loaded. I couldn't find any developer comments online as to why this feature was dropped but it was something I was really excited about.All in all, Mad Max has been some of the most fun I've had this year in games. Ever since I saw "The Road Warrior" as a kid, I've been drawn to the Mad Max universe. This game let me become Max and live in the wasteland. It was an amazing experience for me.TL;DR: A must play for fans of the franchise and a safe bet for anyone else.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Now that I've hit the 12 hour mark, I feel like I can give a meaningful opinion. I echo the rest of the positivity in saying this game is absolutely amazing with the technical performance standing out amongst all the other great elements. While Avalanche Studios is known for quality, the abysmal state of PC versions of games have dismayed and caused many, including myself, to be cautious of any new PC release, especially those with WB as the publisher. There is nothing to worry about with this game. Mad Max runs flawlessly on a wide variety of hardware specifications with even middling and low tier setups able to achieve high settings and fps. I myself play at 1440p at max settings on a GTX 970 with solid 60fps. Due to that, the graphics really shine as the game is about as beautiful as they come. The gameplay is another high point for me personally. I will say that the degree of your enjoyment of this game could hinge on how much of a Mad Max fan you are. I wouldn't say you NEED to be a fan to appreciate it, but liking the franchise will increase your appreciation for how the various mechanics at play meld with one another and how the overall gameplay is presented. The setting is a post apocalyptic wasteland devoid of traditional towns and cities. While it sounds barren, the large map is dotted with enemy camps, strongholds, and ruined areas to explore. In true Mad Max fashion, you're tasked with scavenging for scrap--the currency of the game as well as the material needed to upgrade--fuel, ammo, and water. Everything save for water is relatively scarce in the beginning, but upgrades make fuel a non-issue and ammo, if used intelligently, can last for a good while as well. Ground combat is mostly hand-to-hand with the odd weapon thrown in every once in a while. It's the same as Arkham and Sleeping Dogs, but closer to Sleeping Dogs if we're being technical. It's true that it's one button to attack and one button to parry, but between perfect parries and the upgradable moveset, there's actually more than meets the eye to fighting. In the very early hours it's so simple it's repetitive, but as you upgrade Max's moveset, it begins to become varied and a lot more rewarding. Punches feel weighty, Max feels more like a brawler than a martial artist (as he should) and the overall fighting is gritty and visceral. It's never truly complex, but it more than suffices especially after upgrades. Speaking of upgrades, all the important things are upgradable in this game--Max and his car, the Magnum Opus. You can customize Max's look, his clothes which double as armor, and his moveset in combat. For the car, you can customize your Magnum Opus to drive and perform the way you want and you can even build from preset blueprints called Archangels that compose different playstyles. I will say the driving is absolute trash in the beginning, but that is only because your car is yet to be worked on. Once you begin adding parts and acquiring scrap to upgrade, the handling becomes much better. Car combat is the other star of the show here. Since Mad Max mostly revolves around vehicles, this is appropriate. Car combat is similar to the movies with high speed chases during convoys and all the ramming, grinding, and explosions one can handle. You have various weapons to take advantage of and you can even drive in first person view if you wish. Overall, Mad Max is an excellent game for fans of the series and an equally excellent action-adventure game for those who may not be familiar with everything. It can become a little repetitive, but so can any game. Try it out for yourself!

Posted: September 10, 2015
												When I found out there would be a videogame tie-in to Mad Max, I cringed. First of all, old-school strategy game Road War 2000 had been the ONLY game I'd ever played that came close to capturing the feel of the Mad Max universe. Second, every single movie adaptation in videogame form, in the history of all of time and space, has sucked*.Mad Max rocks. It borrows heavily from previous open-world games, but consider the imitation flattery - this dev team has taken pieces of other games and made them into something new and amazing. There's combat from Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor (which itself borrows much from the Arkham games), crafting as seen in the most recent of the Far Cry games, character development from (name your favorite RPG), and so on, all mesh in a post apocalyptic desert. Max might not look like one of the movie Maxes, but he acts, talks, and grunts like them. As in the films, there's more traffic in the Outback post-nuke than there ever was before; good thing there are so many gasoline refineries around because petroleum goes bad in storage - so if it wasn't still being made, all those goofy looking gas guzzlers would fizzle to a halt.Vehicle combat is a high point, and reminds me of games like the ancient Destruction Derby and the current Next Car Game: Wreckfest. Of course, you can upgrade your car as the game progresses, just as you can upgrade Max himself. Car upgrades drive much of the early plot of the game. Finally, there's value. At nearly 7 hours in, playing side missions to grind and main missions to progress, I'm still in the very early stages of the narrative. I haven't checked what average playtime is, but it has to be at least a couple dozen hours.All in all, great game so far. I'm hoping it stays exciting all the way through.*some rare exceptions have been noted

True to the "Mad Max" NameWelcome to the apocolypse! Mad Max follows the format of Fury Road in a sense by immediately opening up with action.  Max's famous car, the Interceptor, is taken from him just before he is about to begin a periless journey across The Big Nothing.  Max's immediate goal becomes to find find a vehicle that can carry him through that journey.  You play the role of the titular character Max, road warrior and man on the run from his past.  Accompanied with the black finger hunchback mechanic, Chumbucket, you ride through the wastes that has become Australia (I'm assuming).  The main focus of the game is building your vehicle, The Magnum Opus, into the pinnacle of war machines.  Venture through the wastes collecting scrap (the currency of Mad max), fighting caravans of enemies, all while meeting new & intriguing characters.  Many opportunities lie out there in the Wastes!You'll find this game to be well optimized to the point where it is shocking.  I never dropped below 60 FPS at any point in the game with maxed out settings.  Visual effects are impressive as well. Gameplay is well balanced.  While you will do a lotof driving, you will enjoy it.  Only thing I bothersome was having to grind scrap to upgrade the Magnum Opus.  If you're looking for a new adventure in a ruined world then Mad Max is right for you.  So get out there and be witnessed!

												Surprisingly Good game. Pros:Excellent graphics and art style. The wasteland really comes to life. As in, there's not much life, as it's a dead wasteland ;)Runs butter-smooth and one of the best opimised games of 2015. A GTX970 will run this 60fps, 1080p with no frame drops at all max settings (Max/Ultra). Lots to do for an open world game. Vehicle combat is satisfying, and captures the movie combat perfectly, even the first peron view from the trailers is there!There are loads of details in the world of the game, and features, like the ability for a local friend to use an Xbox controller to control the camera in video capture mode to make your own fighting scenes. Huge map, similar in scale to Just Cause (same Devs).Cons:Can get repetitive with the same types of enemies and camps - the mini-bosses are just reskinned with a different weakness. Getting scrap in the mid game can be a grind, expecially to get parts for the car for certain missions. Car handling is frustrating at times, on keyboard (haven't tried controller yet, so may be different). The cars tend to spin out often if you take the slightest jump, and environmental damage seems to do more damage to the car than a head on collision with a Rammerhead truck!7/10

Step Into the World of Mad MaxThis game has its ties to the movies, however this game isn't completely based on a particular Mad Max movie.In an open world environment, you play as Max completing various missions for different people with the rewards going towards upgrading your skills and abilties or the customisation of your car which you control. The graphics are quite nice, the game runs smoothly, the sound effects are good and there are hardly any bugs. This adds to the immersion of the game especially in particular events such as when you get caught in a sandstorm. The combat system works similar to that of the Batman: Arkham series. This is a simple control mechanic, but i think it fits well for Max's character since he was always a heavy hitter and not one to be doing flips and complex combos while in combat. This game will definitely bring some fun hours to the table if you decide to get it.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												I originally picked this up to play it for the day before MGS V: Phantom Pain came out, only to find the silly UK release dates meant it came out on the same day. So, it got left on the backburner for a while. About 6 months on the backburner in fact.Nevertheless, I finished this over the weekend with about 46 hours spent. My review is positive.The storyline is about as much as you'd want out of a Mad Max themed game, probably more so in fact.The driving is decent enough, although vehicle combat never really felt great to me until quite a few upgrades and extra weapons had been unlocked, then it became a lot more interesting and enjoyable.The hand-to-hand fighting. Ok, it's not Batman. I've personally got Arkham City as my 'this does fighting best' game, and judge everything against that. This does a fair stab, and is probably on par with Arkham Origins. There's some 'cheapness' with some of the tougher enemies, who will merrily ignore the fact you're in a canned animation doing a particular special move and hit you out of it, which led to quite the blue language at times. But aside from that, you do get some genuinely nice fights where Max really does feel like an unstoppable bad♥♥♥♥♥The open-worldy-ness. It's a bit dragged out at times. Some of the objectives to liberate areas (think Ubisoft / Just Cause style liberation) can drag on a bit. Running around a sprawling base with Max's only medium-fast sprint to find some secluded oil tanks to blow up can get quite repetitive after the first few.So compared to some other games. I enjoyed both Just Cause 3 and MGS 5 more than this overall, although MGS 5 did its level best to make me hate it later on. Max started ok and generally got better over time, never really standing out amongst the top of the class, but making a decent shout for itself.

												Well written. Well written code. Well directed art team.The world this combination creates is one of post-post-apocalyptic survival, where fuel, water, food, and parts, are power. And it is seamless. The use of religious and cultural tools to at once control and motivate the people that inhabit the world is excellently thought out for a fictional future. The imperative which motlivates the protagonist is singular: survive--and if he can along the way, find and preserve his own humanity.The game, technically, is beautiful. You wouldn't think the sandy sea beds and underwater mountains would hold that much detail, but they do. It is also the contrast between the drifting dunes over old roads worn into the earth, next to ramshackle dwellings made from overturned sea vessels from long ago. The bright flames of Gas Town light up the Northern horizon, if you get up high enough. The weather shifts and blows the world about, with giant sand storms a looming threat while outside and exposed. Resources are rare, and each shot from your gun must be weighed against the certainty of desperately needing one more shot some time in the future--is this that time? Combat is fluid and fairly dynamic. No two engagements are entirely the same, and the options Max has as he unlocks memories and abilities during the normal course of the game, mean an ever expanding array of options for accomplishing objectives. The map is well thought out, and useful, which is unlike the execution for some other open world games. On the con side, I can't really think of too much. I can think of only one bug in the entire game, but that has several good work arounds out there (when you get to a certain fort, and the front gate doesn't open at any point, you are not alone). An easy one I haven't seen mentioned is simply waiting outside the gate when a storm hits; the lightning strikes can set off the pumps within, which was how I did it. Then there was one time, and one time only, after a particularly spectacular crash, that I bounced my flaming vehicle into a terrain feature that kept me pinned. It only necessitated restarting the last checkpoint, which wasn't a big deal. I probably could not recreat the incident. So, yeah. Not much to say on the con side. So, TL;DR version: really, it is a good game that gets more interesting as your abilities and the story unfold. I look forward to playing future interations of the series, if the same group makes them.OH! And this is a strange positive, but the image and video capturing capabilities of the game are very good. Filters, borders, effects, layers, etc. You could make some really great art with this, if you can set up the shot well.

I went the entire game almost without realizing you could upgrade Max's abilities. Explosions. Great story. The sand storms, albeit frustrating, were really well done, it was really cool how you could see them coming over the horizon. Good story, zany "insane" aspects of mad max really well portrayed.It wasn't the best game I've ever played, but I enjoyed it.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Mad Max is a fun and enjoyable game either if you like to rush trough to the end or if you like to explore and spend a long time in the Wasteland. The highlight of the game is the car combat and some of the story missions. All of the different enemy camps also have different layouts and challenges.The drawbacks is that the storyline is in the beginning and spends to much time to get intereisting, it is also short, some more story and side missions would be great. Also tanking out the smaller loot locations gets tiresome and boring after awhile, the same goes for melee fighting.The graphics are good, and there is a large range of options, so the game can run smoothly on lower end computers as well. I enjoyed the game a lot, but if you are going for 100% completion it gets a bit tiresome, boring and repetetive towards the end.
